name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the oral question to the Commission on the European Voluntary Service (O-000107/2016 - B8-1803 / 2016) (2016/2872 (RSP))

name: Silvia Costa
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to dedicate this important Parliament resolution to the 100,000 young people between the ages of 17 and 30 who have worked as volunteers in Europe and abroad in the European voluntary service over the past twenty years. But allow me also to dedicate it to the populations who were again hit by the earthquake this night in Italy and to the many volunteers who are already there. With the Commission for Culture, in our oral question, we thought it right to celebrate the twentieth anniversary of this initiative, asking the Commission and the Member States to create the most favorable conditions for the experience of volunteering throughout Europe to flourish, as a dimension. fundamental of freedom, responsibility of individuals or associates, but also as a concrete expression of those values ​​that Europe so badly needs, those of free commitment to others, solidarity, friendship, intercultural and interreligious dialogue and citizenship active. We know that today in Europe there are at least 100,000,000 volunteers, of all ages and social and personal conditions, engaged in the humanitarian, educational, scholastic, cultural, environmental and sports fields. We know that in every calamity, humanitarian crisis, emergency, such as those we are experiencing in Europe and on our borders, the precious work of the volunteers of non-profit associations and non-governmental organizations supports and often anticipates that of the institutions. We know that the free provision of voluntary services to the community produces not only inclusion, social cohesion, but also innovation, citizenship skills, creates wealth. It is estimated to contribute to 5% of the Union's GDP. The European Voluntary Service within Erasmus + sees more than 5,000 young people leave every year and now there are also other opportunities with the Europe of citizens, the volunteers of the European Union for humanitarian aid, but we must expand these opportunities also in the structural funds. President Juncker has announced the creation of a European Solidarity Corps, I am sure that Commissioner Navracsics will tell us about it, addressed to young people who follows up on the proposal that we have been making for a long time for a European civil service to finally be born, alongside volunteering, also based on the pilot project already underway between the various countries, including mine. But it must be born with the active involvement of associations and with additional resources. We must however, more than 5 years after the European Year of Volunteering, admit that many of the requests made by European volunteering and in particular by the European Volunteer Center have remained unanswered. There is no coordinated policy, there is still a point of contact, information within the EU. We ask the Commission to compare the national regulatory frameworks, to prepare a European legal framework that defines the status of volunteer, with rights and duties, which facilitates mobility, the recognition of skills acquired also in the context of the Europass, also promoting volunteering in Member States and in academic education systems. We also ask the Commission to address the recommendations of the Political Agenda for Volunteering and the European Charter for Volunteers to those Member States that have not yet legislated on the matter by establishing national voluntary service plans. It is also urgent that in the new financial regulation, the Commission recognizes as co-financing in European projects, the contribution of activities given by volunteers even if made free of charge. But we must create the necessary conditions so that everywhere the volunteering experience can become a shared and accessible experience for everyone, for all ages and personal conditions. Therefore, it must be possible to reconcile professional life and voluntary activities and also be supported, with a adequate legal and financial framework, associations and volunteer service centers for indispensable actions: tutoring, training and organization of volunteers. Just as it is essential that the experience gained abroad by the volunteers can become an opportunity for growth for the local and national community. I attended a meeting in Rome with the volunteers who have had this experience and one of the experiences that struck me most is that of handicapped children who have made "their" volunteers and who ask to be increasingly included in the field of the service. Finally, Commissioner Navracsics, I ask you to activate a major information and awareness campaign, in agreement with the European voluntary associations, to highlight its civil and social value. It is very important that for all young people there is this opportunity, that it can become, as in some countries, a part of the school / educational curriculum and that the experiences of comparison also multiply once they return from international, European experiences, because this enriches the communities local, creates bridges and not walls and constitutes a practiced experience of European and world citizenship.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me first express my solidarity to those people who are victims, or whose properties have been damaged or ruined during last night’s earthquake in Italy.  I will take this opportunity to highlight the role of the European Voluntary Service (EVS), which is celebrating its 20th anniversary this year. I will also share with you my ideas on how to further develop the EVS and volunteering in Europe more broadly.  First of all, the EVS and its scope: over the past 20 years the EVS has offered volunteering placements abroad to over 100 000 people between 17 and 30 years of age, regardless of prior experience or qualifications. Around 40% of participants in the EVS are young people with fewer opportunities. They can volunteer anywhere in the EU, in our partner countries neighbouring the EU, as well as other partner countries in the world.  They can engage in a variety of activities: working with disadvantaged people, on environmental projects, for cultural events, and much more. They can work with NGOs, sport and culture organisations, private companies or regions and municipalities.  So the EVS is already covering a very broad scope, but we want more. We are promoting the EVS to get more and new stakeholders on board, notably through our 20th anniversary campaign. In particular, we want to increase the number of volunteering opportunities by creating partnerships between national volunteering bodies, municipalities, enterprises, NGOs and schools.  We are working on a new type of volunteering project, which will complement the current grassroots approach with larger-scale projects, having a stronger impact on volunteering systems. We also want to work with all those involved to improve the quality of volunteering further, through training models, handbooks and toolkits, as well as to promote innovative practices such as online and workshop volunteering. Crucially, we want to make sure that the skills acquired through volunteering are better recognised. This can play a part in helping young people find jobs.  The Commission is also working on a number of other initiatives to boost volunteering. To give young people more opportunities to engage in society, President Jean-Claude Juncker, in his State of the European Union address last month, announced the creation of the European Solidarity Corps. This initiative will give young people the opportunity to express their solidarity by helping others. It will help strengthen social cohesion and the core values of the EU.  The first phase of the European Solidarity Corps will be launched soon, with the first deployments in 2017. We want to have 100 000 young people signed up to the Corps by 2020. The Corps will build on existing professional and volunteering EU programmes for youth, and mobilise established networks of employment, education and civil society actors across Europe. It will be developed in close partnership with Member States, local authorities and NGOs.  And there is more: the Commission is encouraging universities to combine academic content with civic engagement by awarding study credits for volunteering. The SocialErasmus initiative encourages Erasmus students to engage in social and volunteering activities in their host country while abroad. The EU Aid Volunteers initiative, which focuses on humanitarian aid in countries outside the EU, is currently being prepared. The first volunteers will be deployed very soon. The Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund will support projects promoting the participation of third-country nationals in society and the Commission is supporting the Covenant on Demographic Change, which aims to create opportunities for older people to volunteer.  Regarding your question on the legal status of volunteers, this is a matter to be decided by Member States, whose approaches differ largely in this field. The Treaties do not provide the European Union with the competence to harmonise national laws in this area. However, a Council Recommendation in the field encourages Member States to promote the recognition of learning outcomes of voluntary activities. It also recommends the use of EU instruments that can facilitate cross-border voluntary activities such as Europass and Youthpass.  Third-country nationals can already volunteer in Europe. In 2015, 951 of them participated in the EVS. Furthermore, new rules on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purposes of activities such as voluntary service will make it easier for young people from outside the EU to take part in the EVS. It is now up to Member States to implement the respective directive.  You also asked about the impact of volunteering on society and the economy. More than 70% of EVS volunteers believe that their volunteering experience has increased their chances on the labour market. Studies also reveal that there is a clear match between the competences developed through volunteering and the skills employers are seeking. Three out of four employers agreed that volunteering enhances job prospects. The Commission has also launched a new study on the impact of transnational volunteering on individuals, organisations and local communities. We will have the results in April 2017. Finally, to your question on promoting EU citizenship: the Commission is fostering EU citizenship, notably through the Erasmus+ and the Europe for Citizens programmes. Both of these programmes recognise the importance of volunteering, which is an essential element of active citizenship.  Every country has its very own tradition and culture of volunteering and there is a lot of variety across the European Union. A few Member States have a state-run civic service; in others, volunteering is organised by NGOs, and some have a mix of different forms. No single system can be easily applied to all Member States and I do not think we should try to do this. We should instead find a flexible approach that respects the diversity we have.  The Commission plans to map all existing national volunteering schemes to better exploit synergies between them. We are also currently funding several policy experimentation projects which should provide evidence for possible new transnational volunteering models.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: for the PPE Group. - Mr President, volunteering is a virtue to which one can be led, educated and well developed and supported. I am very pleased that we are addressing this issue today and that the European Commission will also pay attention to it. As the Commissioner pointed out here, the European Voluntary Service provides activities that have already been used by 100,000 young Europeans, and we are commemorating 20 years of its existence this year. This service is there to enable young people under the age of 30 to take part in voluntary activities abroad, which can last up to 12 months, without the right to a salary, but with the possibility of providing accommodation, transport, insurance and food. It is certainly a great opportunity for young people that should be further developed. Volunteer projects can include many activities in the field of youth work, cultural activities, social care or environmental protection. We are discussing this topic here today because we believe that volunteering is an important and beneficial activity. It enriches young people with skills that are important for life and for their employment. For all, let's mention, for example, creativity, independence, responsibility or the ability to work in a team. Within international volunteer organizations, it is also the development of language skills. For adults and aging citizens, volunteering is an opportunity to pass on their life experiences and to have a meaningful amount of free time as they increase. I know a number of cases where, thanks to volunteering, monuments have been saved and festivals have been organized, but thanks to volunteering, children and young people are also being led to make meaningful use of their free time. Youth organizations run by volunteers were assessed in surveys of employers as those that make a major contribution to the non-formal and informal learning that employers expect from young people. And a separate chapter is the help of volunteers in crisis situations. In many countries, and I can mention just the Czech one Republic, for example, voluntary firefighters who work with young people, lead young people to save lives and property, are a very important leisure activity. Volunteers also help in countries affected by natural disasters and in migratory crises. I can say that I was very touched by how, for example, in a volunteer center in Italy, young people, but also seniors, helped with the teaching of the Italian language, with the processing of residence documents for refugees. And not only in Italy, but also in Germany and a number of other countries, volunteers from the Czech Republic also joined in the wave of migration and helped refugees in a difficult crisis situation. The resolution we are presenting here calls for volunteering to be better recognized as such, including the status of a European volunteer. And also as a source of certain skills, which should be taken into account in the context of mobility and the recognition of qualifications. The oral questions we have asked here must be said by the Commissioner. It is clear that the European Commission will further develop the European Voluntary Service, support it and also within Erasmus + the conditions must be improved, the administration simplified. I think that volunteering should remain a spontaneous activity which, as the Commissioner rightly said, should be regulated at national level. At European level, we can provide a European framework that is supposed to support, motivate, but not bind and obstruct. Thank you and I look forward to further discussion and support in the field of volunteering. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – As a British MEP I am concerned that, after our vote to leave the European Union, my country may become isolated, and I am concerned that we maintain European solidarity and we maintain good relationships across the continent. I have particularly appreciated the support from Mr Weber, expressed several times in this House, for young people who voted very strongly to remain part of the European Union to have their rights protected in the negotiations. So I would like to ask Ms Šojdrová what she thinks about continuing to involve British young people in volunteering, even after we have left the European Union.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- I fully understand our British colleague and her concern.Personally, I am very sorry that, albeit by a small majority, most of the citizens in the United Kingdom have decided to leave the European Union.And we must do everything we can to ensure that the agreements that are now being prepared for EU-UK cooperation allow meaningful projects to continue and allow young people in particular to move.Young people should not pay for the decisions that most citizens in the UK have made.There is certainly a willingness on the part of the European People's Party to negotiate the best possible relations for youth mobility.

name: Krystyna Łybacka
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr Chairman! Volunteering is a very noble, but often not fully appreciated activity. Therefore, please allow me to start my speech by thanking all volunteers for their work, time, effort and energy. Volunteering, which is on the one hand a process of self-realization and learning, benefits both the volunteers themselves and society as a whole. It is also a hugely important factor in creating social capital and supporting social and economic cohesion. In the context of international exchanges, volunteering has great potential for integration. And if it takes place on the territory of the European Union, it helps to create a European identity. But this potential of cross-border volunteering is not being fully realized. According to data from 2014, it is estimated that around 92-94 million people were involved in voluntary activities, and only 7,000 - in cross-border activities. The full development of cross-border volunteering is hampered by legal, administrative, social and economic barriers, as well as the lack of proper information. This untapped potential is estimated at around EUR 65 million per year. And therefore it is necessary to develop a legal framework that would define the status of volunteering, but also the rights and obligations of volunteers. Mrs Silvia Costa, rightly mentioned the European Charter of the Rights and Responsibilities of Volunteers. We have to answer the question why, for example, a voluntary stay should not constitute a legal basis for a stay in a given country. For people from poorer and disadvantaged backgrounds, for people with disabilities, for example, incomplete health services, and often the loss of social benefits, including unemployment benefits, are a huge problem. Another issue that needs to be resolved is the appreciation of the skills and competences acquired in the course of business voluntary work - the Commissioner has rightly mentioned it. But it is essential that this recognition is promoted in the labor market, especially in the recruitment process. For this purpose, it is necessary to cooperate with employers so that they appreciate the importance of a voluntary internship. The recognition of volunteer working time as an eligible contribution (co-participation) in the case of EU grants should be implemented and supported as soon as possible, and the Commission itself has spoken about this recently. Question to the Commissioner: at what stage is the work on this at? Finally, the local level of volunteering needs to be strengthened in order to share experiences, but there is a need for high-quality information about the opportunities to participate in the program. In the context of the work on the revision of the Erasmus + program, it should be emphasized - as the Commissioner has already done - the great importance of this program for the European Voluntary Service. Each year, several thousand young people get to know another country through Erasmus volunteering, but voluntary organizations keep talking about the need to simplify the application. I have a question for the Commissioner. You spoke about the European Solidarity Corps. What is the relationship between this corpus, volunteering and Erasmus +? (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- First of all, I would like to congratulate Silvia Costa and all the colleagues who initiated this question with an oral answer.Dear colleague, you have exemplified very well here what we need to increase volunteering.Personally, I do not agree with what the Commissioner said, saying that this is complete subsidiarity.And I ask you: don't you think that, for example, at European Union level, there should be some studies, some examples of good practice, that can be disseminated in all the Member States, where results have been obtained?For example, in my country there is a law on volunteering by which voluntary activity is seniority in work for young people.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: answer to a question asked by raising a "blue card".- Thank you very much for this question.I fully agree with the suggestion it contains.In fact, it is important to ensure that all countries have laws that constitute the legal basis for volunteer and volunteer activities.And so far we have a very different status, as well as very different rights for volunteers.I also agree with you that good practices should be shared with regard to the voluntary movement.Besides, it is not only in the field of volunteering that such good practices should be shared.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, volunteering is important for our society and there is no doubt about it. I believe that everyone should participate at least once in their life in a volunteer initiative, and in young people such participation builds qualities and discipline, which are a basic prerequisite for their future development in society. The European Voluntary Service in this respect is a program that helps young people to volunteer abroad. This year it celebrated 20 years since its establishment. 20 years, during which she has assisted over 100 thousand volunteers. This figure speaks for itself about the potential of young people from European nations and the values ​​that volunteering instills in them and that they profess. Almost 100 million citizens of all ages are involved in volunteering, and their work contributes to generating about five percent of the European Union's gross domestic product. 2011 was declared the European Year of Volunteering and gave impetus to the development of policies and the presence of volunteering in key European programs. The movement of young people within the European Union, whether for training, practice or charity, has proven to have a positive impact and should be encouraged. Gaining experience, adapting to the new environment and exchanging good practices is certainly beneficial for all of us. I am proud to say that in Bulgaria - the country I represent - young people are ready and actively involved in such activities. My organization IMRO and I support and stimulate volunteering and are organizers of many activities related to voluntary work on cleaning parks, forests, assistance for the elderly, participation in public events, extinguishing forest fires and much more. Strengthening this activity in society is our duty. Active citizenship and responsibility are at the heart of any self-respecting society and volunteering is just that.Projects to stimulate young people and their participation are necessary and mandatory.All this must reach the most remote areas, the smallest municipalities and regions.

name: María Teresa Giménez Barbat
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, volunteering is included in key European Union programs such as Erasmus + and its European Voluntary Service, which this year celebrates its 20th anniversary. With the Resolution being voted on today, we want to underline the value of volunteer work. Being a volunteer means solidarity, freedom and responsibility at the same time. It means contributing personally to the strengthening of an idea of ​​active citizenship and of a more cohesive society. When volunteering takes place at the European level, it contributes directly to reinforcing one's own European citizenship. However, it is urgent to deepen this concept of volunteering, particularly in times of crisis, as a fundamental pillar of the integration process and for the promotion of union and solidarity in Europe. The European Voluntary Service is not yet well known; its communication should improve and its operation should be easier for those concerned. We also intend to highlight the role of volunteering as a factor of social cohesion, of personal growth of the individual, and even of contribution to economic development. Volunteer work in Europe, as one colleague has said, contributes to the production of 5% of GDP. We also recommend that Member States promote the European Voluntary Service in academic education systems. In my country, Spain, as in most European countries, volunteering is carried out mainly through individual initiatives and local communities, but international volunteering programs are not promoted in schools and neither is known the European Voluntary Service opportunities. I believe that greater cooperation between the European Union and the Member States through joint programs and greater internationalization of the offer could also serve to improve this European proposal. When we think of volunteering, we also think of young people.Volunteering is, in fact, one of the eight areas highlighted by the European Union Youth Strategy.But we must not forget the elderly and the fundamental role that volunteering can play in promoting a culture of active aging, especially if we aspire to a society that integrates all generations.We have come a long way since the celebration of the European Year of Volunteering Activities in 2011, and this is certainly a source of public pride, but we still have a long way to go.

name: Curzio Maltese
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the economic crisis, the sovereign debt crisis, the prevalence of a single neoliberal liberal thought have pushed many European states in recent years on the path of progressive cuts in public services, of extensive privatization. This solution proves to be more unsuccessful with each passing day from an ethical, economic, social, political point of view, creating a poorer, more unjust Europe, and fueling a revolt that today risks overwhelming the Union. If we want to save the European construction, we must return to the founding values ​​and European volunteering embodies these founding values, solidarity, cooperation and direct participation of citizens, in an exemplary way. As a journalist, I have witnessed extraordinary stories of volunteering in my country and in Europe, on the occasion of natural disasters, but also extraordinary difficulties in this sector. We are celebrating 20 years of European volunteering and we do well to celebrate and we do well to be happy with the 100,000 volunteers, but we know that it could be 5 times as much, 10 times as much if we invested more. This report is an excellent step forward, but some things are still missing, there is no shared legislation in Europe, above all there is a lack of adequate funds to develop this phenomenon. There are great difficulties in cross-border volunteering. We need to invest in this. We must remember that every euro invested in volunteering, as various colleagues reminded us, produces an extraordinary economic effect as well as an extraordinary civic and moral effect that is no less important than the economic effect. Help young people develop skills they really need in the world of work. There is a lot of discussion about company intervention programs in the school world that are not as efficient as the voluntary sector. It cannot be said that all investments that pass and are approved in this House have the same extraordinary effect, so I urge the Commissioner to ask for more investment, more communication on this area.(The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- You very rightly mentioned the ethical values of volunteering.In this context, do you not consider, for example, the position of insurers to refuse insurance for disabled people on a voluntary basis to be extremely unethical and deplorable?Don't you find it unethical for every certificate required from a volunteer to be preceded by a fee?

name: Curzio Maltese (GUE/NGL)
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- I personally fight on the rights of people with disabilities together with other colleagues in this House in every sector, also in other sectors of education, in the new regulations for audiovisuals, as my colleagues in the Culture Commission know, so I am perfectlyagree to guarantee these rights as much as possible.

name: Ernest Maragall
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, I believe that we are all quite agreeing on the assessment and diagnosis of what volunteering in Europe means today and what it may mean, of the obvious powers of the concept and of reality. Twenty years. One hundred thousand volunteers in the European Voluntary Service. Five years from the first European Year of Volunteering Activities. The proposed Resolution speaks of an estimated one hundred million volunteers and 5% of GDP. It is an estimate. I think that one of the issues - the motion for a resolution also says - is that we have to study more and we have to know better about the phenomenon, because it seems clear that we are being aware of the tip of the iceberg, a positive, extraordinary point. , but that surely hides realities and situations. In short, it carries very contradictory messages too. Let me tell you that, to some extent, the success or the appearance of success of the concept of volunteering in Europe - for example, in my own country in a very spectacular way - is also a measure, an indicator of social deficits, of needs not covered, of the situations of personal, individual and collective drama that our societies often continue to carry. Where the State does not reach or where the market produces disasters, there appears, indeed and fortunately, the voluntary service that, to a large extent, not only adds but replaces. In any case, let us be clear that there is this substitution value, that there is this value of occupying the space that perhaps could and should be naturally occupied in another way, and then the volunteering could effectively dedicate itself to simply adding, enriching, cooperating to create Europe, and it would be even better than it is now. I believe that we must also highlight the elements of this need for recognition that volunteering has in the sense of access to professionalism, of recognition of capabilities. And it is in that sense that I believe that Europe, the European Union, can and clearly must do more than it does now. We must assume the responsibility to create a framework, to stimulate mobility, to stimulate cooperation, to stimulate learning, to stimulate the coordination also of national legalities and regulations. Look, volunteering is basically a local phenomenon. It appears, is born and grows very close, in reality itself, in response to evident needs appreciated locally. We must avoid a certain risk - how would I say - of institutional arrogance, that from here we are going to organize everything, that from here we are going to know exactly how things have to be. Everything with the citizens because everything is done by the citizens. Please do not be tempted to regulate without citizens. Any progress in this area must be done with the NGOs, with those who are doing it, with those mainly involved. Finally, a scene from two weeks ago, right here in the European Parliament in Brussels. One day, the Italian Coast Guard comes to explain its magnificent activity in the Mediterranean of salvation, of recovery of refugees at sea and, the next day, the Catalan, Spanish NGO, Proactiva Open Arms, comes, which is not a complement , is that it adds value. It is essential; here there is no complementarity: it is a total necessity. Without that NGO, the deaths in the Mediterranean would be thousands more because the military ships cannot do the work that these volunteers do. Let's tell ourselves: not only do you have to congratulate them, you don't just have to reward them, as we just did; you have to know that they are an essential part of the existence of Europe as a concept and as an identity. And there we are. That is what you have to promote. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Thomas Mann (PPE)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Maragall, you have just said that you think that is an enriching element, but that certain measures are primarily replaced and not just supplemented.But isn't it important for young people to be able to try it out?That you can say, before you start your career, that there is a field here in which I can get involved?So that they take a sniff and say: "I would like to show solidarity in my own way"?So that we can say: EVS is something really important and enriching?

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" response.- Mr. Mann, I don't think I said otherwise.I absolutely agree with those virtues of volunteering.One aspect that we have not touched on is that of volunteering in third countries.Do you know the experience of young people who go to Honduras to act as mediators in delicate and dangerous contacts to achieve peace?That is a value for the world and, of course, for themselves.But it is also obvious that they are substituting something to the extent that that problem exists beyond their own responsibility.So, in that sense, that value must be encouraged and recognized, positive for youth, of course.But volunteering is both young and old.And the logical thing is that young people play it up to thirty years of age, and older ones from sixty.That is where we must complement.

name: Isabella Adinolfi
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I congratulate the co-signatories of the joint resolution in which there are several points of merit that can be shared and worthy of support. However, without the procedural and timing forcing, a better result would certainly have been achieved. I hope that this topic will be dealt with with greater procedural clarity in the future and given more visibility on the agenda. I begin by quoting the sentence from the resolution that I probably find most meaningful at the end of paragraph 3: "stress that volunteers should never be considered and used as substitutes". This is a fundamental point, especially at a time of continuing economic and social crisis such as the one we are facing in Europe. Forgetting this would involve the risk of depriving an undoubted and high added value of volunteering of meaning, simply making it a politically correct expression, placed as a justification for situations and initiatives lacking the necessary public support. It is then necessary to restore and promote a framework of values ​​where the sacralization of monetary gain at all costs and of non-solidarity individualism is replaced with a renewed sense of service to the community. In other words, activism. Our movement, the Five Star Movement, which was born on the day of St. Francis, in fact places activism at the center of our political action. For us, no one should be left behind. Furthermore, I consider that there are two preconditions for volunteering to be ethically and politically acceptable. First: the preparation of clear public policies and sufficiently equipped with economic resources, second: the existence of material conditions worthy of all citizens, i.e. work, social coverage systems, so that everyone has the necessary material availability to be able to undertake voluntary actions. Starting from these principles, it is clear that our society must open up to volunteering and stimulate it as a noble expression of an essential human need, as well as a form of active citizenship which is the basis of community life. Volunteering therefore appears to be able to open a positive path within European society. However, it is necessary to set a ceiling on voluntary employment if we do not want to fall into a flagrant contradiction with ourselves, since we must never consider volunteers as replacement labor. A similar warning then signals a significant sociological fact: where there is a conspicuous presence of volunteering, it means that there are shortcomings from the point of view of public policies. This must make us reflect, make us work to remedy these shortcomings whose causes must be identified and addressed. Furthermore, propaganda, emphasis and too strict rules do not reconcile with volunteering. Volunteering is a choice that is made in silence. Allow me to express my solidarity with all those who spent the night on the street tonight because they were victims of the earthquake that is hitting Italy.

name: Dominique Bilde
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr. President, Saint Thomas Aquinas wrote in his Summa Theologica that the best is the enemy of the good. It seems to me that this truth is particularly relevant with regard to the work carried out in this institution. Indeed, who can deny the positive and enriching nature of volunteering? It is not only a question of putting oneself at the service of society, but also of drawing personal fulfillment through the skills that one acquires, the encounters that one can make and the satisfaction of the gift of oneself. We can therefore congratulate ourselves on the fact that over the past twenty years, more than 100,000 young people have taken part in European voluntary service. Still, I don't know if I should worry or admire your ability to twist every good idea in the service of your political ideology. You want to use volunteering to promote European citizenship. However, you forget that citizenship, no offense, is legally and essentially linked to nationality, this nationality which bothers you, because it prevents you from building a European federal state and because you have rooted, attached citizens. to their land, to their nation and to their traditions, these are all the more frontiers to your globalism. You praise the importance of volunteers in managing the refugee crisis. Is it really up to civil society to manage the doldrums that you politicians have created? By following Jean-Claude Juncker in his idea of ​​creating a European Solidarity Corps, you are showing no confidence in the citizens and you are admitting your total irresponsibility in the management of a disaster that you have encouraged; this is the whole point of the EU Aid Volunteers program, launched by DG ECHO. You want to send European volunteers to humanitarian projects all over the world. It's very charitable, well done. But what about the sans fixed domicile in Europe? Do you have a program to help our underprivileged? I remind you that according to the 2014 report of the European Observatory on Homelessness, in France, the number of homeless people has increased by 44% in eleven years, from 80,000 to 150,000 people. These figures are not more glorious in the rest of the European Union: 44% in the Czech Republic, 29% in Sweden, 21% in Germany, 17% in the Netherlands and 16% in Denmark. So I ask you the question: are you also counting on volunteers to help the needy in Europe? Civic service is a great idea, but know that it already exists in several Member States, where it can be effective and be a game-changer, that is to say closer to the citizens. For example, in France, in 2014 there were nearly 35,000 young people in civic service; 50,000 volunteer firefighters are under 35; or 27,000 young people between 11 and 18 years old are young sappers and are learning first aid. What do these examples show? They show that young people want to get involved, but that they want to get involved close to home, to improve the daily life of their grandparents and to be of service to their neighbors. This ties in with another of my concerns: I fear that, like what you are trying to do with Erasmus +, which was nevertheless your only success, you will pervert this beautiful commitment that is volunteering to make it a study of future posted workers with precarious statutes and wages and at the service of your large market. I hope, dear colleagues, that you will hear my message: yes to the recognition of the wonderful work done by the volunteers; no to its political recovery to save the furniture of a house which you yourselves set on fire. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Silvia Costa
text: question "blue card" addressed to Dominique Bilde.- I would just like to know if… faced with a discourse, this truly ideological yes, I feel the need to say that perhaps it is not understood, here we are talking about a transnational experience, a European experience.Perhaps it has escaped that a magnificent European, transnational and international program has existed for twenty years, in which many French boys participate, I am sorry to disappoint Mr Bilde, who is considered a project that holds together quietly, in the conscience of all citizens whothe national dimension, personal identity and international European affiliation participate.Perhaps someone has escaped that we have dual citizenship, Italian, French or Hungarian and European.Perhaps it is not clear that the transnational, European and international dimension is very popular with all young people, including the French.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: answer "blue card".- Mrs Costa, in fact, I understood very well.During my speech, which I nevertheless thought clear, I also cited what had already been done.Most of the time, in this Europe, as we do not use what has been done and do not learn from it, it does not change much.I explained it to you and that's what I don't understand: you always push open doors trying to answer questions with other questions.The problem is simple: we, the French - and this is where your Europe is not working - do not see the same results as those that you constantly tell us in committee.This is why, moreover, we will never agree with your ideologies.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). - Mr President, volunteering, by definition, has no material rewards, although many believe that, for reasons of sustainability, volunteering should be remunerated, not on a paid basis, but by providing the volunteer with free food, accommodation, transportation and other facilities. This is an issue that concerns volunteers and I would like to highlight it. But beyond the informal form of volunteering, that is, the offer on a personal level, the formal form of volunteering has its good and bad side. The good one is more or less known. Formal volunteering has a substantial and long-term goal of the smooth integration of young people into the social system, the acquisition of strong skills and the cultivation of solidarity with fellow human beings. As a Christian and humanist I applaud it. The bad side, however, is the most invisible and unknown to the public. Formal volunteering is mainly related to NGOs. The majority of NGOs, which receive exorbitant amounts of funding, exploit volunteers and treat them as cheap labor. Thus, the voluntary provision of services is an excuse for some fraudsters to get rich by seizing national and community funds. That is why I will disagree with the recognition of volunteering as co-financing. I would rather disagree with promoting access for third-country nationals wishing to volunteer in Europe. We must not open channels for illegal immigrants, ostensibly volunteers, to settle on European soil.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: - Commissioner, Mr President, Rapporteur Costa, volunteering is an expression of solidarity and responsibility, it contributes to greater citizen involvement, personal development and, in our case, it strengthens European values. It is an important tool for non-formal learning and training. Volunteers often help those who need help the most, but on the other hand, they have a strong sense of usefulness. Needless to say, volunteering is a nice option even for those who are not integrated into the school system or the labor market. But perhaps they find a new opportunity in this environment. However, volunteering can also serve as a good example of intergenerational integration, so it is good and right for the European Parliament to address this issue. Congratulations to the rapporteur, Mrs Costa, on the initiative. I am sorry, however, that we have not decided on a different parliamentary procedure, which would give us more time to prepare an even better and more coherent text. This year marks five years since the European Year of Volunteering and twenty years since the creation of the European Voluntary Service, as we have heard several times today, in 2014 the European Voluntary Service was included in the umbrella European Erasmus + program for which I am the rapporteur. I can say that we are dealing with a success story in the European Union, one of the few. As the standing rapporteur on the implementation of Erasmus +, I can add that we should be proud of this program, also because it is not limited to the young, but also includes the elderly. I am currently preparing a report on the implementation of Erasmus +. The general conclusion is that despite some shortcomings, all stakeholders are satisfied with the new program. Despite the fact that we have increased its funding by 40% in this financial perspective, in practice we find that the needs for participation in various Erasmus + sub-programs are significantly greater than the financial possibilities. It is already clear that the potential of Erasmus + will need to be increased in the future. European Voluntary Service is an excellent service with clear frameworks operation. For example, the organizations working in it sign a quality charter. Participating volunteers between the ages of 17 and 30 dedicate themselves exclusively to voluntary activities for a period of two weeks to one year. It is known that EVS covers participants' travel and subsistence expenses, insurance and pocket money. Let me list a few more facts in the making of this document. To date, more than 100,000 volunteers have participated in EVS, as has already been mentioned. This figure alone tells us that the European Commission's communication strategy on EVS is not as bad as it seems. A small part of the text in the resolution refers to this service, a disproportionately larger part was devoted by the rapporteur to volunteering at national level and in general. That is why we have extended the initial title "Resolution on EVS" to "Resolution on EVS and the promotion of volunteering in Europe", which is more in line with the actual content of the resolution. In addition, much of the text is intended for organizations involved in volunteering, it might be a good idea to have even more text for end-users, ie. volunteers themselves. It is known that we have different traditions of volunteering in different countries. In some places the state has a big role, and in some places it is completely in the hands of voluntary organizations or civil society. Or there is something in between. Differences arise from these facts and this should never be overlooked. But we have one common task in front of us: to increase the capacity for international volunteering, so we need to strengthen European volunteering. To sum up: the resolution is good enough, its purpose is good and I hope we will support it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: blue card question.- Mr Zver, in Greece alone, more than 50,000 volunteers have worked to help migrants and refugees who have arrived and continue to arrive.The Commissioner has mentioned a fact: one hundred thousand volunteer positions in twenty years.But, in my opinion, these 50,000 people, most of them young, have taught the Member States a lesson.Along the same lines as colleague Maragall, do you not think that the European Commission should take into account that European value, that commitment when it comes to the European Voluntary Service?

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: The answer to the question posed by raising a blue card.-  You are right.The potential for volunteering is significantly greater than we can establish in the various institutional channels and structures that are, but nonetheless, one such service, as we have now for two decades in the European Union, is an incentive tofacilitates voluntary work for young people at various levels.I particularly appreciate this work that you mentioned in Greece in helping the authorities to manage the refugee and migrant crisis, but the fact is that volunteering is a private matter, a civil society affair, and the state can only help in various ways, including financial assistance.that young people exercise this virtue.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I want to also thank my colleague, Silvia Costa, for promoting this oral question to the Commission. Whilst the EU does not have competence in academic education and curriculum per se, it can be a formidable platform to recognise and promote the role that volunteering, together with sports and arts, plays in strengthening socialisation processes and for the development and wellbeing of societies and individuals, education for citizenship, and in acquiring lifelong transferable skills. Initiatives such as the EVS are more important than ever in times of economic hardship and high youth unemployment, increasing job prospects for young people. The challenge now is to ensure that they are accessible to the most vulnerable young people as well, and for people of all ages and horizons, including people with special needs, minorities, marginalised communities, migrants and refugees. In fact volunteering is a great opportunity for intergenerational learning and intercultural dialogue, necessary to build strong, open and inclusive societies. It must therefore be part of a long-term strategy to develop successful, functional and welcoming communities proud of their heritage and united in diversity. Indeed, informal and non—formal settings, widely used in the context of community education and work with underrepresented groups, provide opportunities for active promotion of common values of freedom, tolerance and non—discrimination and for learning about human rights, including women’s and children’s rights. Openness, tolerance, enriching experiences and encounters, intercultural dialogue and cultural diversity: those are the fundamental elements on which the EVS is based – and so is the European project. Particular recognition should therefore go to those who volunteer in times of crisis, stepping in when governments fail to act, such as the amazing volunteers who have done so much to help the desperate refugees in the Calais and Dunkirk camps, and also the British Muslim youth groups, who were amongst the first people to help the victims of last year’s terrible floods in Cumbria in my north—west England constituency, bringing together different ethnicities in a spirit of shared humanity. As a young person, I learned my values from my parents, but also from my experiences of volunteering. I am one of the people who was failed by conventional formal education, and I found my confidence, my sense of myself and my place in the world largely through volunteering. As a shy, gauche teenager, I joined a youth theatre, where, alongside our normal activities, we spent one evening a week volunteering at a centre for children with profound disabilities. These children became my friends, and I learned to overcome my fear of difference and to fight prejudice and discrimination for the rest of my life. Later I set up many youth theatres and watched young people in my care, many of them troubled and excluded, learn civic values and transferable skills through volunteer projects in their local community and through pan-European and international volunteering experiences. They were doing as I had done: encountering the other through intercultural dialogue and practical action, thereby learning tolerance and mutual respect. I therefore welcome the Commissioner’s statement, but I want to give a word of warning. Volunteering must never be used as an excuse for national governments to cut public services, such as museums, art centres, theatres, libraries and youth clubs, which is, sadly, happening in my country under the current Conservative government, who are replacing real jobs by exploiting the good nature of public-spirited citizens. Volunteering programmes that go hand in hand with a strong social structure and proper investment in public services, offering young volunteers recognition and career pathways and valuing the life experiences of older volunteers, are what is needed in modern society.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR).
text: - When we talk about volunteering, about altruistic care for your loved ones, about your community, about the world around you, I agree with what President Obama said: "The best way not to succumb to despair is to get up and do something. Don't expect good things to happen to you. If you get up and do something good, you will fill the world with hope and you will also fill yourself with hope. ”In addition to altruism, which is virtuous in itself, volunteering deserves recognition and support for a number of other good reasons. It is an ideal way to voluntarily involve people who are worthwhile in useful activities, thus improving the lives of them and those who benefit from volunteering. It is a great way for young people to gain experience and improve their skills, and as we know, youth unemployment is our big common problem. It is an ideal way to use the life experiences of seniors, which will enrich the whole society and can give seniors a sense of application, usefulness, meaning of their future life. By that I mean that volunteering is not just a matter for a specific group - it is a matter for everyone, regardless of age, education or wealth. Volunteering is by definition a voluntary activity of the willing, and if we can find ways to support it, we will support other civic virtues in addition to the mentioned skills and gaining or passing on experience - interest in the world around us, participation in society, active citizenship. And these are the things that every healthy and functioning free society needs. And besides, volunteering creates measurable value, so we should measure and value it. Volunteering should be promoted and valued in every Member State of the Union, as well as by the institutions of the Union itself, if we want it to be a union of well-functioning states with free and active citizens.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, it is very appropriate that 20 years after the EVS was started and five years after the European Year on Volunteering, that we can stand back and reflect on the progress we have made and map out a pathway for the future. As a founder member of the Volunteering Interest Group in Parliament, I and many of my colleagues, many of whom are here today, have worked in partnership with voluntary groups in our own Member States and with the Centre for European Volunteering (CEV).  Indeed after 2011, the CEV coordinated the setting up of an alliance which fed into a document called the ‘Policy Agenda for Volunteering’. This document speaks of the partnership approach which will work towards building and enabling volunteering infrastructure in Europe. Indeed, our own resolution calls on the Commission to facilitate the development of a more coordinated volunteering policy with a view to establishing a single contact point in the Commission. One of the things that I have heard again and again, from the CEV in particular, is that volunteering is spread across a number of different DGs. We need to streamline the system.  Other issues that need to be dealt with include the fact that all Member States adopt the system developed by the ILO to measure volunteering. I am pleased to hear that the Commission is going to support volunteering as an essential part of third-level courses; indeed we have some excellent examples of what we call service learning in NUI Galway and St Angela’s in Sligo. I am also pleased to hear the announcement of the European Solidarity Corps.  Finally I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate my own hometown Sligo, which who has been named European Volunteering Capital for 2017. It is a huge opportunity to recognise and support our wonderful volunteers and I hope it will be a catalyst to encourage even more volunteers and particularly young people, some of whom may well join the European Solidarity Corps.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, Commissioner, the European Voluntary Service and all programs that promote volunteering must be treated with extreme caution. It must be ensured, firstly, that they promote the values ​​of co-operation and solidarity and, secondly, that they are completely separated from actions aimed at replacing the welfare state and state structures and reinforcing distorted patterns of unpaid work. Unfortunately, ladies and gentlemen, in my view, in today's Europe, in the Europe of the crisis, in the current context, the concept of volunteering is being used as a euphemism. Most of the time it means what I pointed out above: exemption of the state from its responsibilities and problems that it has to face, false coverage of social needs. Commissioner, the economic crisis, unemployment, social problems are not natural phenomena that have arisen in some countries so suddenly and therefore can be tackled by individual or private action. It is a result, as has been seen, of the neoliberal policies pursued. Therefore, volunteering is a limited undertaking and can not deal effectively with all these consequences. I want to give you, at the end, two facts. In Greece in recent years about 1,200 young people have been involved in volunteering programs, at the same time that these years we have had the migration of 250,000 Greek scientists to other countries, not voluntarily, but compulsorily, in search of work. So these programs are good, but I emphasize that the priority is to have training programs and to find quality jobs with rights.

name: Raymond Finch (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I understand we are all here today – the few of us that have actually turned up, maybe 3% of all MEPs – to discuss how young people can volunteer, in the name of the EU of course, to help those less fortunate both in Europe and abroad.  My party and nation fully support anybody wishing to volunteer to help wherever the help may be needed. Indeed, our former Prime Minister, Mr Cameron, spent 200 million on his Big Society project after the 2010 election with precisely this in mind. In principle, this was a very good thing. However, because it was political, and not social and local, it failed, and nobody now speaks of the Big Society in any way except ironically.  Which brings me now to the EVS now celebrating, if that is the right word, its 20th anniversary. In reality, what it means is you are celebrating spending 20 years of throwing taxpayers’ money down the drain, and as if this was not enough, the Europe for Citizens programme will cost the taxpayers of our nations a whopping EUR 186 million between 2014 and 2020. Clearly, it is not fulfilling this objective as I see that the Committee on Culture and Education is now developing another citizenship initiative called the European civic service initiative. Just like every other EU project it is a waste of money, it is unnecessary and nobody has heard of it.  While the EU throws money at projects such as this, public services are cut and there is widespread use of food banks all across Europe. How many more schemes will you put in place that will be re-branded at ever greater and greater cost, to fail to achieve the same objective – to create a demos where there is none? While the ostensible goals of these projects are laudable, they are failures under any benchmark and are never really what they say on the tin, so I say ‘stop them now’. National governments already do these things. Give them their taxpayers’ money back and let them get on with it. You are only doing this to make us all feel part of your nations’ EU superstate. Please stop now.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: -  Mister President! If we are discussing EVS, the European Voluntary Service, today, we have to emphasize and emphasize the fundamentally immense importance of volunteering - on the one hand through its positive impact on the development of young people and the promotion of citizenship, but also on the other hand through its essential contribution to them Community, the high economic benefit. In German we have a nice word for it. We call this “volunteering” - voluntarily, but also without payment. Today, of course, it must also be emphasized and stated that this voluntariness has not only existed in Europe for 20 years, because voluntary organizations have been in existence in Central Europe for 150 years, especially in Germany and in my home country Austria: aid organizations such as the volunteer fire brigade for Examples that have been highly deserving for many, many years, rescue organizations such as mountain rescue, such as water rescue, and of course the charitable aid organizations that have been active for many, many years. I have been a member of the volunteer fire brigade myself since I was 14 and I am proud to be a member there to this day. Because in my home country Austria alone we have 338 055 volunteer fire fighters who are ready day and night, whatever the weather, to stand up for property, but also to save and protect lives. That is 1,680,327 hours of use. If I extrapolate that with an average salary, then that's around 50.4 million euros that people volunteer, not counting the belongings or even the life they protect. It is therefore important that today we consider what a positive example these organizations can give for Europe. I think that this is exactly what the EVS would do, to implement these good examples in countries that do not have such organizations. It would also be important to coordinate today.We have a lot of organizations that represent a wild growth for volunteering.We have z.B. The European Youth Foundation with 3.7 million, we have the EU Aid Volunteers with a billion budget, organized by the Commission.We have the Civil International Service in Europe and EFD.So, I think it would be important to coordinate that and, accordingly, to save costs and to use the resources accordingly.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! At least two weeks and no more than a year: With the support of the European Voluntary Service, 100,000 young Europeans have done a lot of good against racism and xenophobia, for tolerance and for understanding. You have already mentioned the cultural area. I am concerned with social services, for example by caring for the homeless or by giving people with disabilities a chance because young people are committed, or in dealing with older people - who are often lonely - or with the marginalized. Such reports of success of solidarity make one who works in the employment and social affairs area in the European Parliament proud. What has been achieved here is great. I also think it's a wonderful example for young people who often don't even know what to do with themselves. That is exactly the area, a highly motivating department. So far, however, Commissioner, the age limit has been from 17 to 30 years. Question: Shouldn't people who are a little older also take part in voluntary work, in order to discover for themselves that they can find access to existing initiatives? I think a good example is being set in my state of Hesse. There is a state volunteering agency there - a service point for citizens, clubs and associations. That is exactly the quality of information that many colleagues have just asked for. Opening up to the European level - yes, I think it is worth considering. Ms. Costa is absolutely right. This is an international project and cannot be seen in just one Member State. Your answer to the colleague from the National Front was absolutely correct and I support her. The possible extension - i.e. the age limit - could of course be achieved with financial resources. That is clear. Furthermore the EVS supports projects that contribute to personal and professional orientation so that competencies and skills can be acquired. Commissioner, you are right, recognition must come for this time. Voluntary - yes of course. But an acknowledgment for that. A lot of young people don't do it because of the money, but because they say: I would like to get involved. That's why it's a very important project, and above all you learn to develop an understanding of values. I think another focus is important too; this has already been indicated in the case of two colleagues. I am the rapporteur for the EPP Group on the integration of refugees into the labor market. For example, if you can help to say: I want to help with the initial reception facility. You can't always do everything pedagogically, that's clear, but you can help. Or with the unaccompanied refugees. There are people in a similar age range. I think that giving them a chance to be there is the most motivating factor, because integration really takes place. Or when it comes to developing language skills. You can't replace a teacher, but you can say: We are also involved, and we create access to local companies so that internships work. May the EU help ensure that precisely these helpers can be helped even better.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, this year we are celebrating 20 years since the establishment of the European Voluntary Service. I believe that the time is more than appropriate to take stock of what has been done on a European scale in support of volunteers and volunteering. We can start with the fact that 2011 has been declared the European Year of Volunteering. This demonstrates the European Union's commitment to supporting and encouraging citizens and organizations working with volunteers. Moreover, the European Union is sounding the alarm about the declining number of active volunteers and calling on the Member States to restore the attractiveness of volunteering. In 2013, in its resolution on volunteering and volunteering in Europe, the European Parliament emphasized the need for a common European approach to volunteering to create more opportunities for the mobility and employment of young people. Since 2014, the new Erasmus + program has enabled young Europeans to travel abroad and participate in volunteer projects. Last but not least, the President of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker announced the creation of a European Solidarity Corps, which will allow young people in the European Union to volunteer to help in crisis situations. The measures taken at European level have undoubtedly given a positive boost to the volunteering sector. However, there are still a number of challenges that still need to be addressed. First of all, it should be noted that there are still too many bureaucratic obstacles at national level, which significantly limit the opportunities for volunteering. At present, the activities of volunteers are not recognized in the legal systems of all Member States. To my great regret, in the context of the European attention to the topic, my country Bulgaria remains one of the few European countries that does not yet have an active one. law on the organization of volunteers. I have drafted a bill on volunteering, and in this regard I will set up a working group next week to discuss it. I believe that such a law would undoubtedly contribute to creating a favorable environment for the implementation of voluntary activities to improve their quality and to give them due recognition. I believe that it is extremely important to pay attention to issues such as the insurance of the volunteer, the reimbursement of his expenses, his accident insurance, training, qualification, respect for paid leave and length of service during the time of volunteering. With regard to possible action at European level, I share the view that the Commission must proceed with the formal recognition of European Voluntary Service status. Moreover, Member States can validate non-formal non-formal education obtained through volunteering. Last but not least, we must pay attention to youth volunteering, because it provides an opportunity to learn and acquire practical skills based on work experience. Let us not forget that five percent of the European Union's GDP is made up of volunteering. And every euro we invest returns five to national budgets.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! This is a very good and important idea, but it has been implemented in the Member States, in Poland, for years. Here my colleague from Austria spoke about voluntary fire brigades - in Poland it is very common. But it is not only about such permanent organizational forms, but also about events depending on certain situations - as it is now called. We recently had World Youth Day in Poland, millions of young people from all continents came and everything turned out great thanks to the work of thousands - mainly young, but not only - volunteers from all over Poland who were very actively involved in it. At this point, I would like to express my sincere thanks to them. However, it is worth saying that this idea should be supported wisely in order to support volunteering that already exists, and not one that, for example, would arise due to EU money, because such situations are bad, unacceptable and certainly not would build the authority of the European Union. It is a pity, in fact, that there are so few of us here today. My colleague from Great Britain said that there are a few people - well, not a few, I counted over thirty - but it is really worth supporting this idea, because in my opinion a certain enthusiasm, enthusiasm of young people in various directions should be given by us - European Parliament , The European Union - supported. Not only because they choose some valuable forms of helping others, but also because - and I end this, Mr. President - that we can regain credibility in the eyes of our voters.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, volunteering is a major force, nurturing civil society and strengthening solidarity, one of the core values of the EU. Voluntary work provides direct ways to learn and develop new skills. Volunteers can give and gain professional experience and expand their networks. Another great value of volunteering is that it brings people together, uniting people from diverse backgrounds to work towards a common goal and benefit our community, addressing human, social and environmental needs and concerns. A great example is the integral role that volunteers play in the current refugee crisis, restoring safety, dignity and hope to people whose lives have been uprooted by war and disaster. This year the European Voluntary Service celebrates its 20th anniversary. During this time about 100 000 volunteers have been supported. Acknowledging the tremendous added value of volunteering, more needs to be done in order to promote and foster voluntary activities. Increasing the understanding and transparency of informal and non—formal learning skills acquired during volunteering experience is essential and therefore Member States should implement concrete validation processes to ensure a better understanding and comparability of those skills and experience.  I believe that the scope, participants, areas of work and destinations of the EVS should be expanded. Helping others and dedicating time to serving the community should know no barriers and therefore we should strive to widen the possibilities for people of different ages to undertake voluntary work, including taking advantage of the possibilities that the new technologies offer.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, we live in a fairly atomized world and the basic links between people are disappearing, and I believe that volunteering is one of the keys to change. By promoting, supporting and developing volunteering and appreciating its contribution, we can contribute to creating a more pleasant environment for all of us. Volunteering offers help to those who need it, and at the same time I provide meaningful content to people who help, which promotes interpersonal solidarity and cooperation. All too often we speak phrases here and in this building, and I think we should rather listen to the story from practice. This is what a long-term volunteer from the Czech Republic writes about volunteering: “I dedicate my time to people who need it, I played two hours of cards with one lady, I was silent with another for an hour and held her hand firmly. I also listened once for a long time to an interesting talk about flying around the world. It's weird, you've been flying in the clouds all your life, you have everything you want, and then someone who takes a bus to the sea will bring you a smile. But he also has everything he wants to have. ”Volunteering needs to be done with heart, desire and inner strength. This is not about money, prestige and racing, who's more, more and better. We should support such people and offer them a helping hand. I would like to say here that I highly value all European volunteers and their activities. They are people who do not look away when they see that someone needs their help, and they see that the creation of values, cooperation and human belonging is part of human life. These are the people who deserve our support, these are the people we should talk about much more often here.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, on October 17 we celebrated in my city, Barcelona, ​​the thirtieth anniversary of the awarding of the organization of the 1992 Barcelona Olympic Games. The city changed from night to day. More than 100,000 people made up the body of Olympic volunteers who were key to the smooth running of those Games. And all of us in Barcelona passionately appropriate those Games. I was a volunteer in 1992 when I was eighteen years old. Colleague Maragall, who preceded me in the use of the word, was the protagonist in the invention and organization of it. Today we also celebrate this other anniversary: ​​twenty years of the European Voluntary Service. "Europe will show solidarity or it will not": this was the message that the President of the Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, gave us during the State of the Union debate last September when he referred to - and I quote - that solidarity is the glue that holds Europe together. ' As we said, twenty years of the European Voluntary Service have been completed, a service that has welcomed more than 100,000 young Europeans and has helped them improve many of their skills and competences, improve their curriculum and, ultimately, provide them with an experience of Incalculable value. When we talk about the European volunteering service, we talk about empowering European citizens who are between seventeen and thirty years old and who, through this service, can get to know other cultures, learn new languages ​​and improve the lives of people close to them thanks to volunteering. This helps us to create and enhance the feeling of European citizenship. Good initiatives such as the train ticket for young Europeans who turn eighteen - which we provided yesterday with a budget line -; the European social pillar, which we are building and which we hope will soon see the light; and the achievement of the social triple A in Europe will also help us to knock down the shadows of the walls that they stalk the Union. Europe - Manfred Weber said yesterday - needs unity, determination and leadership. We must get closer to the European society, to the society of tomorrow and make reach each institute, each school, each classroom, each desk in the European Union, the information necessary for European youth to take a step forward, take pride in the Union's values ​​- peace, solidarity and the common good - and demand their fulfillment from us. And why not, on this twentieth anniversary, start exploring the possibilities of expanding the program to include volunteer service geared toward active aging. It probably doesn't look like it, but it's Europe's time. We must be aware of this and open our focus in order to take advantage of the opportunities we have. We have the European Commission proposal for the establishment of a European Solidarity Corps and we celebrate twenty years of this European volunteer service: let's take advantage of it. We must give our young people the tools - empower them, as I said - and we can also give them the added value of European seniors. It is time to take action, that innovation does not scare us, because of them, of our young people, will be the future of Europe.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in this period of severe crisis of values ​​that is affecting the whole of Europe, a sign of hope comes to us from young people, thousands of young people who every year embark on the path of volunteering. This Parliament has strongly supported the establishment of the European Year of Volunteering in 2011, an initiative that has not only contributed to raising awareness of the added value of volunteering, but has also allowed for the creation and review of numerous national and legal frameworks. on volunteering in Europe. This year the European Voluntary Service celebrates its 20th anniversary. During these 20 years, 100,000 volunteers have been supported, 100,000 young people who have embarked on a path of solidarity and who have responded with concrete actions to social, humanitarian and environmental challenges. The European Voluntary Service program has benefited not only the individuals and the organization involved, but also society as a whole. It's time to take stock. We are proud of the many progress made, however we do not stop there. We ask the Commission to promote a more coordinated European policy on volunteering, including through a single point of contact that will improve access to programs and the interaction of initiatives. Not all Member States have, in fact, set up national voluntary programs with adequate resources. Our encouragement is aimed at improving information on volunteering opportunities, as well as creating national civil service platforms and promoting the dissemination of best practices from the most advanced countries, I am thinking of my country, Italy, in order to promote the creation of a European civil service complementary to the already existing opportunity. Thanks to the 100,000 young people who took part, so I thank them, in the European Voluntary Service and thanks to the volunteers who have already rushed to the areas earthquake in the Marche and Umbria.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
