text: ECR). - Madam President, volunteering is an expression of altruism, solidarity and cooperation. It strengthens the participation of citizens in the fight against social exclusion, poverty and injustice. At the same time, volunteers, and especially young people, can gain experience and enhance a sense of self-satisfaction. In the last twenty years, approximately 100,000 young people have participated in international volunteering, through European volunteering programs, contributing to various fields, such as art, health, sports, social welfare, etc. According to a Eurobarometer survey conducted in April 2015, the most popular volunteering programs are in the fields of charity with 44%, education with 40% and art and culture with 15%. Neoliberalism and the memoranda dismantled the social structures of the state, with the result that volunteering, for reasons of social solidarity, was called upon to fill the gaps arising from the reduction of the welfare state. In the Greece of the memoranda, the solidarity structures supported the impoverished Greek people, with the creation of social pharmacies, social clinics, social grocery stores and social tuition centers. Of course, volunteering cannot and should not replace the welfare state, nor can it be an alibi for banking to dismantle state solidarity structures. On the other hand, various experts, taking advantage of the state's inability to respond to the recent pressures due to the refugee crisis, wearing the lion of volunteerism, have created various NGOs and are now partying with European Union funds for refugees, taking advantage of themselves. unfortunate refugees. So it is time, Commissioner, Mr Navracsics, for OLAF to take action to crack down on these anti-social phenomena that sell and volunteer.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: - At a time when we dream that robots will perform a whole range of functions that make our lives easier, today we must realize that the hands of a man, a fellow human being, ready to help one's neighbor, are irreplaceable, even today in Italy, which has been affected. earthquake. The European Voluntary Service, which has been operating as an organized service for twenty years, has motivated more than 100,000 members, mainly young people, to come to the rescue if necessary, to enrich the local community with their enthusiasm, to sharpen their organizational skills, to strengthen their sense of teamwork. to increase their prospects for breakthrough in future professional fields. It is really impressive to know that 100 million people in Europe are involved in volunteering and that they contribute 5% to their total GDP. When I express my support for the resolution, I think it is particularly important to emphasize that the field of volunteering needs a clear and simple flow of information, which will inform volunteers in the Member States about the possibilities for co-financing programs by the European Union. That is why I also support the proposal to set up a single and active information point at the European Commission. It would be useful for the Commission to commission an analysis of national volunteering schemes and to present good practices that would make them accessible to all and provide adequate financial support. We humans are the wealth of the earth, irreplaceable in our goodness and generosity. That is why the better among us deserve understanding and support.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, we value volunteering, namely the social role that it can assume as a contribution to the promotion of effective solidarity and mutual assistance among citizens, consolidating feelings of altruism and genuine generosity, contrary, moreover, to the culture of individualism that the neoliberal policies of European Union help to promote. The report mentions concepts that we do not follow, such as the concept of European citizenship, European civic service or the European solidarity body. It refers to the relevant role of volunteers in supporting the refugee humanitarian crisis. Valuing this participation, we cannot fail to denounce that those concepts and entities will contribute to legitimize and deepen a dynamic that has been used to take responsibility for the role that States and the European Union should have and do not assume in the response to the very serious humanitarian crisis. Finally, mentioning that volunteering cannot replace jobs, an unfortunately increasingly common practice, which justifies the need to strengthen its legal framework and the defense of its social rights.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE).
text: - Madam President, voluntary service is celebrating its twentieth anniversary. Twenty years of experience. There are indeed as many unique experiences as there are participants. More than 100,000 individuals have thus experienced an enriching adventure both individually and collectively because, basically, this is volunteering: a rewarding experience but, above all, an experience to be valued. The European Union has understood this well by insisting in all its initiatives on informal and non-formal learning, this school of life which has nothing to envy to academic courses. This is why I am convinced that everyone should be encouraged to take part in this type of commitment and program, regardless of age, gender or background. These programs must be opened up to citizens as much as possible, valuing the work carried out by recognizing - an extremely important point - the resulting skills and, also, formalizing the recognition of the status of European volunteer. Volunteering is the European spirit in what is most concrete; it is the expression of solidarity; it is citizenship that does useful work; it is openness to the world and to others. These voluntary activities contribute to mutual and intercultural understanding, an understanding of the other which, too often, is lacking in our societies. Thanks to the European voluntary service, win-win relationships are established and strong human adventures are born. Access to these initiatives must be encouraged and, more generally, the possibilities of European mobility developed, in particular for young people. This new generation asks only that, as demonstrated by various programs, including Erasmus +. All the studies prove it. There is no single model, only one path worth following to find your place in society. Alongside traditional courses, we must in particular stimulate and promote learning through work-study program, which offers a royal route to employment, including with experience abroad. For a few months now, with the European Parliament and with the Commission, which has made a clear commitment, we have been developing this mobility in a pilot project. The European voluntary service is twenty years old, a good age for travel. On the occasion of this anniversary, if there is one wish that can be formulated, it is that this voluntary service be recognized at its true value, a European Union value. European voluntary service, Erasmus + and European work-study programs are all links that will cement the European cohesion of tomorrow. It is a response to those who plead for identities of closure and withdrawal. We must oppose them with open identities with young people, citizens who are well of their village, their region, their country, the European Union, but who are also actors of the world, a generation which does not cultivate egoism but, on the contrary, solidarity.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: - Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank Silvia Costa for this initiative, as well as for this debate and this motion for a resolution that is going to be approved, and also for the initiative of a written statement that some Members have put in place to get forward, to improve the European Voluntary Service and to try, at this time of our twentieth birthday, to give a new impetus to recover many young people and many people who want to collaborate with their communities. Because the truth is that the European Voluntary Service probably unites two great values, two great principles of the European project. On the one hand, work with the community, social assistance, collaboration with the people who need it most, support in these days when we see refugees arriving in Europe. That solidarity, that closeness with citizens, with people who suffer is the best of the European project. But, in addition, the European Voluntary Service also helps to build the European demos, it helps to build European society; It helps the ideal of European citizens, the ideal of European citizenship, to recover and integrate people and give - as I was saying - a new impetus to the European dream in which we are working. I am grateful to the Commission for the proposals it has made here today to try to improve it. I think there are ideas in this House that can help give a new impetus: not only to focus on young people, but also on all ages; create a statute for the European volunteer; improve collaboration with third countries and see how the European Voluntary Service fits in with the initiative that Mr Juncker presented to us in the Union debate to create a volunteer corps that, in this case, helps refugees. I think they are good initiatives that go in the right direction and that have to help us to recover the European dream, to recover the desire to have an inclusive, collaborative society, tolerant, against nationalisms, which is what we are working on.And we appreciate and hope that we go in that direction.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! Volunteering as an initiative that already connects around 100 million Europeans in pursuit of one goal - helping those in need, requires support and good coordination. The willingness to help in the form of volunteering not only increases social commitment, but also activates people of different age and social groups, educates and promotes values ​​such as solidarity, cooperation, leadership and organizational skills, and sensitivity to the needs of other people. Many speakers have already mentioned the anniversary of the European Voluntary Service, which enabled young people to support initiatives in which they believe: helping refugees and immigrants, promoting pro-ecological attitudes, helping children and seniors, or working for non-governmental organizations. Volunteering is not only helping those in need, but also an investment in your own development and competences. It is also an important tool for civic and European education. Thanks to it, young Europeans can have direct contact with other cultures, people and customs in the countries where they help. It is worth adding that for many organizations, the involvement of volunteers in the work of these entities is often an essential element of their functioning. The benefits of this activity are mutual, and not only for the parties directly involved, as they also have a broad economic dimension and contribute to economic development, generating nearly 5% of European GDP. A good example of voluntary activities is volunteering in the dimension of sport. Local sports clubs play an important role in social and cultural life in most Member States, so it is worth disseminating these patterns, also on the pan-European and more broadly international level. Volunteers need a space to learn and gain experience, but they also need to be entitled to appropriate training in a first step to help them better understand the organization they work in and the environment in which they will operate. Scale European Voluntary Service requires simplification of procedures for the involvement of both young and old people.Ease of access, a quick registration process and comprehensive information and insurance are key.It should also be possible for participants to use the acquired skills in other forms of assistance or in regional initiatives.European Voluntary Service is for people who want more from life and therefore it is worth supporting them.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the European Year of Volunteering 2011 represented a major political opportunity to highlight the added value of volunteering in Europe. Volunteering is one of the most visible expressions of solidarity, which promotes and facilitates social inclusion, builds social capital and produces a transformative effect on society.  I believe it should be further strengthened through a legal framework, regulating a support mechanism and establishing appropriate organisational structures. Member States that still need to define a legal environment for volunteers should do so as quickly as possible through the use of recommendations in the Policy Agenda for Volunteering in Europe and the European Charter on the Rights and Responsibilities of Volunteers.  Moreover, I support the call on the Commission to facilitate the development of a more coordinated European volunteering policy, with a view to establishing a single contact point in the Commission which would interconnect the individual initiatives and programmes, and improve access to volunteering programmes.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too thank President Costa for the initiative and I agree that we are dedicating this day, this discussion of ours to the thousands of people affected again by a terrible earthquake in central Italy. As the Commissioner said, the initiative that President Juncker presented to us to create a European solidarity corps that can truly prefigure a European civil service is important. In the meantime, however, and alongside this, we believe that a common framework is needed, a common frameboard, to better coordinate European volunteering in individual countries, it needs to be extended to all age groups, it serves to recognize a series of elements that allow it to function better. Because, as many colleagues have recalled, the aim is also to consolidate a common European identity and there is nothing more useful, I believe, to consolidate it, than getting to know each other in a civil voluntary activity and, therefore, create bonds of solidarity.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the citizens of the European Union have recognized the value of volunteering - almost 100 million volunteers. The benefits are visible in the economy. In some countries, volunteering contributes up to 5% of GDP. The social impact of volunteering is also exceptional, it is an important aspect of active citizenship and democracy because it encourages intergenerational solidarity, creates social capital and contributes to social inclusion. In times of growing xenophobia and populism, volunteers are the bearers of European values ​​of solidarity and non-discrimination. Although the economic crisis has not destroyed the spirit of volunteering in the Union, bureaucratic obstacles, inadequately regulated status and lack of institutional support make it difficult to volunteer. In Croatia, for example, civil society organizations are a driver of volunteering. They are the only ones who educate volunteers and volunteer organizers and organize activities. For every euro received, they withdraw another 4 taxable euros from the state budget from European funds, but their effect on the economy is not valorized nor are they a component of GDP. In conclusion, after the 2011 "Year of Volunteering", we need new initiatives and institutional support to finally give volunteers the status of European Volunteers.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: - Madam President! One could speak for a long time about the advantages of volunteering, its contribution to character development, building active civic attitudes and social bonds. So I think there is a consensus among us that this activity should be supported. EVS is a unique project and therefore especially valuable. In addition to the above-mentioned advantages, it also provides young participants with opportunities to travel and learn about other cultures and societies. In the face of growing anti-EU and racist extremism and attitudes in Europe, the value of shaping open social attitudes is particularly important. Therefore, I am of the opinion that European Voluntary Service should be strengthened and promoted in order to increase its recognition and coverage, also among young people from environments that have so far not used this opportunity or have used it to a limited extent, including rural areas. I believe that a step in this direction would certainly be the formal recognition by the Commission of the European Volunteer status.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a few hours ago another terrible earthquake rocked central Italy and hundreds of volunteers have already given their willingness to help the affected populations. Volunteering represents one of the highest manifestations of solidarity, strengthens active citizenship and contributes significantly to the spread of European values. I am in favor of the creation of European Union solidarity corps that can bring support in other European countries to populations affected by natural disasters, such as an earthquake, a flood or even the landing of migrants. It is necessary to encourage and protect the civil service provided by volunteers who willingly and generously decide to donate their time and commitment to others, but it is also necessary to enhance the professionalizing aspect of volunteering. Volunteers must be guaranteed quality tutoring throughout their entire employment both to make their skills available in difficult situations and to ensure that the skills acquired are useful for entering the world of work.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr Representative.He spoke so quickly that he put interpreters in a difficult position, but it is undoubtedly very important what he said and what is happening in Italy now.Thanks to these volunteers.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, it is enough to see today's newspaper.It is enough to look at today's media in Europe, especially those in Italy, so that we all clearly understand what volunteering means.Without these people who are willing to sacrifice themselves 24 hours there would not be so much solidarity, so much friendship, not only in Italy, but nowhere in Europe, nowhere in the world.I want to highlight the many examples we have.Of course, perhaps firefighting is the most famous example or lasts the longest as volunteering, but even here the current migrant crisis shows how important volunteers are.One experience I have with an Pula association called "Our dream, their smile" shows something that is important, and I want to emphasize that, Mr. Commissioner.NGOs, volunteers get where the authorities can’t get.It is that great added value that volunteers have compared to the public sector.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - European voluntary service provides an opportunity to experience a form of social action that is unfortunately increasingly lost in our time. Contributing to solving social problems on a voluntary basis, supporting those in need, was a natural form of social participation decades ago, while today it is seen in many cases as a deviant social pattern. Community involvement, work for free, for community purposes, strengthens the very fabric of Europe that has weakened, become vulnerable and has almost been forgotten. Volunteering, active citizenship - or as it is called in Szeklerland: kalaka - is much more important than we might think. After all, a person who does volunteer work does so mainly in their own narrow community, and thus does nothing but invest in the future. He expresses his confidence in the future of his community, his willingness to do it for him, and his ability to make sacrifices. That is why it is important for as many European citizens as possible to experience volunteering, which is why it is very important for European voluntary service to be strengthened.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Commissioner, the European Voluntary Service has a special role to play. By increasing volunteering we can prepare young people for the future profession, we can increase solidarity, humanism, mutual knowledge of culture, the interaction between rural and urban. Volunteering must be promoted not only for the crisis situation, as has recently been the case in Italy; Volunteering must be promoted in all areas: supporting the rehabilitation of tourist or cultural objectives, assisting the elderly or people with disabilities. Being a volunteer is a vocation, and we must promote this in schools, in primary classes, in the family, because only together, in solidarity, can we build a better society. That is why I believe, Commissioner, that we need to start here, in the European Parliament, with a greater construction and visibility of what we want through volunteering, and of course the Member States have a special role to play in promoting volunteering in their countries. .

name: Werner Kuhn (PPE).
text: - Madam President! First of all, I would like to congratulate you on 20 years of European Voluntary Service. I think it is very, very important that we have this initiative across borders in Europe. Here in Germany there is a common saying that means: no state can be made without volunteering. That also means that our society would be much poorer without volunteers. The state administrations are very happy that they have such voluntary deployment trains when natural disasters occur, when there are large pile-ups on the highways, that the first aid trains are also from the Red Cross, the fire brigade are there. The civil protection trains, which also do prevention - but also crisis intervention. What is very, very important: Finding relatives when there are injured people. The insecurity that exists in society. Such things are mostly done by young people, but also by old and experienced people who are great role models here. I would like to thank everyone who volunteers. They give the most important thing we have in our life: our free time.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to pay tribute to all the volunteers who devote their time and energy to that very voluntary service. I do not know if there is a high number of 100 000 people who are supposed volunteers at the level of the European continent, in any case, it is the people who have opted for this voluntary service, and we should encourage them. Their influence on GDP, on the social stratification of society and, in fact, on the unification of society is very significant. However, as far as the status of a European volunteer is concerned, I believe that we should be a little moderate, that is, not to unnecessarily tie up the rules of this volunteering space or the space in which they do their work, with excessive regulation. I would warn against this, because volunteering comes from civil society, from a certain openness. And I think that regulation could hurt it even more, that is, rather minimum standards.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: - Volunteering is not a sacrifice. Volunteering is a conscious choice. It's a willingness to help. It is also very often a desire to test yourself before making life choices or working. Almost most of you talked about volunteering young people up to the age of 30. I would like to emphasize, and thus express deep appreciation and respect for senior volunteers, because more and more of them still lead an active life after their professional career, and volunteering allows them to do local activities in their city, and thus to spend their time and carry out help those people who are unable or unable to help the state. Often the senior volunteers who work in universities of the third age work in hospitals and hospices. And I would like, Commissioner, that the stream of money or a special program would also be aimed at seniors, whom we have talked about too little here in this room.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me first thank Ms Costa for raising this issue in this Parliament. It gives us a very good opportunity to discuss all the important aspects of volunteering. There is a growing awareness now of the importance of volunteering. The long list of discontent demonstrates this fact and I think this discussion was a very fruitful and useful discussion for us. When developing the concept and the scheme of the European Voluntary Service we can put all your remarks into the further drafts of the European Voluntary Service schemes.  Let me emphasise one thing. Volunteering is not an ideological issue for me and I think this has been well demonstrated by the fact that we have a lot of supportive remarks from all the political groups in Parliament. This again demonstrates that this is a consensual issue and we have to do more in developing volunteering at local level, regional level, national level, and also at the European level.  What is the fundamental mission of the European Voluntary Service? It is not building up a homogeneous European voluntary scheme. It is about help, it is about solidarity, and it is about charity. The fundamental mission of the European Voluntary Service is to help local initiatives and we do exactly that. We have a lot of projects which help local stakeholders, NGOs, local activists in implementing their own initiatives and we help young people to be mobile. We support mobility schemes to acquire skills and to acquire knowledge in each other’s Member States.  The second, and probably the most important, aspect of volunteering is acquiring skills, and that could be very important in tackling youth unemployment. That is why, when we review the European Qualifications Framework, we will put volunteering skills into the European Qualifications Framework and acknowledge those skills which could be acquired during volunteering.  I think this is quite important because it can help us to promote social cohesion, to give one more chance to those people who have a different social background and probably cannot simply enter the labour market, but by volunteering they can acquire those very important skills which can help them to get better job opportunities.  Last, but not least, we are aware of the fact that the European Voluntary Service concentrates mostly on young people but, as I just mentioned in my introductory remarks, we are working on broadening the scope and giving the opportunity for older people to be included in our schemes and giving them the opportunity to work as volunteers in the framework of the European Voluntary Service.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Six motions for resolutions have been sent to me.I close the debate.The vote will take place today, 27 October 2016, at 12 noon.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today we celebrate 20 years of the European Voluntary Service. This ambitious program, born as a pilot project in 1996, has so far involved as many as 100,000 young people who have chosen to invest their energy and time for free in solidarity projects. The children who choose them, with a time commitment from 2 weeks to 12 months, receive financial support to cover the costs of transport, food and accommodation, as well as medical insurance, moved by the deep desire to devote themselves to the other , to those in need, to those who have less. Supporting this mobility is not only important to allow those who wish to do so, regardless of economic conditions, to volunteer, but it is also a way in which the European Union can encourage the rediscovery of its deepest civil and human vocation. In this moment of crisis of values, it is extremely important to invest in projects for the integration and mobility of young people and to promote the exchange of best practices among member countries. In this way, as Pope Francis recalled, Europe will be able to rediscover its unity, rediscover itself and overcome barriers and walls, sources of division.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the short presentation of the report by Andrea Bocskor, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015 (2015/2351 (INI)) (A8-0250 / 2016)

name: Andrea Bocskor
text: performer. - Ms. President! First of all, I would like to thank all my fellow Members, the shadow rapporteurs, the consultants, my colleagues and everyone who contributed to the report. The economic crisis has hit young people hard, with long-term consequences. Youth unemployment has risen, the gap between certain groups of young people has widened, and some of them have been increasingly excluded from social life. The vision of many of them became uncertain and social passivity increased. Young people are one of Europe's greatest resources, the key to its future. The European Union and the Member States must therefore not overlook the potential of the creativity, creativity and knowledge of the ninety million young people in Europe. An analysis of recent statistics shows that education and employment indicators show positive trends, although they still vary widely from one Member State to another. In the light of the results, we must continue to look for better solutions to the new problems of young people, and it is very important that more systematic cooperation is needed in several policy areas, such as employment, education and training, social policy, youth policy, sport, culture and others. Youth unemployment has fallen in most Member States recently, but the current number remains a major concern. For example, that impoverishment threatens nearly 27 million young people. Young people have a higher poverty rate, part-time work and temporary employment, which often lasts longer, compared to the total population, which fixes a low quality of life for this generation. Therefore, job creation and the promotion of youth employment should be an important priority. Young people are not equally affected by the risk of inactivity, poverty and marginalization. For those who already have fewer opportunities in life or live in less developed regions, the disadvantages often only accumulate. They are more likely to become “NEETs” young people, so catch-up programs, social and talent programs to overcome these disadvantages, and a wide range of information about the opportunities available are very important. Support for mother-tongue education for national minorities should also be emphasized in this area, which is an important priority in the report and is in line with the Committee of the Regions' opinion on a similar subject. Europe also urgently needs to activate young people due to its aging population: a conscious family and youth policy, home-building subsidies and family tax breaks can be of great help. Some countries have recognized this and the indicators have started to improve, such as in Hungary, but we still have work to do in this area. The report emphasizes the importance of the role of the family, school, sport and religious communities in the socialization of young people, but also the involvement of local and regional authorities in youth policy. Knowledge and qualifications are still the greatest value. The share of the unemployed is still lower among graduates than among the unskilled. It is therefore important to improve the quality of education and to better and more effectively match it with labor market needs. We need to better align school and education with the world of work in order to give young people a better chance of entering the labor market. There is a need to increase the dominance of digital and applied sciences, and to improve digital and other skills. The recognition of skills acquired through informal, non-formal and lifelong learning, as well as the cross-border mutual recognition of academic degrees and higher qualifications in the European labor market, is very important.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). - Madam President, I believe that the cause of our young people must be the first priority for all Europeans, and especially for the European Union. We therefore call on you, Commissioner, to take initiatives and actions to strengthen and support young people. As the initiative to provide an Interrail card to our young people has been rightly taken, so it is time to provide Free Wi-Fi to prove that the European Union is close to our young people and gives them access and opportunity, especially at a time when the digital economy is at the forefront. At the same time, I believe that our young people must be the ones to take the initiative, and I believe that if Europe wants to invest in its future, it must invest primarily in young people. I believe that many young people are socially excluded and marginalized, and it is very important to create a pan-European fund to support young people in all forms, especially for their studies. There are many young people who, due to the economic crisis, are unable to attend higher education. I believe that our present and future are the young people and that is why we must support them with all our strength.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Commissioner, the evaluation of the European Union Strategy for Youth is extremely important, especially for what we want to do next. It is important for young people to have access to quality education and training if we want to reduce the high unemployment rate in most Member States. Special measures must also be taken to integrate young women into the labor market. Also, young people with disabilities have additional obstacles in integrating into the labor market due to mentalities, but also the lack of regulations to encourage companies to hire them. Of course, many things are about subsidiarity, but if we are talking about the single market, then we must also have European policies. Much more funding is needed for formal and non-formal education, for vocational and dual education. Personally, I regret that in the 2017 budget the funds proposed by the Parliament for SMEs have been diminished, because many of the SMEs are created by young people and the employees are young. That is why, Commissioner, much more needs to be done by the Commission and the Council in the policies designed to educate and integrate young people into the labor market.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the promotion of mobility must not be the main policy by which we will address high youth unemployment rates, which have been at a critical level in some countries such as Croatia for a long time.Insisting solely on mobility leads to an outflow of labor, which jeopardizes the long-term viability of less developed Member States.I am glad that this report recognizes this.In the last six months alone, about 20,000 young people have left the Croatian region of Slavonia.If this trend continues, Croatia will be an unsustainable state and a burden to other members in ten years, but unfortunately it is not the only one.That is why I believe that we must finally stop using universal solutions at Union level and tackle structural reforms in each country separately.The situation in each of them is specific.The problems are somewhat similar, not the same, and universal solutions will not give the expected results, they have not so far.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I truly believe that investment today in skills development, encouraging and supporting participation in community-building and confidence, and also the resilience of young people, will have a long and lasting effect on the future shape of the EU, its sustainable development and competitiveness. I do recognise the importance of the structural dialogue as a means of listening to young people, both youth organisations and non-organised individuals. But a significant share of the youth still feel they do not have power over the decision-making process. More needs to be done to ensure young people’s voices are heard and that they are fairly represented. We should encourage young people to participate and contribute to all aspects of community life through sport, culture, arts, social entrepreneurship and volunteering. Many Member States need to strengthen their efforts in order to make the best use of the available EU and national policies.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, I am very pleased that the report emphasizes the importance of the European Union's youth strategy, given the alarmingly high youth unemployment. I am convinced that this is a problem that can really have a very detrimental effect on our future. At the last plenary session, we discussed how to throw away a gnawed bone to young people and give them a ticket to their 18th birthday. I am convinced that young people want the future in the first place, and we are not giving them here. The right-wing policy of austerity destroyed the hope for the future for millions of young people and sent them to the labor office. Young people want to work and it is our duty at the moment to give them a chance to work. Our policies and our support must be aimed at ensuring that young people find themselves in Europe, do not want to leave Europe and find employment here and want to live in it in the future. Unfortunately, I do not see this for the time being, and I firmly believe that the Commission will also continue to be so interested in this matter that it will really help young people and not give them stupid tickets.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, it is said in the report - rightly so - that youth policies are the competence of the states, and the European Union, as in so many other things, adopts programs. Programs means encouragement, promotion, help, cooperation, but not politics. And therein lies a part of the problem: Europe does not have its own youth policy. We can salute the success of Erasmus and many other things, but we have the Youth Guarantee halfway through and we have the Youth Employment Initiative still under review of how it is working in the different States. Perhaps it is time to adopt a policy in the name of the general European common interest; to know that only through authentic mutual relationships between countries, realities, regions, etc., can we obtain results. We fill our mouths with the concept of the single market, but we need a European policy that solves the difference between 0% unemployment in Baden-Württemberg ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: - The Youth Strategy should be the cornerstone of current European policy.Its main goals are very important for our society: to provide more opportunities for young people in education and the labor market and to encourage them to actively participate in society as a whole.In the next cycle of implementation of the strategy, Member States must be more determined to achieve the targets.They should take more concrete measures, such as promoting entrepreneurship among young people.It is necessary to introduce internships, apprenticeships and vocational training to acquire appropriate knowledge and skills, which of course meet current and current needs in the labor market.It is also essential and extremely important to harmonize educational programs with employment policies and labor market demand.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, young people represent strength and energy, in which Europe and the Member States must invest through structured long-term strategies that can have effects not only in terms of active participation and social inclusion, as highlighted in the report, but above all for employment, training and self-employment. However, developing effective strategies means putting in place significant financial endowments, so as to create opportunities, in which young people can express ideas, skills and talents. On this, Europe must be more courageous, because investing in young people is equivalent to investing in the future of Europe itself. In this sense, I believe it is fundamental, both at European, national and regional level, for the various European programs dealing with youth policies to be communicated, implemented and coordinated more effectively. It is only through clear objectives and a careful and coordinated management of the tools at our disposal that we will be able to give a concrete response to the needs of young people, also to avoid the risk of social passivity and marginalization.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: - We like to say that young people are our future, but all too often this is just on the level of a phrase.I very much support what has been written and what is written in this report, and certainly job creation and work is what young people want most and what young people in Europe miss the most today.That is why I myself strongly support the fact that young people, together with the school system and various other policies, are being trained today for jobs that have a perspective in the 21st century, that have a perspective in the digital world.I myself estimate that there are mistakes in the school system.Too little of the dual system, what makes it most difficult for young people in Europe to access the workplace today, and from there young people find themselves alone.I therefore hope that this recommendation, the report, will help to create these very important policies.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Madam President, indeed, economic changes and globalization have significantly modified the labor market and young people have been the first victims. It is therefore necessary, by all means, to facilitate their social and professional integration. Training is, of course, one of the ways. A number of mechanisms, both in the States and at European level, are moving in this direction, but mobility is, in my opinion, another means. We must of course welcome the Erasmus program and I believe that we must go even further, particularly with regard to the mobility of apprentices. An ongoing pilot project can effectively foreshadow a new organization of European learning that allows both mobility and the acquisition of new skills and languages. I think it is important, in Europe, to allow this mobility so that the young people of our Europe can speak different languages ​​and acquire competences at European level.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first I wish to thank the Committee on Culture and Education and especially the rapporteur, Mrs Bocskor, for her excellent report, which follows up on the Joint Council and Commission report regarding the EU Youth Strategy. I would also like to thank all the participants for their very valuable remarks in that debate. Thanks to the joint report, we defined our new shared priorities in the field of youth, which all contribute to the current top priorities of the EU. I am very pleased that the European Parliament is stressing the importance of the EU Youth Strategy. It is indeed an essential framework that has proved useful for Member States and for young people. The mid—term evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy conducted for the years 2010-2015 shows many positive impacts of European cooperation in the youth field. With the EU Youth Strategy Work Plan for 2016—2018 we have a focused cooperation agenda which deals with important issues: the need for increased social inclusion of all young people, stronger youth participation in democratic and civic life, and an easier transition of young people from youth to adulthood. Your report also stresses the importance of the structured dialogue with young people. I believe that this tool is very useful to engage with young people. For example, more than 67 000 young people participated in the consultation on the evaluation of youth policy cooperation in the EU launched during the summer. However, there is room for improvement. To this end, I want to promote bottom—up mechanisms, such as the one developed with my One Million outreach project and the New Narrative for Europe, where young people from a broader range of backgrounds make their voice heard and participate. Your report focuses on investing in young people through the creation of quality and secure jobs, more mobility, more apprenticeship and a stronger focus on key competences such as digital skills and entrepreneurship. I particularly welcome the emphasis the report places on promoting civic education and a set of soft competences that will contribute to personal development and will ensure young people’s engagement in society, critical thinking and languages, for instance. For this to happen, Europe has to optimise its education assistance and fully exploit all aspects of education, both formal and non-formal. Europe also needs to get better at linking the worlds of education and the job market. Cooperation with education and training providers is also an integral part of the Youth Guarantee. Schools’ central role in supporting its implementations stems from their ability to ensure that pupils make the most of the opportunities at school, signal where there is a risk of early exits, and provide support to students on professional pathways available to them. We need to continue and step up our efforts to address youth unemployment. From the Commission’s side, we want to continue supporting Member States and particularly the hardest hit regions. That is why we have proposed to further boost the Youth Employment Initiative with EUR 1 billion for 2017—2020, which should be matched by at least another EUR 1 billion from the European Social Fund. This will make it possible to support more young people after 2020 in Member States most affected by youth unemployment. National funding to boost youth unemployment also needs to be prioritised in Member States’ budgets, as the European structural and investment funds and the Youth Employment Initiative alone are not sufficient to overcome the problem. Finally, your report rightly stresses the importance of supporting and recognising youth voluntary activities as a form of non-formal learning. The Commission could not agree more. This is why we are strengthening youth volunteering in all its forms, not least by launching the European Solidarity Corps in the very year of the twentieth anniversary of the European Voluntary Service. The Corps will allow even more young people in Europe to get this life experience and to make a valuable contribution to our society. We aim to have 100 000 young people signed up by 2020. Let me end by once again thanking Parliament and the rapporteur for the very valuable input and strong support for our joint efforts in this field.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place today, 27 October 2016, at 12 noon.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - The human and social capital represented by young people is the main resource of the European Union. While responsibility for youth lies with the Member States, the EU plays the key role of coordination, guidance and support. Many young people struggle to find quality employment, which hinders the achievement of their autonomy. I believe that the open method of coordination adopted by the EU is appropriate but not yet sufficient for framing concrete policies in the youth field. Greater and more intense collaboration between the various actors is needed to concretely pursue the priorities defined by the European Youth Strategy. The EU structured dialogue between policy makers, young people and their representatives is an essential listening tool to influence ongoing national dialogues. Member States must make every effort to disseminate EU programs and related funding opportunities among young people. A Europe that invests in young people will certainly be a better Europe.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The so-called millennials, born in the last twenty years of the last century, face huge problems, primarily those relating to inclusion in the world of work and, also as a consequence of this, social inclusion.A report on the EU Youth Strategy should therefore have this as a starting point and primary objective of any kind of intervention, and not rest on "business as usual" policies which, evidently, have not had sufficient effects.For this reason, the strategy identified, while not stating anything wrong, cannot be considered satisfactory.It is indeed essential that, at a time when youth unemployment is skyrocketing, the signal from the institutions comes loud and clear.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – Franklin D. Roosevelt once said ‘We cannot always build the future for our youth, but we can build our youth for the future’ and this must be the premise for today’s debate. To build a better future, a better generation, we must focus on empowering our young people by giving them the tools to face the challenges of today with solutions of tomorrow.  With 5.6 million young people under 25 still not in work, it is more than ever essential that we implement measures to help young people have careers, not just jobs. We must raise our youth in a way that makes them aware of how crucial sustainability is, and helps them implement this principle in their day-to-day lives without a second thought. We need generations of eco-warriors and young people with a social conscience to ensure a maintainable, progressive future. We must, above all, address the issues of today, to ensure a better tomorrow.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. - I welcome the report on the evaluation of the European Union's youth strategy. We deal with many interesting and important topics in Parliament, but I do not think I am alone in making the issue of youth and family policy one of the most important. If we do not support the new generations, all our other activities in this house will only be for themselves, as there will be no one to continue the work we have begun, no one to carry on the legacy. If we cannot ensure that a sufficient number of children are born with the right quality of education and upbringing, there will be no one to take over the work from us when our generation has already given it up. I believe that encouraging childbearing is one of the most important tasks, which is also one of the greatest challenges of our time. We need to support starting a family and draw attention to the fact that having a child is not a forced duty but a natural order in life. I would like to highlight another important topic in the report, the fight against youth unemployment. We must not let young people lose their motivation at the very beginning of their careers. We must support young workers by all possible means.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. - The youth strategy must be based on a real knowledge of the needs of young people. Young people themselves must be actively involved in these processes, bringing their knowledge, needs and experience to them. Despite the existence of formal documents, actual cooperation and involvement of young people in public life is insufficient, which is reflected in low turnout. Lack of interest, insufficient and not always quality education, not meeting the needs of the labor market, insufficient and dysfunctional social agenda create space for the penetration of extremist views, movements and parties that can have catastrophic consequences for the future of generations. Therefore, it is necessary to allocate resources and develop activities that, even through modern technologies, will lead to a wider involvement of young people in public life, increase their interest in education and lifelong professional growth. The future of generations depends on the quality of education and work with the current generation of young people, which will be reflected in the whole spectrum of social and political life. The European Union must also continue its programs to support young people, which lead to a reduction in unemployment. The Youth Employment Initiative is proof of this.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. - The austerity policy pursued in Greece for the last 6 years, has severely affected our country's workforce. Unemployment plagues our society and especially the youth, with youth unemployment rates reaching 50%. The younger generations of our country are sinking into long-term unemployment, seasonal uninsured work and the devastating twelve hours of 300 euros. The consequence of the memorandum policies and the catastrophe that every productive group of our country suffers is the tendency of the new generation to migrate to other EU countries. According to the Bank of Greece, Greece ranks fourth in the EU in terms of mass outflow of migrants in proportion to the country's workforce. In 2013 alone, more than 2% of the country's total workforce left to work abroad. The young people who are the main guarantors for the future of Greece will overthrow the memoranda of poverty with their struggles and will seek a better life.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE)
text: in writing. - Considering high youth unemployment in the EU and its often unused potential, this group deserves special attention and support. It is necessary to provide young people with appropriate education, practical skills and access to the labor market, as well as to undertake intensified activities involving the largest possible number of young people in social activities and grassroots initiatives. It is they that have a huge impact on personal development and contribute to greater social inclusion of people with disabilities and other vulnerable groups. The necessity to learn foreign languages ​​or education adapted to the real needs of the market is of great importance. The great potential of informal education and development through sport should also be emphasized, including the need to create conditions for two-track education and a professional alternative after completing a sports career. At the same time, the implementation of the above objectives should be carried out within the widest possible cooperation and based on dialogue with young people.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the statement by Eric Andrieu, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, entitled 'How can the CAP help create jobs in rural areas?'Summary of the report (2015/2226 (INI)) (A8-0285 / 2016).

name: Eric Andrieu
text: protractor. - Madam President, Commissioner, this is the first time in 54 years that the subject of employment and the CAP has been directly addressed. We are in the midst of a paradox: the budget of the common agricultural policy represents almost 40% of the budget of the European Union and employment is at the dawn of our priorities, the first that we have recorded within the bodies of the European Union. For more than 50 years, the common agricultural policy has modeled agriculture by orienting it towards the intensification of its production (s) towards international markets and by developing increasingly concentrated and specialized farms. These choices were marked by a spectacular increase in labor productivity, which had a considerable impact on agricultural employment. In 1957, in a Europe of six, farmers represented 20% of the workforce across the European Union. They are now only 4% in a Union of twenty-eight. Over the past decade, we have lost a quarter of our farms. If we continue with this policy, we will not be able to attract young people in the years to come. Furthermore, over time, the CAP has gradually lost its legitimacy. Today, it no longer meets the needs of farmers and it is contested by all of our European citizens. The elements which have structured the common agricultural policy for a long time are no longer appropriate today, and the liberal choice applied to this policy since the 1990s has led us to a dead end. This model destroys many jobs in production and in the territories, and more particularly in the most fragile. We need to thoroughly rethink the CAP, which must remain a common policy for all European agriculture. Today we are faced with several challenges: the food challenge, the environmental and climatic challenge and the territorial challenge. As for the challenge food, the CAP must ensure, as a priority, the food security of the 500 million European citizens and give everyone access to sufficient food in quantity and quality. The issue of human health and the nutritional aspect must be at the heart of the future reform of the common agricultural policy. One in two Europeans has concerns about being overweight or obese. As for cancer, the new forms of the disease among young European populations, young men and young women, especially in rural areas, cannot leave us indifferent to the policies that we must implement. The environmental and climate challenge and the productivist model show us every day their limits in terms of sustainability. Above all, it is important to produce, but to produce better by managing more efficiently and better protecting natural resources and biodiversity, which can play a positive role for the climate thanks to soils. This presupposes changes in our production methods, which will have to be adapted to each region and each ecosystem. We cannot grasp the territorial challenge with force. We need to re-territorialize agriculture. Agriculture is an essential component of the development of rural and peri-urban territories. In addition, these territories conceal significant resources making it possible to diversify agricultural and forestry activities. We must reinvest in short circuits, circular economies and organic farming. The responses to these challenges lead to three specific responses: a main policy to help young people settle in; a policy of regulating agricultural markets - direct aid must be re-legitimized and targeting small and medium-sized agricultural enterprises at Community level; a developed rural policy that enhances territorial engineering and, in the field of international trade, the market must be reinvested European.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: - Thank you for the floor, thank you also to my colleague Eric Andrieu for the report, in which he emphasized the very important area of employment and the links between this employment in rural areas and agriculture.We are all following these trends, which are similar all over Europe, that is, the number of farms is declining, and it is becoming increasingly difficult for young people to become interested in agricultural activity.That is why I think that one of the measures we have in agricultural policy, that is the measure for young farmers, is one of the highest quality, which also gives the best results.Because the Slovenian countryside and, of course, the European countryside really need young people, new knowledge, new approaches, because I am afraid that it will be very difficult to resist modern trends only in the old, traditional way.I myself think that digitalisation is also one that, together with rural mobility, should be put in the context of agricultural policy, regional policies, and thus also improve employment in rural areas.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to implement a comprehensive generational renewal strategy, it is essential that the Member States give young farmers concrete prospects, making full use of the aid from the first and second pillars of the CAP. To support agricultural employment, we need to invest in new risk and crisis management tools, in order to limit the negative effects of price volatility. Short supply chains, linking farmers and local producers, can stimulate job creation in rural areas, just as quality schemes, geographical indications and organic farming can represent important development opportunities in the agri-food sector and, therefore, of potential job creation in rural areas. It would be desirable that the post-2020 CAP provides for modernization and investment tools capable of guaranteeing competitiveness in rural areas by focusing on agri-food, tourism, energy and services. Kudos to Eric Andrieu for a great relationship.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, the Common Agricultural Policy is really facing huge problems. While there is a lot of money being spent by the European Union, we still have problems in the agricultural sector today. Farmers across Europe are protesting. The key thing to understand is that now that markets are being liberalized, duty-free agricultural products are allowed to be imported from third countries. And this creates a problem in agricultural production, it creates a problem for all European farmers. Especially for Greece, the problems are much greater, because there is a tax evasion policy imposed by the troika, there is an increase in the tax on agricultural oil, there is an increase in agricultural oil, zero subsidies, but also seizures by the government of subsidies of farmers. In addition, our farmers as a whole, both in Greece and in Europe, have been affected by the embargo imposed on Russia. Immediate action must therefore be taken now for farmers.

name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE).
text: - Madam President! It is of course important to deal with job security in rural areas, and for that I would like to thank the rapporteur very much. It is also a fact that the common agricultural policy has to be further developed and adapted in some areas in order to actually keep young people in rural areas and also to create jobs in the upstream and downstream areas. But it is also a fact that this report is very specifically tailored to the French national implementation of the common agricultural policy and that things are being asserted that do not apply to all countries. For example, the decoupled premiums are addressed. I can say very clearly here that in Germany in the mountain regions EUR 1.5 billion has actually flowed away from the favorable locations and the small businesses in the disadvantaged regions are being strengthened. I would also like to mention the social security system that has existed in Germany for agricultural holdings since 1957.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: -  Madam president; thanks to the speaker for his magnificent work. It is regrettable that a debate as important as the future of the CAP goes so unnoticed, as if the European Union did not manage subsidies for primary production and regulate agricultural and livestock markets; as if the CAP did not define the future of the European countryside: if the aid should go to the rentiers or the authentic farmers or if we must tolerate that no control is imposed on the exploitation of day laborers and agricultural workers. The crisis in the countryside is not a temporary problem: it is the consequence of the lack of regulation and support for our production. We need live agriculture and livestock that unite and structure rural areas. For this, we must protect a dignified and attractive productive activity for those who live from it, with social norms that are respected and with minimum prices that protect farmers from the abuses of large distribution. We must guarantee access to land and protect our production from global dumping and from treaties such as CETA or TTIP, because without agriculture there is no future.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: - I would like to thank the rapporteur, Eric Andrieu, for a well-prepared report.It sets out a vision of what the European countryside needs from the current CAP reform and the new CAP twenty years from now.The problems of Europe's countryside are manifested not only in fluctuating prices, uncovered farmers' incomes, abuse of intermediaries, but also in relatively much higher unemployment than in cities.We need to place more emphasis on the importance of the countryside, quality and ecological food, a clean environment, and adequate social infrastructure.We must also strive for a level playing field for farmers, in particular through the harmonization of direct payments in all the countries of the European Union.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF).
text: - Madam President, I personally believe that this report is based on good intentions, but that in reality it is useless.It only contains scoops.Today, the CAP is synonymous with ruin for European farmers.It is often said back home that hell is paved with good intentions.This report is polluted by demands on the integration of migrants into the European labor market.It also contains claims on gender neutrality.In addition, the title skewed the report from the start, because relying on the CAP to create jobs is totally paradoxical.It is in fact the CAP which destroyed a large part of agricultural jobs, more particularly since 1992 and the MacSharry reform, which had an impact, of course, on prices.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Madam President, the European Union's erroneous tactic of subordinating agricultural policy to neighborhood policy for reasons of political expediency and allowing the uncontrolled and influx of duty-free products from third countries has exacerbated existing problems in European agriculture and resulted in a reduction in number of farmers, their incomes, but also jobs in rural areas. Greek farmers are in a tragic situation in this area, suffering from the effects of the memoranda. Agriculture, as an important factor of primary production, can largely meet the food needs of the populations of the countries and, therefore, care must be taken. We must boost agricultural production, we must exploit agricultural and forestry wealth, and we must also stop unfair competition with third-country products. Thus, jobs will be strengthened, because young farmers will remain in the countryside and growth will be possible.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: - Madam President!I honestly admit that I read with amazement the text of the original report which questioned the financial and quantitative approach to agricultural production and questioned new technologies and types of crops.I come from Poland and I would like to say that before 1989 even the communists in Poland did not question such things.However, I believe that this text is slightly better today.First of all, art.51 talking about equal direct payments for farmers in the European Union.If we want to build a fair internal market, farming conditions must be equal.The second pillar of the common agricultural policy should support sustainable development and diversification of activities into forms such as energy production or small and micro-commercial and service enterprises.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I would first of all like to sincerely congratulate colleague Éric Andrieu on his vision for the future in terms of agricultural policy. I think this is essential for the future of the rural world in general, which is structured, as everyone knows, around agricultural activities. I also believe that it is essential, in order to keep an agricultural world alive, to keep the jobs that go with it. I believe that the future CAP should indeed favor employment over the hectare and that the orientation given in the report is very important. The expansion of farms harms employment. I want to say that we need more neighbors and less hectares in the future for farms. I believe that this rural world today contributes to the good balance between food, the fight against global warming and the maintenance of a good environment. I believe that this report is completely in the right direction and I really hope that all members of the House will support it.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, I agree with the rapporteur that we need to strengthen the role and position of small and medium-sized family farms within the Common Agricultural Policy.Small farms are the heart of the European countryside and the custodians of traditional production and a guarantee of the survival of life in rural areas.But I am not sure that this ambitious goal can be achieved under the existing Common Agricultural Policy.Unfortunately, the CAP has been the most expensive, but at the same time the most inefficient, European policy since its earliest days, which needs to be radically changed.And that’s something that obviously no one deals with.Direct payments to farmers per hectare have led to a reward for farm size rather than productivity.The little ones are getting too little money, and the big ones are lulled, because their taxpayer money is practically guaranteed.We really need to change that.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would also like to join in underlining the importance and importance of maintaining jobs in rural areas.It should be emphasized that, by 2040, it is estimated that over 70% of Europe's population will live in the largest cities.This relocation must, as a minimum, be hampered by our effective European Union policy instruments in such a way that the countryside does not really become depopulated and move only to agglomerations.This risk is very fundamental.On the other hand, I would like to agree with what my colleague Müller said.In my opinion, the report is indeed too French.It responds to local problems, but does not describe the situation on the whole of the European continent in a completely credible way.I can also prove this in the weakening of the rural development program, which is currently contained in the draft report.I consider this report to be controversial and I will not support it.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Commissioner, the Common Agricultural Policy must lead to an increase in the number of the employed population, but we note the opposite. In many countries, villages are depopulated, land uncultivated, livestock farms closed because farmers are no longer motivated. Unfortunately, we import toxic and poor quality products for European citizens because we do not have trade defense policies against third markets - Mr Juncker acknowledged yesterday. The Common Agricultural Policy must be linked to other economic policies. In order to increase employment in rural agriculture, we need to have infrastructure development projects, to have markets, fair competition. The European Commission must open up third markets for the sale of products. How can we have animal husbandry when milk is sold for less than a liter of water, when producers cannot sell their products? The Cohesion Fund should be directed to less developed areas. That is why I believe that the report is welcome, but it should not be left on paper alone.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Madam President, with all due respect to our very hardworking rapporteur, I think this report is a missed opportunity. Rather than really focusing on the concrete recommendations on how CAP could contribution to creating jobs and growth in rural areas, we have ended up with a lengthy, repetitive and inconsistent report which completely lacks a coherent message, and that is reflected in the size of the voting list.  Of course there are positive elements in the report – highlighting the tools available to diversify and add value to agricultural activities, simplifying the CAP for individual farmers, providing better access to services – these are all issues on which I can absolutely agree, but there are so many points lost in this wish list of demands. This was supposed to focus on employment, and yet it talks extensively, with excessive criticism, of intensive farming as a dominant model. What is that? It is not relevant to the core point and it completely loses the core point in a lot of unhelpful wish lists.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - The circumstances affecting farmers' lives vary greatly from one Member State to another, so these realities must be taken into account when planning the future of the CAP after 2020. While the average European farmer has 12 hectares of land, this figure is only 3.6 in Romania, for example. If we look at the average farm size of individual producers, ie farmers, it is only 2 hectares. This figure is 56 hectares in Germany, 54 in France, 79 in Italy and 90 hectares in the United Kingdom. The inequalities are therefore huge, not to mention other aspects such as the existence of sales networks, the creditworthiness of farmers or the technological opportunities available to them. The European farming model is based on food security and the balanced and sustainable development of rural areas. However, the achievement of these objectives is at risk in some Member States.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of Commissioner Hogan, I would like to thank the rapporteur Mr Andrieu and the rapporteurs for opinion, Ms Lopez Bermejo and Ms Kostinger, for this report. I would also like to thank the honourable Members who contributed to this morning's debate on the report. This report is a very useful contribution to the debate about the way in which the agri-food sector can realise its potential to contribute to growth and job creation in the EU over the coming years, particularly in rural areas where employment opportunities are not as plentiful. Just last month, more than 340 stakeholders, representing all shades of opinion and from all 28 Member States, gathered in Ireland and agreed on the Cork 2.0 Declaration entitled ‘A better life in rural areas’. I am particularly pleased to note that the European Parliament was well represented at the conference. The document agreed is a shared blueprint for the development of rural areas and recognises the fundamental importance of agriculture, forestry and their related sectors for the economic and social development of viable rural areas and communities. The associated value chains of the agriculture and forestry sectors are engines of rural growth, providing jobs and livelihoods to tens of millions of Europeans. The EU’s Rural Development Policy plays a very important role in securing and creating jobs and growth in rural areas through investments in farm competitiveness, diversifying farm businesses, promoting innovative approaches, or fostering knowledge transfer. The unemployment rate in rural areas has shown a positive trend in recent years, with 2015 values already at the level of 2009. Nonetheless, we can and must do more. For example, we need to significantly improve access to fast or ultra-fast broadband to allow rural areas to seize the opportunities of the digital society, like e-commerce. Commissioner Hogan is particularly focused on the issue of rural broadband and regards it as a priority for the further development of our rural communities. Commissioner Hogan has also stressed the value of adding value through the achievement of quality recognition for high-quality agricultural products. This recognition will increase the added value for primary producers and is essential for boosting exports and therefore maintaining and creating jobs. It is encouraging to see how interest in achieving such status is increasing. The Cork 2.0 Declaration recognises that bottom-up and locally-led initiatives should be rolled out to mobilise rural potentials. Integrated and participatory local development strategies based on approaches like Leader have proved their value and will be important to ensure dynamic rural areas as well as securing and creating jobs and growth. Having created a vision for the development of rural areas and communities, one must make it happen, and that requires investment. Therefore, facilitating access to finance is crucial to encourage investment and the setting up of new enterprises. We also need to think beyond traditional means of finance and credit, which are often not available to young entrepreneurs. The use of innovative financial instruments has enormous potential in this area as a means of having a positive effect on job creation in rural areas. Indeed, the recent proposal accompanying the review of the MFF specifically includes provision to make access to finance easier for young farmers. Europe is the world’s biggest agri-food trading region, with record export levels achieved in 2015 of EUR 129 billion, confirming the EU’s position as the world’s most important exporter of agri-food products. In the State of the Union address, President Juncker pointed out that trade means jobs. For every one billion euros of additional exports, 14 000 extra jobs are created across the EU, and more than 30 million jobs. One in seven of all jobs in the EU now depend on exports to the rest of the world. The EU is also the world’s biggest importer of agri-food products. It is closely involved in global value chains and needs to rely on stable trade relations and functioning global markets. The agri-food sector is the largest provider of employment in the EU, with 44 million people employed. Many of the challenges quite rightly identified in the report can be addressed with the tools already available in the common agricultural policy, in particular under the rural development policy. But we need to constantly ask ourselves if the policy is fit for purpose and how we can do better. Reflecting these questions, the Commission will now consult widely on the modernisation and simplification of the CAP, as included in the work programme for 2017 presented to this House on Tuesday. I know that Commissioner Hogan welcomes and indeed looks forward to your suggestions. Together with the recent Cork 2.0 Declaration, they could be used to identify consistent ways to boost jobs, growth and investment in rural areas for the benefit, not only of our rural communities, but for the European economy as a whole.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place today, 27 October 2016, at 12 noon.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: in writing. –I thank the rapporteurs for the work done. This report intends to develop jobs in rural areas, it is a laudable project! However, he proposes a mid-term review of the current CAP, which is not relevant. We cannot afford to change the rules of the game midway through today. If the goal is simplification, the best way to achieve it is stability. Reforming now would be tantamount to mortgaging the substantive discussions, which should be carried out during the preparation of the next CAP. In addition, this report proposes several questionable measures. It transforms the CAP into a social assistance policy, that is not its vocation. The CAP must help create and maintain jobs in the agricultural and agro-food sector. However, the reform proposals in this report are not in line with the foundations of this policy. In addition, the report takes a position on trade agreements that go beyond the subject. As it stands, I find it difficult to support this report, although I am in favor of its project. Some ideas are interesting avenues for reflection that need to be deepened.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. - I am strongly opposed to any attempt to cover the crisis caused by social and demographic change from the budgetary resources of the common agricultural policy, either on a voluntary or compulsory basis. It is extremely important to me that the resources of the common agricultural policy actually go to farmers. Therefore, together with my fellow Hungarian MPs, I will not be able to support the Andrieu report.
