I have to do this despite the fact that the text proposes a strong and well-financed common agricultural policy, an objective that is fully in line with the interests of Hungarian farmers. However, provisions have also been included in the draft report which would jeopardize the future financing of the CAP. Paragraphs 21 and 77 of the report and AI. Recital 1 proposes that we also support social and demographic projects from agricultural sources. It is extremely important to us that the resources of the common agricultural policy actually go to farmers. Therefore, we must not allow direct or compulsory development funds to be used to cover crises caused by social and demographic change, either on a voluntary or compulsory basis. Funding for social issues does not have a place in the common agricultural policy, which is why in 2013 EU support for the most deprived people came out of this policy. Unfortunately, the same proposal has been included in the planned amendment of EU legislation that provides the backbone of the Structural Funds and the CAP, the so-called omnibus package. Here, too, we will stand up for the defense of the common agricultural policy.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to announce that the Conference of Presidents has just awarded this year's Sakharov Prize to Nadia Murad and Lamiya Aji Bashar. (Applause) Ladies and gentlemen! Nadia Murad and Lamiya Aji Bashar share a painful and tragic story. Both can testify to the atrocities of the so-called Islamic State. Both witnessed their closest family members being killed in front of their eyes, and both were exploited and humiliated as sex slaves. But her tragic story doesn't end there. Nadia Murad and Lamiya Aji Bashar managed to escape. They escaped to Europe and found shelter in our midst. During their escape, these two young women had to experience bad things and overcome fears. Ms. Aji Bashar was seriously injured while trying to escape. But they fought because they felt they had to and wanted to survive, because they felt it was their duty to survive, to fight for those they had to leave behind, and above all, for to fight through their survival and the testimony they can bear against impunity - impunity against those who have committed and are committing monstrous crimes. The courage these two women stand for and the dignity they represent are indescribable. Today the two are strong advocates for the protection of victims of sexual violence, for the fight against the enslavement of people by the so-called Islamic State. They have become the representatives of the Jasidi community in Iraq and they call on us all to do what they are doing: to fight against the genocide strategy that this terrorist organization represents and which it is leading against its own religious community. The two women are the voice of the countless victims of human trafficking - one voice that ends calls for such atrocities and speaks for respect for human dignity, freedom of belief and individual freedom and justice.We have sworn to ourselves here in Europe that we want to defend these values with all our resources, and that is why it is so important, ladies and gentlemen, that Nadia Murad and Lamiya Aji Bashar be honored by us.With this we show that their fight was not in vain and that we are ready to get actively involved to help these courageous women in the fight against misery and, above all, against the brutality, terror and the bloodshed of the Islamic State, thetoo many people are still exposed to support.Thank you for your attention.(Loud applause)

name: Antonio Tajani (PPE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I just wanted to inform Parliament that another terrible earthquake struck central Italy last night, in the same areas where the 24 August earthquake occurred.The earthquake also hit the city of Rome, the foreign ministry was evacuated.Many Italian citizens are on the street, they are outside their homes.Fortunately, there was only one death from a heart attack.And since the solidarity of European citizens, on the occasion of the earthquake of 24 August, helped those populations a lot, I ask this Parliament to send a message of solidarity to my fellow citizens, to our European fellow citizens who have been hit once again.from a terrible earthquake.

name: President. –
text: Thank you, Mr Tajani. I know that we all share the grief for the victims of the now two earthquakes.

name: Gabriele Zimmer (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President!We have just received a message from the President of Parliament that the Yazidi women who have been nominated will also be awarded the Sakharov Prize.At this point I would like to point out that a former MEP - Yezidi - who worked here in the European Parliament for ten years was beaten up by the police last night in Diyarbakir, just as they were walking forwardHas posed women who have been brutally attacked during a demonstration and are now in hospital: Feleknas Uca.I just want to send her the best of recovery wishes from here and also declare our solidarity with her.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you, Mrs. Zimmer!Here too, solidarity is clear - also from this House.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, this will be one of the last times I vote on budget discharge, in common with other British MEPs. We have spent years shovelling money from the general population to people lucky enough to be working in the Brussels institutions or in one of the parastatal organisations or the various groups of consultants, contractors and others who have turned the EU into a handy living. I am not really making the point that it would be good for the taxpayer – I have made that point several times before – if the budget were smaller. Let me make a different point. Think of how wonderful would be the boost to the economy if we released all of the people working directly or indirectly for the EU into the private sector to make things and sell things instead of sitting in EU institutions meddling with the business of everybody else. A lot of them are hugely qualified, well—educated, good—natured people with ambition and brains. What a terrible waste of talent that they should all be cooped up in the European Union.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - For 9 years, Parliament has not given a discharge to the Council, and the Council is behaving as if nothing had happened. The council does not send us the documents to see how he spent the money. So there is a total lack of transparency in the Council. Also, the Council does not provide anything in terms of interpreter, travel, external, construction, maintenance, construction expenses, we do not have any Council expenses and, if we do not have them, we do not have them. it doesn't have the population of the European Union either, the citizens don't have them and let's not forget, we keep repeating every time: it's the money of the European citizens. How much longer does the Council need to wake up? To realize that trust in the European Union stems primarily from trust in the Council, in the Member States, and at the moment there is no trust precisely because they are non-transparent. How much longer does he need to help us all regain it, because we all suffer from a lack of mistrust in the Council, which is totally non-transparent.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The European Parliament has proposed for the eighth consecutive year to postpone the budget discharge for the Council.The main reason for the postponement is the fact that the Council's expenditure is not subject to the same control procedures as the other institutions.In fact, the Council does not communicate the annual report on expenditure to Parliament, undermining transparency towards citizens.As I consider this to be unfair and undemocratic, I decided to vote in favor by not granting discharge.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted in favour of this decision and non—binding resolution to refuse the granting of discharge to the Council. Discharge is a procedure whereby the EU Parliament looks at the internal budgets of each EU agency and institution and gives an opinion on its implementation. There is a decision regarding discharge (non-binding opinion) and a decision on closing the accounts for the relevant body. According to the Lisbon Treaty, the European Parliament is only supposed to grant discharge to the Commission, however it has taken upon itself (and created a whole procedure) to grant discharge to every EU agency and institution. The Council always refuses to cooperate because of this legal point and have been refused discharge by the Parliament for the last few years. The refusal of discharge in this case does not include a decision on the closure of accounts, which should be decided at a later date. The motion for a resolution criticises the Council and calls for more transparency. UKIP’s general position on discharge votes is to refuse the granting of discharge, in order to register our opposition to EU bodies and the EU spending British taxpayer’s money.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- The European Council and the Council still do not present separate accounts, an annual report on their activities or clearly answer questions from the parliamentary committee on budgets.I consider this lack of transparency to be inadmissible, which is why I have refused the 2014 discharge.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of refusing the discharge because the Council refuses to provide the necessary elements for the MEPs to be able to effectively scrutinise the Council expenditure.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Second Report on the discharge in respect of the implementation of the European Union general budget for the financial year 2014, because I firmly believe that effective financial control requires the cooperation of Parliament and the Council.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: written.- In this discharge report, the EU Parliament once again expresses its regret that the European Council and the Council are not making their annual activity report available to Parliament and that the budgets of the European Council and the Council have not yet been separated, as it was dated byParliament was recommended in its recent discharge resolutions.I agree with the demands and share the view that the European Council and the Council are sending a negative message to the citizens of the Union by their unwillingness to cooperate with the discharge authority.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. - This is the second report, the discharge having been postponed in the first vote in April. Once again the Council refuses to cooperate with Parliament, the budgetary discharge authority. This is a serious breach of the obligations laid down by the Treaties, the Council's expenditure having to be controlled in the same way as that of the other institutions. Once again, the Council did not send Parliament its activity report. As every year, the report takes up the idea of ​​imposing a separation between the budgets of the Council and the European Council in order to ensure more transparent financial management, a constraint which the Council seems to want to avoid. The report requires the Council to provide Parliament with accurate data on building projects and their costs. Naturally, the report underlines the absence of rules on whistleblowers in the Council statutes and invites it to participate in the EU transparency register, to adopt an internal code of conduct for the institution as well as anti-corruption guidelines. In short, every pretext is seized to underline the absence of parliamentary control over the Council's budgetary activity. I therefore voted in favor of this report which calls for the discharge for the implementation of the 2014 budget to be refused.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This decision is to refuse discharge of the Council. Every year Parliament goes through a procedure of discharge. This is where they give an opinion regarding how the budget has been operated and close the accounts for every EU institution and agency. Legally speaking the Lisbon Treaty only gives them the power to grant discharge to the Commission, but Parliament has taken upon itself to do every EU institution and agency. This is where the problem arises with the Council. Because of the provisions in the Lisbon Treaty, the Council does not cooperate with the discharge procedure. For the last few years Parliament has refused discharge (which is more of a political statement rather than anything binding) because of this lack of cooperation. UKIP’s general position is to refuse discharge for every EU agency because we do not want them to exist, so we will support this decision to refuse discharge. A proposal to close the accounts for the financial year should be taken separately at another time.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report which provides for not granting discharge for the implementation of the general budget for the 2014 financial year of the European Council and the Council, given the lack of cooperation with Parliament concerning the provisionthe documents necessary for the evaluation of the respective expenditure.There is an urgent need for the European Council and the Council to take their responsibility towards European citizens by being more transparent.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- Although the European Council and the Council, which are the institutions of the Union, should be democratically accountable to the citizens of the Union because they use money from the general budget of the European Union, the European Council and the Council do not report to the European Parliament.Also, the budget of the European Council and the Council has not yet been separated, as recommended by Parliament in its recent discharge resolutions.I therefore agree that the lack of cooperation between the European Council and the Council with the European Parliament is a negative signal to the citizens of the Union.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted in favour of this decision and non-binding resolution to refuse the granting of discharge to the Council. Discharge is a procedure whereby the EU Parliament looks at the internal budgets of each EU agency and institution and gives an opinion on its implementation. There is a decision regarding discharge (non-binding opinion) and a decision on closing the accounts for the relevant body. According to the Lisbon Treaty, the European Parliament is only supposed to grant discharge to the Commission, however it has taken upon itself (and created a whole procedure) to grant discharge to every EU agency and institution. The Council always refuses to cooperate because of this legal point and have been refused discharge by the Parliament for the last few years. The refusal of discharge in this case does not include a decision on the closure of accounts, which should be decided at a later date. The motion for a resolution criticises the Council and calls for more transparency. UKIP’s general position on discharge votes is to refuse the granting of discharge, in order to register our opposition to EU bodies and the EU spending British taxpayer’s money.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. - I have decided to support this report because the Council is once again showing its refusal to cooperate with Parliament, the budgetary discharge authority. This is a serious breach of the obligations laid down by the Treaties, the Council's expenditure having to be controlled in the same way as that of the other institutions. Once again, the Council did not send Parliament its activity report. As every year, the report tries to impose a separation between the budgets of the Council of the Union and the European Council in order to ensure more transparent financial management, a constraint which the Council seems to want to avoid. The report requires the Council to provide Parliament with accurate information on building projects and their costs. Naturally, the report underlines the absence of rules on whistleblowers in the Council statutes and invites it to participate in the EU transparency register, to adopt an internal code of conduct for the institution as well as anti-corruption guidelines. How can the Council still wish to escape Parliament's control over its budgetary activity in this way?

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report unanimously approved by the Committee on Budgetary Control and which refuses to grant discharge to the Secretary General of the Council for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and of the Council for the financial year 2014.The report regrets that the Council was silent on the comments made by Parliament in April 2016 on the discharge and that the European Council and the Council do not present an annual activity report to Parliament.He once again invites the Council to send him a whole series of information and calls on him to adopt a code of conduct as soon as possible in order to ensure the integrity of the institution.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: written.- Although I am voting in favor of this report, I believe it is important to regret that the European Council and the Council have not provided their annual activity report to Parliament.I consider this inadmissible, as it unnecessarily damages the reputation of the Union's institutions.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. - The budget discharge procedure represents an important moment in the institutional life of the European Union. On this occasion the European Parliament, the only institution elected by universal suffrage by the citizens, decides on the recommendation of the Council whether or not to guarantee the final approval of the implementation of the budget for a given financial year. This is a fundamental step which is also an opportunity to address specific recommendations to the institutions and agencies that make up the structure of the Union. Following the advice of the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT), I decided today to vote in favor of the Czarnecki report on postponing the 2014 budget discharge for the Council and the European Council. For years now, Parliament has been asking the Council to provide complete data on the implementation of the budget, receiving little cooperation from this institution. Due to the lack of transparency regarding budgetary and accounting data, Parliament decided to refuse discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and of the Council for the financial year 2014.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- In relation to the European Council and the Council, I vote in favor (rejecting the download and approval of accounts) given the lack of cooperation from this institution and its opacity.The report is in favor of rejecting his accounts, as has been customary in the last times that his management has been assessed.I vote with the majority of Parliament, which in recent times has rejected the management of the European Council and the Council.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report on the 2014 discharge of the European Council and the Council.When it was our turn to vote, the Council refused to send certain types of documents and, due to lack of clarity in the accounts, we decided not to approve it.We continue to regret that you have not yet provided your annual activity report to Parliament.This is a very bad sign for the public and for transparency.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which recommends refusing discharge to the European Council and the Council for the implementation of their 2014 budgets. It is nevertheless incredible that the Council persists in refusing to cooperate with the Parliament, which is nevertheless, in one of the rare elements of democracy present in the European treaties, the budgetary discharge authority.The Council thus refuses to transmit its activity report but also opposes any process of transparency, such as for example the separation of the budgets of the Council and the European Council.This opacity is also retained by the Council in the costs of its real estate projects, whistleblowers, internal codes of conduct or the fight against corruption.This clearly shows all the respect the Council has for the only democratically elected European institution.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- The report being voted on the postponement of the discharge is balanced and criticizes and criticizes the European Council and the Council which I believe can be shared.I therefore supported this text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - I have supported the Decision by which the Parliament denies the Secretary General of the Council discharge approval in the execution of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2014, as well as the Parliament resolution in which it regrets that the The European Council and the Council have not provided their annual activity report to Parliament, an inadmissible fact that damages the reputation of the institutions of the European Union, and the budgets of the European Council and the Council have not been separated, in accordance with recommended by Parliament in recent Resolutions on discharge. Parliament recalls that all Union institutions must be transparent and fully accountable to the citizens of the Union for the funds entrusted to them as Union institutions, and that both the European Council and the Council, as institutions of the Union Union, they should be subject to democratic accountability vis-à-vis citizens to the extent that they are beneficiaries of the general budget of the European Union.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which deals with the 2014 Discharge to the European Council and the Council. The European Parliament emphasizes that the Council's expenditure must be scrutinized as closely as that of the other institutions, and that the key elements of this scrutiny are set out in last year's discharge resolutions. Parliament called on the Council to provide information on its administrative modernization process, in particular on the expected impact on the Council's budget. Also calls on the Council to adopt a code of conduct as soon as possible in order to ensure the integrity of the institution; reiterates its call on the Council to extend the rules on whistleblowing without delay. Parliament called on the Council to contribute to the Union's Transparency Register in order to ensure its transparency and accountability. Reminds the Council, furthermore, of its call for comprehensive anti-corruption guidelines and independent internal policies of its structures, as well as of its call for a systematic increase in the transparency of legislative procedures and negotiations.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing.- In this case, I approved the non-granting of discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Council and of the Council.Discharge was not granted due to non-transparent operations and non-compliance with previous recommendations.I also believe that the European Council and the Council, as institutions of the Union, should be democratically accountable to the citizens of the Union, as they receive funding from the general budget of the European Union.Furthermore, I agree that the budget of the European Council and the Council should be kept separate, that the Code of Conduct should be adopted as soon as possible, participate in the Union's transparency register and develop detailed guidelines against corruption and independent policies within its structures.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this 2014 Discharge Report for the European Council and the Council.Parliament's interpretation in Article 319 TFEU clearly provides for a difference in roles between the two institutions.Parliament has institutional power in the Discharge Treaty.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament decided with 633 votes in favor and 10 against without abstentions, to postpone the granting of discharge to the Secretary General of the Council for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and of the Council for the year 2014. MEPs regret that the European Council and the Council do not submit the annual activity report to Parliament; this is unacceptable and undermines the reputation of the EU institutions. They ask the Council to submit the necessary information and to adopt a code of conduct as soon as possible to ensure the integrity of the institution. Furthermore, they invite him to participate in the transparency register in the EU and to develop detailed guidelines for the fight against corruption. They stress that effective budgetary control requires cooperation between Parliament and the Council. Parliament also recalls that transparency and the control of public finances are general democratic principles which the Union cannot deviate and that the discharge procedure is part of the concept of representative democracy. In general, MEPs believe that the lack of cooperation of the European Council and the Council with the discharge authority sends a negative signal to EU citizens.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing.- The report invites MEPs to refuse to vote on the discharge for the implementation of the 2014 budget. This is the second time this year that a report has been drawn up on the discharge for the 2014 budget. It isnow a habit: the Council refuses to cooperate with the European Parliament, which is, according to the Union treaties, the budgetary discharge authority.By not providing an exhaustive activity report, it is therefore freeing itself from the basic rules of operation of a faltering Union.More specifically, the report indicates that no exact data has ever been obtained on the cost of certain real estate projects.It also underlines the absence of rules relating to transparency or the fight against corruption and of separation between the budgets of the Council and the European Council.For all these reasons, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - The institutions of the European Union have an obligation to operate in a transparent manner with the funds entrusted to them, being accountable to the citizens of the Union. Following its audits, the Court of Auditors considered that the funds allocated to the two institutions, the European Council and the Council, had been spent in accordance with existing needs, with no significant errors in payments for administrative and other expenditure of the institutions and related bodies. However, I cannot help but regret the failure to comply with the recommendations issued by Parliament regarding the separation of the budget of the European Council and the Council. I believe that there is still a need for intensive cooperation between Parliament and the Council for an effective budgetary control exercise. I spoke in favor of the report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the European Union general budget for the financial year 2014, Section II - European Council and Council, as I believe that the two institutions managed the funds correctly and in line with their needs. real.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the report in question as I believe that an effective budgetary control exercise requires cooperation between Parliament and the Council, as furthermore specified in the resolution of 28 April 2016. To date, however, Parliament is not able to make an informed decision on granting discharge. Article 335 TFEU states that "the Union is represented by each of the institutions, on the basis of their administrative autonomy, for matters related to the functioning of the respective institution" and that, consequently, taking into account Article 55 of the regulation (EU, Euratom) no. 966/2012 (the "Financial Regulation"), the institutions are individually responsible for the implementation of their budgets. The Council remains silent on the comments made by the Parliament in the discharge resolution of 28 April 2016 regarding the trend in previous years of an increase in under-spending and carry-over of commitments. Both the European Council and the Council do not forward their annual activity reports to Parliament and this is certainly damaging to the reputation of the EU institutions. Moreover, contrary to what Parliament recommended in recent discharge resolutions, the budget of the European Council and the Council have not yet been separated.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of refusing the discharge because the Council refuses to provide the necessary elements for the MEPs to be able to effectively scrutinise the Council expenditure.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of not granting discharge to the Council as it has failed once again to cooperate with Parliament in addressing a number of important issues highlighted in Parliament’s first report. The Council should develop detailed anti-corruption guidelines and independent policies within its structures, as well as systematically increasing the transparency of legislative procedures and negotiations. The Council continues to fail to provide answers to Parliament’s questions, and the difficulties repeatedly encountered in discharge procedures to date have been due to a lack of cooperation on its part.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The European Parliament has proposed, in the first instance, to postpone the granting of the Council's budget discharge.It is therefore now a question of voting whether or not to grant discharge definitively.Colleague Czarnecki's report confirms that Parliament is unable to take an informed decision on granting discharge and therefore requests that the Council not be granted discharge: it is recalled that the European Parliament's refusal to grant discharge is politically significant,but unfortunately it has no legal consequences.I voted in favor.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing.- We support the report and stress that the exercise of effective financial control requires the cooperation of Parliament and the Council.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - It is with great regret that I am forced to refuse discharge for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for 201. This decision, however, has its reason in the failure of the institutions involved to reply to the questions submitted by PE. It appears at least singular that out of twenty-seven requests presented by Parliament, the Council provides justifications on three issues, just as the lack of information on the funds entrusted to the European Council and the Council, whose budgets, for other, have not yet been divided. Furthermore, the absence of information relating to the costs of buildings or the progress of real estate projects with a clear distribution of the costs incurred represents a profound lack of respect towards citizens. Therefore, for the reasons mentioned above, I urge the Council to join the EU register for transparency and accountability as soon as possible, as we are witnessing a serious breach of the obligations prescribed by the Treaties. The latter undoubtedly require a joint revision of the Financial Regulation to clarify the purposes and processes of the discharge procedure itself, but until then they require compliance.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the vote to refuse the ‘2014 Discharge – EU general budget – European Council and Council’ and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing.- For the eighth consecutive time, with a large majority of Parliament, the Council is given discharge for the year 2014. For the eighth time, the Council disregards Parliament's budgetary competence.It ignored requests for more information, namely with regard to the Council's real estate heritage, which is undergoing remodeling and new construction.He ignored the request for greater transparency and continued not to send the account report.It ignored the request for administrative modernization and separation of accounts between the Council of Ministers and the European Council.This approach does not dignify the Council and casts a stain of liability on all European institutions.Once again, the European Parliament - and rightly so - reiterates that it will not agree with this approach, refusing to give discharge to this institution and thus postponing the conclusion of the discharge procedure.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: written.- I voted against the discharge because the Council's expenditure needs to be monitored in the same way as that of the other institutions.I regret the recurring difficulties with the discharge procedure due to the lack of cooperation from the Council.The Council, too, has a duty to be transparent to the taxpayer, and the Union is democratically accountable to it too.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of rejecting the discharge for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council and of the attached resolution, as the European Council and the Council have not yet taken action on the comments made by the European Parliament in its resolution of 28April 2016, just as they did not even submit to Parliament the annual report on their activities and the other required reports on the progress of building projects within the European Union.Furthermore, the Council did not reply to twenty-four of the twenty-seven questions submitted by the Committee on Budgetary Control for the year 2014, so Parliament can only declare itself unable to take an informed decision on granting discharge.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- The European Council and the Council still do not present separate accounts, an annual report on their activities or clearly answer questions from the parliamentary committee on budgets.I consider this lack of transparency to be inadmissible, which is why I have refused the 2014 discharge.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. - There are three fundamental points in this report that I want to highlight. The first concerns the unjust and disproportionate suspension of the ESI Funds. Second, with regard to the migration and refugee challenges, some progress has been made, but further action needs to be taken. I welcome the positions of the Commission for the inclusion of budgetary flexibility in this regard, albeit obviously oriented towards the short term. More needs to be done in the long term in addition to increasing the funds for the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund. The adoption of the instrument for emergency support is also important, which has achieved good results in the context of humanitarian needs in the countries of arrival of refugees and migrants. In fact, one could act in a structural way, intervening on the European Fund for Search and Rescue together with a planned and adequate budget for Frontex and the European Border and Coast Guard. Finally, it is important to support the guidelines of the European Semester on investment, innovation and the creation of quality jobs, ensuring budgetary policies towards sustainable growth.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported the discharge report for the 2014 EU general budget, thereby expressing my refusal to grant discharge.The report describes in great detail the discharge process of the European Council and Parliament.Neither the Council of the EU nor the European Council was involved in this process in general, so I decided not to grant discharge and therefore to support the content of the report by voting in favor.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report which refuses the discharge of the European Council and Council as I believe that Parliament must be provided with the annual activity information of both the European Council and the Council. The Council should seek to answer Parliament’s questions on its budget in order to ensure transparency. I support the idea that all institutions must collaborate together, be accountable and ensure transparency in all sectors. All European Union institutions must be fully accountable to the citizens, for the funds entrusted to them as European Union institutions.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing.- For the eighth year in a row, the European Parliament has decided to refuse the granting of budgetary discharge to the Council and the European Council, mainly due to the lack of cooperation with the Parliament, the discharge authority.Only three of the twenty-seven questions submitted by Parliament find a clear answer in the documents provided by the Council and the European Council.Faced with this repetitive and gruesome situation, I consider that various options for updating the rules for granting discharge to the Council, the budgetary authority, enshrined in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, should be considered.Supporting the conclusions of this report, I voted in favor of refusing to grant discharge to the Council.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- For the sake of transparency in the management of public funds, I voted in favor of the report refusing discharge for the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2014. As long as the European Council and the Council refuseto provide clear answers to each of the questions asked by the European Parliament on its management of public funds and to transmit the requested documents, the European Parliament must refuse to grant this discharge for the 2014 budget year.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - This report calls for the discharge for the implementation of the 2014 budget to be refused. Once again, the Council refuses to cooperate with the Parliament, the budgetary discharge authority. This is a serious breach of the obligations laid down by the Treaties, the Council's expenditure having to be controlled in the same way as that of the other institutions. Once again, the Council did not send its activity report to Parliament. As every year, the report takes up the idea of ​​imposing a separation between the budgets of the Council and the European Council in order to ensure more transparent financial management, a constraint which the Council seems to want to avoid. The report requires the Council to provide Parliament with accurate data on building projects and their costs. Naturally, the report underlines the absence of rules relating to "whistleblowers" in the Council's statutes and invites it to participate in the European Union's transparency register, to adopt an internal code of conduct for the institution. as well as anti-corruption guidelines. I therefore voted for the refusal of this budgetary discharge.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: In written form. - The European Council and the Council did not provide Parliament with their annual activity report. In addition, there is no information on the costs incurred in connection with the buildings, nor reports on the progress of construction projects and a detailed breakdown of the costs incurred so far. The rapporteur also calls on the Council to provide information on the process of administrative modernization, in particular the expected impact on the Council's budget, and I fully support it. We need more transparency. We are representatives of the people's voice and we must have information without which we cannot justify the costs incurred by the Council or the European Council. This is already happening for the sixth or seventh consecutive year. For the reasons set out above, I voted in favor of the report, which rejects the discharge of these two institutions.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing.- The reported financial data must be sufficient, accompanied by actions to correct previous observations, in order to accept the exemption for the financial year 2014.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to reject this discharge report because there is still inadequate exchange of information between the Council and the European Parliament. The Council discharge has been continually rejected by Parliament for this reason since 2009. It is of concern to myself and my constituents in Wales.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing.- Union institutions must be transparent and fully accountable to Union citizens for the funds entrusted to them as Union institutions and both the European Council and the Council must be subject to the democratic accountability of Union citizens,as they are beneficiaries of the general budget of the European Union.I regret that the European Council and the Council do not provide Parliament with its annual activity report, which for me is unacceptable and damaging to the reputation of the EU institutions and the fact that the budget of the European Council and that of the Council have not yet been separated, as recommended by Parliament in recent discharge resolutions.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Vote for: the report calls for refusing the discharge for the implementation of the 2014 budget. Once again the Council refuses to cooperate with Parliament, the budgetary discharge authority.This is a serious breach of the obligations laid down by the Treaties, the Council's expenditure having to be controlled in the same way as that of the other institutions.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Extending a long and long-standing institutional war between the European Parliament and the Council, the report proposes to refuse discharge to the Council. We voted in favor, as on previous occasions. The Council has not yet commented on the observations made by Parliament in its April 2016 discharge resolution on the trend of previous years for an increase in under-utilization of appropriations and in the carry-over of commitments. The European Council and the Council do not provide Parliament with its annual activity report. The report reiterates the request for reports on the state of progress of real estate projects and a detailed breakdown of expenses incurred to date. Considers that information on costs arising from the delay in completing the Europa building should be provided. The report reiterates the request to the Council to provide information on the administrative modernization process, in particular on the expected impact on the Council's budget. The Council is requested to urgently adopt a code of conduct in order to guarantee the integrity of the institution; the request for the application of rules on whistleblowing is repeated; the Council is urged to join the EU transparency register in order to ensure the institution's transparency and accountability.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the resolution accompanying the postponement of the discharge as there are criticisms related to the lack of transparency of the Council and the European Council in the management of their buildings policy.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favor of the second report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the European Union general budget for the financial year 2014, Section II - European Council and Council, as the financial data reported must be adequate, accompanied by remedial action, to accept the discharge for the financial year 2014, and because it does not grant a discharge to the Secretary - General of the Council in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Council and of the Council for the financial year 2014.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Discharge was refused, as it has been for several years now. Parliament and the Council continue to hold different legal views on the discharge procedure. The Council does not recognise Parliament’s authority but sees itself on the same level, as one of two arms of the EU budgetary authority. Parliament’s interpretation of Article 319 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union clearly distinguishes the two institutions’ roles – Parliament being the authority which gives the discharge, whereas the Council gives a recommendation on whether to grant discharge.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the proposal for a European Parliament decision on discharge in respect of the implementation of the European Union general budget for the financial year 2014, Section II - European Council and Council, in defense of the prerogatives of the European Parliament under the Treaties and of its important function of exercising public control over expenditure financed by the EU budget, and therefore by European taxpayers. The Council, by not replying to or following up on the European Parliament's report of last April, has once again proved a deaf face to legitimate requests for transparency and clarification, delegitimizing our institution. Parliament's requests for separate budgets between the Council and the European Council, for greater transparency in the management of real estate assets, for the presentation of the annual report and for more information on the problem of underutilization are acceptable and deserve to be welcomed: Parliament, in as a body elected by the citizens, even as a budgetary authority, together with the Council, it must be able to exercise a function of public scrutiny on the use of Union resources, in a spirit of loyal institutional cooperation. On these grounds alone, I believe that Parliament can grant discharge for the 2014 budget.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report “Discharge 2014: General Budget of the EU - European Council and Council” because this report shows very well the serious shortcomings in the budget's transparency.The Council refuses to really reveal many areas to Parliament.This is unacceptable from the point of view of the citizens and of Parliament as a financial control body.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: written.- I am voting in favor of the discharge for the implementation of the EU general budget for the European Council in 2014.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- In relation to the European Council and the Council, I vote in favor (rejecting the download and approval of accounts) given the lack of cooperation from this institution and its opacity.The report is in favor of rejecting his accounts, as has been customary in the last times that his management has been assessed.I vote with the majority of Parliament, which in recent times has rejected the management of the European Council and the Council.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament’s interpretation of Article 319 TFEU clearly sees a distinction between the two institutions’ roles. Parliament has an institutional power in the Treaty to grant discharge.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The European Parliament granted a discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Council for the financial year 2014. The Court of Auditors concluded that the payments as a whole for the year ending 31 December 2014 for administrative and other expenditure by the institutions and bodies were free from material error.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- We voted in favor of this report, as the Council refuses to respond adequately to the additional expenditure incurred in 2014. We believe that all EU institutions must be audited transparently, adequately and on an equal footing with respect to their budgets.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion that called on Parliament to refuse to grant the Secretary-General of the Council discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Council and of the Council for the financial year 2014. The repeated difficulties in the discharge procedure are regrettable. It is also regrettable that the Council continues to fail to provide answers to Parliament’s questions and that only three out of 27 questions submitted to the Council in relation to the financial year 2014 received a clear reply in the documents provided by the Council within the discharge exercise. I believe a revision of the Treaties and of the Financial Regulation is needed in order to clarify the objectives and processes of the discharge procedure, and to define sanctions for failing to comply with the rules as stated in the Treaties.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the second discharge report on the implementation of the European Union general budget for the financial year 2014, Part II.- the European Council and the Council, as it refuses to give a discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council.I believe that all the institutions of the Union should operate transparently and responsibly, and that the availability of information and documents is key to raising citizens' trust in the European institutions.In this context, I consider it inappropriate for the European Council and the Council not to submit their annual activity reports to Parliament, and that there is a real need to modernize the administration of the Council itself.In addition, it is necessary for the Council to draw up detailed anti-corruption guidelines, and therefore cooperation between the Council and Parliament is inevitable in the form of effective budgetary control.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- We can only deplore the Council's refusal to cooperate with Parliament by sending its activity report, clear proof of non-compliance with the rules established by the Treaties, expenditure traditionally being subject to the control of Parliament, which is responsible forbudget discharge.I support the proposal to separate the budgets of the two institutions for better transparency and join the collective effort to recall Parliament's role in monitoring the Council's budgetary activity.I voted for.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted against granting discharge for the general budget of the EU to the European Council and the Council.This vote was motivated by the Council’s lack of cooperation with the discharge authority.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written.- The motion for a resolution criticizes the European Council for unwillingness to cooperate with the discharge authority.It is emphasized in particular that the European Council does not make its annual activity report available to Parliament, which seriously undermines the rights of the citizens of the Union to information and transparency.This is a worrying symptom of a democratic deficit in the Union's institutions. That is why I would have agreed to refuse discharge.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament’s interpretation of Article 319 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union clearly sees a distinction in the two institutions’ role. Parliament has an institutional power in the Treaty to grant discharge.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted for this text because it deplores the lack of transparency in the execution of the Council's budget.It is scandalous that the Council has refused to provide Parliament with information on its accounts.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted for the 2014 discharge report concerning the European Council and the Council. This report calls for the discharge for the implementation of the 2014 budget to be refused. Once again, the Council refuses to cooperate with the Parliament, the budgetary discharge authority. This is a serious breach of the obligations laid down by the Treaties, the Council's expenditure having to be controlled in the same way as that of the other institutions. Once again, the Council did not send its activity report to Parliament. As every year, the report takes up the idea of ​​imposing a separation between the budgets of the Council and the European Council in order to ensure more transparent financial management, a constraint which the Council seems to want to avoid. The report requires the Council to provide Parliament with accurate data on building projects and their costs. Naturally, the report underlines the absence of rules relating to "whistleblowers" in the Council's statutes and invites it to participate in the European Union's transparency register, to adopt an internal code of conduct for the institution. , as well as anti-corruption guidelines.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: in writing. - Once again, the Council refuses to cooperate with Parliament, the budgetary discharge authority. This is a serious breach of the obligations laid down by the Treaties, the Council's expenditure having to be controlled in the same way as that of the other institutions. Once again, the Council did not send its activity report to Parliament. The report requires the Council to provide Parliament with accurate data on building projects and their costs. Naturally, the report underlines the absence of rules relating to "whistleblowers" in the Council's statutes and invites it to participate in the European Union's transparency register, to adopt an internal code of conduct for the institution. as well as anti-corruption guidelines. Thus, the report calls for the discharge for the implementation of the 2014 budget to be refused and underlines the lack of factual and worrying control by Parliament over the Council's budgetary activity. That’s why I voted for this report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- The European Council and the Council still do not present separate accounts, an annual report on their activities or clearly answer questions from the parliamentary committee on budgets.I consider this lack of transparency to be inadmissible, which is why I have refused the 2014 discharge.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of rejecting the discharge, that is, rejecting the approval of the European Council's final account.The European Council did not provide the European Parliament with the final accounts for 2014 or the annual report, so the approval of the final account cannot be supported.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - The report notes that the Council, in the documents submitted under the discharge procedure, clearly answered only three of the 27 questions related to the financial year 2014. This is just one in a series of difficulties in the discharge procedures caused by the Council's non-cooperation. . The Commission's January 2014 position emphasized that all institutions must fully implement the recommendations made by Parliament in the context of the discharge procedure and that they must work together to ensure the smooth implementation of the discharge procedure. By refusing to submit the requested documents to Parliament, the Council also undermines the right of EU citizens to information and transparency, which is a cause for concern. Such a situation leads to a serious breach of the obligations arising from the Treaty, which makes it necessary for the Council to join the Union Transparency Register in order to guarantee the institution's accountability. Failure by the European Council and the Council to cooperate with the discharge authority shall send a negative message to the citizens of the Union. I therefore supported this report, which refuses to give a discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and of the Council for the financial year 2014.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- Referring to my speech at the Plenary Session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 26 October 2016, I voted in favor of the second report, which does not grant discharge to the Secretary General of the Council regarding the implementation of the European Council and Council budget for the 2014 financial year.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted for this text.Notably, we can see in this text the refusal to vote on the discharge for the implementation of the 2014 budget. The Council having refused to cooperate with the Parliament and to transmit its activity report, it is indeed not possible togrant discharge for the implementation of the budget.In addition, the report proposes to clarify the financial management of the institutions: a pious wish to which we can only be in favor.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported the EP resolution on the discharge to the European Council and the Council in respect of the implementation of the general budget for the financial year 2014.The resolution calls on the Council to make transparency and democratic accountability to the Union's taxpayers more effective, as well as to develop comprehensive anti-corruption guidelines and independent internal policies to increase the transparency of legislative procedures and negotiations in order to restore people's confidence in the EU institutions.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- This report proposes to refuse to grant discharge to the European Council and the Council for the implementation of their 2014 budgets. The Council is in fact violating several of its budgetary obligations and does not send Parliament the reports necessary for it to be able to exercise itsbudget Control.This is nothing new, since Parliament has already refused to grant discharge for the Council's budgets for 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012 and 2013. We therefore do not see what this new refusal will change.As long as Parliament does not take responsibility for blocking the budgetary procedure as it theoretically has the power to do, the Council will continue to ignore its votes with the complacency of the Commission.Although it is therefore symbolic, I nevertheless vote for this refusal of discharge.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing.- All European institutions that depend on the budget of the European Union must be strictly supervised by the Court of Auditors and by all entities with this function.It is necessary to assess whether Community funds are being used well, whether these institutions are complying with the objectives set and whether there is no waste of resources.In general, with few exceptions, to be assessed by the inspections that are known, we can say that the institutions concerned are using the funds made available correctly and complying with the proposed objectives.In this sense, my vote against the discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2014

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported Parliament’s position not to grant the discharge of the 2014 general budget as the Council continues to refuse to provide the Parliament their annual activity report and respond to questions from Parliament’s Budget Committee.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing.- As far as I am concerned, the institutions of the Union must work as openly as possible, in the most transparent manner but also as close as possible to the citizens.These are absolutely essential criteria, from which we can not derogate, because they represent the very essence of the European Union, which has a duty of explanation, of clarification, of information towards the European citizen.Not considering that the European Council and the Council have fulfilled their duty of transparency by not presenting to Parliament their annual activity report but also several other information concerning the expenditure incurred, I decided to refuse the discharge to the Secretary General of theAdvice on the implementation of the budget of the European Council and of the Council for the financial year 2014. Their behavior, in my opinion, damages the reputation of the institutions of the European Union.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in agreement with Parliament’s interpretation of Article 319 of the TFEU, which clearly sees a distinction between the two institutions’ roles. Parliament has an institutional power in the Treaty to grant discharge. Therefore I have voted in favour of the report

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - The proposal for a decision submitted to Parliament by the Committee on Budgetary Control proposes that Parliament refuse to grant the Secretary-General of the Council discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2014. The attached motion for a resolution justifies this by refusing to cooperate with Parliament in the context of effective budgetary control by the European Council and the Council; they do not submit their annual activity reports to Parliament and only three of the twenty-seven questions put to the Council by members of the Committee on Budgetary Control for the financial year 2014 are clearly answered in the documents submitted by the Council under the discharge procedure. Parliament is therefore not in a position to take an informed decision on the discharge, just as it was not in a position to take an informed decision on the discharge for the financial years 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012 and 2013. neither in question. I voted in favor of the proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing.- The report recommends refusing the discharge for the implementation of the 2014 budget. Once again, the Council refuses to cooperate with Parliament, the budgetary discharge authority.This is a serious breach of the obligations laid down by the Treaties, the Council's expenditure having to be controlled in the same way as that of the other institutions.The Council did not send its activity report to Parliament.As every year, the report takes up the idea of imposing a separation between the budgets of the Council and the European Council in order to ensure more transparent financial management, a constraint which the Council seems to want to avoid.The report requires the Council to provide Parliament with accurate data on building projects and their costs.My vote is in favor (namely the refusal of the discharge).

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - The institutions of the European Union must be transparent and fully accountable to the citizens of the Union for the funds entrusted to them as institutions of the Union. The European Council and the Council, as institutions of the Union, must be democratically accountable to the citizens of the Union , as they are beneficiaries of the general budget of the European Union. I endorse the rapporteur's position, regretting that the European Council and the Council do not provide Parliament with their annual activity report, considering that this is unacceptable and damaging to the reputation of the EU institutions. Given that it is Parliament's competence to grant discharge under Articles 316, 317 and 319 TFEU, in line with current practice and interpretation, namely to grant discharge for the execution of each budget line, in order to maintaining transparency and ensuring democratic accountability to Union taxpayers, and since the Council has not submitted the requested documents to Parliament, it undermines the right of Union citizens to information and transparency.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament’s interpretation of Article 319 TFEU clearly sees a distinction between the two institutions’ roles. Parliament has an institutional power in the Treaty to grant discharge.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text which refuses the granting of discharge.I followed the opinion of the CONT committee which unanimously decided to refuse the discharge in particular because of the Council's lack of cooperation with the discharge authority.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing.- I felt obliged to reject the 2014 discharge.The main reason for this is the lack of willingness of each institution to cooperate with the European Parliament.Where can one expect full transparency, if not in EU-level institutions?We did not get answers to fundamental questions such as the cost of maintaining buildings.I will only agree to the implementation of the exemption if we receive clear answers and explanations to our questions.And I am particularly pleased that my colleagues share this view.The European Parliament is chosen by the people so that their interests are properly represented, and that is exactly what we are doing now.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Each year the European Parliament takes a decision, under the form of a recommendation by the Parliament from the Council, regarding the discharge for budget implementation through which it releases the Commission from its responsibility on managing the given budget for a specific year by marking the end of its execution. I have voted for this report on the EU general budget for the European Council and Council 2014 discharge.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution because the European Council and the Council are also being viewed critically for their unwillingness to cooperate with the discharge authority.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported.Each institution is responsible for the correct implementation of its budget.Parliament has a oversight role in this process.It is unfortunate that the institutions in question do not submit their annual activity report to the European Parliament and that the agencies' budgets have not yet been separated.The 2014 budget of the Council and the Council must be rejected, as there are still a significant number of outstanding issues.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted in favour of this decision and non-binding resolution to refuse the granting of discharge to the Council. Discharge is a procedure whereby the EU Parliament looks at the internal budgets of each EU agency and institution and gives an opinion on its implementation. There is a decision regarding discharge (non-binding opinion) and a decision on closing the accounts for the relevant body. According to the Lisbon Treaty, the European Parliament is only supposed to grant discharge to the Commission, however it has taken upon itself (and created a whole procedure) to grant discharge to every EU agency and institution. The Council always refuses to cooperate because of this legal point and have been refused discharge by the Parliament for the last few years. The refusal of discharge in this case does not include a decision on the closure of accounts, which should be decided at a later date. The motion for a resolution criticises the Council and calls for more transparency. UKIP’s general position on discharge votes is to refuse the granting of discharge, in order to register our opposition to EU bodies and the EU spending British taxpayer’s money.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing.- There is no doubt that all institutions must be transparent and accountable to the citizens of the Union for the funds entrusted to them.Given that the Union is represented by each of its institutions on the basis of their administrative autonomy and, therefore, given the proposal under consideration, I would like to say positively.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I supported the Decision on Discharge for the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2014, although in April the decision on discharge was postponed due to insufficient cooperation of the Council. I support Parliament's earlier view that the Council should show greater transparency and accountability to the citizens of the Union in managing the funds entrusted to it by participating fully and in good faith in the annual reporting on EU budget spending, just as the other institutions do. Of the EU. In 2014, the European Council and the Council had a general budget of EUR 534 200 000 with an execution rate of 91.3%, which is reason enough to make their work transparent to citizens directly represented by the European Parliament and whose interests it protects. I believe that only full transparency can affect the confidence of citizens in the European Union and its institutions, especially in the turbulent times in which we live today exposed to various, major and minor crises, which citizens who finance the work of these Councils feel on their skin in every corner Union.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - By not cooperating with our institutions, we are sending a negative message to the citizens of the Union. By refusing to submit the requested documents, the Council undermines the right of Union citizens to information. The Union institutions must be transparent and accountable to the citizens of the Union with regard to the funds entrusted to them. I regret that the Council still does not comment on the remarks made in Parliament's discharge resolution of 28 April 2016 regarding the trend of increasing unspent funds and the transfer of commitments in recent years. I call on the Council to provide information on the process of modernizing its administration, adopt a code of conduct, implement whistleblower rules, develop detailed anti-corruption guidelines and join the Union's transparency register to ensure the institution's transparency and accountability. It is Parliament's power to give discharge under Articles 316, 317 and 319 TFEU, for each budget heading individually, in order to preserve transparency and democratic accountability to Union taxpayers. Council expenditure must be monitored in the same way as that of other institutions. I regret that the budgets of the European Council and the Council have not yet been separated. Relevant stakeholders must take the necessary steps without further delay to address this issue. A revision of the Treaties and the Financial Regulation is needed to clarify the objectives and procedures for granting discharge and to define the penalties for non-compliance with these rules.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- As the Council has not yet commented on the observations made by Parliament in its discharge resolution of 28 April 2016 on the trend of previous years towards an increase in under-utilization of appropriations and in the carry-over of commitments, they have not provided thePE your annual activity report, we follow the proposal to not give discharge.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: in writing. - Discharge is only possible if the European institutions show sufficient transparency and are able to provide the necessary answers to Parliament's budgetary questions. Unfortunately, we did not see that again in the case of both the Council and the European Council, which do not show signs of sufficient cooperation. For this reason, I voted in favor of refusing to grant the Secretary-General of the Council discharge in respect of the implementation of the two institutions' budgets for 2014. Although the administrative expenditure of the Union budget is only around 5% of its total, it is incomprehensible that motivated to present and answer accounts properly. The European budget is stretched to the last thread, struggling with a payment crisis, for which even an interinstitutional strategy had to be drawn up. MEPs are also working to find ways to fund as many policies as possible through the flexibility instruments to increase citizens' well-being and security. I am sorry and I find it shameful that, even in this context of an obvious lack of funding, it is not possible to officially close their accounts due to the passivity of the rising Council and the European Council. So, in the end, I was convinced to revise the contracts and the financial regulations. This is the only way to clarify the discharge procedure and introduce severe sanctions if the rules are not respected.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing.- The report recalls that the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and the Financial Regulation of the European institutions give the European Parliament the prerogatives relating to the granting of discharge for the implementation of the budget.I stress that all Union institutions should strive to be as transparent as possible and should be fully accountable to Union citizens for the use of the funds entrusted to them.Due to a variety of outstanding issues, the European Parliament has decided not to grant the European Council and the Council of the EU discharge in respect of the implementation of the European Union general budget for the financial year 2014, Section II.I too voted in favor of this decision, hoping that the aforementioned institutions will provide comprehensive and detailed answers as soon as possible in the interest of European citizens.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- Following the unanimous decision taken in the Committee on Budgetary Control, we have decided to refuse to grant discharge due to the Council's lack of cooperation with the discharge authority.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. - The discharge procedure is the European Parliament's final approval of the way in which the EU budget for a given year is implemented. Parliament examines the reports of the Parliamentary Committee on Budgetary Control and, taking into account the Council's recommendation, decides to grant, postpone or refuse discharge. However, the discharge of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2014 is not yet finished, because several issues, referring to Section II - European Council and Council, are still ongoing. In the documents provided by the Council, only three of the twenty-seven questions submitted by Parliament, have obtained a clear answer. Requests for information on real estate assets, the report of accounts, among others, were ignored. It is totally unfortunate that the European Council and the Council do not provide Parliament with their annual activity report, making the institutions of the European Union unacceptable and damaging to their reputation, especially in the current situation. Finally, I remind the Council of the Commission's view, expressed in 2014, that all institutions should participate in the follow-up to the observations made by Parliament in the context of the discharge exercise and all institutions should cooperate to ensure the correct the discharge procedure. For the above, I support this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted in favour of this decision and non-binding resolution to refuse the granting of discharge to the Council. Discharge is a procedure whereby the EU Parliament looks at the internal budgets of each EU agency and institution and gives an opinion on its implementation. There is a decision regarding discharge (non-binding opinion) and a decision on closing the accounts for the relevant body. According to the Lisbon Treaty, the European Parliament is only supposed to grant discharge to the Commission, however it has taken upon itself (and created a whole procedure) to grant discharge to every EU agency and institution. The Council always refuses to cooperate because of this legal point and have been refused discharge by the Parliament for the last few years. The refusal of discharge in this case does not include a decision on the closure of accounts, which should be decided at a later date. The motion for a resolution criticises the Council and calls for more transparency. UKIP’s general position on discharge votes is to refuse the granting of discharge, in order to register our opposition to EU bodies and the EU spending British taxpayer’s money.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor, as I believe that the failure by the Council to present the documents requested by Parliament above all undermines the right of Union citizens to information and transparency and is becoming a matter of concern, as it reflects a certain democratic deficit withinof the Union institutions. I believe that this situation constitutes a serious breach of the obligations arising from the Treaties and that interested parties should take the necessary measures to resolve this problem without delay.Thus, a revision of the Treaties and financial regulations may be necessary to clarify the objectives and procedures of the discharge procedure and to define sanctions in case of non-compliance with the rules set out in the Treaties.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written. - I supported the decision by which the Parliament denies the Secretary General of the Council discharge approval in the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2014, as well as the resolution of the Parliament in which it regrets that the European Council and the Council have not provided their annual activity report to Parliament, an inadmissible fact that damages the reputation of the Union institutions, as well as the fact that the budgets of both institutions have not been separated as recommended by Parliament in recent resolutions on discharge. Parliament recalls that all Union institutions must be transparent and fully accountable to the citizens of the Union, for the funds entrusted to them as Union institutions and that both the European Council and the Council, as institutions of the the Union, they should be subject to democratic accountability vis-à-vis citizens to the extent that they are beneficiaries of the general budget of the Union.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this motion for a legislative resolution which, in accordance with the prerogatives of the European Parliament, denies the Secretary General of the Council discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Council and of the Council for the financial year 2014. Indeed,, the failure to transmit to Parliament the financial documents requested from the Council undermines both the right to information and to transparency vis-à-vis the citizens of the Union.It is therefore necessary for the Council to take the measure of the problem urgently in order to respect the role of the European Parliament which has been conferred on it by the Treaties.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - All European institutions must be guided by criteria of rigor, transparency and accountability with regard to the funds entrusted to them.
