While, of course, UKIP supports international cooperation on issues such as this on a bilateral basis, its general position on discharge votes is to refuse the granting of discharge, in order to register our opposition to EU bodies and to the EU spending British taxpayers’ money.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor, since the annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking faithfully reflect, in all material respects, its financial situation as at 31 December 2014, as well as the results of its operations and cash flows for the year endedon that date, in accordance with the provisions of its financial regulations.I underline the progress made by the ITER Council, according to which, on the one hand, an effort to concentrate on the essential elements through the first plasma should effectively limit the risks associated with the ITER Project and, on the other, the updated integrated timetable is, in technical terms, the best solution to advance to the first plasma, which will mark the completion of the main assembly and commissioning phases of Tokamak and the support facilities.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing.- Grants discharge to the Director of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy for the implementation of the Joint Undertaking's budget for the financial year 2014.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the discharge of the director of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy in the implementation of the budget of said Company for the financial year 2014 in view of the report prepared by the Commissionof Budgetary Control, which verifies that the annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking faithfully present, in all their significant aspects, its financial situation as of December 31, 2014 and the results of its operations and cash flows for the year ended, in accordance withprovided in its Financial Regulations.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I have decided to grant discharge to the Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking for the implementation of the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking and discharge to the Director of the European Joint Undertaking ITER for the implementation of the budget of thejoint undertaking for the financial year 2014. By voting on these two reports, I nevertheless support the recommendations made to these two companies and hope that they will be taken into account in the future.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy (Joint Undertaking) was created in March 2007 for a period of 35 years and started to operate autonomously in 2008. According to the report of the Court of Auditors on the annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2014, these faithfully reflect, in all relevant respects, its financial situation in December 2014, as well as the results of its operations and the cash flows for the financial year in accordance with provisions of its financial regulations. Due to the challenges currently facing the ITER project, the new Director General of the Organization presented to the Council of the Organization, an action plan that includes specific measures that address the problems that currently affect the development of this project. According to the June 2016 conclusions of the ITER Council, it is confirmed that the project is now in the right direction, which allows for a solid, realistic and detailed proposal of the timetable and associated costs, so I voted to approve this discharge.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- In relation to the ITER report, the CONT report assesses the efficiency, transparency and regularity of the ITER accounts.This is the second report, because the decision was postponed in spring.I am voting against, because despite the fact that some papers have been regulated, ITER continues to be an inefficient waste of resources for a doubtful, centralizing project with high opportunity costs.Therefore I vote against the approval of the discharge.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on the discharge of the ITER Joint Undertaking and the development of fusion energy.In June 2016, the EU Council presented an updated plan for the ITER project, which was now up for approval.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted against the ITER management report and the development of Fusion Energy due to the very high cost of this type of research.The European budget must be aimed at solving the many problems that European citizens are facing.I am not against the development of this type of research, but the Union has a budget that must be aimed at solving problems of a European nature.The high cost has been demonstrated shortly after its inception;It is an ambitious project that must be financed at the expense of fundamental policies for the citizens of the Union.I believe that the Union needs a much larger budget.Therefore, in this context, I cannot support a project with these characteristics.That is why I have decided to vote against this project.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The ITER Joint Undertaking is a public-private partnership in the field of fusion energy. In April of this year, the S&D Group supported the rapporteur’s proposal to postpone discharge on the grounds that the long-awaited and much-delayed ITER Action Plan had not yet been published. Since then, this report has been published and on this basis, the rapporteur has proposed to grant discharge to ITER. Joint Undertakings (JUs) bring together industry and research bodies in public-private partnerships to support research, new technology and demonstration activities and to accelerate the market introduction of specific technologies. Domains covered include air traffic control, carbon-lean energy, nanotechnology, computing technology, cleaner aviation technologies and nuclear fusion. Our Group supports the JUs in their many areas of work, which is of clear benefit to EU citizens.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - I have decided to support the discharge to the Director of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy for the financial year 2014. This discharge was originally postponed in April this year due to the fact that the long-awaited and delayed ITER Action Plan was still not published. In the meantime, however, the ITER Joint Undertaking has presented this Action Plan. The new Director-General of the ITER Organization presented concrete measures to address the main constraints that currently block the further development of the project itself. The audit states that the action plan has been implemented since March 2015 and that improvements in the company's operations are expected soon. So far, there have also been problems with renting out the Joint Undertaking's premises. I therefore welcome the agreement offered by the Spanish Government, under which the joint venture will have its current long-term lease and that its office space will be expanded by one floor. Joint ventures are an important area for industry and research cooperation for the EU. These companies are based on a public-private partnership that supports research, new technologies and faster launch of specific technologies. ITER has also developed a working definition of what is the application of fusion, which will allow it to operate in accordance with intellectual property rights. I therefore hope that ITER will succeed in fulfilling its mandate.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- We appreciate that the management of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER, which is involved in the development of fusion, has responded flexibly and effectively to the technical and administrative problems that have recently arisen.The procedure of the acting director and the bodies subordinate to him in dealing with them can serve as a model for other companies and institutions.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: written.- I did not agree to the resolution of the European Parliament on the "discharge for the implementation of the budget of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the development of fusion energy for the financial year 2014".The EU should not operate in the form of joint undertakings.This creates non-transparent shadow households.The company itself is wrong in terms of economic policy.Even if you approve of research subsidies, research should not be done directly by the EU.ITER has a budget of almost 1.2 billion euros in 2014. The refusal to grant discharge is imperative.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the second discharge report on the implementation of the budget of the ITER Joint Undertaking and the Development of Fusion Energy for the financial year 2014. The Court of Auditors found the 2014 ITER Joint Undertaking to be in compliance with its financial rules and to close its accountsfairly represents its financial position on the last day of 2014 and its profit or loss and cash flows.I welcome the action plan, which includes specific measures to address the main obstacles currently affecting the development of the ITER project presented by the new Director-General.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- Our disagreement with nuclear power plants is clear.That is why we voted against the discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the development of nuclear fusion for 2014.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing.- The reported data must be sufficient, accompanied by actions to correct previous remarks, in order to accept the exemption for the financial year 2014, without leaving a trace of doubt as to the legality of the respective operations.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - The discharge of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy (set up in 2007 for a period of 35 years) for the financial year 2014, ie the approval of the use of its financial resources, was postponed by the European Parliament in April 2016. the delayed ITER Action Plan has not been presented. In the meantime, this material has been completed, so the rapporteur proposes to grant a discharge in this second report. Previously, these reports on discharge procedures were also used by MEPs to question the existence of fusion energy development, while in the present case there was a broad consensus that the use of funds should be given the green light. Joint Undertakings bring together industry and research organizations (mainly in the form of PPPs) to support research, new technologies and demonstration activities, and to accelerate the uptake of a given technology. In this case, this formation covers several areas, such as air traffic control, low-carbon energy, nano- and cleaner aviation technologies, computing, and nuclear fusion. I agree with the socialist and democratic approach that it is worth supporting joint ventures that guarantee clear benefits for EU citizens, which is why I voted in favor of this report.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up.- In April this year, the discharge for the ITER Joint Undertaking, a public-private partnership in the field of fusion energy, was postponed.Given that the much-delayed ITER Action Plan was subsequently published, however, all the conditions for granting discharge to ITER were met.In this context, and emphasizing the importance of the areas concerned, such as air traffic control and nanotechnology, I vote in favor of granting discharge.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the discharge.I would like to take advantage of this explanation of vote to underline my disappointment at the fact that the European Council and the Council do not present their annual activity report to Parliament.This is unacceptable and it damages the reputation of the institutions of the European Union!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy is an innovative energy initiative and research project aimed at providing a link between plasma physics and engineering and future commercial fusion-based power plants. The 2014 joint undertaking report is a document that consolidates the annual accounts of the EU for the 2014 financial year on the basis of information provided by the various institutions, organisations and bodies of the EU. The document sets out how the joint undertakings spent and implemented their budget in 2014. I voted in favour of the report to discharge the 2014 budget, which also made a series of recommendations on improving future budgets and auditing project costs, making for improvement and more transparency in future budgets.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written.- The European Union has created the European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy, whose tasks are to ensure the European Atomic Energy Community's contribution to the ITER International Fusion Energy Organization, to ensure Euratom's contribution to wider access activities with Japan.to prepare for the construction of experimental fusion reactors and associated plants.Given the importance of this Joint Undertaking in terms of its responsibility for public research activities in the European and international interest, I believe that we should not give it discharge until the 2014 budget is fully discharged in order to achieve budget transparency.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the proposal for a decision on the discharge for the implementation of the budget of the Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy for the financial year 2014. The European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy was set up in March 2007 for a period of 35 years. In its report on the final accounts of the Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2014, the Court of Auditors stated that, in all material respects, it represents fairly its financial position at 31 December 2014 and its profit and loss and cash flows for that year in accordance with its provisions. financial rules. The final budget for 2014, which was available for implementation, included commitment appropriations of EUR 1,168,800,000 and payment appropriations of EUR 567,600,000. In response to the challenges currently facing the ITER project, the new Director-General of ITER presented an action plan to the Council, which includes specific measures to address the main obstacles currently affecting the development of the ITER project. Parliament shall give a discharge to the Director of the Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy in respect of the implementation of the Joint Undertaking's budget for the financial year 2014. Parliament shall approve the annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy for the financial year 2014.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- In relation to the ITER report, the CONT report assesses the efficiency, transparency and regularity of the ITER accounts.This is the second report, because the decision was postponed in spring.I am voting against, because despite the fact that some papers have been put into order, ITER continues to be an inefficient waste of resources for a dubious, centralizing project with high opportunity costs.Therefore I vote against the approval of the discharge.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing.- The report concerns the discharge of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy.It should be recalled that in spring the discharge was strongly opposed by the Court of Auditors, the institution responsible for auditing the Union's accounts.In the qualified opinion, the Tribunal then drew attention to a number of irregularities, includingthe information needed to calculate the error rate in the Member States' audits is missing.Despite sending additional documents by the national authorities, I have doubts whether the existing irregularities have been eliminated.At this stage of the procedure, Parliament only has two options: it can grant discharge (in line with the rapporteur's resolution) or refuse it.I voted against the resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- In relation to the ITER report, the CONT report assesses the efficiency, transparency and regularity of the ITER accounts.This is the second report, because the decision was postponed in spring.I am voting against, because despite the fact that some papers have been regulated, ITER continues to be an inefficient waste of resources for a doubtful, centralizing project with high opportunity costs.Therefore I vote against the approval of the discharge.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the second report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy for the financial year 2014. The European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy was set up in March 2007 for a period of 35 years. The report stresses that the Court of Auditors stated that the Joint Undertaking’s annual accounts present fairly, in all material respects, its financial position as at 31 December 2014 and the results of its operations and its cash flows for the year then ended, in accordance with the provisions of its financial rules. Due to the challenges currently faced by the ITER Project, the new Director General of the ITER Organization presented to the ITER Council an action plan including specific measures to address the main constraints that are currently affecting the development of the ITER Project. I voted in favour because I believe that the milestones set up at the ITER Council meeting of 18 and 19 November 2015 are well advanced.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted against the ITER management report and the development of Fusion Energy due to the very high cost of this type of research.The European budget must be aimed at solving the many problems that European citizens are facing.I am not against the development of this type of research, but the Union has a budget that must be aimed at solving problems of a European nature.The high cost has been demonstrated shortly after its inception;It is an ambitious project that must be financed at the expense of fundamental policies for the citizens of the Union.I believe that the Union needs a much larger budget.Therefore, in this context, I cannot support a project with these characteristics.That is why I have decided to vote against this project.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- The ITER project is an international collaborative project that aims to develop fusion energy.According to the Court of Auditors' report on the annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy for the financial year 2014, the annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking faithfully reflect, in all materially relevant aspects, its situationon December 31, 2014, as well as the results of its operations and cash flows for the year ended on that date, in accordance with the provisions of its financial regulations.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- Since its inception, the ITER nuclear fusion project has been viewed as extremely controversial from several sides due to exploding costs, poor administrative planning and unrealistic forecasts.According to a commission report from 2010, the cost estimate for the construction project for the research reactor tripled from the previously planned 2.7 billion euros to 7.3 billion euros, while numerous experts have criticized the lack of scientific progress.The report does not contain any suggestions for solutions or improvements for the problem areas mentioned, which is why I rejected the application.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: written.- The PVV voted against the discharge of the budget of the ITER Joint Undertaking.The PVV is of the opinion that no matter how agencies such as ITER use their budget, the European Union does not add value to research budgets.Research can be easily funded by the sovereign member states themselves.In addition, ITER has not been able to show many results for the billions of Euros research budget spent on nuclear fusion.According to the PVV, there is therefore no reason whatsoever to support or finance EU agencies.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Marinescu report for agreeing with the discharge for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy. I emphasize my support for the formula of joint ventures that combine private institutes and public partnerships in supporting research through synergies that can accelerate the introductionon the market for new technologies, whenever they bring clear added value for European citizens.The ITER Joint Undertaking in particular seeks to cover the areas of air traffic control, low carbon energy, nanotechnology, aviation technologies and nuclear fusion.I note that the ITER project today faces challenges that affect its development, so it is necessary to carry out the measures provided for in the ITER Organization's action plan in order to successfully complete all stages of the project.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament decision of 27 October 2016 on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy for the financial year 2014. I supported the discharge to the Director of the European Joint Undertakingfor the financial year 2014, as the Court of Auditors stated in its report on the final annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2014 ('the Court of Auditors' Report') that it represents, in all material respects, its financial position at 31 December 2014;its profit or loss and cash flows for the year then ended in accordance with the provisions of its financial rules.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, just to say that you voted in favor of this resolution, to express closeness above all to the Iraqi people, to underline the right of displaced populations to return to their lands and to have their rights recognized, thus protectingChaldeans, Syriacs, Assyrians and all the indigenous Christian communities.Two figures tell us how many Christians in Iraq have suffered prolonged discrimination: in 2003 alone there were more than one and a half million, today the Christian community is reduced to 200,000 presences.They are truly sacrificial victims of the conflict.Obviously, and I also strongly emphasize what the resolution says, to fight firmly the further advancement of the jihadist ideology of Isis is certainly a precondition for pacifying the region and guaranteeing a stable and prosperous future.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, with this resolution this House clearly stated that it is time to act. We have to help the local people, and especially minorities like the Chaldeans (which are Syriacs), Assyrians, Christians, Yazidis, Turkmen and other groups. They suffer the most. It is crucial to send in mining and rebuilding teams as soon as possible so we can help them rebuild their future in their homelands. Our help should be humanitarian and political too. In 2014, on the premises of the European Parliament, representatives of Christians, Yazidis, Turkmen and other minorities in the Nineveh Plains signed a social contract that envisions future administration for the land that once belonged to them. There will be no sustainable solution if there is no political empowerment of the minorities returning to their homelands in Sinjar, Tal Afar and the Nineveh Plains. They are capable of governing their own land. With this motion for a resolution we urgently ask the High Representative to start acknowledging the political efforts of these minorities, as without them there will be no peace in Iraq.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I fully supported this resolution. I am very pleased that the European Parliament is constantly addressing the issue of human rights and democracy in the world, and that we are not silent about the tragedy that is taking place around Mosul and in the city itself, and that we have adopted this resolution. My colleagues have already made this clear here, it is good that part of the resolution is the issue of minorities who lived in this area and were expelled from this area. Christians, Yazidis, Turkmen were mentioned here. I think that we must do everything we can to ensure that these people can return to their homeland after the end of the war, and it is good, so I read that in that resolution is the European Union's commitment to help these people in the aftermath of the war to returning to their homeland. The aid will have to be logistical, financial, and it is good that we are already debating how to allow these people to return after the end of the war and the defeat of the Islamic State.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The situation in some regions of Iraq and especially in Mosul has reached a critical level.I firmly believe that the people of those areas have the right to live in better conditions and above all I believe that it is very important to give the displaced people back a home and that this should represent a primary need for the Iraqi government.However, I believe that the continuous use of arms aggravates the tragic conditions in which the populations of those places are already forced to live, so I have decided to abstain.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: written. - My vote shows the undeniable socialist commitment to the fight against international terrorism of Daesh, with the urgency of a rapid liberation of Mosul and the surrounding populations, with the least possible number of civilian victims and with the need to protect the most vulnerable In this crossfire I make it clear that we do not support a contest that breaks the rules of war, much less violates international humanitarian law. At the socialist proposal, our call to the International Coalition to put the protection of civilians as the focus of military action, to ensure evacuation through humanitarian corridors, to give urgent humanitarian aid to the displaced and to start up an urgent plan for the reconstruction and development of Iraq. We deeply regret that the representatives in the European Parliament of the parties of: PODEMOS, IU, EH BILDU, Galician Alternative, NEC and EQUO did not join our call for the protection and end of terrorism. Once again, with their abstention, they leave thousands of people helpless. In this case, almost 1.5 million Iraqis who are being held in Mosul.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non—binding resolution. We are pleased to see the successful assault on Mosul and the further dislodgement of ISIS strongholds in Iraq. Appropriate measures must be taken to prevent a further wave of migrants and refugees taking the dangerous routes into Europe. However, the report contains several calls for EU action, which we cannot support.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have abstained, because there are many elements that currently concern us in the offensive on Mosul: that in order to destroy Daesh, humanitarian law should be left aside; the constant misinformation of what is going on in Mosul; or Turkey's role in the entire conflict, including its invasion of Iraqi territory, and the corridor through which they allow terrorists to flee to Syria and attack Kurdish and Syrian forces; we are concerned about the proposal to arm the local militias, which will aggravate the situation, as long as we do not provide sufficient funds to UNHCR, an organization that helps refugees. In the final vote, I abstained considering that although I disagree on many things, the resolution had some positive element, such as expressing concern about the recent tensions between regional actors, and calling for the territorial integrity and integrity to be fully respected. the sovereignty of Iraq and refrain from undertaking any military action in Iraq without the consent of the Iraqi Government, underlining the importance of fostering dialogue between Iraq and the countries of the region in order to achieve a more secure Middle East.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing.- I fully support the actions of the Iraqi government and the anti-Daesh coalition in Iraq aimed at the liberation of Mosul.It is fundamental that, in the process of this operation, international humanitarian law is respected.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Iraq and Mosul, because it refers to the ongoing and comprehensive effort to combat terrorism promoted by ISIS / Daesh.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: written. - This motion for a resolution recalls that 1.5 million people in Mosul are at immediate risk of displacement. The EU has so far provided € 134 million for humanitarian aid in Iraq, € 50 million of which for Mosul. In addition, the Iraqi authorities are urged to protect the civilian population during the offensive and to avoid human rights violations. All parties to the conflict are called upon to open humanitarian corridors, provide protection and set up a United Nations mechanism for monitoring by third parties. I support the call to call on the Iraqi government to take all necessary precautions to protect the civilian population, hospitals and schools as they advance into Mosul. I also advocate that the International Criminal Court be brought before the IS atrocities against Christians, Yazidis and other minorities.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing.- The group resolutions and the joint resolution which resulted from them constitute the European Parliament's commentary on the battle for Mosul where the Iraqi army supported by the international coalition intends to defeat the Islamic State group.The joint resolution, like all those of the political groups, with the exception of that of the ECR group, criticizes humanitarian action to demand an international role for the EU to which it cannot claim and, moreover, to demand additional resources whichwill be requested from States.I criticized in the hemicycle the hypocrisy that reigns on the subject in the European Parliament.You can find my intervention on my website.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I felt it appropriate to abstain on this resolution overall. I supported an amendment calling for the withdrawal of Turkish troops from Iraqi territory. There was much of this resolution which I could support, but also too much of a call for European Union involvement in a situation which (internationally) should be considered by the UN, not the EU.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this joint resolution which supports the operation of Iraqi forces to liberate Mosul from the "Islamic State" group, while recalling that the protection of the civilian population must be a top priority.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- The Iraqi army, backed by the ISIS Coalition Force and the Kurdistan Regional Government's pre-shuttle forces, as well as the People's Mobilization Force, has launched an operation to liberate Mosul, Iraq's second largest city, and many towns and villages along the so-called Mosul Corridor from ISIS.I therefore support the operation launched by Iraq to free Mosul from ISIS, and I believe that this operation will be a crucial part of the global effort to ensure the long-term defeat of ISIS.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. We are pleased to see the successful assault on Mosul and the further dislodgement of ISIS strongholds in Iraq. Appropriate measures must be taken to prevent a further wave of migrants and refugees taking the dangerous routes into Europe. However, the report contains several calls for EU action, which we cannot support.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained from this vote because, if the project has a humanitarian aim towards which one can only be favorable, the European Union would have been granted a diplomatic role to which it cannot claim.It is for sovereign nations to decide on such matters.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing.- I approved the joint resolution supporting the operation launched by Iraq to liberate Mosul from the “Islamic State” group.It also recalls that troops and militias on the ground must respect international humanitarian law and international human rights law during their operations.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. - Mosul, Iraq's second largest city, has always been a multi-ethnic reality in which the Sunni Arab majority has peacefully lived alongside Chaldeans, Kurds, Yazidis and Turkmen. For the past two years it has been in the hands of Daesh which has imposed a climate of terror, persecution and violence in a vast area that includes the plain of Nineveh, Tal Afar and Sinjar. The Iraqi army has recently launched an operation to remove the city and surrounding territories from the control of terrorists, an action conducted jointly with the global anti-ISIS coalition, the Peshmerga forces and those of popular mobilization. The resolution voted today by Parliament, and shared by me, strongly supports this operation, considering it a decisive step to put an end to the terror regime imposed by Daesh. The text asks regional and international actors not to hinder military action and to act in full respect of Iraqi sovereignty. After the liberation of Mosul, the commitment must be to continue to fight to prevent the spread of Islamist ideologies that act as theological and political instigation for the crimes perpetrated by ISIS.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I support the struggle and preservation of the independence, integrity and sovereignty of the Iraqi people, as well as the self-determination of the peoples who suffer the greatest vulnerability in their territory.However, from a vision that advocates an active multilateralism and a peaceful resolution of conflicts, I oppose the introduction into the territory of military assistance as a protection measure for ethnic minorities in the conflict, which will only contribute to the generation ofmore tensions in the region.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written. - I have supported this motion for a resolution on the Iraqi operation to liberate Mosul from the ISIS jihadists, which calls on the Iraqi authorities to do everything possible to protect civilians, hospitals and schools in their advance towards Mosul. The atrocities of the jihadists and the genocide against Christians, Yazidis and other minorities must be judged by the International Criminal Court - the text says. Today, we also celebrate the awarding of the Sakharov Prize to two Yazidi women. The information about the use that ISIS makes of children, the elderly, women and the most vulnerable people as human shields in the face of the military operation against them is very worrying and the extreme violence that is spreading in Iraq must be condemned. In addition, Daesh is committing genocides against Christians, Yazidis and other minorities, and EU countries must be asked to bring the case before the International Criminal Court. For all these reasons, I have supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - I preferred to abstain on this resolution concerning the situation in northern Iraq and Mosul. I have indeed supported the observations made on the humanitarian situation itself, in particular with regard to the precarious situation of Christian minorities and their essential role for the stability of the region. It is thus necessary to underline - which I myself have done in various resolutions - the real ethnico-religious purification of which Christians are victims. Iraq had 1.5 million Christians in 2003, today it has only 200,000 to 350,000, who live in dire poverty. Moreover, it was, it is true, important to raise the issues of population displacement and I was particularly pleasantly surprised that my colleagues mentioned in this resolution the "right of return to the country of origin". However, I reject the European Union's diplomatic role in this resolution. It is up to the Member States, armed with their military, their experiences and their diplomatic relations, to act together to resolve this situation. The European Union, as a supranational legal UFO, does not benefit from this sovereign prerogative constituting states.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- The resolution analyzing the situation in Northern Iraq and Mosul is well structured and balanced.I share the condemnation of the genocide against the Christian population and other minorities residing in Iraqi territory by Isis.Islamic terrorists must be fought and stopped as soon as possible.For all these reasons, I intended to support this text with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have abstained. The situation in northern Iraq / Mosul is in an extremely critical situation, and is not far from a humanitarian catastrophe. It is therefore very important and important for the European Parliament to speak on this issue. On the other hand, the European Parliament should refrain from commenting on the humanitarian situation and support processes for peace and security for the civilian population. The reason I abstained was that the resolution goes further than that and in its political commentary omits both criticism of Turkey and explicit support for Kurdish independence. But above all, the resolution also omits the responsibility of EU Member States for Daesh / ISIS when they buy oil produced on Daesh-controlled land, which is driven by trucks through Turkey. The GUE / NGL tabled amendments to include this aspect, but the other political groups voted against it. The widespread arms trade between Member States and countries in the Middle East, which is a major contributor to the unrest in the region, which of course also affects Iraq and Mosul, has also been left out. Furthermore, the EU's role and responsibility in the refugee situation now created by the conflict in northern Iraq / Mosul is not mentioned - on the contrary, the EU's development policy commitment in Iraq is praised as it can enable faster deportation of refugees (paragraph 9).

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - My vote shows the undeniable socialist commitment to the fight against international terrorism of Daesh, with the urgency of a rapid liberation of Mosul and the surrounding populations, with the least possible number of civilian victims and with the need to protect the most vulnerable In this crossfire We certainly condemn the violation of international humanitarian law. At the socialist proposal, our call to the International Coalition to put the protection of civilians as the focus of military action, to ensure evacuation through humanitarian corridors, to give urgent humanitarian aid to the displaced and to start up an urgent plan for the reconstruction and development of Iraq. We deeply regret that the representatives in the European Parliament of PODEMOS, IU, EH BILDU, Alternativa galega de esquerda, NEC and EQUO did not join our call for the protection and end of terrorism. Once again, with their abstention, they leave thousands of people helpless. In this case, almost 1.5 million Iraqis who are being held in Mosul.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution, in which the European Parliament draws attention to the situation in northern Iraq (Mosul). He notes the warning from the United Nations Humanitarian Coordinator about the lack of funding in view of a possible humanitarian crisis of unprecedented proportions that could result from the attack on Mosul. Parliament welcomed the European Union's action in Iraq, in particular its previous humanitarian aid efforts and its assistance in dismantling improvised explosive devices, which would be crucial for the rapid return of refugees and internally displaced persons. However, urges the EU and its Member States to step up their efforts to stabilize the liberated areas. Parliament also called on all parties to the conflict to respect international humanitarian law during and after hostilities, and to respect the principles of proportionality, separation and precaution during the conflict. In addition, it calls in particular for all necessary precautions to be taken to ensure that children and their families are protected from bombing, to minimize casualties and to protect civilian infrastructure, in particular schools and hospitals.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. - The motion calls on all parties to the conflict to respect international humanitarian law during and after the hostilities and to adhere to the principles of proportionality, differentiation and precaution during the conflict. It urges all parties to the conflict to open humanitarian corridors for the civilian population fleeing the conflict, avoiding being trapped in Mosul and being used as a living shield by ISIS / Daesh. Ensure access to security and humanitarian assistance and provide support and protection to the civilian population in accordance with national and international standards during security screening, in particular to avoid breaking up families and endangering children, and to build a a third-party monitoring mechanism involving third parties. In particular, it calls for all precautionary measures to be taken to ensure that children and their families are not injured in the bombings, that the number of victims is kept to a minimum and that civilian infrastructure, in particular schools and hospitals, is protected. In the light of the above, I voted in favor of the motion.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing.- In this case, I support the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in northern Iraq / Mosul, as I support the operation launched by Iraq to liberate Mosul from ISIS domination, which is seriously violating human rights and causing civilian casualties.I also recognize the independence, territorial integrity and sovereignty of Iraq and its right to take the measures necessary to preserve them.I believe that the Iraqi authorities must take concrete measures to protect civilians during the offensive, including effective militia leadership and control and the prevention of human rights violations.It seems important to me to emphasize that, even after the liberation of Mosul, we must continue to fight against the further spread of Islamist-jihadist ideologies in this region and elsewhere.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this Statement on the situation in northern Iraq / Mosul.I fully support the Iraqi government and the actions of the international coalition forces in Iraq aimed at liberating Mosul.What we must all insist on together in the process of this operation is respect for international humanitarian law.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament supports the operation launched by Iraq to liberate Mosul from ISIS, seeing it as a decisive element of the global effort to defeat ISIS permanently. It reaffirms its full support for Iraq's independence, territorial integrity and sovereignty and calls for these to be fully respected; it also calls for the Iraqi authorities to take concrete measures to protect civilians and to avoid the violation of human rights. It also calls on the parties involved in the conflict to observe international humanitarian law and urges them to open humanitarian corridors to allow civilians to flee. He argues that the EU, the United Nations and the international community should work with Iraq's national and regional governments to help reintegrate Iraqis and all ethnic and religious minorities who have been displaced. It stresses the absolute importance of ensuring security in a timely and effective manner, as well as restoring the rule of law and basic services, as failure to provide them could lead to the re-emergence of extremist forces. It also highlights the need to continue to combat the spread of Islamist-jihadist ideologies, including Salafi jihadism which serves as a theological and political incitement to the crimes perpetrated by ISIS.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - Mosul is a city of significant strategic importance to ISIS, which was conquered by this terrorist group in 2014. Iraqi forces launched an offensive to regain control of Mosul, but this action faces difficult obstacles, having Given that the most frequently used strategies used by ISIS are suicide bombings. This offensive could lead to a major humanitarian crisis, as civilians are in an ungrateful position to choose between two equally dangerous options, as if they choose to remain in the city, they risk being used as human shields, and if they leave Santa, they are in danger of becoming the target of ISIS attacks. The situation in Mosul can only worry us and cause us to react in order to ensure security conditions so that all people who have been forced to leave the country benefit from protection and human living conditions. I spoke in favor of this report because I believe that, now more than ever, we need the solidarity of all European institutions and actors to express our support for the civilian population in Mosul.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: written. - My vote shows the undeniable socialist commitment to the fight against international terrorism of Daesh, with the urgency of a rapid liberation of Mosul and the surrounding populations with the least possible number of civilian victims and with the need to protect the most vulnerable in This cross fire I make it clear that we do not support a contest that breaks the rules of war, much less violates international humanitarian law. At the socialist proposal, our call to the International Coalition to put the protection of civilians as the focus of military action, to ensure evacuation through humanitarian corridors, to give urgent humanitarian aid to the displaced and to start up an urgent plan for the reconstruction and development of Iraq. We deeply regret that the representatives in the European Parliament of the parties of: PODEMOS, IU, EH BILDU, Galician Alternative, NEC and EQUO did not join our call for the protection and end of terrorism. Once again, with their abstention, they leave thousands of people helpless. In this case, almost 1.5 million Iraqis who are being held in Mosul.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing.- The Iraqi government and the international coalition launched on the night of October 16 to 17, 2016, a major offensive with the objective of freeing Mosul and northern Iraq from the grip of Daesh.This resolution fully supports this operation because the humanitarian situation on the ground could not last any longer.Indeed, ethnic and religious minorities such as Christians and Yazidis are daily victims of persecution in the regions occupied by Daesh.The text calls on member states to do everything in their power to ensure that the International Criminal Court judges crimes committed by Daesh as "genocide".We must also step up humanitarian aid from the European Union in the region.I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Northern Iraq / Mosul, because Europe and the international community need to work firstfor the protection of civilians, today "trapped in Mosul and in nearby villages and exposed to combat zones. Secondly, it is necessary to ensure that aid and humanitarian assistance arrives for the inhabitants of the Nineveh Plain. Fortunately, the offensive against the jihadistsof Daesh in Mosul, in northern Iraq, seems to be making progress. It is a question of freeing a city that still has 1.3 million inhabitants, men, women and children, from a ruthless occupation, living in dramatic conditions under theyoke of the jihadists Every effort must be made to avert a humanitarian catastrophe.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The battle of Mosul is a landmark moment in liberating Northern Iraq from Islamic State occupation, but it is important that we are ready to engage in the aftermath of the battle. The international community needs to ensure the provision of assistance to the region’s most vulnerable inhabitants as well as the future return of millions who have fled, including numerous native minorities. Northern Iraq is facing a humanitarian disaster, as an overwhelming number of inhabitants of Mosul may be forced to flee the battle. The importance of the international community’s role in securing humanitarian assistance on-site cannot be emphasised enough. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- Our role, as European champions of humanitarian aid, is not enough if it is not accompanied by a clear vision of the destinies of the liberated territories.We support the creation with an inclusive process of new autonomous provinces for the Nineveh plain, in Tal Afar, in Sinjar and wherever it is necessary to guarantee security and democracy to minorities in their ancestral territories.However, we will not accept that the ashes and oil of Mosul become the object of a shameful bargaining at the table on the skin of its citizens, because Mosul will eventually fall, and I believe soon, but it could have already fallen for some time if the discord and the opposing egoismshad not harbored the minds of the powers involved.Recent history teaches us that in Iraq the difficulty is not winning the war, the difficult is certainly not losing the peace.I have chosen to abstain on the final vote.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing.- We support the report and unequivocally condemn the continuing violence and mass executions by ISIS / Daesh in Iraq.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - I take this opportunity not only to express my support for the joint resolution, but to express my closeness to the Iraqi army which, with the support of the Global Anti-Daesh Coalition, the Peshmerga forces of the Kurdish regional government and the forces of popular mobilization, launched an operation to remove Mosul, and numerous towns and villages along the "Mosul corridor", from ISIS control. In recent weeks we have been witnessing dismay at the atrocious suffering and mass executions to which the inhabitants of the region have been constantly subjected for years by ISIS, without forgetting the one and a half million people at imminent risk of displacement due to ongoing operations. We can only hope that continued protection of civilians will be guaranteed through alternative routes or humanitarian cordons, as well as the restoration of the rule of law and basic services such as health care, electricity and education in the liberated areas. It is known, in fact, that the failure to provide services, security, a long-term strategy to combat the root causes and efforts to promote social cohesion leads to the upper hand of extremist forces.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on the situation in Northern Iraq/Mosul and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Iraq, alongside Syria, has been one of the countries most affected by the incursions of the self-styled Islamic State. The terror and slaughter that has sown in this region are at the origin of the largest number of displaced people since the Second World War. This offensive against Daesh is, however, of particular importance, because it attacks its last great stronghold in Iraq. Not only is Mosul the second largest city in Iraq, but due to the ethnic and religious diversity of this region, it is a paradigmatic example of the destruction caused by the occupation. The effort made by the coalition led by the United States and, in this case, with the support of the Iraqi army and the Peshmerga forces of the Kurdish Regional Government, is commendable. However, it is crucial to take care now of the future of this region, guaranteeing humanitarian aid, a State that allows to guarantee the security of the territory and respects the countless minorities. Only in this way is it possible to restore stability to the region. The European Union must play a key role here. I think the moral duty is clear, in addition to the geostrategic importance.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the measure as it firmly supports the operation launched by Iraq to free Mosul from ISIS / Daesh and identifies in this operation a decisive element of the effort currently undertaken at a global level to defeat ISIS / Daesh in permanently. The voted text also reminds the Iraqi authorities of the need to take concrete measures to protect civilians during operations, exercising effective command and control over the militias and taking all possible precautions to avoid civilian casualties and human rights violations during offensive actions . On the other hand, the violence and mass executions taking place in Iraq by ISIS / Daesh are strongly condemned, expressing deep concern for the continuous reports denouncing the use by ISIS / Daesh of children, the elderly , women and vulnerable people as shields against the ongoing military liberation operations in northern Iraq.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have abstained, because there are many elements that currently concern us in the offensive on Mosul: that in order to destroy Daesh, humanitarian law should be left aside; the constant misinformation about what is happening in Mosul; o Turkey's role in the entire conflict, including its invasion of Iraqi territory, and the corridor through which they allow terrorists to flee to Syria and attack Kurdish and Syrian forces; we are concerned about the proposal to arm the local militias, which will aggravate the situation, as long as we do not provide sufficient funds to UNHCR, an organization that helps refugees. In the final vote, I abstained considering that although I disagree on many things, the resolution had some positive element, such as expressing concern about the recent tensions between regional actors, and calling for the territorial integrity and integrity to be fully respected. the sovereignty of Iraq and refrain from undertaking any military action in Iraq without the consent of the Iraqi Government, underlining the importance of fostering dialogue between Iraq and the countries of the region in order to achieve a more secure Middle East.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Iraqi military, with the support of the global anti-ISIS coalition, Kurdish Peshmerga forces and popular mobilization forces, has launched an operation to remove Mosul from ISIS control. I voted in favor of this resolution, because it expresses support for ongoing operations to wrest Iraqi territory from Daesh control and highlights the need to take concrete measures to protect civilians during operations. In fact, at least 1.5 million civilians are at risk of suffering a real humanitarian catastrophe and the concern that ISIS uses civilians as human shields is real, considering what has already happened in Manbji, Falluja and Sirte. The resolution also stresses that the indigenous communities of the Nineveh plain, Tal Afar and Sinjar, already victims of significant flows of internally displaced persons, have the right to protection, security and regional autonomy within the federal structure of the Republic of 'Iraq. I am convinced that respecting the multi-ethnic reality of Iraq during and after the anti-terrorist operations is the first step towards building the political, economic and social future of the country.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported the resolution on the situation in northern Iraq and Mosul, which aims to ensure that all parties to the conflict comply with international humanitarian law.It is important to ensure that civilians have access to medical care and humanitarian aid, and to enable them to safely leave conflict territories.There is a constant conflict in Mosul between the government of Iraq and its allies and the Islamic State occupying the area since 2014.I voted in favor of the resolution because I believe that measures should be taken as soon as possible to improve the situation of Iraqi citizens, including those currently in refugee camps.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union must be a catalyst in promoting peace and security. I support this report as our absolute priority must be that of protecting all civilians and ensuring that their lives are safeguarded from heavy gunfire and bombs. I fully support this report as action needs to be taken and we must use all available mechanisms to help all in need.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing.- This resolution follows the conquest by the jihadist group "Islamic State" of Mosul, and the Iraqi operation to liberate the city.The resolution urges the Iraqi authorities to take the necessary measures to protect civilians and public service buildings.The resolution also denounces the crimes against humanity perpetrated by ISIS against Iraqi minorities, in particular Christian minorities, and calls on the International Criminal Court to rule on the matter.Considering that the protection of civilians and stabilization, supported by the European Union, are the priorities of the Iraqi military forces, I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the resolution on the situation in northern Iraq and Mosul.The “Islamic State” group is engaged in a veritable massacre of Christians, Yazidis and other ethnic and religious minorities.These atrocities perpetrated in Iraq include war crimes, crimes against humanity whose horror is unspeakable.I call on the Member States of the European Union to deploy their efforts so that the International Criminal Court can be seized and try these crimes committed, in particular, in Iraq, Syria and Libya by the Islamic State.We must continue to intensify our efforts to protect Christians in the East in particular.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution to support the Iraqi operation to liberate Mosul from the hands of the Islamic State group. This operation is being carried out jointly with the forces of the Kurdish peshmerga and the international coalition. It turns out, in my opinion, essential to liberate this city in which the “Islamic State” group has been engaged in atrocities and genocide against Christians, Yazidis and other ethnic and religious minorities since 2014. However, we must be very cautious as 1.5 million people are at imminent risk of displacement as a direct consequence of this military intervention. It is therefore urgent that all parties to the conflict open humanitarian aid corridors and guarantee assistance. All necessary measures must be taken to protect civilians! However, I believe our mission will not end there. Once this city is taken over, EU member states will have to step up efforts to stabilize the liberated areas. Given the historical ethno-religious diversity of Northern Iraq, the international community will have to support the establishment of a sustainable and inclusive structure after the conflict with greater autonomy for the regions of the Nineveh Plain, Sinjar and Tal Afar.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: in writing. - The armed conflicts in Syria and Iraq represent a challenge for the world and for Europe. The war disrupts the game of alliances in the Middle East and has repercussions as far as Europe, overwhelmed by the influx of civilians fleeing the violence. It is essential to fight against the group "Islamic State" (IS) in order to reduce the terror. Iraqi and Kurdish forces have launched a massive ground operation to retake Iraq's second city, Mosul, from ISIS since 2014. This offensive must be accompanied by humanitarian support. According to UNHCR, 1.5 million residents are at imminent risk of displacement linked to the ongoing operation. There is an urgent need to open and secure camps to accommodate them. Humanitarian corridors must be established to channel needed aid from neighboring countries. The Union must also intervene at political level. Reconstruction, stabilization and security for all local communities must be supported through enhanced dialogue between Iraq and the countries of the region.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing.- This is the comment of the European Parliament on the battle of Mosul where the Iraqi army, supported by the international coalition, intends to defeat the group "Islamic State" and various jihadist militias.The various resolutions on the subject are texts of a humanitarian nature.The joint resolution, like all those of the political groups, with the exception of that of the ECR group, criticizes humanitarian action to invoke an international role for the EU from which it cannot benefit.In addition to the fact that this would violate the sovereignty of states, it would have the effect of increasing their contributions.Also, I preferred to abstain.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: In written form. - I supported the resolution on the situation in northern Iraq / Mosul, as I believe that the European Union suffers the most from the conflict there, which is flooded with hundreds of thousands of illegal refugees, many of whom are not Iraqis or Syrians at all. The resolution calls on all parties to the conflict to respect international humanitarian law and to ensure that civilians are protected, have the opportunity to leave areas affected by violence and war safely, and that they have unhindered access to health services and humanitarian aid.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing.- We are voting against the joint motion for a resolution.Aside from the fact that no resolution even suggests Turkey's destabilizing role, the attempt to impose the creation of autonomous states within the Republic of Iraq is more than unacceptable interference within a sovereign country and serves Turkey's plans.Of course, we support and want the Islamic Caliphate to be overthrown as soon as possible.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing.- According to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), more than 1.5 million people are at imminent risk of displacement in Mosul, as a direct consequence of the operation to regain this area.So far, the EU has provided 134 million euros in humanitarian aid to Iraq, 50 million of which to Mosul.I believe it is important to redouble efforts to stabilize the liberated areas.I strongly condemn the violence and mass executions that continue to be perpetrated by IS in Iraq and the “draconian regime” that it imposed in Mosul, calling for full respect for the rights of the different ethnic and religious minorities in the country, in particular the Yazidis, theChaldeans / Syriacs / Assyrians and Turkmen.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Abstention on the joint resolution: this one, like all the resolutions of the political groups (with the exception of that of the ECR group), critically uses humanitarian action to demand an international role for the EU which it does notwould know how to claim and demand moreover additional means which will be requested from the States.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution does not contextualize the instability that Iraq has experienced since the country was invaded in 2003, in violation of international law, nor the responsibilities that the US and the EU have in destroying and destabilizing the country. Under the supposed fight against the Islamic State, Iraq's territorial integrity and sovereignty have been violated, and the crisis that the country is experiencing, of conflict between different ethnicities, of interference and of external interference in the country, in fact compromise its independence and sovereignty. Also mention the role of Turkey in Iraq in defending its political, economic and geostrategic interests. We also note that when Mosul has been under occupation for two years, without any kind of initiative to free it, it is at this precise moment that a city that plays a role in the Syrian conflict is moving forward. What could it do to link an alleged humanitarian intervention to military objectives related to the Syrian conflict?

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- I vote in favor of the resolution that supports Iraq's operation to free Mosul from Isis and condemns the real genocide against the Christian minority and all the other minorities in the territory that Isis is committing.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing.- I vote against the motions for resolutions on the situation in northern Iraq and Mosul as a whole, as apart from the fact that no resolution indicates even the destabilizing role of Turkey, the attempt to impose the creation of autonomous states within the Republic of Iraq is somethingmore than unacceptable interference in the interior of a sovereign country and serves Turkey's plans.Of course, I support and want the Islamic Caliphate to be overthrown as soon as possible.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The launch of the Mosul operation is crucial in the campaign to defeat Daesh. We must strongly support the Global Coalition against Daesh, which has played a major role in the preparation and conduct of this operation. The European Union is an important part of this coalition and, in these critical times, must stand firmly by the Iraqi authorities and the Iraqi people. During the Mosul campaign the protection of the civilian population must be prioritised. It is fundamentally important that international humanitarian law should be observed in full and that efforts are made to guarantee the protection of the civilian population. I strongly support the stabilisation process after military operations and the focus, in particular, on the removal of so-called IEDs (improvised explosive devices), which is a pre-condition for the return of internally displaced people.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the situation in northern Iraq and Mosul, as the liberation of Mosul is a decisive step for the future of Iraq. This resolution is a strong signal of the Union's support in the fight against Daesh, but also of a commitment to the reconstruction and stabilization of Iraq beyond this battle. We put forward the absolute priority of protecting civilians, of dealing with the humanitarian situation, in particular that of internally displaced persons, whose number will increase significantly further. The resolution also has the merit of emphasizing two priorities: on the one hand, the return of the displaced persons in Iraq, in particular minorities including Christians, on the other hand, the representation of these minorities within the new administration and their full political participation. On the return and reintegration of refugees and internally displaced persons, the stability of the country in the future and its ability to act as a bulwark against terrorist expansion in the region will depend. The European Union and its Member States must play a key role and prepare decisive support for the stabilization of northern Iraq today.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: written. - My vote corroborates the socialist commitment against international terrorism of Daesh, with the urgency of a rapid liberation of Mosul and its neighboring populations, with the least possible number of civilian victims and with the need to protect the most vulnerable in this crossfire . Said commitment does not mean support for a contest that violates international humanitarian law. At the socialist proposal, our call to the international coalition has been reinforced in the text to ensure the protection of civilians, the objective of military action, guarantee evacuation through humanitarian corridors, provide urgent humanitarian aid to the displaced and launch a Iraq's urgent reconstruction and development plan. We deeply regret that representatives in the European Parliament of Podemos, IU, EH BILDU, Alternativa Galega, NEC and EQUO did not join our call for the protection and end of terrorism. Once again, with their abstention, they leave thousands of people helpless. In this case, about a million and a half Iraqis who are being held in Mosul.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: written. - My vote shows the undeniable socialist commitment to the fight against international terrorism of Daesh, with the urgency of a rapid liberation of Mosul and the surrounding populations, with the least possible number of civilian victims and with the need to protect the most vulnerable In this crossfire I make it clear that we do not support a contest that breaks the rules of war, much less violates international humanitarian law. At the socialist proposal, our call to the International Coalition to put the protection of civilians as the focus of military action, to ensure evacuation through humanitarian corridors, to give urgent humanitarian aid to the displaced and to put in motion an urgent plan for the reconstruction and development of Iraq. We deeply regret that the representatives in the European Parliament of the parties of: PODEMOS, IU, EH BILDU, Galician Alternative, NEC and EQUO did not join our call for the protection and end of terrorism. Once again, with their abstention, they leave thousands of people helpless. In this case, almost 1.5 million Iraqis who are being held in Mosul.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing.- I fully supported the joint resolution of the political groups on the situation in Northern Iraq, in particular for the commitment required of Europe, the external action service and the entire international community to provide practical and diplomatic support for asustainable and inclusive post-war region.I believe it is particularly important to work to ensure that the indigenous peoples of the region are politically represented in an autonomous province, and this also to give a gesture of inclusion and attention to all ethnic and religious minorities, which are still largely displaced in the country.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the joint resolution of the European Parliament on the situation in northern Iraq in the Mosul area because I am baffled by the news coming from Mosul, which shows us a terrible reality, in which women and children are used as human shields and they suffer all kinds of atrocities, including the use of chemical weapons. I therefore hope that the Iraqi forces, the Kurdish army and the international coalition that fights Daesh will be able in the shortest possible time to free the city and stop these horrible war crimes and that those responsible can be brought to justice and serve their sins in international headquarters. These operations must take place as quickly as possible avoiding civilian casualties and protecting the most vulnerable, women and children. I also share the report's call to the need to guarantee a future of peace, freedom, religious and ethnic inclusion and mutual respect when the city is liberated from Daesh. It is absolutely necessary to avoid further tensions and vendettas of a religious nature, and to establish a real civil coexistence between the various ethnic groups and religions that populate Mosul. Only in this way will we be able to restore to Iraqi citizens, after so many years of wars, that peace and freedom to which they are entitled.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: written.- As a human rights expert in my group, I voted for the resolution on the situation in northern Iraq and Mosul.I welcome a joint, internationally coordinated fight against IS - precisely to guarantee the situation of Christians in the region and compliance with the fundamental right to religious freedom.I would particularly like to thank the Kurdish troops for their commitment and condemn reports that the Turkish President is claiming the city of Mosul for himself or Turkey.Any change to the existing borders in the border area of Turkey, Iraq and Syria is to be condemned by the EU and - as well as a possible reintroduction of the death penalty and repeated attacks on the democratic forces of Syria - to be sanctioned with an immediate termination of all EU accession negotiations.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: written.- While the military liberation of Mosul is currently taking place, it is important for the European Union to be aware of its international responsibility and to provide leading support for the reconstruction in Mosul and in all of Northern Iraq.It is particularly important to ensure the protection of minorities and to provide humanitarian aid.The European Union must influence the Iraqi government here so that the minorities living in Iraq (e.g. the Christian and Yazidi minorities) are granted more sovereignty and protection.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. - The deterioration of the situation in Iraq and the launch of military operations, complex but indispensable in our battle against the terrorist organization Daesh / ISIS, must be on the agenda of our European and national foreign policy agendas. And the attention on these issues is even more delicate if we consider the repercussions that these operations could have on Syria: if effective, within a few weeks, the military offensive in Iraq will push the ISIS militias to abandon Mosul and retreat. towards Syria. I voted in favor of this resolution precisely to reiterate this concept and express my full support for the report made today and the ultimate meaning of these events: to restore security to the international level and protect civilians forced to leave their homes and their homes cities, doing everything in our power to avert a situation of humanitarian crisis and preparing as best we can to guarantee assistance to the Iraqi population.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I support the struggle and preservation of the independence, integrity and sovereignty of the Iraqi people, as well as the self-determination of the peoples who suffer the greatest vulnerability in their territory.However, from a vision that advocates an active multilateralism and a peaceful resolution of conflicts, I oppose the introduction into the territory of military assistance as a protection measure for ethnic minorities in the conflict, which will only contribute to the generation ofmore tensions in the region.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion for a resolution which calls on all parties to abide by international humanitarian law, respecting the principles of proportionality and distinction, and to take all precautions to minimise casualties and ensure that civilians and civilian infrastructures are protected from bombing. The evidence of the war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by Daesh should be preserved in order to ensure the accountability of all perpetrators.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The European Union, the United Nations and the entire international community should continue to support the Iraqi Government sustainably with humanitarian and military assistance during the ongoing liberation operations across several regions of Iraq. Therefore,  the EUR 50 million in humanitarian assistance provided by the European Union to the region of Mosul, which is facing an extraordinary, unprecedented humanitarian disaster, is an important step towards the stability in the region.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: written. - My vote shows the undeniable socialist commitment to the fight against international terrorism of Daesh, with the urgency of a rapid liberation of Mosul and the surrounding populations, with the least possible number of civilian victims and with the need to protect the most vulnerable In this crossfire I make it clear that we do not support a contest that breaks the rules of war, much less violates international humanitarian law. At the socialist proposal, our call to the International Coalition to put the protection of civilians as the focus of military action, to ensure evacuation through humanitarian corridors, to give urgent humanitarian aid to the displaced and to put in motion an urgent plan for the reconstruction and development of Iraq. We deeply regret that the representatives in the European Parliament of the parties of: PODEMOS, IU, EH BILDU, Galician Alternative, NEC and EQUO did not join our call for the protection and end of terrorism. Once again, with their abstention, they leave thousands of people helpless. In this case, almost 1.5 million Iraqis who are being held in Mosul.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- The situation in northern Iraq and Mosul is very serious.The joint resolution, however, contains problematic points that do not allow us to vote in favor.Also, the role of Turkey in the region is not mentioned at all and in addition it does not contain any reference to the responsibilities of the USA and the EU member states for how we have reached this point.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I decry in the strongest terms the regime that ISIS has imposed on the citizens of Mosul and Northern Iraq. Equally I support the operation started by Iraq to liberate Mosul from ISIS. This operation is a decisive part of an ongoing, global effort to inflict a lasting defeat on ISIS once and for all. It is also imperative that all parties to the conflict abide by international humanitarian law during and after hostilities and, in the conflict, to abide by the principles of proportionality, distinction and precaution.

name: Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: written. - The military operation recently launched to liberate the city of Mosul is an important step in ending IS / Daesh's heinous abuses in the region. Together with the international coalition against IS / Daesh, it is the Iraqi government that bears the main responsibility for the military action. We Swedish Social Democrats support the operation and want to emphasize the importance of it being carried out in strict accordance with international humanitarian law and international human rights law. Paragraph 17 of the resolution calls on EU Member States to include local security forces in the list of forces entitled to receive assistance. Since the paragraph does not specify the type of help to be included, we chose to refrain from this writing.
