It is of the utmost importance that all civilians, regardless of religious affiliation, are protected and do not become targets in these battles, but it must be the Iraqi authorities, with the support of the EU and the international community, who are responsible for this.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: written.- IS has been occupying Iraqi Mosul for two and a half years.The area is currently being retaken by the Iraqi army, Kurdish Peshmerga, allied militias with the support of the US armed forces and other allies.Thousands of civilians have already left the embattled area.The UN reports on massacres perpetrated by IS on the civilian population.This is where the resolution picks up.It calls on all parties to the conflict to abide by international humanitarian law and to ensure that civilians are protected, have unhindered access to medical care and humanitarian aid and can safely leave disputed areas.It goes without saying that I support these humanitarian values and that is why I voted for the resolution.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the Iraqi army’s offensive to liberate Mosul from Daesh, as well as any anti-Daesh coalitions working towards the same end. Iraq is, and should be treated as, a sovereign state that must have full territorial integrity.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the situation in northern Iraq / Mosul, given the need to support the efforts of the joint forces fighting to liberate Mosul, Iraq's second largest guard from ISIS, as well as efforts to avoid civilian casualties.Mosul is an important milestone in the liberation of Iraq and the reintegration of the country.Regional, ethnic, religious and other specificities should be taken into account and, through the decentralization of the country, guaranteeing the return of evicted communities (especially indigenous ones) and securing their rights, create conditions for its reintegration and survival.Of course, before that the only precondition is the liberation of the country.The EU needs to play an important active role in the process of restoring peace and the future establishment of the country's independence and integrity, which has a major impact on the stability of the Middle East.The EU should play an active role in the necessary humanitarian efforts facing the UN, lacking the necessary resources.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution mainly focuses on humanitarian considerations, which are rather sensitive in essence, but gives the European Union a diplomatic role that it should not have.I therefore abstained.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In reaction to recently started operation to liberate the city of Mosul in Northern Iraq from so-called ISIS/Daesh and extremely worrying humanitarian situation in the territory, I voted in favour of this resolution. It urges the European Union, United Nations and the whole international community to continue to support sustainably the Iraqi Government with humanitarian and military assistance. The Republic of Iraq has the right to defend its sovereign territory and the European Union should support it in the fight against ISIS/Daesh. The long-term aim must be then the reintegration of all Iraqis including all ethnic and religious displaced minorities.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Lars Adaktusson on the situation in northern Iraq and Mosul.With this vote, we are supporting the Iraqi authorities to take all necessary measures to protect civilians and free Mosul from Daesh terrorists.In this perspective, the European Union has provided Iraq with 134 million euros in humanitarian aid and 50 million euros for Mosul.Therefore, it is more than ever necessary to maintain our efforts to stabilize this region.I am delighted that this report was adopted by a large majority.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written.- I would vote in favor of this joint motion for a resolution.The horror that the so-called “Islamic State” has wrought must end and the terrorist movement and its supporters must be fought.The member states are called upon to cooperate with the Iraqi government and local security forces - especially those who have protected minorities from the IS anomalies.In addition, the demand to prevent the further spread of Islamist-jihadist ideology and Salafist jihadism and to bring their henchmen before the international criminal court is worthy of support.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution which fully supports the Iraqi Government and international anti-Daesh coalition’s actions in Iraq directed at the liberation of Mosul. It also insists that in the process of this operation, international humanitarian law has to be respected.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The situation in northern Iraq is very dramatic. On the one hand, there has been, for quite some time, a stabilized autonomous territory of the Kurds, on the other hand, to the south and southwest of this territory, in places where the core of ancient Assyria used to be, in the majority Sunni part of Iraq, where she lived in the past. very diverse communities, then there is only chaos. The failure to reach a new agreement on the formation of a new government after the last elections in Iraq has created a power vacuum, and the Islamic State has taken advantage of this. The disbanded army of the former Iraqi regime has become a rich reservoir of trained military forces. The bloody repression of the Sunni part of Iraq was just another spark. The disbanded Iraqi army evacuated Mosul and the central part of the country virtually without a fight. She left weapons, ammunition and practically undamaged office buildings and documents on the spot, as well as money in bank buildings. The Yazidis and Christians have found themselves in a critical situation, with forced conversion, kidnappings, and the slavery of women and children threatening the very existence of these communities. Thanks to the intervention of the USA and the Allies, the existence of the entire community has been threatened by a relatively advanced Iraqi functional state. It is also the fault of the EU and it is high time to intervene effectively, otherwise we remain complicit.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: written.- IS has been occupying Iraqi Mosul for two and a half years.The Iraqi army, Kurdish Peshmerga, allied militias with the support of the armed forces of the United States of America and other allies are currently retaking the area.Thousands of civilians have already left the embattled area.The United Nations reports of massacres perpetrated by IS on the civilian population.This is where the resolution picks up.It calls on all parties to the conflict to abide by international humanitarian law and to ensure that civilians are protected, have unhindered access to medical care and humanitarian aid and can safely leave disputed areas.It goes without saying that I support these humanitarian values and that is why I voted for the resolution.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on this resolution.Certainly, it has the merit of supporting the Iraqi forces against the Islamist militias.But she tries to give a diplomatic role to the EU when I believe that diplomacy must remain the prerogative of states.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on the resolution on the situation in northern Iraq and Mosul.This situation is indeed very worrying.While the text rightly raises humanitarian issues, it attributes a diplomatic role to the European Union to which it cannot claim.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: written. - My vote shows the undeniable socialist commitment to the fight against international terrorism of Daesh, with the urgency of a rapid liberation of Mosul and the surrounding populations, with the least possible number of civilian victims and with the need to protect the most vulnerable In this crossfire I make it clear that we do not support a contest that breaks the rules of war, much less violates international humanitarian law. At the socialist proposal, our call to the International Coalition to put the protection of civilians as the focus of military action, to ensure evacuation through humanitarian corridors, to give urgent humanitarian aid to the displaced and to start up an urgent plan for the reconstruction and development of Iraq. We deeply regret that the representatives in the European Parliament of the parties of: PODEMOS, IU, EH BILDU, Galician Alternative, NEC and EQUO did not join our call for the protection and end of terrorism. Once again, with their abstention, they leave thousands of people helpless. In this case, almost 1.5 million Iraqis who are being held in Mosul.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: written. - My vote shows the undeniable socialist commitment to the fight against international terrorism of Daesh, with the urgency of a rapid liberation of Mosul and the surrounding populations, with the least possible number of civilian victims and with the need to protect the most vulnerable In this crossfire I make it clear that we do not support a contest that breaks the rules of war, much less violates international humanitarian law. At the socialist proposal, our call to the International Coalition to put the protection of civilians as the focus of military action, to ensure evacuation through humanitarian corridors, to give urgent humanitarian aid to the displaced and to put in motion an urgent plan for the reconstruction and development of Iraq. We deeply regret that the representatives in the European Parliament of the parties of: PODEMOS, IU, EH BILDU, Galician Alternative, NEC and EQUO did not join our call for the protection and end of terrorism. Once again, with their abstention, they leave thousands of people helpless. In this case, almost 1.5 million Iraqis who are being held in Mosul.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have abstained, because there are many elements that currently concern us in the offensive on Mosul: that in order to destroy Daesh, humanitarian law should be left aside; the constant misinformation of what is going on in Mosul; or Turkey's role in the entire conflict, including its invasion of Iraqi territory, and the corridor through which they allow terrorists to flee to Syria and attack Kurdish and Syrian forces; we are concerned about the proposal to arm the local militias, which will aggravate the situation, as long as we do not provide sufficient funds to UNHCR, an organization that helps refugees. In the final vote, I abstained considering that although I disagree on many things, the resolution had some positive element, such as expressing concern about the recent tensions between regional actors, and calling for the territorial integrity and integrity to be fully respected. the sovereignty of Iraq and refrain from undertaking any military action in Iraq without the consent of the Iraqi Government, underlining the importance of fostering dialogue between Iraq and the countries of the region in order to achieve a more secure Middle East.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: written.- IS has been occupying Iraqi Mosul for two and a half years.The area is currently being retaken by the Iraqi army, Kurdish Peshmerga, allied militias with the support of the US armed forces and other allies.Thousands of civilians have already left the embattled area.The UN reports on massacres perpetrated by IS on the civilian population.This is where the resolution picks up.It calls on all parties to the conflict to abide by international humanitarian law and to ensure that civilians are protected, have unhindered access to medical care and humanitarian aid and can safely leave the contested areas.It goes without saying that I support these humanitarian values and that is why I voted for the resolution.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I stayed.The resolution welcomes Iraq's operation against the Islamic State on its territory (Mosul), condemns the violence by the Islamic State.In my opinion, the resolution will not help, but it does not contain anything that I would not agree with.That's why I stayed.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written.- The Iraqi army, with the support of the global coalition to fight ISIS / Daesh and his associates, has launched an operation to liberate Mosul and its environs.In the wider region, the homes of Christians and other peoples have been displaced, living for centuries in the spirit of general pluralism, stability and communal cooperation.ISIS / Daesh in Mosul imposed a draconian regime.They are increasingly committing war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.Today, the number of Christians in Iraq has plummeted from more than 1.5 million in 2003 to 200,000 to 350,000, many of whom live in poverty and insecurity.The EU and its members must work to build prospects for all those who have been forced to leave their homeland and those whose lives are at stake.It is necessary to provide protection and assistance to all targets of ISIS and other terrorist organizations in the Middle East.I therefore supported this Resolution.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing.- Military operations in the Iraqi city of Mosul must be conducted in accordance with international humanitarian law.There are one and a half million civilians in Mosul who need to provide basic food and necessities.Therefore, all participants in operations should focus on helping and protecting these people.Suppressing terrorists in Iraq is a priority that takes precedence over any settlement of territorial claims.At the same time, Iraq must respect the rights of ethnic, religious and national minorities in its territory.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in northern Iraq / Mosul, because it is complete and well-founded.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained for this text.The city of Mosul had been under Daesh control since 2014. This motion for a resolution constitutes a comment by the European Parliament on the recent efforts of the Iraqi army, supported by the international coalition, to reclaim the city.This text, of a humanitarian nature, is fairly balanced.On the other hand, we are opposed to the EU using humanitarian action to, on the one hand, justify its international role, and, on the other hand, to justify requests for additional resources from the Member States.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution calling on all parties to the conflict in northern Iraq, in particular Mosul, to respect international humanitarian law.It is imperative that all parties to the conflict open humanitarian corridors to allow civilians to escape and not be trapped in Mosul, preventing them from being used as human shields.Equally important is ensuring the assistance and protection of civilians during the security screening process.Among other things, it is necessary for all parties fighting ISIL / Daesh in the Republic of Iraq to develop sustainable, inclusive and long-term political cooperation and dialogue, in order to serve as the basis for an Iraq free of radical movements.and extremists.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: written.- This motion for a resolution welcomes the liberation of Mosul.The indigenous communities have a right to security and regional autonomy within the federal structure of the Republic of Iraq.The mass executions by IS are also condemned and the evidence of any war crimes is to be documented.I therefore voted in favor of this motion for a resolution.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the EP resolution on the situation in northern Iraq (Mosul).2016October 17a military raid was launched to recapture the city of Mosul from terrorist Islamic State (IS) forces.This city has been controlled by IS since 2014.summer, it imprisoned about a million civilians.The city of Mosul is the last largest IS-occupied city in Iraq.The EP urges the Iraqi Government to facilitate the return of refugees and internally displaced persons and the full restoration of their fundamental rights, including property rights.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The resolution rightly denounces the abuses committed by the "Islamic State" group in Iraq and more particularly in Mosul. The resolution "strongly supports the operation launched by Iraq to liberate Mosul from the Islamic State group" while at the same time the EU condemns the operations to liberate East Aleppo from the yoke of the jihadists. The resolution naively believes that "this operation constitutes a decisive element of an ongoing global effort aimed at inflicting a lasting defeat on the group" Islamic State "" while it is already observed that some members Daesh are retreating to the town of Rakka, which only shifts the problem to Syria. Finally, the resolution ignores the heterogeneous nature of the coalition, which itself poses threats to the civilian population, mostly Sunni, in particular from the Shiite militiamen of the Popular Mobilization Forces or Hachd al-Chaabi. I vote in favor, denouncing the asymmetry of the assessment of the treatment of military operations in the Middle East and its purely propagandist character.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing.- The Iraqi army, with the support of the international coalition against ISIL / Daesh and the Peshmerga forces of the Kurdish Regional Government (GRC) and the Popular Mobilization Forces, launched an operation to free Mosul, the second largest city in Iraq, and manycities and villages located in the EIIL / Daesh.0020 «Mosul corridor».I am in favor of the operation launched by Iraq with a view to liberating Mosul from ISIL / Daesh, this operation constitutes a decisive element of an ongoing global effort to inflict a lasting defeat on the Islamic State.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this cross-party resolution, which expresses Parliament’s support for the operation to liberate Mosul from the forces of the so-called Islamic State. Whilst the recent reports of civilians being taken hostage to be used as human shields are consistent with tactics used by ISIS in the past, they are nonetheless horrific and efforts must be taken to limit the loss of life.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. - By voting in favor of the resolution on the situation in northern Iraq and Mosul, we are once again showing the continued and determined support of the European Union to the Iraqi authorities in their fight against the "Islamic State" and to the Iraqi populations who are victims of serious human rights violations. Our concern is to urge all those involved in this struggle to inflict a lasting defeat on Daesh. As the ICRC says, people have the right to flee and seek safety just as they have the right to recover their property and to be protected in accordance with humanitarian and international law. For the Iraqi authorities, it is a question of ensuring respect for human rights for any individual, any minority whatever their religion, by helping them to flee the city, by ensuring sufficient protection of infrastructures, hospitals and schools. The European Union must use all its political and diplomatic influence so that the International Criminal Court can try members of the Islamic State group for war crimes and crimes against humanity.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing.- A motion for a resolution has been tabled by the ECR, EFDD, S&D, GUE / NGL, ALDE, PPE and Verts / ALE groups.Of the seven groups, the first of the six mentioned agreements was reached and a joint compromise motion was drawn up.I voted in favor of the compromise proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - In view of the operation launched by Iraq with a view to liberating Mosul from ISIL / Daesh, which constitutes a decisive element of a global effort to inflict a lasting defeat on the Islamic State, it is essential to fully respect Iraq's territorial integrity and sovereignty. I argue that the Iraqi authorities should take concrete measures to protect the civilian population during the campaign, notably through effective command and control of the militias and taking all necessary precautions to prevent civilian casualties and human rights violations during the offensive and that forces in the must respect international humanitarian law and human rights. It is vital to ensure safety in a timely and effective manner, through routes. I call on the European Union, the United Nations and the entire international community to collaborate with the national government and the regional governments of the Republic of Iraq, to ​​oversee the reintegration of all Iraqis and ethnic and religious minorities who have been displaced. I endorse the rapporteur in calling on the EEAS, Member States and the international community to give practical and diplomatic support to a sustainable and inclusive post-conflict structure for this region.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text relating to the situation in northern Iraq and Mosul, which supports the action being taken at this very moment to liberate this city in which the Islamist barbarians have proclaimed the Caliphate and inwhich they continue to carry out mass abuses every day.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution regarding the operation to liberate the town of Mosul in northern Iraq, reaffirming the EU’s strong support for Iraq’s independence, territorial integrity and sovereignty.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution because I believe it is very important at this time to support the Iraqi military's military operations against Daesh.The struggles for the recapture of the city of Santa Claus are very heavy, as we can see from the images transmitted by the sources on the spot, and will probably continue for a longer period.At the same time, all necessary steps must be taken to protect civilians in the city and those who have managed to escape Daesh control.I believe that the EU and the international community must continue to support Iraq in this fight and increase its financial support for UN efforts to protect civilians.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the resolution in response to the launch of the operation to liberate Mosul, Iraq's second largest city, and many towns and villages located in the so-called Mosul corridor from ISIS.Maximum support must be given to all units involved in the operation to liberate Mosul, namely the Kurdish Peshmerga, the Iraqi army and the Shiite militias, and to call for their united and coordinated approach, taking into account the civilian population.Following the liberation, negotiations with the Kurdistan Regional Government and the Iraqi Government must ensure that ethnic minorities in the region, in particular Christians (Chaldeans, Syrians and Assyrians) and Yazidis and Turkmen, are granted legitimate rights and incorporated into the new administrative structure,thus preventing the outbreak of new conflicts.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I spoke out in favor of this report because action must be taken against further spreads of Islamic jihadist ideology and Salafist jihadism.The member states should ensure that the crimes of the Islamic State in Iraq, Libya, Syria and other countries are brought before the International Criminal Court;I can only support this.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported.It is important to release Mosul and other areas in the hands of ISIS from ISIS.At the same time, the Iraqi authorities must take steps to protect civilians during the attacks and comply with international humanitarian and human rights law.Care must be taken not to persecute ethnic minorities, to ensure adequate humanitarian aid, the ability to clear the country of improvised explosive devices, and so on.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - Mosul is a decisive step forward in our quest to defeat Daesh. Our absolute priority is the protection of civilians. We must ensure that they do not remain trapped in Mosul by gunfire and bombings and that they are not used as human shields by Daesh. We call on all parties to respect international humanitarian law, the principles of proportionality and discrimination, to take all precautionary measures to minimize losses and to ensure that civilians, schools and hospitals are protected from bombing. I would also like to express my full support for a sovereign and independent Iraq. This will be done through further humanitarian assistance and the restoration of the rule of law and its basic services, such as health care, education and the guarantee of the safe return and reintegration of refugees and internally displaced persons, and the protection of vulnerable minorities. and the political participation of all ethnic and religious minorities. I firmly believe that negotiations on the future of Mosul should include all religious minorities. We urgently need concrete measures to protect civilians, including protection zones and humanitarian corridors.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament resolution defiantly defends the imperialist war waged by the EU and its US and NATO allies in the wider Middle East, focusing on Syria and Iraq in the face of fierce competition from other powers, such as Russia. The KKE had warned that the "EU global strategy", the Euromilitary, the enhanced EU-NATO operational alliance, the NATO presence in the Aegean were a harbinger of new imperialist wars against the peoples. No matter how many crocodile tears the EU-US-NATO shed for the victims, the refugees, no matter how many declarations of peace they make, their dirty role in Syria and Iraq is obvious. They are now opening a new front in Mosul, slaughtering peoples for their energy rivalry with Russia. The jihadists are the convenient pretext for their interventions in the area. Turkey is also invading Syria and Iraq undisturbed, indulging in a barrage of provocative violations, arson and unhistorical statements, such as those of Erdogan, who challenge international treaties and Greek sovereign rights, who systematically pretend that the US and the EU do not listen. NATO. The dangerous imperialist plans, in which the SYRIZA-ANEL government is actively involved, can be ruined by the peoples, by their struggle against monopolies and capitalism, their real enemies.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. We are pleased to see the successful assault on Mosul and the further dislodgement of ISIS strongholds in Iraq. Appropriate measures must be taken to prevent a further wave of migrants and refugees taking the dangerous routes into Europe. However, the report contains several calls for EU action, which we cannot support.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing.- The Iraqi army, with the support of the Global Anti-ISIS / Daesh Coalition, the Peshmerga forces of the Kurdish regional government and the popular mobilization forces has given way to the operation to free Mosul from ISIS control.Considering that the necessary security conditions should be guaranteed to all the people who have been forced to abandon their lands of origin and, also to guarantee their safety, given, therefore, the relevance of the proposal under consideration, I would like to comment positively.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - Building a stable and secure environment is not only necessary in the city of Mosul, but in the wider area around that big city. The protection of civilians must be a priority, not only of the forces fighting for the liberation of the city, but also of all other actors involved in the operation non-combatantly. It is necessary to ensure that no revenge campaign is launched against those who remained in the city even during the terrorist occupation and control of the city. The European Union must insist on the consistent implementation of international humanitarian law and ensure that there is full protection for all religious and ethnic minorities in Mosul in order to avoid the potential persecution already perpetrated against Christians in this area. It is necessary to establish safe zones and evacuation corridors for the civilian population as well as timely inform the citizens of Mosul about the planned activities. Following the operation, the Iraqi government, the EU and coalition forces must work to restore normal life, stabilize and organize the city, and reduce radicalization. I am of the opinion that it is necessary to enable Christians to govern themselves in Nineveh and that the EU urgently needs to sever all trade relations with those who finance ISIS.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Union must offer all its support for the efforts that the Iraqi-led coalition is making for the liberation of Mosul and, at the same time, must do everything possible to alleviate the humanitarian crisis affecting local populations, in particular ethnic and religious minorities. For centuries these communities have coexisted peacefully, in a general climate of pluralism and cooperation. The ISIS / Daesh occupation of the city of Mosul and the provinces of Nineveh, Tal Afar and Sinjar has caused unspeakable suffering for the inhabitants, victims of crimes against humanity and genuine genocides. Europe, which supports the anti-ISIS / Daesh coalition and wants to see those responsible for these crimes judged and punished, also appeals to the Iraqi authorities to take all necessary measures to protect civilians during the campaign, especially women, the elderly and children. EU support will also be crucial after the reconquest of Mosul and the surrounding region. Its help in terms of skills and economic resources will be indispensable in the reconstruction of an inclusive and sustainable Iraq, which guarantees participation and fundamental rights to each community and to each individual citizen.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - The Iraqi army, with the support of the global anti-Da'esh coalition and local forces, has launched an operation to liberate Mosul, which is an important step towards the final defeat of Da'esh. I fully support the moves by Iraq that are necessary to preserve independence and territorial integrity. I call on all parties to the conflict to respect international humanitarian law during and after the fighting and to keep humanitarian corridors open - to send aid to those civilians fleeing violence. I stress the need to take all precautions to avoid civilian casualties during the bombing, as well as the destruction of civilian infrastructure. I call on the EU and its Member States to help the Iraqi and Kurdish authorities to establish security and rebuild the liberated territories - we want safe homes to which the peoples of Iraq can return and start building a new future. It is necessary to provide basic services and security to the population and to define a long-term strategy for dealing with the reasons for the collapse of social cohesion and the emergence of radical currents. The EU must support the stabilization, resilience and development of Iraq. It is important to enable political participation for minorities in and around Mosul. Peaceful coexistence and respect for the rights of minorities, overcoming hatred and division are the only right path for the country. I emphasize that the fight against the Da'esh, the Al-Nusra Front and other terrorist organizations on the Security Council's list remains a priority in Iraq and Syria. The region needs peace as soon as possible.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The Resolution does not contextualize the instability that Iraq has experienced since the country was invaded in 2003, in violation of international law, nor the responsibilities that the US and the EU have in destroying and destabilizing the country. Under the supposed fight against the Islamic State, Iraq's territorial integrity and sovereignty have been violated, and the crisis that the country is experiencing, of conflict between different ethnicities, of interference and of external interference in the country, in fact compromise its independence and sovereignty. Also mention the role of Turkey in Iraq in defending its political, economic and geostrategic interests. We also note that when Mosul has been under occupation for two years, without any kind of initiative to free it, it is at this precise moment that a city that plays a role in the Syrian conflict is moving forward. What could it do to link an alleged humanitarian intervention to military objectives related to the Syrian conflict?

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Iraqi army, backed by Western and Arab allies, recently launched a long-awaited offensive to free Mosul from ISIS (Daesh) fighters. This event is part of an ongoing global effort to permanently defeat ISIS. The European Union fully supports Iraq's independence, territorial integrity and sovereignty, as well as its right to preserve all these attributes. I fully agree with the resolution, which also calls on all parties to the conflict to respect international humanitarian law during and after hostilities. In particular, it is essential that civilians are not endangered by getting stuck right in the middle of the fighting. That is why I join the call for all parties to the conflict to open humanitarian corridors. From my point of view, however, it is also important to start dealing with the situation that will arise after the defeat of ISIS. It is necessary to prevent a vacuum in the country after the end of the fighting. From this point of view, I consider it important to maintain full support for the current Iraqi Government and to step up our assistance in rebuilding the country.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the operation of Iraqi forces to liberate the city of Mosul from the grip of the so-called Islamic State group.The presence of jihadists dispersed in the region, from Iraq to Syria, threatens the stability sought in the area.It is especially civilians and minorities (Christians and Yazidis in particular) who are the victims of Daesh's atrocities.We must fight with the greatest force against these barbarians, eradicate their presence and restore to the populations the simple right to live in peace.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. - The situation currently experienced in Mosul is very worrying. According to reports by inhabitants who managed to escape from there, the regime imposed by ISIS brought hunger, terror and despair to residents of this Iraqi city. Mosul is a multi-ethnic city, where a majority of Sunni Arabs live side by side with Chaldeans / Syriac / Assyrians, Kurds, Yazidis, Shabaks, Kaka'is and Turkmen (Shiites and Sunnis), thus the presence of ISIS, which proudly commits crimes genocide against ethnic and religious minorities in that territory, a criminal act in itself. I support the operation launched by Iraq with a view to liberating Mosul from ISIS; believing that this operation constitutes an important element of a global effort to inflict a lasting defeat on ISIS. In addition to the release of Mosul, it is essential to ensure the restoration of the rule of law and basic services, such as health care, electricity and education, in the liberated areas, as well as ensuring humanitarian aid and security in that territory. I strongly condemn the violence and mass executions that continue to be perpetrated by ISIS and this time, I support this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. We are pleased to see the successful assault on Mosul and the further dislodgement of ISIS strongholds in Iraq. Appropriate measures must be taken to prevent a further wave of migrants and refugees taking the dangerous routes into Europe. However, the report contains several calls for EU action, which we cannot support.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor, since the Daesh imposed a draconian regime in Mosul and that, according to reports by inhabitants who managed to escape recently, the population is hungry and desperate to be released.Considering that Mosul is a multi-ethnic city, this resolution underlines the importance of Mosul for the whole of Iraq and calls for the representation of minorities in a new Mosul administration.Guaranteeing the legitimate right of ethnic and religious minorities to political participation and the restoration of their property rights as well as peaceful coexistence and full respect for the rights of different ethnic and religious minorities.The necessary security conditions must also be ensured for those who were forced to leave their homeland or to move, in order to make their right to return to their homeland effective as soon as possible.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written. - My vote shows the undeniable socialist commitment to the fight against international terrorism of Daesh, with the urgency of a rapid liberation of Mosul and the surrounding populations, with the least possible number of civilian victims and with the need to protect the most vulnerable In this crossfire I make it clear that we do not support a contest that breaks the rules of war, much less violates international humanitarian law. At the socialist proposal, our call to the International Coalition to put the protection of civilians as the focus of military action, to ensure evacuation through humanitarian corridors, to give urgent humanitarian aid to the displaced and to start up an urgent plan for the reconstruction and development of Iraq. We deeply regret that the representatives in the European Parliament of the parties of: PODEMOS, IU, EH BILDU, Galician Alternative, NEC and EQUO did not join our call for the protection and end of terrorism. Once again, with their abstention, they leave thousands of people helpless. In this case, almost 1.5 million Iraqis who are being held in Mosul.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing.- By voting in favor of this resolution, I wish to lend my support to the operation launched by Iraq to liberate Mosul from the Islamic State organization.Of course, it is crucial that the Iraqi authorities take all possible measures to protect the civilian population during these operations.In addition, and as stressed in this resolution, it is also important to be able to open humanitarian aid corridors in order to allow the civilian population to flee.Finally, I would like to express my deep disgust at the odious behavior of Daesh members who use the civilian population as human shields against military liberation operations.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- I welcome the resolution that has been drafted.We Europeans must pay due attention to the protection of human rights throughout the world.At the same time, I would like to draw colleagues' attention to the fact that Mosul and all of northern Iraq are still at the heart of the anti-terrorist operation at the moment.An operation that is not doing well so far, and it is already possible to talk about the fact that this ancient city will soon be freed from the control of the dark forces.Therefore, I think some of the wordings may be a little too strict, and support for the efforts of the Alliance coalition is not strong enough.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported this motion for a resolution that aims to support the operation launched by Iraq to free Mosul from the self-proclaimed Islamic State. This proposal urges the parties to the conflict to open humanitarian corridors with a view to assisting the civilian population and, at the same time, preventing it from being used as a human shield. The intention is to appeal once again to respect for the rights of the diverse ethnic and religious minorities present in Iraq, such as the Yazidis, a community to which the two women belong to which the European Parliament awarded the 2016 Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Expression this year. . This climate of violence and atrocious executions which, systematically and violently, continue to be perpetrated by the Islamic State must be the object of our deepest condemnation and strong condemnation, since it is a matter of committing crimes against children, women and the elderly, used usually as human shields against ongoing military operations. It is absolutely vital to stop this barbarism, which is the meaning of this resolution, by calling on the parties to the conflict to respect international humanitarian law and by advocating that these war crimes and crimes against humanity be properly prosecuted by the International Criminal Court.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution which gives European Parliament support for the Iraqi operation to free Mosul from the terrorist group "Islamic State". This terrorist organization uses children, the elderly, women and the vulnerable as shields against the military liberation operations carried out by Iraq, the Peshmerga and Kurdish forces; it is unacceptable. It is therefore crucial and urgent that the Iraqi authorities take all necessary measures to protect civilians, schools and hospitals. Faced with the systematic massacre of religious and ethnic minorities by the “Islamic State” group in Iraq, it is essential to act without delay against these abuses and to bring to justice those who are at the origin of such atrocities. In this sense, I supported this text which qualifies, once again, the systematic persecutions and executions of Christians, Yazidis and other minorities as genocide.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I support the struggle and preservation of the independence, integrity and sovereignty of the Iraqi people, as well as the self-determination of the peoples who suffer the greatest vulnerability in their territory.However, from a vision that advocates an active multilateralism and a peaceful resolution of conflicts, I oppose the introduction into the territory of military assistance as a protection measure for ethnic minorities in the conflict, which will only contribute to the generation ofmore tensions in the region.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have abstained, because there are many elements that currently concern us in the offensive on Mosul: that in order to destroy Daesh, humanitarian law should be left aside; the constant misinformation about what is happening in Mosul; o Turkey's role in the entire conflict, including its invasion of Iraqi territory, and the corridor through which they allow terrorists to flee to Syria and attack Kurdish and Syrian forces; we are concerned about the proposal to arm the local militias, which will aggravate the situation, as long as we do not provide sufficient funds to UNHCR, an organization that helps refugees. In the final vote, I abstained considering that although I disagree on many things, the resolution had some positive element, such as expressing concern about the recent tensions between regional actors, and calling for the territorial integrity and integrity to be fully respected. the sovereignty of Iraq and refrain from undertaking any military action in Iraq without the consent of the Iraqi Government, underlining the importance of fostering dialogue between Iraq and the countries of the region in order to achieve a more secure Middle East.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which calls on all parties to abide by international humanitarian law, to respect principles of proportionality and distinction, and to take all precautions to minimise casualties and ensure that civilians and civilian infrastructures (such as schools and hospitals) are protected from bombing. The evidence of the war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by Daesh should be preserved in order to ensure the accountability of all perpetrators.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - Mosul is the second largest city in Iraq. The media brings threatening footage daily from this city, where ISIS / Daesh has set up a harsh regime, where children, mothers and civilians are dying, where there is a risk of hunger and disease, so people living there are desperately waiting for liberation and humanitarian aid. UNHCR operates five camps around Mosul and is ready to shelter 45,000 people fleeing Mosul and surrounding areas, and plans to increase the number of camps to 11 in the coming weeks with a capacity for 120,000 people. For this reason, the EU provides € 134 million in humanitarian aid in Iraq, of which € 50 million in aid to Mosul. The EU expressed its support for Iraq's operation to liberate Mosul from ISIS / Daesh and considers it a crucial part of the ongoing global effort to permanently defeat ISIS / Daesh. At the same time, with the resolution, we recalled that saving civilian lives and respecting international humanitarian law are fundamental political preconditions for reconciliation and development and the only way to defeat hatred and division, and that it is very important not to incite further tensions between communities and lay the foundations for a stable and prosperous Iraq.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: written.- IS has been occupying Iraqi Mosul for two and a half years.The area is currently being retaken by the Iraqi army, Kurdish Peshmerga, allied militias with the support of the US armed forces and other allies.Thousands of civilians have already left the embattled area.The UN reports on massacres perpetrated by IS on the civilian population.This is where the resolution picks up.It calls on all parties to the conflict to abide by international humanitarian law and to ensure that civilians are protected, have unhindered access to medical care and humanitarian aid and can safely leave the contested areas.It goes without saying that I support these humanitarian values and that is why I voted for the resolution.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- In this context, it is important for the European Union to work with the Iraqi Government and the Kurdish Regional Government to reach a consensus on the city of Mosul and other disputed territories.The Iraqi government needs, first and foremost, to take concrete steps and measures to protect civilians and new legislation to protect minorities.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: written.- I approved the resolution of the EU Parliament of October 27, 2016 on the “Situation in Northern Iraq and Mosul”.I do not agree with every detail, but I share the basic tenor that the persecuted minorities, especially Christians, should enjoy protection.In particular, I support the overarching concern of the political decentralization of Iraq in order to give its diverse minorities extensive political autonomy.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in northern Iraq / Mosul.Residents of Mosul, Iraq’s second-largest city, are suffering from a brutal ISIS regime, starving and desperately waiting for liberation.I support the resolution, which strongly supports the operation to liberate Monsul, which will play a decisive role in the current global efforts to permanently defeat ISIS.In doing so, the resolution does not deprive Iraq of the right to take the measures necessary to preserve its independence, territorial integrity and sovereignty.The priority of the Iraqi government should be to exercise the right to return displaced indigenous peoples displaced throughout Iraq.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing.- Any attempt to resolve the tension-crisis in northern Iraq must be made with respect for the sovereign rights of the state and human rights.Particular emphasis should be placed on tackling Turkey's destabilization policy and actions in the region, as well as on the fight against Daesh.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution because I am convinced that the European Union cannot remain speechless in the face of one of the most serious international war situations and humanitarian crises in the region neighboring Europe.The report recalls the intolerable security and humanitarian situation in northern Iraq, especially in the wake of the siege of Mosul, the consequences of jihadist terror, genocide, and the systematic persecution of Yazidis, Christians and other religious and ethnic minorities.I hope that our strong parliamentary resolution will force the EEAS and the EU Member States, and the Union as a whole, as a global player, to take stronger and more concrete action.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. - The number of Christians in Iraq in 2003 was over 1.5 million, but has since dropped to 300,000, many of whom now live in poverty and a sense of constant danger. Parliament has classified ISIS 'activities in the area as genocide against Christians and Yazidis, as well as other religious and ethnic minorities that do not agree with the ISIS / Da'esh interpretation of Islam. The European Parliament resolution called on the EU and its Member States and the UN to work with the national and regional governments of the Republic of Iraq, as well as with all relevant national and international actors, to oversee the peaceful return to their homeland of indigenous peoples from the plain of Nineveh, Tal Afar and Sinjar . There was also a call to ensure the territorial integrity and security of the area. It is now imperative to step up efforts to address the humanitarian problems of the Iraqi people, especially children, the elderly, pregnant women and other vulnerable people. For if we ignore the situation in this area, the number of people killed and displaced may increase several times in the coming months.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - The terrorist phenomenon has seen new heights of cruelty and violence against civilians after the emergence and expansion of the Islamic State in the Middle East. This diabolical experiment is currently affecting the entire international community, including the Member States of the European Union. In response to this new threat, Member States have decided to support the efforts of the international coalition against the Islamic State, with the stated aim of removing this structure so unfavorable to the people of Syria and Iraq. In these circumstances, the European institutions can only welcome the launch of the offensive in northern Iraq, aimed at freeing the city of Mosul from the occupation of Islamic terrorists. This action will restore the Iraqi state's legal sovereignty over its territory, whose integrity the EU recognizes in terms of respect for the rights of ethnic and religious minorities, but also for the Kurdish Regional Government. However, this military intervention must take into account the regulations of international humanitarian law and human rights, in order to protect the civilian population. The current resolution correctly expresses the position of the EU and its citizens on the conflict in Iraq. That is why I support its immediate adoption.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. - With this vote, we take a firm stand for the operation launched by Iraq to liberate Mosul from the Islamic State group. I believe this operation is a critical part of an ongoing global effort to inflict a lasting defeat on the "Islamic State" group. I am convinced that Iraq will prevail in this struggle against a common enemy and liberate Mosul and other parts of the country from the presence of the "Islamic State" group. We reaffirm our full support for the independence, territorial integrity and sovereignty of Iraq, and for its right to take the necessary measures to preserve them. We are concerned about recent tensions between regional actors. We demand that the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Iraq be fully respected and that no military action be taken in Iraq without the consent of the Iraqi government. We stress the importance of fostering dialogue between Iraq and the countries of the region in order to build a more secure world in the Middle East.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The motion for a resolution on the situation of Northern Iraq/Mosul outlined the expected effects of the Global Coalition operation to liberate the Mosul region from ISIS forces. The operation, which is expected to begin before the end of 2016 will likely generate humanitarian consequences with regards to the re-integration of ethno-religious minorities back into the communities and overall their cohesion in the region. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, which outlines standards and laws to be followed by the Iraqi government as well as the international community during the process of rehabilitation and re-integration, in order to minimise the trauma and discourage another civil war. I believe that is the EU responsibility as promoter of the rule of law and human rights, to call on the UN and the international community, alongside EU forces, to work with national and regional governments in Iraq to oversee the reintegration of the Iraqis including the displaced ethnic and religious minorities.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. - Mosul is the second largest city in Iraq, occupied by ISIL in 2014, since when it has been considered the last major stronghold of militants. A major offensive operation (the "Battle of Mosul") is under way to liberate the city and surrounding territory by a joint force of the Iraqi government and allies, as well as limited US-backed US infantry forces. It is believed that there are still about 1.5 million civilians in Mosul along with about 5,000 ISIL militants. In the last 10 days, over 5,000 people have fled the conflict territory to a refugee camp across the border into Syria. They came to the al-Hol refugee camp, which is already crowded and where conditions are extremely poor. Current information is that another 1,000 refugees are waiting to cross the border and it is becoming increasingly certain that the world will soon face one of the biggest humanitarian crises of recent times. Therefore, I strongly support this European Parliament resolution calling on all parties to the conflict to respect international humanitarian law, to enable the protection of civilians and access to humanitarian and medical assistance, and to enable civilians to leave areas affected by violence safely and with dignity. Urgent and uncompromising humanitarian support from the European Union and the rest of the international community to the people of Iraq is now imperative.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the situation in northern Iraq / Mosul. The Iraqi army, with the support of the World Coalition to Fight ISIS / Daesh, the Peshmerga of the Kurdish regional government and the forces of the People's Mobilization paramilitary organization, launched an operation to liberate Mosul, Iraq's second largest city, and many towns and villages in the Mosul corridor. Daisha. ISIS / Daesh in Mosul has imposed a brutal regime, with residents who recently managed to escape the city reporting that people in the city are starving and desperately waiting for liberation. According to the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), about 3.3 million Iraqis have been forced to flee their homes due to the war since 2014. In Mosul, more than 1.5 million people are threatened with imminent displacement as a direct result of the operation to retake the area. Parliament supports the operation launched by Iraq to liberate Mosul from ISIS / Daesh control and considers that this operation plays a crucial role in the current global efforts to defeat ISIS / Daesh permanently. Even after the liberation of Mosul, it will be necessary to continue the fight against the further spread of Islamist-jihadist ideologies in this region and elsewhere, including Salafist jihadism, through which ISIS / Daesh theologically and politically incites to crime.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I support the struggle and preservation of the independence, integrity and sovereignty of the Iraqi people, as well as the self-determination of the peoples who suffer the greatest vulnerability in their territory.However, from a vision that advocates an active multilateralism and a peaceful resolution of conflicts, I oppose the introduction into the territory of military assistance as a protection measure for ethnic minorities in the conflict, which will only contribute to the generation ofmore tensions in the region.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing.- The Iraqi military, with the support of allied forces from Europe and the US, conducts Operation Conquest and Fatah against Islamic State fighters pushed to northern Iraq and the city of Mosul.During this operation, the fate of the people of Iraq deserves attention.In just a dozen or so days, 5,000 people fled the conflict zone, finding refuge in a refugee camp on the border with Syria.Another thousand people are waiting at the border.The international community must monitor developments in northern Iraq and Mosul.All parties to the conflict must respect international humanitarian law and guarantee the protection of civilians.I voted in favor of the resolution

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I support the struggle and preservation of the independence, integrity and sovereignty of the Iraqi people, as well as the self-determination of the peoples who suffer the greatest vulnerability in their territory.However, from a vision that advocates an active multilateralism and a peaceful resolution of conflicts, I oppose the introduction into the territory of military assistance as a measure of protection for ethnic minorities in the conflict, which will only contribute to the generation ofmore tensions in the region.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Motions for a resolution on the Situation in Northern Iraq/Mosul. The Resolution calls on Iraqi authorities to make every effort to protect civilians, hospitals and schools, as they progress towards Mosul. It underlines that Daesh atrocities and genocide against Christians, Yazidis and other minorities should be referred to International Criminal Court. The EU has provided EUR 134 million to date in humanitarian aid in Iraq, including EUR 50 million for Mosul where 1.5 million people are at imminent risk of displacement. The Resolution urges all parties to the conflict to open humanitarian aid corridors and guarantee assistance, and also suggests setting up a UN third-party monitoring mechanism. I voted in favour because I believe that it is of crucial importance to urge Iraqi authorities to protect civilians and prevent civilian casualties and human rights violations during the ongoing operation.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have abstained, because there are many elements that currently concern us in the offensive on Mosul: that in order to destroy Daesh, humanitarian law should be left aside; the constant misinformation about what is happening in Mosul; o Turkey's role in the entire conflict, including its invasion of Iraqi territory, and the corridor through which they allow terrorists to flee to Syria and attack Kurdish and Syrian forces; we are concerned about the proposal to arm the local militias, which will aggravate the situation, as long as we do not provide sufficient funds to UNHCR, an organization that helps refugees. In the final vote, I abstained considering that although I disagree on many things, the resolution had some positive element, such as expressing concern about the recent tensions between regional actors, and calling for the territorial integrity and integrity to be fully respected. the sovereignty of Iraq and refrain from undertaking any military action in Iraq without the consent of the Iraqi Government, underlining the importance of fostering dialogue between Iraq and the countries of the region in order to achieve a more secure Middle East.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: written. - The Iraqi army, backed by the international coalition against ISIS / Da'esh and the Peshmerga fighters of the Kurdish Regional Government and the Hashd al-Shaabi militias, has launched an offensive against Mosul, Iraq's second largest city. , and to recapture many towns and villages in the Mosul corridor from ISIS / Da'esh. The leader of ISIS is said to be hiding there. It is one of the last strongholds of the terror organization. The resolution urges the Government of Iraq and its international partners to give priority to finding peaceful solutions to conflicts across the internal borders of the Republic of Iraq. I supported this resolution because it urges the European Union, the United Nations and the entire international community to work with the national and regional governments of the Republic of Iraq to ensure the reintegration of all Iraqis and all displaced ethnic and religious minorities. The conflict must end and citizens must be able to return to humane situations.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- Mosul is a multi-ethnic city, where a majority Sunni Arab lives side by side with Chaldeans / Syriac / Assyrians, Kurds, Yazidis, Shabaks, Kaka'is and Turkmen (Shiites and Sunnis).The areas surrounding the city also have a history of ethnic-religious diversity, with a concentration of Christians on the Nineveh plain, Yazidis around the Sinjar mountains and Muslim Turkmen in Tal Afar.We follow the humanitarian concerns in the reports.However, these concerns are not without a good deal of cynicism.Because these minorities lived in peace before the criminal operations of the United States, NATO and the European Union that have now destabilized the entire region.We continue to believe that the only solution is to end support for the terrorist gangs that infest the region, giving rise to a political solution that respects international law.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- The report names important measures and requirements in the fight against the Islamic State.It stresses the need for decisive action against Islamist ideologies in the region and beyond, and calls on member states to ensure that the International Criminal Court deals with the crimes of ISIS.In this context, the Iraq-led military coalition is urged to take the necessary measures to ensure that evidence of the crimes committed by IS is preserved and that the perpetrators can be held accountable.I support this concern and have therefore approved the report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to join my colleagues in condemning the violence, persecution and crimes against humanity perpetrated by Daesh in Iraq and Syria. I also join in calling on the EU and its Member States to do whatever they can in order to provide assistance to Daesh’s victims, particularly women and girls, and call on the international community to work for the safety, wellbeing and human rights of ethnic minorities in Iraq.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution. This area is politically and militarily very instable at the moment, and this goes at the expense of the population in Iraq. ISIS imposed a draconian regime in Mosul and the inhabitants who managed to escape recently report that people are starving and desperate to be liberated. This situation goes against any human right, that’s why I stand behind this resolution. The necessary security conditions should be ensured for all those who have been forced to leave their homeland or have been forcibly displaced. I strongly condemn the ongoing violence and mass executions by ISIS/DAESH in Iraq, and that’s why we are trying to take any possible action to alleviate this situation.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing. - The situation in the Middle East has long been a matter of concern in terms of both regional and global security. I agree with the resolution supporting the operation in northern Iraq to liberate the city of Mosul from the domination of the terrorist organization Daesh. A key factor in the success of the operation will be the cooperation of a broad coalition led by the Iraqi army and in cooperation with the Kurdish Regional Government (KGR). However, we must not forget that, despite the state of war in the country, it is necessary to pay attention to human rights and freedoms and to prevent victims of the civilian population, including the destruction of public civilian facilities such as schools and hospitals. It is clear that Mosul is a strategically important city, the conquest of which can bring us closer to the complete defeat of Daesh. However, a military victory will not be enough to defeat this terrorist organization. It will be essential to create a sustainable and inclusive structure in the region after the end of military operations. This requires the diplomatic support of the international community, as well as the political representation of the autonomous provinces, including the Nineveh Plain, Sinjar and Tal Afar in the decision-making process. Humanitarian aid also needs to work with local churches and religious organizations. A clear priority for the subsequent stabilization of the situation in the region is to guarantee the territorial integrity of Iraq and respect for its borders.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament resolution defiantly defends the imperialist war waged by the EU and its US and NATO allies in the wider Middle East, focusing on Syria and Iraq in the face of fierce competition from other powers, such as Russia. The KKE had warned that the "EU global strategy", the Euro-army, the enhanced EU-NATO operational partnership, the NATO presence in the Aegean were a harbinger of new imperialist wars against the peoples. No matter how many crocodile tears the EU-US-NATO shed for the victims, the refugees, no matter how many declarations of peace they make, their dirty role in Syria and Iraq is obvious. They are now opening a new front in Mosul, slaughtering peoples for their energy rivalry with Russia. The jihadists are the convenient pretext for their interventions in the area. Turkey is also invading Syria and Iraq undisturbed, indulging in a barrage of provocative violations, arson and unhistorical statements, such as those of Erdogan, who challenge international treaties and Greek sovereign rights, who systematically pretend that the US and the EU do not listen. NATO. The dangerous imperialist plans, in which the SYRIZA-ANEL government is actively involved, can be ruined by the peoples, by their struggle against monopolies and capitalism, their real enemies.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported the resolution prepared by Parliament's Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) on the situation in Mosul in northern Iraq.Mosul has been occupied by ISIS / Daesh since 2014, and according to the latest testimonies, people in the area are starving and executions are constantly being carried out under the cruel ISIS regime, and civilians are being used as human shields.A joint operation led by Iraq is currently being conducted in the area to liberate Mosul.That is why, in our resolution, we expressed our support for this operation, support for the territorial integrity of Iraq and called on all parties to the operation to respect international humanitarian law and ensure that they hit the civilian population as little as possible, which must be provided with humanitarian assistance orsafely leave the conflict area.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution of 27 October 2016 on the situation in northern Iraq / Mosul.On 4 February 2016, the European Parliament found that ISIS / Daesh was committing genocide against Christians and Yazidis and other religious and ethnic minorities.The atrocities committed by ISIS / Daesh against religious and ethnic minorities in Iraq include war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.I therefore join in supporting the operation launched by Iraq to liberate Mosul from ISIS / Daesh domination, as this operation could play a decisive role in the current global efforts to permanently defeat ISIS / Daesh.I believe that it is essential that all parties to the conflict, in and after hostilities, respect international humanitarian law and, in times of conflict, the principles of proportionality, differentiation and caution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of this Resolution of the European Parliament which precisely condemns the increase in repression by the Turkish Government against journalists and the media. The drift of the Turkish Government is very worrying for those of us who defend civil and democratic rights, but also - and it must be remembered - it is extremely worrying that the same European Union, here, in this Parliament, rightly condemns the Turkish Government, to the It once passes resolutions that give Turkey the status of a safe country. Turkey is not a safe country, neither for journalists, nor for Kurds, nor for opponents. It must be said and it must be said that, for example, Alp Altinors, vice president of the Turkish HDP, continues to be detained, who is still in prison today, and we directly ask for his release from here. Ladies and gentlemen, if you are concerned about journalists in Turkey, please also worry about what is happening with Kurdish broadcasters in Europe, which have had the right to broadcast in their language taken away. Let's worry, in general, about what is happening and stop looking the other way when we are interested.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I also supported this resolution, which concerns the protection of human rights and democracy in the world. I am glad that there is a clear criticism of Turkey and the situation regarding freedom of speech and the independence of the media in this country. At times, I feel that some representatives of European countries and the European Union are too lenient towards Turkey, and that especially after the current administration is dealing with a 'failed coup' and reacting very disproportionately and repressively to it, I do not think we can remain silent. We must make it clear that the situation of freedom of speech is crucial for us, and that at a time when more than two thousand journalists were released in Turkey, around a hundred journalists were detained awaiting further trial and one hundred and fifty media outlets were closed, that is completely unacceptable, and Turkey is moving away from Europe rather than Europe, so it is difficult to talk about visa-free travel and strengthening our cooperation.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - In Turkey, the situation is very worrying.There are many, many journalists who are in prison.In the press freedom ranking compiled by Reporters Without Borders, Turkey ranks 151st out of 180 countries, so it is at the bottom of the list.In addition, the totalitarian tendencies of the Ankara regime are accentuated after the coup attempt.I understand that the ruling party will send constitutional changes to Parliament;they will give increased powers to the president, that is, he will go to dictatorship.We now know, on the other hand, that Turkey is an important partner of the European Union in NATO and in the refugee crisis.But we must have a values-based partnership, we cannot accept anything from Turkey just because we need Turkey not to send refugees to the European Union.So let's have a partnership in which Turkey also respects its obligations.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- After the failed coup, the situation of journalists in Turkey is to be considered critical.Many of them were in fact arrested without any evidence of criminal activity.I believe that the detention of journalists for the content of their articles and the closure of a very large number of information centers are aspects that dangerously threaten the democracy of a country.For these reasons I have decided to vote in favor.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: written. - The situation of journalists and press freedom has suffered a constant deterioration in Turkey, especially after the coup attempt last July, the resolution condemns the coup and supports the legitimate institutions of Turkey, however, it indicates that The failed military coup cannot serve as an excuse for the Turkish government to repress the opposition, nor for it to prevent journalists and the media from exercising freedom of expression, calling on the Turkish authorities to release all journalists and media professionals detained without strong evidence of criminal activity. The resolution denounces that the Turkish authorities have closed the offices of more than one hundred broadcasting organizations, newspapers, magazines, leaving more than 2,300 journalists and communication professionals without employment and revoking the press credentials of at least 330 journalists. The resolution calls for the release of all detained journalists and communication professionals without strong evidence of criminal activity. Finally, remember that a free and plural press is an essential element of any democracy, freedom of expression and of the press.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non—binding resolution. We share serious concerns over developments in Turkey, including freedom of the press. However, this report does not tackle the most serious underlying issue: that Turkey remains an EU accession country and receives EU financing due to this status.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted in favor, because it contributes to the international denouncement of the dramatic human rights situation currently being experienced in Turkey, especially as regards the free and full exercise of freedom of expression. Unfortunately, Erdogan is taking advantage of the alleged coup against him, to carry out a purge against journalists, teachers, judges, doctors, among others. It acts against anyone who is suspected of being opposition to its government, and has deployed an offensive against its people that is de facto going unpunished, and it is a moral indignity that the Union remains silent and is an accomplice by omission in the face of these crimes of a State that it should not be a reliable partner, nor should it be considered safe by the Union. We would have liked the text to reflect more strongly and clearly the condemnation of the behavior of the Turkish government, which acts contrary to international law, however, it is a good start to highlight this situation of violence against journalists in Turkey.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing.- I co-signed this resolution.I condemn the recent police raids and the detention of several journalists and media representatives in Turkey.These actions undermine media freedom, an essential pillar of democracy.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing.- This text clearly notes the appalling situation of press freedom and freedom of opinion in Turkey, but does not draw the logical and obvious conclusion, namely that Turkey does not meet the criteria to negotiate its accession to theEU and that these negotiations must therefore be stopped.The ENL group tabled its own resolution, and three amendments on the joint resolution.None of these proposals were adopted.Traditional political groups like the European Commission continue to deny reality and refuse to recognize that Turkey has no place in the European Union.I therefore voted against the joint resolution.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe it is important that Turkey should respect the rule of law and human rights. I supported amendments and an alternative motion for a resolution which called for the end of Turkish accession to the European Union. However, I abstained on the resolution as a whole as I could not support all of the text.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted against this proposal on the situation of journalists in Turkey tabled by the ENF group.While there is a need to denounce the action of the Turkish authorities against journalists in the country, I believe that the considerations made in this resolution are directed towards defending the interests of the ENF group.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. - The attempted coup d'état in Turkey, which took place in July this year, had a traumatic effect on the Turkish regime and greatly disturbed Turkish society. This resolution strongly condemns this event and supports the legitimate institutions in Turkey, a key partner of the EU. This does not mean, however, that the European Union can guarantee the repression that the Turkish authorities have exercised on freedom of expression, following the attempted coup, through the arrest of dozens of journalists and writers, the majority without being sustained in a formal charge. . The pressures on journalists and the media were already being felt, before the events of July. I cannot, therefore, agree more with a resolution that calls on the Government of Turkey to stick to the rule of law and to restrict the emergency measures adopted to full respect for the rule of law, calling for the release of journalists who find detainees without irrefutable evidence and the reopening of the closed media based on inconsistent allegations.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- According to Reporters Without Borders, 89 journalists were arrested during the first six weeks of the state of emergency and 104 media outlets were closed, with more than 2,300 journalists later lost their jobs and at least 330 journalists accredited.I therefore agree that the Turkish Government must comply with all the conditions of democracy and the rule of law and stop discriminating against citizens on the basis of freedom of expression and other fundamental rights.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. We share serious concerns over developments in Turkey, including freedom of the press. However, this report does not tackle the most serious underlying issue: that Turkey remains an EU accession country and receives EU financing due to this status.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- This text is remarkable in that it takes due note of the disastrous situation of freedom of opinion in Turkey, about which we should not remain silent, and that it still happens not to know indraw the logical consequences.Indeed, the proposal refuses to stop the negotiations for the accession of this country to the European Union while it underlines that the criteria are very far from being met.I naturally voted against.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
