text: in writing.- I approved this resolution which strongly condemns the coup d'état in Turkey, supports the legitimate institutions in Turkey and recognizes the right of the Turkish government to react to this attempt, but which considers that this cannot serve as a pretext for gagging it.legitimate opposition or deprive, through disproportionate and unlawful acts, journalists and the media of the peaceful exercise of their freedom of expression.The resolution therefore calls for the release of journalists and media workers who are detained without irrefutable evidence of criminal activity.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. - Following the failed coup on July 15, the Turkish government arrested 99 journalists and writers, revoking the accreditation for another 330 journalists and closing the offices of more than 100 broadcasters, newspapers, periodicals, publishing houses and companies distribution. According to Human Rights Watch, many of these lawsuits were prosecuted without any evidence of the accused's participation in the failed coup. The resolution passed today by Parliament, which I supported with my vote, strongly condemns the attempted coup, reaffirming its full support for the legitimate Turkish authorities. However, the text expresses deep concern over the arbitrary detentions of journalists, measures which cannot be interpreted as a legitimate response to military action and instead constitute a reality that undermines the principles of the rule of law. The free and pluralist press is indeed an essential component of democracy, as are due process, the presumption of innocence and the independence of the judiciary. Turkey must commit to reducing the scope of emergency measures, freeing detained journalists without irrefutable evidence and encouraging impartial investigations into the facts of the failed coup.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I vote in favor of a text that condemns the cycle of increasing repression by the Turkish Government against journalists and the media, exacerbated after the coup attempt in July 2016, and which has resulted in the closure ofnewspapers, the persecution and imprisonment of journalists and the establishment of a climate of authoritarianism and censorship absolutely incompatible with democracy and the rule of law.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- I believe that it is essential to give this wake-up call to the Turkish Government, which has taken advantage of the operations to control the failed coup of July 15 to carry out a real persecution against journalists and intellectuals critical of the current Government, closing more than 150 media outletsof communication and persecuting hundreds of critical journalists.Similarly, we insist with our support on the need for adequate respect for minorities, especially the Kurdish people.If this minority is routinely mistreated in Turkey, the operations to control the failed coup have also served to intensify the punishment operations against its members.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - I obviously supported the alternative resolution tabled by the ENL group on the situation of journalists in Turkey, but opposed the joint resolution of the other groups, which curses the consequences of the causes it cherishes. I myself have tried several times to raise awareness about the situation of journalists and freedom of expression in general in Turkey. It is nevertheless incredible that this resolution recognizes that these fundamental freedoms are violated, without also calling for an end to negotiations within the framework of Turkey's accession process. The Union, so quick to slap on the fingers of the Member States when it comes to respect for the rule of law, does not seem to realize its total schizophrenia when it comes to from Turkey. Recall that since July 15, the date of the failure of the military coup in Turkey, dozens of media have been closed (three news agencies, 45 newspapers, 16 television channels, 23 radio stations, 15 magazines and 29 publishing houses), 150 generals were sacked, 1,099 officers were expelled from the army, over 15,000 people were taken into police custody and thousands of teachers were made unemployed.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- The report rightly condemns the repression of journalists in Turkey by the Erdogan government, but goes no further, it does not emphasize the fact that human rights violations in this country are on the agenda and are unacceptable.I believe that Turkey does not in any way respect the founding values of the EU and that negotiations for accession to the Union must be suspended immediately.For this reason I could not fully support this text and I decided to express myself with an abstention.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - The situation of journalists and press freedom has suffered a constant deterioration in Turkey, especially after the coup attempt last July, the resolution condemns the coup and supports the legitimate institutions of Turkey, however, it indicates that The failed military coup cannot serve as an excuse for the Turkish government to repress the opposition, nor for it to prevent journalists and the media from exercising freedom of expression, calling on the Turkish authorities to release all journalists and media professionals detained without strong evidence of criminal activity. The resolution denounces that the Turkish authorities have closed the offices of more than one hundred broadcasting organizations, newspapers, magazines, leaving more than 2,300 journalists and communication professionals without employment and revoking the press credentials of at least 330 journalists. The resolution calls for the release of all detained journalists and communication professionals without strong evidence of criminal activity. Finally, remember that a free and plural press is an essential element of any democracy, freedom of expression and of the press.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution, which deals with the situation of journalists in Turkey. The European Parliament calls on the Turkish authorities to release journalists and media workers detained without any convincing evidence of criminal activity, and stresses that journalists should not be detained for the content of their journalistic activities or alleged links, including when accused, and stresses the need ensure that pre-trial detention remains an exceptional measure. Parliament also expresses its deep concern at the closure of more than 150 media outlets and calls for them to be reopened, allowed to remain independent and for their dismissed staff to be returned in due course. Calls, furthermore, on the Turkish authorities to put an end to abuses of the penal code in order to appoint trustees to private media organizations and to end administrative interference in independent news organizations, including editorial decisions, dismissals of journalists and editors, pressure on critical news services and journalists and their intimidation. Parliament called on the European External Action Service and the Member States to continue to monitor closely the practical impact of the emergency and to ensure that all trials of journalists are monitored.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Turkish government has the right and responsibility to respond to the coup attempt. At the same time, I would like to emphasize that the failed military takeover of the Turkish Government must not be used as an excuse to further stifle legitimate and peaceful opposition and to prevent journalists and the media from exercising their freedom of expression peacefully through disproportionate and illegal actions and measures. I would like to remind you that a free and pluralistic press is an essential element of democracy, as are due process, the presumption of innocence and the independence of the judiciary. The Turkish authorities must be as careful as possible with the media and journalists. Freedom of expression and freedom of the press remain central to the functioning of a democratic and open society. In view of the above, I supported the adoption of the motion.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the proposed resolution, as I absolutely support media freedom and condemn the unjustified imprisonment of journalists in Turkey.Freedom of expression and freedom of the media are central to the functioning of a democratic and open society, so I think it is right to call on the Turkish Government to limit the scope of emergency measures and not use them to restrict freedom of expression.Investigations into alleged involvement in a coup attempt should be conducted impartially and on the basis of convincing evidence, and not on the basis of collective guilt, which can lead to group punishment - including of journalists.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- We discussed the resolution related to the situation in journalism, which is extremely worrying and is the clearest indicator of what is happening in Turkey.But it must not be forgotten either that a huge number of teachers, deans at universities, ended up in prison.So it goes to all segments of society, from informing the public to influencing young people.The visa regime is currently the only trump card in Europe's hands.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. - The situation regarding freedom of the press in Turkey has worsened considerably over the past decade. The Turkish government is abusing the state of emergency and the failed coup of July 2016 to significantly reduce freedom of expression and freedom of the media. Parliament noted that 89 journalists were arrested without charge in the first months of the state of emergency. The Turkish government had carried out numerous and systematic violations of the freedom of the press even before the failed coup attempt and the resulting state of emergency. Thousands of websites are currently blocked in Turkey. However, violations of freedom of expression and of the media are not the only structural problem in Turkey; such problems also include the treatment of minorities, the refusal to recognize the Republic of Cyprus and the ambiguity towards terrorist groups in Syria and Iraq. Therefore, the European Parliament calls on the Government of Turkey to respect all conditions of democracy and the rule of law and to put an end to all discrimination against citizens with regard to freedom of expression and other fundamental rights.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. - This joint motion for a resolution draws a realistic view of the appalling climate in which journalists have been operating in Turkey since the failed coup attempt of July 15, 2016. In October 2016, there were no less than 130 media professionals detained for facts related to the exercise of their activity. Some of them have been denied the right of access to a lawyer. However, this joint motion for a resolution is limited to a simple sterile description of the persecution of journalists and does not at any time call for a definitive end to Turkey's membership negotiations in the European Union. That is why I voted against this joint motion for a resolution and why I supported the motion for a resolution of the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group. The latter recalled the incompatibility of the authoritarian excesses of the Turkish government with European fundamental rights.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: written. - The situation of journalists and press freedom has suffered a constant deterioration in Turkey, especially after the coup attempt last July, the resolution condemns the coup and supports the legitimate institutions of Turkey, however, it indicates that The failed military coup cannot serve as an excuse for the Turkish government to repress the opposition, nor for it to prevent journalists and the media from exercising freedom of expression, calling on the Turkish authorities to release all journalists and media professionals detained without strong evidence of criminal activity. The resolution denounces that the Turkish authorities have closed the offices of more than one hundred broadcasting organizations, newspapers, magazines, leaving more than 2,300 journalists and communication professionals without employment and revoking the press credentials of at least 330 journalists. The resolution calls for the release of all detained journalists and communication professionals without strong evidence of criminal activity. Finally, remember that a free and plural press is an essential element of any democracy, freedom of expression and of the press.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the declaration by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation of journalists in Turkey because unfortunately the events of last July worsened the situation with an even greater contraction of thefreedom, especially that of expression.Reporters Without Borders reports at least 110 journalists in prison, including 70 arrested after the coup.More than 150 reported on the loose.It must be clear that concrete respect for rights and freedoms remains vital for a country aspiring to join the European Union.The European Union must work to ensure that European standards of democracy are guaranteed in this country, with no ifs and buts.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Resolution as I am concerned that following the coup attempt of 15 July 2016 the Turkish police have arrested a substantial number of journalists and writers, most of whom have had no charges brought against them to date. Whereas some have been released, the remaining detained journalists have been denied the right of access to a lawyer and are being kept in inhumane conditions and are being threatened and mistreated. Restrictions on the media and pressure on journalists were already considerable before the failed coup, but following the attempted coup d’état, this increased exponentially. It is important to highlight that the failed military take-over cannot be used as an excuse for the Turkish Government to further stifle legitimate and peaceful opposition and to prevent journalists and the media in their peaceful exercise of freedom of expression through disproportionate and illegal actions and measures.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The real coup d'état actually succeeded Erdogan and journalists are paying dearly for it.The candidate of the 5 Star Movement for this year's Sakharov Prize, the journalist Can Dündar, editor of the Cumhuriyet newspaper, and many others who have denounced over the years the troubled involvement of the national secret services, for example in arms trafficking inSyria, they are among those who are paying for their freedom of thought with prison.Meanwhile, the statistics are growing, we arrive at 100,000 websites blocked, we arrive in a country that is now 151st in terms of freedom of the press, 183 newspapers closed, 127 journalists arrested.I remind the European Union and the Commission that freedom of expression is a right and not a crime, on the contrary, it is the salt of democracy.And if we do not strongly reiterate it vis-à-vis the Turkish government, we will lose all credibility.My vote was positive.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We are here, in the same work, spectators, to accuse Turkey of abuses and violations. This time the victims of Turkey are the journalists, the representatives of freedom in the press, in the information. The right of citizens to be informed freely, democratically, objectively is being strangled. This is the country that wants to become an EU member and for which some people are breaking their robes because its accession process is not progressing. This is a country that for some is a strategic partner of the EU. Turkey has become a vast prison and it is a rule to arrest, convict and kill innocent people, innocent journalists.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - The complex situation that Turkey has been experiencing since this summer has shaken our parliamentary activity and reading the newspapers every day, I am fortunate to be able to witness one of the greatest freedoms for the human being: that of expression. If we were to be without it, my own role would probably become empty. Many can make statements that are far from our vision of the world, sometimes even indefensible, yet the very right to make those statements is inalienable and must be preserved in its essence. Consequently, my support for the resolution as well as my total disgust at the repressive actions taken against Turkish journalists are clear. It is estimated that as of 20 October 2016, 130 media operators were detained on charges allegedly related to the exercise of their right to freedom of expression; at the same time it emerged that after the attempted coup the Turkish authorities closed the offices of over 100 broadcasters, newspapers, periodicals, publishing houses and distribution companies. I believe that the government should reduce the scope of emergency measures in order not to harm freedom of expression.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on the situation of journalists in Turkey and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing.- I reiterate the premise of this resolution, so that there is no doubt: I deplore coups d'état against legitimately elected institutions and I regret the victims that resulted from the attempt in Turkey in July 2016. Furthermore, I recognize that terrorism in the broadest sense constitutes athreat to that country.However, they can neither serve nor violate the core of the fundamental freedoms of Turkish citizens, nor threaten the rule of law.That is why it is not permissible for journalists to be arrested without charge in the name of security, for 150 media to be shut down, for journalists and their families to be threatened due to disagreement of opinion.Let us be clear: freedom of the press and expression is a non-negotiable value.I therefore vote in favor of this resolution.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution because, following the coup attempt in Turkey last July, the European Federation of Journalists and the Association of Turkish Journalists denounced numerous arrests of operators in the sector against which,in most cases, no accusations have yet been made and that many broadcasters, newspapers, periodicals and publishing houses have been shut down.While condemning the attempted coup, the provision calls on the government of Turkey to reduce the scope of emergency measures so that they can no longer be used to limit freedom of expression as a free and pluralist press is an essential component of any democracy.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted in favor, because it contributes to denouncing internationally the dramatic situation that human rights are currently experiencing in Turkey, especially in terms of the free and full exercise of freedom of expression. Unfortunately, Erdogan is taking advantage of the alleged coup against him, to carry out a purge against journalists, teachers, judges, doctors, among others. It acts against anyone who is suspected of being opposition to its government, and has deployed an offensive against its people that is de facto going unpunished, and it is a moral indignity that the Union is silent and complicit by omission in the face of these crimes of a State that it should not be a reliable partner, nor should it be considered as safe by the Union We would have liked the text to reflect more strongly and clearly the condemnation of the behavior of the Turkish government, which acts contrary to international law, however, it is a good start to highlight this situation of violence against journalists in Turkey.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. - After the failed coup, President Erdoğan has launched an operation to purge alleged infiltrators of the Gülenist movement in the meshes of public administration and Turkish society. The mass arrests campaign also involved media and journalists, who already enjoyed restricted freedom of expression even before the coup. After the coup, the situation worsened with the closure of 102 journalistic bodies, authorized by a decree of 27 July 2016, and with the detention of 101 journalists as of 14 September 2016. I voted in favor of this resolution, because it supports the efforts by the legitimate authorities of Turkey to address the coup attempt of 15 July 2016. At the same time, it reiterates that these efforts must not go against the rule of law, which implies the right to a fair trial for all journalists against whom Lawsuits were initiated in the absence of any evidence of participation in the failed coup attempt. While recognizing the enormous terrorist threat that weighs on Turkey, I am convinced that neither the coup nor the legislation in use can be exploited to prevent journalists and the media from peacefully exercising freedom of expression through disproportionate actions and emergency measures.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- On the motion for a resolution on the situation of journalists in Turkey, I have decided to abstain.Of course, I believe that the EU should express its concern about the situation of journalists in this country, where the aftermath of the July coup to overthrow President Erdoğan is still being felt.The president is being accused of an increasingly authoritarian way of governing the country and thus violating the fundamental rights and freedoms of citizens.Already in 2015, the Commission and the Parliament expressed their concern about the violation of the right to media freedom in Turkey.The situation has worsened since then as many TV stations have shut down and journalists have lost their jobs or have been detained.In my opinion, the motion for a resolution needs to be improved as it fails to solve the most important problems, which is why I chose to abstain.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation of journalists and media freedom has been constantly deteriorating in Turkey. Already before the attempted coup d’état of 15 July, there remained only a handful of independent media outlets and numerous journalists were imprisoned. Freedom of speech and expression is a universal fundamental right and is a fundamental principle of democracy. For these reasons I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing.- This resolution concerns the situation of journalists in Turkey.Since the failed coup of July 15, 2016, the Turkish government has arrested at least 99 journalists, removed press cards from at least 330 journalists, and closed the offices of more than 100 media outlets.These measures led to the loss of more than 2,300 jobs in the press.This resolution strongly condemns the policy of the Erdogan government towards the media and the press, denouncing the violation of press freedom, an essential principle in the European Union.The resolution recalls that "a free and plural press is an essential component of any democracy".Considering that the emergency measures following the attempted coup must not be used as a pretext for the government to undermine freedom of expression, I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported this resolution on the situation of journalists in Turkey.The reaction of the Turkish government after the attempted coup of 15 July 2016 must not jeopardize freedom of expression and allow the opposition and journalists to be gagged.Freedom of expression and the freedom of the media are essential components of any democratic and open society, as are the right to a fair trial, the presumption of innocence and judicial independence.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: in writing. - Following the failed coup attempt in Turkey, the Turkish government adopted numerous repressive measures leading, among other things, to the arrest of journalists and media leaders all over the country as well as the closure of several newspapers, TV stations, radio stations and online media. According to Reporters Without Borders, in the first two and a half months of the state of emergency, 99 journalists were jailed, sometimes without charges, making Turkey the state with the largest number of journalists in prison. The attempted coup must be condemned. But it must not be used as a pretext to silence the opposition, deprive, through disproportionate and unlawful acts and measures, journalists and the media of the peaceful exercise of their freedom of expression. The Union must denounce these attacks on freedom of expression, freedom of the press and media pluralism and act to strengthen the rule of law in the country.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing.- This text is lucid about the appalling situation of press freedom and freedom of opinion in Turkey.However, he does not draw the logical and obvious conclusion that Turkey does not in any way meet the criteria to negotiate EU membership and that these negotiations should therefore end.The ENF group tabled its own resolution as well as three amendments to the joint resolution.None of these proposals were adopted.The political groups of the system as well as the European Commission continue to deny the reality and refuse to recognize that Turkey has no place in the European Union.Also, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: In written form. - I supported the resolution on the situation of journalists in Turkey, as what is happening in this neighbor of ours is beginning to resemble the actions of an authoritarian regime. Following the failed coup in July, Turkey was engulfed in civil and political chaos with final decisions by President Erdogan. According to the latest Reporters Without Borders report, Turkey ranks 151st out of 180 in terms of press freedom and holds the record for most journalists in prison. The European Union must take decisive action to stop the arbitrariness of President Erdogan, who is currently taking advantage of the wave of immigrants sweeping the EU.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing.- According to official figures, 89 journalists were detained during the first six weeks of the state of emergency and 104 media outlets were closed, leaving more than 2,300 journalists out of work, and at least 330 journalists had their professional card revoked.There are also reports of multiple systematic violations of press freedom prior to the attempted coup d'état and the subsequent declaration of a state of emergency, the most notable cases being the investigation of terrorism and espionage that a Turkish newspaper was targeted.I agree that Turkey must respect all conditions of democracy and the rule of law and put an end to discrimination against citizens as regards freedom of expression and other fundamental rights.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Vote: for the ENF resolution and against the joint resolution.The text of the joint resolution clearly notes the appalling situation of freedom of the press and freedom of opinion in Turkey, but does not draw the logical and obvious conclusion, namely that Turkey does not meet the criteria to negotiate itsaccession to the EU and that these negotiations must therefore be stopped.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution is based on the coup d'état that took place in Turkey in July and addresses the situation of persecution and imprisonment of journalists and writers for alleged links to the coup. Furthermore, it criticizes the closure of newspapers and other publications, as they are considered against the Turkish government. The resolution essentially follows the official EU line. It recognizes the Turkish Government's legitimacy to react to the situation, but considers that this cannot be an excuse to persecute the opposition and condition civil and political rights. There is a clear concern not to nip the relations that the EU considers privileged with Turkey. Look at the shameful EU-Turkey Agreement on refugees; the importance that Turkey assumes in the Syrian War; the fact that Turkey belongs to NATO. In other words, there are many reasons for the tone of the resolution to be conditioned, compared to other resolutions, on other situations in the world. The complexity of the situation requires caution. There is still much to be clarified around this coup. It is a fact that the repression was reinforced, but it already existed before the coup d'état and the EU saw it conveniently. There are many contradictory interests that revolve around the situation in Turkey.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing.- I vote against the motion for a resolution on the situation of journalists in Turkey as a whole, as I do not agree with what they are saying.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the attempted coup on 15 July 2016, the Turkish authorities have arrested academics, students, members of the opposition and many others. Media outlets have also been targeted. The Kurdish minority has been particularly affected. I think we should remind the Turkish authorities that emergency decrees should not be used as a pretext to facilitate serious human rights violations, to silence dissent and to close down media outlets, as a free and pluralistic press is an essential component of any democracy and remains central to the functioning of a peaceful and open society. The recent police raids and the detention of a number of journalists and media representatives in Turkey must be strongly condemned, as these actions undermine the freedom of the media, which is a core principle of democracy.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: written. - The situation of journalists and freedom of the press has suffered a constant deterioration in Turkey, especially after the attempted coup last July, the resolution condemns the coup and supports the legitimate institutions of Turkey, however, it indicates that The failed military coup cannot serve as an excuse for the Turkish government to repress the opposition, nor for it to prevent journalists and the media from exercising freedom of expression, calling on the Turkish authorities to release all journalists and media professionals detained without strong evidence of criminal activity. The resolution calls for the release of all detained journalists and communication professionals without strong evidence of criminal activity. Finally, remember that a free and plural press is an essential element of any democracy, freedom of expression and of the press.

text: written. - The situation of journalists and press freedom has suffered a constant deterioration in Turkey, especially after the coup attempt last July, the resolution condemns the coup and supports the legitimate institutions of Turkey, however, it indicates that The failed military coup cannot serve as an excuse for the Turkish government to repress the opposition, nor for it to prevent journalists and the media from exercising freedom of expression, calling on the Turkish authorities to release all journalists and media professionals detained without strong evidence of criminal activity. The resolution calls for the release of all detained journalists and communication professionals without strong evidence of criminal activity. Finally, remember that a free and plural press is an essential element of any democracy, freedom of expression and of the press.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing.- Freedom of thought, of the press, of speech: Turkey does not seem to worry about such unacceptable violations of human rights, perpetrating operations of pressure and repression on its main press organs.The numbers recorded only after the coup d'état a few months ago are impressive: 102 media closed and 101 journalists detained.The regret, frankly, does not exhaust the profound indignation towards these acts totally incompatible with the concept of democracy that Europe cannot and must not tolerate.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. - I strongly supported the European Parliament resolution on the situation of journalists in Turkey because Turkish journalists still work in difficult circumstances, subjected to regular censorship and government intimidation. The forced closure of numerous newspapers, radio and television stations in the aftermath of the failed coup is a phenomenon that the EU strongly condemns and which does not favor the ongoing accession negotiations. Freedom of the press is a sign of democracy and justice, independence and respect for the rights of journalists are the guarantors of this freedom. With this resolution the European Parliament intends to strongly condemn the intimidation directed at the media sector. I therefore share the deep concern over the deterioration of the situation regarding freedom of speech, expression and opinion in the country over the past two years. It is therefore essential that the Turkish government continue on the path of European integration and fully align itself with European values, principles and standards of freedom and democracy, immediately ceasing the mass arrests of journalists and freeing those who are in prison: these are non-negotiable conditions for the Group of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the situation of journalists in Turkey because I believe it is the order of the day for the EU to take an open position against what seems to me to be the arbitrary acts of the Turkish President.The closing of numerous media outlets and the arrest of hundreds of journalists - most recently the editor-in-chief of Cumhuriyet - cannot be justified democratically and is completely against the fundamental values and convictions of the EU.For me, this is reason enough - together with many others - to stop the EU accession negotiations with Turkey immediately.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today we face a necessary and inevitable debate on the worrying condition of one of the fundamental rights in a democracy, freedom of expression, within Turkey, our indispensable partner for historical and strategic reasons. The immigration agreement is there to reaffirm how important Turkey is for Europe and for the stabilization action it plays at the regional level. But this cannot prevent us from denouncing the attack on the freedom of the press and of information as a whole. Since the failed coup last July, the squeeze on newspapers and information channels has been relentless and indiscriminate. The arrest of many, too many journalists, has been in the international daily news for months and will certainly not help the Turkish regime to embark on the road to transparent democracy. The simultaneous squeeze on the judiciary is helping to close ranks on journalists who are still trying to do their work independently. With conviction, I am voting in favor of this report because we Europeans must have the courage to firmly demand that all this stop as soon as possible.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I vote in favor of a text that condemns the cycle of increasing repression by the Turkish Government against journalists and the media, exacerbated after the coup attempt in July 2016, and which has resulted in the closure ofnewspapers, the persecution and imprisonment of journalists and the establishment of a climate of authoritarianism and censorship absolutely incompatible with democracy and the rule of law.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this motion, which highlights that a free press is an essential component of any democracy, as is due process, presumption of innocence and judicial independence.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. I strongly condemn the attempted military take-over of 15 July 2016 and the attempts to illegally and unconstitutionally change and undermine the legitimate Turkish Government and the freely elected Grand National Assembly as well as the mass arrests of journalists and the government’s campaign against media and journalists. Thus, the EU calls on the authorities to urgently produce credible evidence to back the accusations that the arrested individuals have committed the criminal offences they are charged with and to proceed swiftly with the judicial proceedings, in full transparency and with adequate legal safeguards ensuring due process and a fair trial.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: written. - The situation of journalists and freedom of the press has suffered a constant deterioration in Turkey, especially after the attempted coup last July, the resolution condemns the coup and supports the legitimate institutions of Turkey, however, it indicates that The failed military coup cannot serve as an excuse for the Turkish government to repress the opposition, nor for it to prevent journalists and the media from exercising freedom of expression, calling on the Turkish authorities to release all journalists and media professionals detained without strong evidence of criminal activity. The resolution calls for the release of all detained journalists and communication professionals without strong evidence of criminal activity. Finally, remember that a free and plural press is an essential element of any democracy, freedom of expression and of the press.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The resolution calls on Turkey to immediately end the arrests, threats, violations and restrictions it imposes on journalists and their families. According to the European Federation of Journalists and the Organization of Turkish Journalists, since July 15, more than 99 journalists / intellectuals have been arrested without charge. If we add the arrested media workers, then the number reaches 130. In addition, the resolution calls on Turkey to relax the state of emergency, which, in line with the existing anti-terrorism law, catalyzes any notion of the rule of law. . For these reasons we voted in favor and co-signed the resolution.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly condemn the attempted coup in Turkey of 15 July 2016 and support the legitimate institutions of Turkey, while deploring the high number of casualties. Given that a free and pluralistic press is an essential component of any democracy, as are due process, presumption of innocence and judicial independence, I condemn the Turkish Government’s actions in disrupting and arresting opposition journalists in the country.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: written.- Of all 57 Islamic states, Turkey was for a long time the only country in the world that set out on the path to democracy, respect for human rights and freedom of the press.Since the coup attempt, everything has supposedly been different.But I would like to point out that long before the attempted coup, human rights were trampled on in Turkey.Media houses were closed beforehand, journalists were arrested beforehand, and peaceful protesters were beaten up beforehand.We mustn't fall for it and now pretend it's all a result of the coup.When Erdoğan says, "It was a gift from God", he not only exposed himself, he was also profane.That is why I approved the joint text by EPP, S&D, ECR, ALDE, GUE / NGL, Verts / ALE and EFDD to put negotiations with Turkey on hold.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The freedom of the media, a core principle of democracy, should be upheld in Turkey. Any countries attempting to join the ascension process to the European Union should protect such values and principles. As such, the detention of media representatives in Turkey is severely frowned upon.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted for the Report on the Position of Journalists in Turkey, given that there are numerous cases of abuse of repressive authorities against media freedom.Turkey has unfortunately been faced with a recent attempt at an undemocratic overthrow of the government through a coup, then Turkey is facing terrorism from which it is threatened not only security but also economically.The EU, as a partner, should help Turkey address these issues, but these issues should not be used as an excuse and an instrument to shut down opposition media or detain unwanted journalists if there are no indications of criminal activity.Everyone should be provided with a fair trial and defense from freedom.It is necessary for the competent EU institutions to monitor the situation and report to the European Parliament.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- I note that this text mentions the deplorable situation of freedom of opinion in Turkey but does not draw the conclusion that is binding on all, namely that this country does not meet the criteria to negotiate its integration into Turkey.the European Union, which thereby proves the impossibility of continuing this process.I voted against.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- Turkey was ranked among the worst in terms of freedom of the press and media even before the failed coup attempt.The situation has deteriorated significantly since the coup.Thousands of people have been imprisoned and fired.In a resolution adopted by a large majority, the European Parliament calls on the Turkish Government to drop the unfounded charges against journalists and to abandon conceptual proceedings against writers and journalists.The EU institutions and Member States must take consistent action to ensure that the principles of human rights and democracy prevail in the Union's partners, especially in countries with which the EU has close links.Of course, the Union can only do this consistently if it takes constant and proper care of these core values within the Union's borders.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation of journalists in Turkey with regard to measures taken by the Turkish Government after the failed military coup on 15 July this year. Since then, the Turkish Government has arrested at least 99 journalists and writers, revoked the press credentials of at least 330 journalists and closed the offices of more than 100 media outlets, leaving over 2 300 media workers without jobs. The failed coup cannot be used to further repress legitimate and peaceful opposition and to curtail journalists’ freedom of expression. A free and pluralistic press is an essential component of any democracy and the EU must closely monitor the implications of the prolonged state of emergency.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Renate Sommer on the situation of journalists in Turkey.Since the failed coup d'état of July 15, more than 23,000 media professionals have been unemployed (removal of press cards, arrest or closure of media).With this vote, we strongly condemn the battle that the Turkish authorities are waging against all those opposing the regime peacefully.We call for the release of journalists against whom there is no compelling evidence of criminal activity.I am delighted that this report was adopted by a large majority.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written.- I would vote in favor of this motion for a resolution.The situation of journalists in Turkey is deteriorating noticeably, while the country is developing further and further away from a constitutional democracy.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it condemns the recent police raids and the detention of a number of journalists and media representatives in Turkey, underlining that these actions undermine the freedom of the media, which is a core principle of democracy.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - In July, Turkey was the victim of a failed coup that had serious repercussions on the whole of Turkish society. As we know, hundreds of people lost their lives and more than 2 100 were injured. But some serious consequences have been suffered by journalists, of which about 100 have been arrested and more than 300 have been deprived of accreditation. It is a violation of citizens' rights, which have also seen the closure of more than 100 broadcasters, newspapers, publishers and distribution companies. We condemn these acts and express solidarity with the victims and their families, while proposing urgent recommendations for Turkey. We therefore remind Turkey, an important partner for the EU, of the importance of protecting human rights and the rule of law, and that freedom of expression and the media, hence a free press, are fundamental parts of a democratic society. We therefore call on Turkey to reopen the media that have been closed and to release journalists, guaranteeing them a fair trial.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution because it shows great hypocrisy.She rightly protests against the violation of press freedom in Turkey, but does not draw the obvious conclusion, namely that Turkey does not meet the criteria to negotiate its accession to the EU.Note: the alternative resolution of the ENF group, which called for the end of Turkey's accession process, received only 83 votes out of 751.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - In response to the July 15 coup in Turkey, Erdogan's regime has unleashed a massive witch hunt in the Turkish state apparatus. With these purges in the army, the administration, education and Turkish justice, it is all the institutions that are brought into line, leaving only the press and the media as checks and balances in the face of the abuses of the government. Turkish power. They are also the victims: since the coup attempt, Turkish police have arrested at least 99 journalists and writers, most of whom have not been charged so far. Around 100 broadcasters, newspapers, magazines, publishers and distribution companies have been arbitrarily closed, as a result of which more than 2,300 journalists are unemployed and 330 journalists have been deprived of their press cards. Parliament's resolution strongly condemns these maneuvers by Turkish power against media freedom, pressure against journalists and their entourage. She is also concerned about the current abuses and calls for the scope of emergency measures to be reduced so that they can no longer be used to undermine freedom of expression. I therefore associated myself with this resolution by co-signing it.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against the joint resolution on the situation of journalists in Turkey.This text clearly notes the appalling situation of press freedom and freedom of opinion in Turkey, but does not draw the logical and obvious conclusion, namely that Turkey does not meet the criteria to negotiate its accession to the EU.EU and that these negotiations must therefore be stopped.Traditional political groups like the European Commission continue to deny reality and refuse to recognize that Turkey has no place in the European Union.

text: written. - I voted in favor, because it contributes to the international denouncement of the dramatic situation that human rights are currently experiencing in Turkey, especially as regards the free and full exercise of freedom of expression. Unfortunately, Erdogan is taking advantage of the alleged coup against him, to carry out a purge against journalists, teachers, judges, doctors, among others. It acts against anyone who is suspected of being opposition to its government, and has deployed an offensive against its people that is de facto going unpunished, and it is a moral indignity that the Union is silent and complicit by omission in the face of these crimes of a State that it should not be a reliable partner, nor should it be considered safe by the Union. We would have liked the text to reflect more strongly and clearly the condemnation of the behavior of the Turkish government, which acts contrary to international law, however, it is a good start to highlight this situation of violence against journalists in Turkey.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I stayed.The motion for a resolution calling for the conclusion of negotiations with Turkey on accession to the EU was not passed in a split vote.In the end, the resolution contains only a condemnation of the coup attempt, a call on the Turkish government to release the detained journalists, and regret that the Turkish government has stopped publishing 150 opposition media.In my opinion, these are empty proclamations without any action, so I refrained.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written.- The European Parliament strongly condemns the attempted coup in Turkey on 15 July 2016 and expresses its support for legitimate institutions.The resolution calls on the Turkish government to release journalists detained without convincing evidence of their criminal activities and expresses concern over the shutdown of more than 150 media outlets.It is also necessary for the Turkish authorities to narrow the scope of the emergency measures so that they cease to be used to restrict freedom of expression.Although Turkey faces the threat of terrorism, it should not use its counter-terrorism legislation to punish journalists who exercise their right to freedom of expression.Because of all of the above, I supported this resolution.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing.- The significant restrictions on freedom of expression and freedom of the media since July 2016 only confirm Turkey's unpreparedness for EU accession.However, Turkey also does not meet other requirements in the area of respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, so I do not consider the issue of its accession to the EU to be topical.Turkey is our neighbor and we must care that our neighbor is a safe and democratic country, with equal rights for women and men, a functioning judiciary, low corruption, social rights and a rising standard of living.This will be greatly helped if Turkey fulfills the association agreement with the EU.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- I support the joint motion for a resolution on the situation of journalists in Turkey, because it is sufficiently substantiated, as well as for the reasons I gave in detail in my speech to the European Parliament on 26 October 2016.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against the joint motion for a resolution.Turkey does not meet democratic criteria, and should not be allowed to negotiate its membership of the European Union.This text pretends to ignore this truth while observing that the situation of journalists in Turkey is unacceptable and that freedom of the press, like that of opinion, is not respected.This proposal does not admit that it is absolutely necessary to put an end to the negotiations with this country which does not and will never belong to European civilization.We tabled a motion for a resolution which quite logically arrived at this conclusion, but it was rejected by the rest of the MEPs who prefer to delude themselves and believe that they can change Turkey and make it "European".We do not share this vision.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: written.- Given the situation of journalists in Turkey, I support the resolution of the European Parliament to ask the Government of that country to reduce the scope of application of the emergency measures, so that these professionals can continue to make use of their right to freedomexpression.Fairness and evidence-based procedures should govern any judicial action.Turkish anti-terrorism legislation should not be used to punish journalists.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: written.- This motion for a resolution deals with the situation of journalists and media professionals in Turkey.Among other things, the release of journalists and media workers who are detained without compelling evidence for criminal activities is demanded.The government of Turkey is also asked to reduce the extent of the emergency measures so that they can no longer serve as a basis for encroaching on the right to freedom of expression.I therefore voted in favor of this motion for a resolution.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution. According to the European Federation of Journalists and the Turkish Association of Journalists, after 2016 July 15 In an attempt to carry out the coup, Turkish police arrested at least 99 journalists and writers, most of whom have not been charged so far. Detained journalists have been denied access to a lawyer and are being held in inhumane conditions, threatened and ill-treated. The media was heavily constrained and there was a lot of pressure on journalists even before the failed coup. According to the Committee on the Protection of Journalists, after the coup attempt, the Turkish authorities closed more than 100 offices of broadcasters, newspapers, magazines, publishers and distribution companies, leaving more than 2,300 journalists and media workers out of work. The European Parliament recognizes the right and responsibility of the Turkish Government to react when an attempt is made to carry out a coup d'état and when there is a real threat of terrorism. However, the Turkish government cannot use the failed military coup as an excuse to further suppress the legitimate and peaceful opposition, nor to take disproportionate and illegal actions and measures to prevent journalists and the media from exercising their right to freedom of expression peacefully.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Following the coup attempt, in July 2016, the Turkish authorities closed the offices of more than 100 broadcasters, newspapers, magazines, publishers and distribution companies, leaving 2,300 journalists and media professionals without employment, and 330 journalists were deprived of their press card. The resolution "calls on the Turkish authorities to release journalists and media workers who are detained without compelling evidence of criminal activity" while recognizing "the right and responsibility of the Turkish government to respond to the attempted coup". I regret that this text does not mention Can Dündar, former editor-in-chief of the Turkish daily Cumhuriyet, arrested in November 2015 for "revealing state secrets", after the publication by his newspaper of articles and a video showing a delivery weapons, operated in 2014 by the Turkish Secret Service (MIT) for Syrian Islamist groups. His case shows, however, that the situation of journalists was already problematic before the “attempted coup”. So I voted for this text despite its culpable amnesias and shyness.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing.- In Turkey, on July 15, 2016, an attempted coup d'état that killed more than 250 people and left more than 2,100 injured.A free and pluralist press is an essential element of any democracy, as is the fair trial, the presumption of innocence and the independence of the judiciary.Hence my condemnation of the way in which many journalists were treated in Turkey, following the attempted coup d'état attempted there.I therefore vote in favor of this resolution.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this cross—party resolution, which discusses the recent coup attempt in Turkey but also calls for the release of journalists that are being held without compelling evidence.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. - Following the attempted military coup of July 15, the Turkish government carried out arrest and intimidation measures against journalists and media professionals as well as television and radio. There are over 130 detainees in the media sector and over 99 arrests of journalists and writers by Turkish police are recorded. The declaration of a state of emergency led the government to intensify repressions, violating all the respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, the principle of the separation of powers, the rights of minorities, and freedom to practice the worship of his choice, etc. While strongly condemning the attempted coup and expressing my sincerest solidarity with the victims and their families, I would like to stress that the government's response can in no way give rise to disproportionate or even arbitrary acts of repression. , against journalists and media who peacefully exercise their freedom of expression. The actions taken are in total contradiction with the principles of democracy and the rule of law, defended by Europe. To compromise on these principles is not acceptable.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing.- A motion for a resolution has been tabled by the ENF, EFDD, S&D, ECR, GUE / NGL, ALDE, PPE and Verts / ALE groups.Of the eight groups, the latter seven reached an agreement and a joint compromise motion was drawn up.I voted in favor of the compromise proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - I subscribe to the rapporteur's position by vehemently condemning the attempted coup d'état that took place in Turkey on 15 July 2016 and support for Turkey's legitimate institutions. The high number of victims is to be regretted, expressing, from now on, my solidarity with the victims and their families. I argue that this failed military coup attempt cannot be used as a pretext for the Turkish government to further repress legitimate and peaceful opposition and prevent the peaceful exercise of freedom of expression by journalists and the media through actions and measures disproportionate and illegal. It is vital for the EU to work with the Turkish authorities to release journalists and media workers who are in detention without irrefutable evidence of criminal activity, including journalists known as Nazli Ilicak, Sahin Alpay, Asli Erdogan, Murat Aksoy, Ahmet Altan and Mehmet Altan. It is imperative to avoid detention of journalists based on the content of their work, including where they are the subject of a formal charge and the need to ensure that pre-trial detention remains an exception.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- This text related to the current situation of journalists in Turkey.Following the failed coup of July 15, 2016, the government made further arrests in the press community, while the majority of journalists arrested have no charges against them.This text emphasizes that the coup d'état in Turkey must not be used by the government to arrest journalists who are practicing their profession in order to gag the opposition.I voted for.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing.- I, along with other colleagues, condemn the coup attempt in Turkey, which has resulted in hundreds of deaths and more than 2,000 injuries.At the same time, it is my view that the Turkish Government must ensure, even in times of emergency, that fundamental human rights are not violated.I do not find it acceptable that hundreds of journalists are still being held in prison, that the free media is no longer really free.I consider Turkey to be an important partner of the European Union and, as a member of the delegation to the EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee, I am paying particular attention to developments.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this motion for a resolution, which called for the end of negotiations regarding Turkey’s accession to the EU.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: signed up.- I supported this motion for a resolution in today's vote, because I thought it reflected a realistic approach to how we should look at the events in Turkey during the coup attempt, but also in the period that followed.Of course, this coup attempt entitles the Turkish state to take the necessary measures to identify the perpetrators and those who support them, but I have to stress the concern that extremely harsh, even violent, measures have been taken against a large number ofjournalists.I support the text of this resolution and hope that the Turkish authorities will understand that freedom of expression, human rights and especially the right not to go to prison without evidence are values that must be respected if Turkey is to remain a reliable democratic partner for the EU.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the resolution that at least 99 journalists and writers have been arrested by the Turkish police following a failed coup attempt in Turkey, most of whom have not yet been charged.At the same time, the number of media workers detained on charges that are believed to be related to the exercise of their right to freedom of expression reached at least 130 on 20 October 2016. All detained journalists who have not been proven criminal should be released immediately.and their prosecution and detention cannot be accepted on the basis of the content of their journalistic work.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because Turkey is not part of Europe, and furthermore, a country that is moving further and further away from democracy has no place in the European Union.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported.A free and diverse press, the presumption of innocence and the independence of the judiciary are an integral part of any democratic society.The Turkish Government must not use the failed military coup attempt as a justification to suppress legitimate and peaceful opposition and to prevent journalists and the media from exercising their freedom of expression peacefully through disproportionate and illegal measures.Illegally detained journalists and media workers must be released.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. The failed July coup left 241 dead and thousands injured, while 90 journalists were jailed, more than 2,500 lost their jobs and arrest warrants were issued against hundreds of media workers. In late September, the Turkish government shut down about 20 TV and radio channels, accusing them of "spreading terrorist propaganda" and extending for 90 days the state of emergency declared after the coup attempt (since October 19). Can Dündar, former editor-in-chief of Cumhuriyet, Turkey's main opposition daily newspaper, was arrested in November 2015 following reports in his newspaper showing Turkish intelligence officials selling contraband weapons to Syrian rebels. He was later sentenced to five years and ten months in prison for "disclosing state secrets". Freedom of speech is a fundamental right that must be accepted and respected by all. We must safeguard this right so that objective and impartial information can continue to exist.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. We are pleased to see the successful assault on Mosul and the further dislodgement of ISIS strongholds in Iraq. Appropriate measures must be taken to prevent a further wave of migrants and refugees taking the dangerous routes into Europe. However, the report contains several calls for EU action, which we cannot support.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing.- While taking into consideration the aspects presented in the document relating to the situation of journalists in Turkey and admitting that I will follow the development of the above argument with interest, I believe that the points object of the objection do not fully correspond to my idea and therefore I would not feel like supporting itand I would vote negatively.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - Turkey has expressed a desire to join the European Union. The accession and negotiations that accompany this process aim to ensure a high level of respect for and implementation of the democratic standards adopted in the European Union. This also applies to media freedom and responsible media reporting. I condemn the behavior of the Turkish authorities towards foreign and domestic journalists and support this call for a resolution in order to release innocent journalists as soon as possible. Freedom of public expression and transmission must be respected as the highest democratic standard that is the foundation of democratic pluralism. Violence and torture to which family members of detained Turkish journalists are subjected is unacceptable and should be addressed through sanctions against those responsible. It is contrary to the legal order and legal practice to deprive persons of their liberty without making well-founded accusations and the possibility of appearing and defending themselves against such accusations. Turkey must commit to the fight against terrorism and other asymmetric security threats, but it is also necessary to adjust Turkish anti-terrorism law in a direction that will allow the free work of independent foreign and domestic media and journalists. The closure of news outlets is also an unacceptable precedent and an example of censorship and a violation of the right to freedom of the media, information and work.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. - The arrests of so many, too many, local journalists, writers, academics and politicians in Turkey raise strong concerns about respect for pluralism and freedom of expression. Turkey is an important partner for the EU. With a view to its future accession, it must fully respect, as it has undertaken to do, the principles expressed by the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms. In the country, for journalists and the free press, the situation is becoming increasingly difficult. Even before the failed July 15 coup, there were many imprisoned journalists and very few independent media left. Following the coup attempt, even the last ones were closed: on 27 July 2016, in one fell swoop, 102 media outlets were closed by decree; as of September 14, 101 journalists were detained. The Turkish government has every right to prosecute the perpetrators of the execrable coup attempt, but this cannot be used as a pretext for the violation of human rights and to silence the opponents and the press. For these reasons, I agree with the resolution's call for journalists in prison to be released immediately and unconditionally.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - During the first two and a half months of the state of emergency, the authorities closed about 150 media outlets, leaving more than 2,300 journalists without jobs. Furthermore, police have arrested at least 99 journalists and writers, and no charges have been filed against most of them to date. The arrested journalists were denied their legal rights, while several journalists were allegedly abused in prison. Journalists are also targeted by administrative sanctions, which include the confiscation of passports. Even family members of journalists, despite not being under investigation themselves, are the target of threats and administrative sanctions. Foreign journalists, on the other hand, were deported from Turkey. We therefore join calls on the Turkish authorities to immediately release all detained journalists in the absence of convincing evidence of criminal activity, to lift administrative sanctions against journalists and to refrain from threatening family members of suspected journalists. We also call on the Turkish authorities to prevent violence against the suspects and to investigate allegations of torture of detained journalists. We also demand that closed media be allowed to continue working and be independent in their work.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The resolution strongly condemns the coup d'état, expressing solidarity with the victims. It recognizes the Turkish Government's legitimacy to react to the situation, but considers that this cannot be an excuse to persecute the opposition and condition civil and political rights. He asks for the release of those who are in prison, no type of evidence is imposed on them. Calls for the reopening of closed newspapers. It calls for a restriction of the state of emergency so that it does not serve as a justification for attacking freedom of expression and other rights. It asks for a control of all practical consequences of this situation by the EEAS. By comparison with other initiatives undertaken by the EP in relation to third countries, care and moderation in the approach can be seen, although maintaining a profile of subtle interference. A stance that is linked to the stage of contradictions that Turkey has always been at the service of the imperialist powers to control the Middle East. On the other hand, it is important to point out that, if it is a fact that there was an increase in repression in Turkey, it already existed before the coup, and that none of the main actors in Turkey, external or internal, have real concerns about workers' rights. and the Turkish people.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. - The situation of journalists and media freedom in Turkey is constantly deteriorating. Even before the coup attempt, there were only a handful of independent media and journalists in Turkey, and many more were arrested at the time. After the coup, the remaining were imprisoned. According to Reporters Without Borders, 89 journalists were arrested and 104 in the media during the first six weeks of the state of emergency. Many journalists lost their jobs. I condemn Turkey's actions towards journalists and the media, as well as the recent police raids against them. These steps undermine media freedom, which is a fundamental principle of democracy. I consider it completely inadmissible for these journalists to be detained and imprisoned without any charge being brought against them. I therefore call on the Turkish Government to respect the conditions of democracy and the rule of law and to stop discriminating against citizens in terms of freedom of expression and other fundamental rights. The situation after the failed coup must not be harshly abused in favor of strengthening the positions of Erdogan and his loved ones.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of a resolution urging the Turkish government to release journalists arbitrarily arrested and detained in the country.The Turkish government has multiplied over the recent period and particularly since the attempted coup d'état in the country (which demonstrates the political instability that can take hold there) of actions going against fundamental freedoms defended withinof our European states.As a reminder, since July 2016, the offices of nearly 100 Turkish media have been closed by the authorities and around 100 journalists have been arrested.Against this background, the issue of Turkey's accession to the European Union necessarily arises, the negotiations for which have been going on for several decades.I repeat firmly: I am and will remain opposed to Turkey's entry into our community of the European Union.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. We share serious concerns over developments in Turkey, including freedom of the press. However, this report does not tackle the most serious underlying issue: that Turkey remains an EU accession country and receives EU financing due to this status.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. - (PT) I voted in favor, as I believe that the defense of democracy is imperative, with an unconditional commitment to human rights and the rule of law, it is important, as is the cooperation between the EU, the Council of Europe and Turkey in this matter. The restrictions imposed on the media and the pressures on journalists were already considerable before the failed coup attempt, which according to the Committee for the Protection of Journalists, the Turkish authorities closed the offices of more than 100 broadcasters , newspapers, magazines and publishing and distribution companies, following the coup attempt, leaving more than 2,300 journalists and media workers out of a job. This resolution urges the Turkish Government to delimit the scope of emergency measures, so that they cannot continue to be used to curb freedom of expression and that investigations into the alleged involvement in the attempted coup d'état should be carried out in accordance with the law, impartially and based on irrefutable evidence and not on guilt by association, which can lead to collective punishment.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. - The deterioration of freedom of expression in Turkey has continued to increase, especially after the attempted coup d'état of 15 July this year. 130 journalists and writers were arrested. The authorities ordered the closure of 3 news agencies, 16 TV channels, 23 radio stations, 45 newspapers, 15 magazines and 29 publishers. Freedom of expression is also the right to disagree. This is called Democracy. Journalists have the right to inform and they also have the right to have an opinion, with Turkey running the risk of becoming a dangerous regime that takes its people to the precipice of unique thinking. Is this a credible partner? Not at this moment! And it is not only the situation of journalists, long known, but also that of judges, women, banned books, citizens who are silent. If the right to information had been taken care of, we might have known earlier about the dozens of children to be enslaved in Turkey and who, instead of picking up books, have a needle in their hands to sew the clothes of several European multinationals. We await explanations of these. From Turkey, respect for the rule of law.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written. - The situation of journalists and freedom of the press has suffered a constant deterioration in Turkey, especially after the attempted coup last July, the resolution condemns the coup and supports the legitimate institutions of Turkey, however, it indicates that The failed military coup cannot serve as an excuse for the Turkish government to repress the opposition, nor for it to prevent journalists and the media from exercising freedom of expression, calling on the Turkish authorities to release all journalists and media professionals detained without strong evidence of criminal activity. The resolution denounces that the Turkish authorities have closed the offices of more than one hundred broadcasting organizations, newspapers, magazines, leaving more than 2,300 journalists and communication professionals without employment and revoking the press credentials of at least 330 journalists. The resolution calls for the release of all detained journalists and communication professionals without strong evidence of criminal activity. Finally, remember that a free and plural press is an essential element of any democracy, freedom of expression and of the press.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this European Parliament resolution calling for the release of journalists detained without proof of criminal activity.Turkey holds the sad first place in the world for the detention of journalists.There is an urgent need for the more than 150 media outlets that have been closed to be able to operate independently again and for the dismissed employees to be reinstated.Freedom of the press is a value that must be protected in a democratic society.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - In July 2016, Turkey suffered an attempted coup d'état, which killed around 250 people and injured more than 2100. This was an attack on democratic values, human rights and the rule of law, which was not we must nor can we remain indifferent. It also constitutes a violent blow to freedom of expression - and particularly to freedom of the press, with the Turkish police detaining more than 100 journalists and writers after the blow, without any basis or formal charge of committing any crime, without access to defense, kept in totally inhumane conditions, in a climate of constant threat, terror and torture. The EU cannot accept these gross violations of the basic principles of the rule of law, based on the primacy of democratic governance and respect for the fundamental rights of citizens. To that extent, I was absolutely in favor of passing this resolution, which strongly condemns the illegal detentions and attacks on the rights, freedoms and guarantees of journalists, writers and other Turkish media workers. I endorse the position of urging the Turkish authorities to release the detainees immediately, in what must be a free and democratic society.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I vote in favor of a text that condemns the cycle of increasing repression by the Turkish Government against journalists and the media, exacerbated after the coup attempt in July 2016, and which has resulted in the closure ofnewspapers, the persecution and imprisonment of journalists and the establishment of a climate of authoritarianism and censorship absolutely incompatible with democracy and the rule of law.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted in favor, because it contributes to the international denouncement of the dramatic situation that human rights are currently experiencing in Turkey, especially as regards the free and full exercise of freedom of expression. Unfortunately, Erdogan is taking advantage of the alleged coup against him, to carry out a purge against journalists, teachers, judges, doctors, among others. It acts against anyone who is suspected of being opposition to its government, and has deployed an offensive against its people that is de facto going unpunished, and it is a moral indignity that the Union is silent and complicit by omission in the face of these crimes of a State that it should not be a reliable partner, nor should it be considered safe by the Union. We would have liked the text to reflect more strongly and clearly the condemnation of the behavior of the Turkish government, which acts contrary to international law, however, it is a good start to highlight this situation of violence against journalists in Turkey.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The S&D Group voted in favour of this motion which recalls that a free and pluralistic press is an essential component of any democracy, as are due process, presumption of innocence and judicial independence.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - Turkey is a strategic partner for the EU in resolving the refugee crisis. Turkey has also been a long-standing candidate for EU membership, but we still cannot turn a blind eye to the events that are taking place in Turkey. Turkish police have arrested at least 99 journalists and writers after a coup attempt on 15 July 2016, and most of them have not yet been charged. At least 130 journalists are currently imprisoned. Detained journalists are denied the right to a lawyer and many are imprisoned in inhumane conditions. I supported the motion for a resolution because I agree with calling on the Turkish Government to narrow the scope of the emergency measures so that they cannot be abused while restricting freedom of expression. Only a free and pluralistic press is an essential element of democracy in any free country. Turkey must guarantee fair trials, the presumption of innocence and the independence of the judiciary.
