We recognize that Turkey faces a serious threat of terrorism, but the fight against it cannot serve to punish journalists for exercising their right to freedom of expression.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- The situation of journalists imprisoned in Turkey is alarming after a failed coup attempt.Freedom of speech is one of the basic manifestations of democracy.By applying for membership of the European Union, Turkey has formally committed itself to the rule of law and fundamental rights, by which we also understand freedom of expression as a fundamental democratic value.In this context, Turkey must provide protection against the abuse of power, not only against journalists who face dismissal, prosecution, censorship and, last but not least, many arrests.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: written.- The EU Parliament has passed a motion on the "Situation of Journalists in Turkey".As I indicated in the debate the day before (see video), the strong words were not followed by actions.An application to end the accession negotiations found only 38 supporters and was thrown out with 507 votes against.An application calling on Turkey to observe human rights and minimum democratic and rule of law requirements was rejected.Not even an amendment criticizing the treatment of religious minorities and the refusal to recognize the Republic of Cyprus was accepted.The EU and its parliament are extremely weak towards the dictator from the Bosporus.I therefore did not agree to this motionless, limp and toothless resolution, but abstained.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation of journalists in Turkey.More than 250 people were killed and more than 2,100 were injured in the coup attempt.Regardless of the fact that Turkey is a key partner of the European Union in the migrant crisis, we must continue to demand and insist on respect for human rights and the rule of law.During the coup attempt, the Turkish police arrested at least 99 other journalists and writers, against whom no charges have been filed to date, which may worry us.The resolution rightly emphasizes that the Turkish government must not further suppress the legitimate and peaceful opposition under the pretext of a failed military coup, or prevent journalists and the media from exercising their right to freedom of expression peacefully through disproportionate and illegal acts and measures.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The situation of press freedom in Turkey has deteriorated over the last decade and especially after the failed coup, as the Turkish government abuses the state of emergency it has declared to significantly restrict freedom of speech and the media. In all, about 100 journalists and writers were arrested. Most have not even been charged. 104 media outlets were shut down, resulting in more than 2,300 journalists losing their jobs, the accreditation of at least 330 journalists has been revoked and arrest warrants have been issued against hundreds of media workers in the country. All this is mentioned in the European Parliament resolution. The resolution also stressed that the failed coup could not be used as a pretext to silence the opposition and journalists and called on the Turkish authorities to immediately release journalists and media workers detained without any action against them. The reopening of the media is requested, as well as the re-employment of the dismissed staff. Among other things, Turkey is being called upon to stop violating freedom of expression. For these reasons, we voted in favor of the joint resolution.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing.- Turkey repeatedly and repeatedly violates human rights and does not apply the rules of international law.The EU, for its part, must use its economic power and put in place all legal means to prevent Turkey from continuing this tactic.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution, expressing the fact that I find it unacceptable that the Erdogan government, under the pretext of a recent coup attempt, is grossly restricting freedom of the press, imprisoning journalists, imprisoning journalists, citing an overly broad and vague anti-terrorism law me. The decision clearly draws attention to the fact that one of the most important values ​​of the European Union is freedom of the press, guaranteeing the diversity of the press and the safety of its staff, which a major partner and candidate country such as Turkey is particularly expected to respect. I hope that the EP resolution will guide both the Commission and the Council in further shaping EU policy towards the Erdogan government. However, as a Hungarian opposition MP and Democrat, I cannot ignore the current parallel with the situation in Hungary, where the regime - by more nuanced means - also severely restricts press freedom, eliminates editorials critical of the government and exposing the corruption of its leaders. (People's Freedom Case). With regard to the European Parliament's current resolution, I am convinced that the EU's criticism of Turkey cannot be effective and credible without similar determination against one of its Member States, the Orbán regime, which restricts freedom of the press.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. - The attempted coup in Turkey on July 15, 2016 resulted in the deaths of hundreds of people and over 2,000 people were injured. A few days later, the Turkish authorities introduced a state of emergency that now gives the government almost unlimited control over society. As a result of the coup d'état, Turkish authorities closed the offices of more than 100 newspapers, magazines, publishing houses and distribution companies. At the same time, over 100 journalists and media workers were detained and 330 lost their jobs. The European Parliament resolution strongly condemned the coup d'état in Turkey, stressed the importance of safeguarding democracy and called on the Turkish authorities to release journalists and media workers as well as to open closed offices. A free and pluralist press is essential to any democracy, as are the right to trial, the presumption of innocence, and legal independence. Currently, these elements of democracy are not respected in Turkey, therefore it is imperative that the European Union and its institutions unequivocally call on the Turkish authorities to return to the path of a democratic state of law.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The role of a free press is fundamental in establishing transparency and accountability, especially in a critical situation like the one Turkey is facing now. However, the breach in the freedom of expression of journalists, editors and media workers has gravely deteriorated, even prior to the coup d’état attempt that took place on 15 July. Before the attempted coup, there were only a handful of independent media outlets remaining and numerous journalists imprisoned. Following the event, even the last ones closed down: altogether 102 media organs were shut down by decree on 27 July 2016. Furthermore, as of 14 September 2016 there were 101 journalists detained. I, together with the S&D Group in Parliament condemn the recent police raids and the detention of a number of journalists and media representatives in Turkey, underlining that these actions undermine the freedom of the media, which is a core principle of democracy, and one of the fundamental values of the European Union.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- I am a co-signatory of this resolution.We demand that the Turkish government respect all the conditions of democracy and the rule of law and end discrimination against citizens, with regard to freedom of expression and other fundamental rights.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ On the subject of the deteriorating conditions of journalists in Turkey, the draft motion for a resolution details the violations of freedom of the press, arbitrary detention of journalists, the closure or appropriation of independent media outlets, as well as the alleged torture of imprisoned journalists, all resulting from the failed coup in July 2016. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation of journalist in Turkey, because Turkey, a candidate for EU membership, as well as a close economic and political ally to the EU cannot be allowed to continue violating human rights and the freedom of expression of their own citizens. It is important that the EU holds Turkey accountable and uses every means to ensure Erdogan’s regime loosen its grip on its journalists and opposition.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written.- The situation in Turkey after the attempt to overthrow Erdogan in June this year is chaotic, both politically and civilly.Erdogan has been accused of an authoritarian style of governing, permeated by violations and undermining of fundamental human rights and freedoms.The Commission and Parliament have already expressed concern in their resolutions about violations of media freedoms, but according to information coming from Turkey, the situation has deteriorated sharply after a failed attempt to overthrow Erdogan - hundreds of media outlets have been shut down and dozens of journalists arrested.I believe that Turkey, therefore, should be urgently called upon to respect human rights, including the right to expression, which is at the very heart of democratic values - those which Turkey has committed itself to respecting when applying for membership of the European Union.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the situation of journalists in Turkey. The state of press freedom has deteriorated significantly in Turkey over the last ten years. Turkey ranks 151st among 180 countries in the 2016 Press Freedom Index published by Reporters Without Borders, and ranked 98th in 2005. Freedom of expression and freedom of the press are essential and fundamental components of any democracy, and Turkey remains a candidate for EU membership. According to Reporters Without Borders, 89 journalists were arrested in the first six weeks of the emergency, 104 media outlets were closed, causing more than 2,300 journalists to lose their jobs, and at least 330 journalists had their revocation cards revoked. Violations of media freedom in Turkey have also affected citizens of European countries, such as German satirist Jan Böhmermann and Dutch journalist Ebru Umar. Parliament calls on the Turkish government to respect all the conditions of democracy and the rule of law, and to end discrimination against citizens with regard to freedom of speech and other fundamental rights.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I vote in favor of a text that condemns the cycle of increasing repression by the Turkish Government against journalists and the media, exacerbated after the coup attempt in July 2016, and which has resulted in the closure ofnewspapers, the persecution and imprisonment of journalists and the establishment of a climate of authoritarianism and censorship absolutely incompatible with democracy and the rule of law.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motions for a resolution on the situation of journalists in Turkey. The resolution urges the Turkish authorities to release those journalists and media workers being held without compelling evidence of criminal activity following the coup attempt of 15 July 2016. At least 99 journalists and writers have been arrested, denied the right of access to a lawyer and kept in inhumane conditions in which they are threatened and mistreated. The offices of more than 100 broadcasters, newspapers, magazines, publishers and distribution companies have been closed. The resolution strongly condemns the attempted coup of 15 July 2016 and supports the legitimate institutions of Turkey and their right to respond to the failed military take-over, but stress that this event cannot be used as an excuse to further stifle legitimate and peaceful opposition and to prevent journalists from exercising their freedom of expression. I voted in favour because I believe that a free and pluralistic press is an essential component of any democracy’ and open society.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted in favor, because it contributes to the international denouncement of the dramatic situation that human rights are currently experiencing in Turkey, especially as regards the free and full exercise of freedom of expression. Unfortunately, Erdogan is taking advantage of the alleged coup against him, to carry out a purge against journalists, teachers, judges, doctors, among others. It acts against anyone who is suspected of being opposition to its government, and has deployed an offensive against its people that is de facto going unpunished, and it is a moral indignity that the Union remains silent and is an accomplice by omission to these crimes of a State that it should not be a reliable partner, nor should it be considered safe by the Union. We would have liked the text to reflect more strongly and clearly the condemnation of the behavior of the Turkish government, which acts contrary to international law, however, it is a good start to highlight this situation of violence against journalists in Turkey.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: written.- I took the floor in plenary to say that Europe really needs to reconsider its position on Turkey.Not only does Erdogan harm the rule of law, he also completely ignores democracy and free speech.We can no longer pretend our noses are bleeding and ignore this.We urgently need to reconsider Turkish status as a candidate country and our cooperation projects with Turkey.Erdogan cannot get away with this with impunity.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament adopted a resolution on the situation of journalists in Turkey calling on the Turkish government not to use the failed coup attempt of July 15 to gag the opposition, the media and the judiciary. The resolution denounces media shutdowns, unjustified imprisonments of journalists, breaches of the right to access a lawyer, pressure on the families of journalists and on foreign correspondents. It also once again calls on the government of Turkey to reform its anti-terrorism legislation and reduce the scope of emergency measures in order to put an end to their extensive interpretations that violate freedom of expression. She calls for the reopening of arbitrarily closed media and the release of unjustly imprisoned media professionals. So many reasons why I am a signatory of this text. I regret, however, that the resolution is confined to journalists and media alone, without mentioning the imprisonment of several thousand judges, which undermines the independence of the judiciary and therefore the rule of law. I also regret that the persecutions to which the media and Kurdish personalities are victims were not denounced and that, in this context, the candidacy of Can Dundar for the Sakharov Prize was not retained.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The resolution is based on the coup d'état that took place in Turkey in July this year and addresses the situation of persecution and imprisonment of journalists, writers for alleged links to the coup. Furthermore, he criticizes the closure of newspapers and other publications for being considered against the Turkish Government. There are about 130 media professionals detained at the moment, with about 64 released, while those who remain in detention remain without any proven charges; without the right to a lawyer and being the targets of ill-treatment. The resolution focuses excessively on the coup d'état and does not pinch the privileged relations that the EU maintains with Turkey. See the EU-Turkey Agreement on refugees and the role of NATO member Turkey in the Syrian War. The complexity of the situation requires distance, which should not be confused with simple support or condemnation of the Turkish regime. There are many contradictory interests that revolve around the situation in Turkey.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- The report criticizes the massive restrictions on freedom of expression and freedom of the press and the systematic intimidation of journalists in Turkey after the attempted coup.Reference is also made to the problematic treatment of members of religious and other minorities, the refusal to recognize the Republic of Cyprus and the unclear attitude towards terrorist groups in Syria and Iraq.I share this assessment and have therefore approved the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported the report in favor of the protection of Turkish media and journalists. The restrictions on their freedoms, as we know, are constantly increasing. As we know, even before the attempted coup on July 15, there were relatively few independent and free journalists in Turkey, subject to intimidation and threats from the government. Now this number is gradually increasing: in recent months it is estimated that since the failed coup, following the approval of the decree of 27 July 2016, 102 media have been forced to close as they are accused of collaborating with Gulen, considered the mind of the attempted coup. Furthermore, 101 journalists who are still in detention have been arrested since 14 September 2016. The European Parliament cannot ignore it and must take a serious and firm stance to protect democracy in Turkey, firmly condemning the growing restrictions on freedom of expression imposed by the government.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to express my deep concern for the situation in Turkey and the situation of journalists there, particularly in the Kurdish regions. The recent coup is no justification for the ongoing government crackdown against civil society and media outlets. This dismantling of democracy is unacceptable. Turkey must release all political prisoners, re-open all media outlets, and end violence and persecution of Kurdish communities. I have recently returned from a fact-finding mission in Diyarbakir, where I saw some of the impacts of the intimidation and violence in the region first hand. Working together with civil society organisations, local activists, human rights defenders and journalists, I will continue to speak out for peace and human rights in Kurdistan and elsewhere in Turkey, in an effort to raise international awareness.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since for me as a liberal, the situation of the journalists in Turkey is unacceptable both from a human rights and freedom perspective. We have to stand and defend democracy, with a full commitment to human rights and the rule of law. Certain journalists are still being persecuted by Erdogan’s government and journalism in the country is still totally biased and influenced by the government, and this is totally against my liberal point of view. I believe that we as Europe, should stand united against this trampling on human rights.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing.- Following the failed coup attempt in Turkey, the situation in the country remains serious.Despite the Turkish government's legitimate reaction to the coup attempt, I am concerned about the ongoing purges in the area of freedom of the press.So far, at least 130 journalists have been detained and denied not only the right to a lawyer, but also a reasonable suspicion that these people were and are imprisoned in inhumane conditions.Respect for the right to freedom of expression is also a principle of every rule of law, which is why I fully support this resolution, which calls on the Turkish authorities to respect the freedom and pluralism of the press and the release of journalists and media workers who have been wrongfully imprisoned.We must not forget that freedom of the media and expression in general is a key indicator of a functioning democratic, and especially advanced, society.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - The resolution of the two parliamentary committees deals with the situation of journalists in Turkey. After the coup attempt in July, Turkey is experiencing a wave of chaos, dismissal and imprisonment, which journalists are not avoiding either. Concerns about the state of freedom of expression and freedom of the media in Turkey have already been expressed by the Commission and Parliament in previous resolutions. However, since the adoption of these resolutions, the situation has worsened, several media outlets have been closed and many journalists detained. I think that every country, not to mention a country that wants to become a member of the European Union, must respect fundamental rights and protect the plurality of views that undoubtedly belong to a democratic state, and I therefore agree that the situation of journalists in Turkey is not closed to eyes that we are dealing with it intensively in Parliament. I therefore hope that it will also be a signal for Turkey to try to improve the deteriorating situation.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution of 27 October 2016 on the situation of journalists in Turkey.According to the European Union of Journalists and the Turkish Association of Journalists, Turkish police arrested at least 99 journalists and writers after an attempted coup on July 15, 2016, against whom no charges have been filed to date.Detained journalists are also denied the right to a lawyer and detained in inhumane conditions, threatened and ill-treated.I therefore join in the call for the Turkish government not to further suppress the legitimate and peaceful opposition under the pretext of a failed military coup, or to prevent journalists and the media from peacefully exercising their right to freedom of expression through disproportionate and illegal acts and measures.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, this debate comes during a period of great turbulence in the UK. One of the questions we are asking ourselves in the wake of our decision to leave the EU is: what is our place in the world? I feel very strongly that our place is alongside our allies as part of a peaceful and prosperous Europe.  In this context, the renewal of the Trident nuclear weapons system is not only in breach of our commitments under the Non-Proliferation Treaty, it is also inappropriate, anachronistic and misguided. It is disappointing that Labour continue to support the renewal of Trident, based partly on the idea that nuclear-weapons manufacture and maintenance creates jobs. In response to what I find an illogical and unethical argument, I have commissioned a report into the Devonport dockyard which makes it clear that, for far less public investment, we could invest in socially productive employment to replace Trident related jobs.  I commend those politicians from all parties and countries who work for genuine peace and security in which nuclear weapons can play no part. Using the multilateral negotiations for a legally binding instrument to prohibit nuclear weapons launched at the UN this afternoon, we can finally rid ourselves of these vile and immoral weapons.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, on this point, I would like to say that I ultimately supported the resolution, but I hesitated for a long time, which is why I have to make a reservation here when explaining the vote. I have a problem with a part of this resolution, especially paragraph 16, which mentions and very much welcomes the agreement on Iran's nuclear program. In short, I am skeptical that this agreement will be fulfilled, and in short, I have a large number of reservations about the Iranian regime. However, I ultimately supported the resolution because there are a number of other positive things, in my opinion, be it criticism of North Korea and its permanent threat from nuclear weapons. Or the fact that there is a clear warning of the growing danger of a nuclear threat from Russia, which, as we know, has been in great danger of nuclear weapons lately. It even simulates military exercises simulating the deployment of nuclear weapons against Poland, against Central Europe, and that is a big problem. So in the end, he has support. But there is a big question mark for Iran.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - I have problems with Iran too ... I mean the previous speaker. The security environment in the Union's neighborhood has deteriorated and become increasingly unpredictable. Without saying a word, I sincerely believe that humanity is in danger. The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons is the cornerstone of the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons, but as we know, it has not been signed by all states and in 2015 this did not succeed. So states that are not parties to this treaty are not subject to fundamental international obligations not to proliferate nuclear weapons. This treaty also presents the risk that it will be used against us, so its credibility is very low, the treaty not being signed by all states. Russia currently has the largest arsenal in the world, and media reports have shown that Russia has installed the nuclear-powered Iskander missile system in the Kaliningrad region, which is right next to the European Union, namely Poland and Lithuania. . So we are in danger.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna tuarascáil seo agus dar ndóigh glacadh leis le móramh mór. The work of the Treaty on the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons represented a key effort in hindering the spread of nuclear weapons technology on an international scale.  However, our work does not end here. We will continue to promote the peaceful use of nuclear energy even if total eradication is not a realistic option at present. By this means, we may advance progress towards global nuclear disarmament. Vigilance and cooperation will remain central to these efforts, wherein we will continue to prevent, detect and indeed punish offences related to the use of nuclear materials.  I must say that as a member of the Iranian delegation I look forward to the ordinary citizens of Iran benefiting from economic progress, but also, hopefully, a concomitant improvement in the record of human rights in that country.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- History teaches us that nuclear weapons were the cause of tragic events that destroyed the population of entire cities.To date, in addition to the 5 powers that are part of the UN Security Council, many States are in possession of nuclear weapons, creating a situation of extreme danger for the Member States of the European Union.I believe that the great world powers should strive to seek peace and security without nuclear weapons by promoting the elimination of nuclear weapons.For the reasons described above, I decided to vote against.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. Nuclear deterrence is purely a matter for the currently recognised nuclear powers in Europe, namely the United Kingdom and France. We completely reject any attempt at EU interference in this and all other aspects of Member State defence policy. Non-proliferation is supported by a long-standing international regime, legally based on the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and other international treaties, and supported by international institutions such as the UN, the International Atomic Energy Agency and others. We see no reason for the EU to potentially displace an already largely successful international norm.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted against it, because despite having a positive intention and speaking out in favor of nuclear disarmament, it is a remarkably unbalanced and biased text, which does not contribute to the serious and deep discussion of such an important issue.Once again, the Union suffers from a lack of balance when it comes to making analyzes and proposals that can really serve to contribute to solutions to transcendental issues, such as nuclear security and non-proliferation.An attempt that could be of great contribution to the fight for peace, is lost in disproportionate attacks against the Russian Federation, and at the same time omits the responsibility of NATO and the United States in the proliferation of nuclear weapons.Nor is Israel mentioned, which has more than 300 nuclear warheads, as if it were not a leading actor on the nuclear issue and in the world geopolitical configuration.Faced with this hypocrisy, I have voted against.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted for this resolution because I am deeply concerned about the deterioration of the security situation in the Union's neighborhood and beyond, which could lead to a resurgence of nuclear weapons as an active deterrent andpossible proliferation among state and non-state actors, as well as the lack of effective disarmament and non-proliferation measures.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. - This report constitutes the extension of the European strategy of 2003 against nuclear proliferation and takes place in the context of the anniversary of the non-proliferation treaty. While the objective of reducing nuclear armaments can be accepted as an international objective, most of the resolutions contain serious attacks on State sovereignty, such as: the desire to force France and England to give up their strike forces; the joint resolution also calls for the establishment of a principle of binding international law (jus cogens) imposing an end to nuclear weapons - such a provision is a danger for classic international law based on the will of states; the various resolutions call for an end to technological improvement and maintenance of nuclear arsenals; the fight against proliferation is already attributed at the international level to various agencies such as the IAEA, the EU does not have to use this cause to acquire an international role. It should be noted that only the ECR resolution - in favor of which I voted - respects the sovereignty of States and their right to possess tactical nuclear weapons in accordance with voluntary international conventions. As for the joint resolution, I voted against.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the alternative motion for a resolution by the ECR group, as it was unobjectionable and far better than the resolution as a whole. I voted against the resolution as a whole for a number of reasons, but fundamentally the key point is that it is not for the European Union to instruct Member States what their defence policies should be. Defence of the realm is a matter of national sovereignty and I cannot support any resolution which seeks to undermine that.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this joint resolution denouncing the deteriorating security situation in the Union's neighborhood and beyond.The proliferation of nuclear weapons, coupled with the lack of effective disarmament measures, is a real threat and it is necessary that the Union, in collaboration with international institutions, take measures to counter the phenomenon.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen (ALDE)
text: written.- The VVD is against unilateral nuclear disarmament and has only agreed to the non-proliferation resolution because it does not advocate unilateral steps.The VVD also endorses the report's observation that nuclear intimidation from Russia is on the rise and that this is a threat to Europe, in particular to the Eastern European and Baltic member states.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- Currently, 191 states are parties to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, including five states recognized as nuclear-weapon states: the United States, the United Kingdom, Russia, France and China.The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons is a precedent-setting international treaty aimed at preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons and weapons technology.I therefore agree that the goals of non-proliferation must provide the basis for a global effort to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons, to promote the safe and peaceful use of nuclear energy for civilian purposes and to achieve the elimination of nuclear weapons in the world.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. Nuclear deterrence is purely a matter for the currently recognised nuclear powers in Europe, namely the United Kingdom and France. We completely reject any attempt at EU interference in this and all other aspects of Member State defence policy. Non-proliferation is supported by a long-standing international regime, legally based on the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and other international treaties, and supported by international institutions such as the UN, the International Atomic Energy Agency and others. We see no reason for the EU to potentially displace an already largely successful international norm.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- I was unable to vote in favor of this resolution, which intends to grant the European Union a diplomatic role that would encroach on French sovereignty, while de facto reducing the influence and defense capabilities of our country.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing.- I supported this joint resolution in which Parliament expresses its deep concern at the deterioration of the security situation in the Union's neighborhood (resulting in particular from the attitude of Russia) and beyond.This deterioration could lead to a resurgence of nuclear weapons as an active deterrent and proliferation among state and non-state actors as well as the absence of effective disarmament and non-proliferation measures.The resolution therefore calls on all nuclear powers to take concrete interim measures to mitigate the risk of nuclear explosion and to rapidly reduce the number of nuclear weapons of all types.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. - The issue of nuclear safety and non-proliferation has received renewed attention in the last period following the increase in international tensions and the tightening of relations between states that hold nuclear weapons. As of January 2016, nine states (USA, Russia, United Kingdom, France, China, India, Pakistan, Israel and North Korea) were reported to possess approximately 15,395 nuclear weapons. The resolution approved today by Parliament, and supported by me, expresses deep concern about the deterioration of the security environment in the area around the Union, and beyond its neighborhood, and the role that nuclear weapons have returned to assume in military doctrines. Europe has a duty to strengthen disarmament and non-proliferation policies and international cooperation on the peaceful use of nuclear energy. States possessing warheads must reduce all types of nuclear weapons and become the protagonists of a new United Nations conference in 2017 that can negotiate a legally binding instrument to ban nuclear weapons.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- A safer world needs us to take the disappearance of nuclear arsenals really seriously and we must lead by example.The growing climate of insecurity may give rise to a new episode of proliferation of this type of weapon of mass destruction.That is why we do not agree with any type of operation that, in European countries with nuclear arsenal, is developed to manufacture new weapons or improve existing ones.This is incompatible with the signing of the NPT, which obliges to reduce and / or eliminate arsenals and not to join this new impulse to the military doctrine of deterrence.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against the joint resolution relating to nuclear security and non-proliferation because, although this text starts out with a good intention, it falls short of interference in the policy of defense strategy of Member and non-member states. It bothers me that a supranational but non-state structure like the EU notably allows itself to dictate to sovereign nations what military doctrines they should apply. It is also interesting to note that, at the same time as it wishes to channel the defense capabilities of the Member States, the EU seems to want to increase its own. If this resolution therefore draws the outlines of a “defense Europe”, it would obviously be carried out within the framework of NATO, that is to say under American control: however, the authors of text no. are not afraid to accuse Russia of all possible violations of freedom. One wonders what freedom would be for a European army with the boot of the Atlanticist strategy. Finally, I wanted to support the resolution brought by ECR on the subject because it has the merit of being respectful of the sovereignty of States as well as of international conventions.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- We all want a world in which there is no danger of a nuclear war, however unclear passages remain in the resolution that led me to a vote of abstention.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written.- I have voted in favor of the proposed Resolution on nuclear safety and non-proliferation, since United Nations Resolution 1540 is the main instrument to articulate arms control, serving to prevent non-state agents from acquiring or using weapons of mass destructionfor terrorist purposes.Currently there has been a deterioration of security conditions in Europe, in addition to armed conflicts near our borders that pose serious threats to peace, security and stability, elements that must always be present in European and global politics, forwhat is necessary to increase international cooperation.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution, which deals with nuclear security and non-proliferation. The European Parliament is deeply concerned about the deteriorating security environment around the European Union and beyond, as nuclear weapons could be re-introduced as active deterrents and acquired by state and non-state actors, as well as the lack of effective safeguards. disarmament and non-proliferation measures. It therefore calls on all nuclear-weapon States to take concrete intermediate measures to reduce the risk of nuclear explosions, including reducing the status of nuclear weapons and their transfer from storage to storage, reducing the role of nuclear weapons in military doctrines and rapidly reducing the amount of nuclear weapons. Parliament approves the 2016 the Nuclear Security Summit, which recognized that the illicit trade in and use of nuclear materials poses a direct threat to global security, and hopes that full tracing and physical protection of all materials suitable for the production of weapons will be pursued.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. - The motion responds primarily to the deteriorating security situation in the European Union's neighborhood. All this could lead to a resumption of the practice of nuclear armaments for deterrence. In addition, there is a further risk of non-implementation of effective steps towards disarmament and non-proliferation. The motion calls on nuclear-weapon States to take concrete measures to reduce the risk of nuclear explosions and to take immediate action to reduce the number of nuclear weapons. In addition, the motion expresses concern about Russia’s role and attitude, which has significantly increased the nuclear threat. As a result, the global security situation has deteriorated, stability and predictability have faltered, and NATO-Russia relations have deteriorated significantly. The motion also supports the convening of the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit, recognizing that the unauthorized trade and use of nuclear materials poses a direct and serious threat to world security.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the resolution on nuclear safety and non-proliferation. I agree with the fact that the global security environment, and in particular the EU security environment, has deteriorated greatly and become less predictable. The deterioration of relations between nuclear-weapon states has also not contributed to this. As a matter of priority, I agree with preventing access to terrorist organizations or countries to acquire or use nuclear weapons. It is important that we continue towards the goal of reducing and destroying all nuclear arsenals and advancing towards a world without nuclear weapons. I welcome the fact that nuclear-weapon-free treaties already exist in some regions of the world, namely Latin America and the Caribbean, the South Pacific, South-East Asia, Africa and Central Asia. I am concerned about the fact that countries that have nuclear weapons and are signatories to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons are updating and strengthening their nuclear weapons.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this Report on Nuclear Safety and Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons.When international peace, security and stability are seriously challenged by various events, including the deteriorating relations between nuclear-armed states, it is important to emphasize what we need to stand for the most: peace, security and stability.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament recognizes the right of states with recognized nuclear weapons to maintain their nuclear deterrent as an important element of national security. It supports the NPT's goals in laying the foundations for global efforts to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons, to promote the safe and secure use of civilian nuclear energy and to pursue the goal of a world without nuclear weapons. It also believes that the conditions for security and sustainable nuclear disarmament can only be achieved through a multilateral process. It therefore deplores Russia's absence from the 2016 nuclear safety summit and encourages renewed efforts to promote cooperation with Moscow. Supports the work of the International Atomic Energy Agency in promoting cooperation in the nuclear sector for the safe and peaceful use of nuclear technologies and encourages the continued promotion and strict implementation of the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Materials, urging countries that have not yet ratified the convention to do so. It also calls for intensified cooperation efforts and effective action regarding the safety of nuclear materials in order to minimize the risk of such products falling into the hands of terrorist groups.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution is part of the 2003 European strategy against nuclear proliferation. We obviously share the desire to contribute to the reduction of nuclear weapons. However, we cannot support this motion for a resolution, which seriously undermines the sovereignty of the Member States. This text advocates, in effect, forcing France and England to give up their strike forces. In addition, we are calling for an end to technological improvement and the maintenance of nuclear arsenals without realizing the consequences that such measures could have for the safety of our fellow citizens. Finally, we recall that the fight against nuclear proliferation must be addressed between sovereign nations at the international level. Therefore, the European Union has no diplomatic legitimacy to intervene in this area. I therefore voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - International security and stability are threatened by deteriorating relations between nuclear powers such as the United States and Russia, as evidenced by Russia's suspension of the 2000 Pluto Management and Disposal Agreement and ongoing tensions between India and Pakistan. Following the deterioration of the security environment around the European Union, there is the issue of the resurgence of nuclear weapons as an active deterrent, but also a possible nuclear proliferation, which contradicts the principles of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons preventing the spread of nuclear weapons, promoting the safe and secure use of civilian nuclear energy and pursuing the goal of a world without nuclear weapons. I am in favor of this motion for a resolution on nuclear safety and non-proliferation, because I believe that every effort must be made to ensure a stable security environment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the declaration on "Nuclear Safety and Non-Proliferation" by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, because nuclear disarmament is the most important goal of global policies inarms control matters.The goal of a nuclear-free world should be the ultimate long-term ambition.Unfortunately, there is concern for international stability following the deterioration of relations between states with nuclear weapons, such as the United States and Russia.There is also concern about the reappearance of the nuclear spectrum, as a deterrent, at the borders of Europe.The EU needs to work tirelessly to continue the disarmament program and to call for an ad hoc conference for 2017 to negotiate a "legally binding" instrument to definitively ban the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ On the resolution for nuclear non-proliferation I voted in favour of the joint resolution. I supported it as this resolution is explicit in opposing the multilateral proliferation of nuclear weapons, and clear in supporting disarmament. The successful vote on this joint resolution took place just before the UN General Assembly’s First Committee voted in favour of beginning negotiations for a treaty on the prohibition of nuclear weapons. This resolution gives support to that process.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I wanted to expresses my deep concern at the increased nuclear threats with implications for security, stability and predictability at global level, and at the deteriorating relationship with NATO, statements indicating an increased readiness to use nuclear weapons, and statements indicating consideration of the potential deployment of nuclear weapons to additional territories in Europe by Russia. I welcome the inclusion of non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction (WMD) clauses in the EU’s agreements with third countries and action plans and that such measures must be implemented by all the EU’s partner countries without exception. I welcome regular engagements with these topics via the EU Non-Proliferation Consortium and other civil society organisations and think tanks, and invite the EU Non-Proliferation Consortium to broaden its agenda and include disarmament.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the key messages included in the present resolution, and that is why I voted in favour of it. In the current security context, where a number of state and non-state actors raise asymmetric risks and use hybrid and other types of warfare, we have to be strict on the global nuclear control policy. The international agreements in this sector have to be respected and implemented. The risk is simply too high to overlook it.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing.- We believe that the conditions for security and sustainable nuclear disarmament can only be achieved through a multilateral process in which the parties participate in good faith.We also believe that nuclear disarmament is the most important goal of global arms control policies and that the pursuit of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) for a world without nuclear weapons should be the ultimate long-term ambition..

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - Firmly supporting this resolution represents for me a firm attempt to improve the world. On the other hand, if we believe that the spread of nuclear weapons is inevitable, then we are admitting in some form that the use of nuclear weapons will be inevitable. Therefore, in the face of global security that is vacillating from every point of view given the emergence of the most disparate and multiform risks, a further delay in the full application of non-proliferation is not admissible. The diffusion of weapons of mass destruction and of the relative vectors constitutes a mammoth fear for the international community, in particular it is essential to prevent terrorists from obtaining and using them. Therefore, a prompt establishment of a nuclear-free zone in the Middle East would be essential in order to guarantee a lasting and stable peace. I have great hope for the absolute traceability and safety of all nuclear materials intended for military use and I yearn with great participation in the conference set up for 2017 by the United Nations to negotiate legally binding instruments to ban nuclear weapons and allow them to be complete elimination.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on nuclear security and non-proliferation and supported Amendment 2, which calls on nuclear-weapon states to refrain from the use or threat of use of nuclear weapons.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The global security situation and the deteriorating security context around the European Union pose serious risks for the resurgence of nuclear weapons as an active means of deterrence and of the possible proliferation between state and non-state actors, causing serious concern about possible violations of the Treaty of medium-range Nuclear Forces, which has generated tensions in relations within NATO. I support this Resolution as I consider it necessary to take the path of non-proliferation of nuclear weapons. I advocate a deepening of the dialogue with all nuclear weapon states, with a view to pursuing a common program aimed at the progressive reduction of the arsenal of nuclear warheads, as well as taking measures to reduce the risk of explosions and their transfer of nuclear weapons. deployment zones for storage locations. To welcome the results achieved by the UN Open Working Group charged with moving forward with multilateral negotiations on nuclear disarmament, the progress made by the Preparatory Commission for the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization with regard to the conclusion and effective implementation of the International Surveillance System. I welcome the inclusion of nuclear non-proliferation clauses in the Agreements between the EU and third countries.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the provision as starting from the consideration of how the global security situation, particularly as regards the EU, has worsened, the current scenario could lead to the reappearance of nuclear weapons as an active deterrent andtheir possible proliferation between state and non-state subjects.It is therefore necessary that all states that possess nuclear weapons take concrete interim measures to reduce the risk of nuclear weapons explosions, progressing towards a weakening of their operational status and moving from their deployment to their storage.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted against it, because despite having a positive intention and speaking out in favor of nuclear disarmament, it is a remarkably unbalanced and biased text, which does not contribute to the serious and deep discussion of such an important issue.Once again, the Union suffers from a lack of balance when it comes to making analyzes and proposals that can really serve to contribute to solutions to transcendental issues, such as nuclear security and non-proliferation.An attempt that could be of great contribution to the fight for peace, is lost in disproportionate attacks against the Russian Federation, and at the same time omits the responsibility of NATO and the United States in the proliferation of nuclear weapons.Nor is Israel mentioned, which has more than 300 nuclear warheads, as if it were not a leading actor on the nuclear issue and in the world geopolitical configuration.Faced with this hypocrisy, I have voted against.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. - Nuclear safety and non-proliferation is an important issue on the European agenda, especially in the face of the current context of European and global security, which has worsened as it is more permeable to hybrid and non-conventional threats. Since its entry into force in 1970, the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) has been the legal reference point for non-proliferation and disarmament at the international level. Through its three pillars - nuclear disarmament, non-proliferation and the use of atomic energy for peaceful purposes - the treaty aims to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons and to promote cooperation between states on nuclear energy for civilian uses. Nuclear weapon states and NPT signatories are modernizing and upgrading their nuclear weapons arsenals and delaying actions to reduce or eliminate them and to break away from a military doctrine of nuclear deterrence. Furthermore, Russia's exercises in some EU states, such as Poland, raise concerns about a new nuclear rearmament. By voting in favor of this resolution, I intend to support compliance with and full implementation of the NPT Treaty and the Treaty on Medium Range Nuclear Forces (INF).

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- On the motion for a resolution on nuclear safety and non-proliferation, I chose to abstain.I appreciate the efforts of world leaders to narrow international cooperation.In the face of the threat of nuclear terrorism, it is so important to improve security and take steps to prevent the proliferation of such weapons.In my opinion, the motion for a resolution needs to be fine-tuned because it is too general and does not provide precise guidelines on how to counter the problem of nuclear proliferation.For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing.- This resolution concerns nuclear non-proliferation and the preventive measures relating to it.Considering that this resolution goes well beyond simple recommendations on nuclear management, by insisting on the need to "rapidly reduce the number of nuclear weapons of all types", by establishing a binding legal instrument banning nuclear weapons andpaving the way for their total ban, including for recognized military powers such as France, I decided to vote against this report which goes beyond the framework of its mandate without effectively tackling the issue of proliferation in theworld.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I did not support the resolution on nuclear security and non-proliferation.Although it is extremely important to have a strict framework on the issue of nuclear proliferation to prevent, in particular, that terrorists or new states do not acquire or use nuclear weapons, I am not in favor.the holding of a conference open to all States to negotiate a legally binding instrument banning nuclear weapons and paving the way for their total ban.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution on nuclear security and non-proliferation because it includes paragraphs which make proposals that are inappropriate to the reality of certain Member States.The text indeed proposes a ban on nuclear weapons, to move towards total elimination.This proposal seems to me unsuitable for countries which have a nuclear arsenal and conduct a strictly defensive and dissuasive policy.I am more in favor of pragmatic and gradual disarmament, but this resolution unfortunately does not offer that solution.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. - The motion responds primarily to the deteriorating security situation in the European Union's neighborhood. All this could lead to a resumption of the practice of nuclear armaments for deterrence. In addition, there is a further risk of non-implementation of effective steps towards disarmament and non-proliferation. The motion calls on nuclear-weapon States to take concrete measures to reduce the risk of nuclear explosions and to take immediate action to reduce the number of nuclear weapons. In addition, the motion expresses concern about Russia’s role and attitude, which has significantly increased the nuclear threat. As a result, the global security situation has deteriorated, stability and predictability have faltered, and NATO-Russia relations have deteriorated significantly. The motion also supports the convening of the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit, recognizing that the unauthorized trade and use of nuclear materials poses a direct and serious threat to world security.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. - The motion responds primarily to the deteriorating security situation in the European Union's neighborhood. All this could lead to a resumption of the practice of nuclear armaments for deterrence. In addition, there is a further risk of non-implementation of effective steps towards disarmament and non-proliferation. The motion calls on nuclear-weapon States to take concrete measures to reduce the risk of nuclear explosions and to take immediate action to reduce the number of nuclear weapons. In addition, the motion expresses concern about Russia’s role and attitude, which has significantly increased the nuclear threat. As a result, the global security situation has deteriorated, stability and predictability have faltered, and NATO-Russia relations have deteriorated significantly. The motion also supports the convening of the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit, recognizing that the unauthorized trade and use of nuclear materials poses a direct and serious threat to world security.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing.- This text follows on from the 2003 European strategy against nuclear proliferation and takes place in the context of the anniversary of the non-proliferation treaty.While it is laudable to aim for the reduction of nuclear weapons as an international objective, the joint resolution advocates the establishment of a principle of binding international law (jus cogens) imposing an end to nuclear weapons.Such a provision constitutes a danger for classical international law based on the consent of States.Finally, let us remember that the fight against proliferation has already been attributed at the international level to various agencies such as the IAEA.The EU should not use this cause as an excuse to play an international role.So I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: In written form. - The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons aims to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons and technology, as well as to promote cooperation in the peaceful uses of nuclear energy and to achieve comprehensive and complete nuclear disarmament. I supported the resolution on nuclear security and non-proliferation, as global cooperation in this area must be strengthened in order to minimize the threat of nuclear terrorism, which is becoming increasingly real today.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing.- We are voting against the joint motion for a resolution because it is ungrounded, exposes Europe to danger and is openly against Russia, although it is clearly not to blame for the current tense situation.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. - The motion responds primarily to the deteriorating security situation in the European Union's neighborhood. All this could lead to a resumption of the practice of nuclear armaments for deterrence. In addition, there is a further risk of non-implementation of effective steps towards disarmament and non-proliferation. The motion calls on nuclear-weapon States to take concrete measures to reduce the risk of nuclear explosions and to take immediate action to reduce the number of nuclear weapons. In addition, the motion expresses concern about Russia’s role and attitude, which has significantly increased the nuclear threat. As a result, the global security situation has deteriorated, stability and predictability have faltered, and NATO-Russia relations have deteriorated significantly. The motion also supports the convening of the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit, recognizing that the unauthorized trade and use of nuclear materials poses a direct and serious threat to world security.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this important vote which calls on the Member States to vote in favour of a UN General Assembly resolution today which will trigger work on a new treaty banning all nuclear weapons. It also refers to the withdrawal of all tactical nuclear weapons from Europe, the need to establish a nuclear-free zone in Europe and to continue working on the conference leading to a Middle East free of weapons of mass destruction. It criticises the modernisation of nuclear arsenals. As someone who has long campaigned against nuclear weapons and supported a nuclear-free Wales, I was delighted this report was adopted.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - The global security situation, and in particular that of the EU, has deteriorated significantly in recent years, becoming more unstable, dangerous and unpredictable. International peace, security and stability are seriously threatened by several developments, including the deterioration of relations between nuclear weapon states, such as the Russian Federation and the United States of America, India and Pakistan, as well as the continuation of North Korea's nuclear capacity development. I am deeply concerned about the deteriorating security environment around the European Union and its neighborhood, which can lead not only to the resurgence of nuclear weapons as an active means of deterrence, but also to the possible proliferation between state and non-state actors. I consider it essential that all states with nuclear weapons take concrete provisional measures to reduce the risk of nuclear explosions, namely by reducing the operationality of nuclear weapons and their transfer from deployment areas to storage sites, reducing the role of nuclear weapons. nuclear weapons in military doctrines and the rapid reduction of all types of nuclear weapons.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Vote against the joint resolution: while the reduction of nuclear armaments can be accepted as an international objective, the resolution involves serious attacks on the sovereignty of States.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution is corroded at the base. It is absolutely partial in analyzing the problem. Launching fierce criticism of Russia or the People's Democratic Republic of Korea, stripping them of context, regional framework and scale, it omits the role that the USA and European nuclear powers (France and the United Kingdom) have taken on in this regard, namely by continuing to renewal of its nuclear arsenal, and NATO's increasingly belligerent role. We note the absence of condemnation of Israel's nuclear policy, or criticism of the growing militarization of the EU, the intention to increase the military budgets of States, the deepening of the CSDP, the claim for a European Defense Union parallel to NATO, the decentralization of weapons by the USA for different countries. Absurd, and yet revealing, the absence of any reference to the imperative defense of peace, as opposed to the apocalyptic scenario that may result from a nuclear conflict on a global scale. There is an urgent need for the reduction and elimination of nuclear weapons and the creation of a policy to eliminate these types of devices, the creation of a Europe free of nuclear weapons, and to implement initiatives such as the UN resolutions of December 2011 and 2012, of free zones. nuclear weapons in the Middle East, the Mediterranean and Northeast Africa.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstain from the resolution denouncing Russian "war games" on its western border without the slightest mention of EU and NATO responsibilities.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: in writing. - I strongly support the provisions expressing deep concern about the intensification of the nuclear threat as a result of Russia's attitude - which has implications for security, stability and predictability at the global level - and the deterioration of relations with NATO, including potential violations of the Treaty on the Elimination of Medium and Intermediate-Range Missiles, statements pointing to increased nuclear readiness and consideration of the possibility of deploying nuclear weapons in the occupied Crimea and Königsberg. I am glad that the European Parliament drew attention to the Russian military exercises simulating the use of nuclear weapons against Poland and expressed its deep concern about the deployment of Iskander missiles in the Królewiecki region and the fact that Russia was carrying out exercises and flights with the use of systems capable of carrying nuclear warheads. The EP rightly condemns the Kremlin's breach of the Budapest memorandum, and draws attention to the statements by Russian leaders about the importance of nuclear deterrence and Russia's decision to suspend the plutonium disposal agreement. I likewise assess the condemnation of North Korea for violating a number of UN Security Council resolutions, including the last resolution of March 2, 2016. Once again, however, the correct assessment of the facts contradicts some conclusions. I am referring to the weakening of the role of deterrence, which I cannot agree to in light of the above facts. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing.- I vote against the motions for resolutions on nuclear safety and non-proliferation as a whole, as they pose a threat to Europe and are openly directed against Russia, although it is clearly not to blame for the current tense situation.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the agreement reached on this resolution but I would like to express my deep concern for the many nuclear threats that are arising in different parts of the world. North Korea continues to reject UN Security Resolutions and to conduct nuclear test. This is not tolerable and has to be condemned by all means. Russia has deployed short-range missiles to Kaliningrad and, possible, in Crimea. This deteriorated situation is extremely dangerous for the security of the Euro Atlantic Area, especially in the Black Sea region. The fact that they believe they have the right to deploy nuclear weapons in these two areas represents a serious global threat and the European Union should have to respond accordingly, in cooperation with NATO.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: in writing. – I have voted in favour of this resolution because I am concerned about the deteriorating security environment around the EU and beyond its neighbourhood and the atrocious humanitarian impact of nuclear weapons. First of all, I strongly support the references in the resolution to existing mechanisms on nuclear security and non-proliferation. I am convinced that our world order should be anchored on international law. Therefore, I am in favour of the full implementation and enforcement of multilateral disarmament, non-proliferation and arms control treaties and regimes. I think the EU should use every means at its disposal to assist in resolving proliferation crises, as we successfully did on the Iranian nuclear programme. For that reason, I also welcome the suggestion to convene a UN conference in 2017 to negotiate a legally binding instrument to prohibit nuclear weapons. Such a conference might foster the EU Member States to agree on a joint position on nuclear disarmament and make of EU a driving force in strengthening and taking forward multilateral nuclear disarmament and non-proliferation agreements.

text: in writing. - The motion responds primarily to the deteriorating security situation in the European Union's neighborhood. name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the joint resolution of the European Parliament on nuclear safety and non-proliferation because I share the concerns it contains and the proposals made. The disarmament of all nuclear weapons for a world free from this threat was one of the great goals behind the creation of the United Nations. The horror of Hiroshima's images is still a vivid memory today, more than seventy years later. The agreement with Iran seemed to be a decisive step towards this goal, but unfortunately we have to take several steps backwards. The international climate has in fact worsened considerably in recent years and we are witnessing provocative behavior by nations that threaten the use of nuclear technology with an unacceptable lightness. The actions of North Korea and Russia, the continuous nuclear exercises, the positioning of Russian missiles on the NATO borders are in fact actions that we strongly condemn. I therefore join in the appeal of fellow Members for an immediate cessation of all frivolous hostilities and for a common international effort in favor of a complete disarmament of nuclear weapons.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: written.- I abstained from the vote on the resolution on 'Nuclear Safety and Non-Proliferation'.Although I fully support the goal of a world free of nuclear weapons, I nevertheless urge you to respect national competences and sovereignties in this case too.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: written.- The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT), concluded in 1968, still represents a central regime for dealing with nuclear weapons. The nuclear disarmament and the ban on the proliferation of nuclear weapons are a central component of our modern peace order in Europe and worldwide.Therefore, the NPT must continue to be upheld and the work of the International Atomic Energy Agency supported in promoting cooperation in the nuclear field.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted firmly in favor of this motion because it is important for Parliament too to make its voice heard firmly, to indicate in this area also what European citizens want.The global strategy of the European Union presented by the Vice-President / High Representative rightly fits into the wake of this debate by pointing to the pursuit of international security as the guideline for our joint action.The update of the EU anti-proliferation strategy may be the right occasion for the EU to be at the forefront of this global awareness battle, so that as many countries as possible can confidently take the path of non-proliferation andnuclear disarmament.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution which expresses our deep concern at the deterioration of the security environment around the Union and beyond its neighboring States, which could lead to the reappearance of nuclear weapons as an active deterrent andits possible proliferation between state and non-state agents, as well as, in the absence of effective disarmament and non-proliferation measures.The resolution also supports the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit and recognizes that the unauthorized trade and use of nuclear materials is an immediate and serious threat to global security, and hopes to achieve a complete monitoring and physical security ofall the appropriate materials for the construction of weapons, something that we consider essential.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. A deep concern was expressed about the deterioration of the security environment around the European Union and beyond its neighbourhood, which could lead to the re-emergence of nuclear weapons. Therefore I support the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit, recognising that the unauthorised trade in and use of nuclear materials is an immediate and serious threat to global security, and it is important to achieve the complete tracking and physical securing of all weapons-grade materials.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ While I am concerned about the deterioration of the security environment around the European Union and beyond its neighbourhood, which could lead to the re-emergence of nuclear weapons as an active deterrent and possible proliferation among state and non-state actors, and about the lack of implementation of effective disarmament and non-proliferation steps, I believe it to be necessary that the maintaining of nuclear weapons should be limited and indeed stopped. Accordingly, I have voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: written.- The last nuclear safety summit, held in DC, resulted in good suggestions for improvement and support from international institutions.The summit was a success, although it is unfortunate that Russia did not attend, especially given the size of its nuclear arsenal.Still, 101 countries still comply with the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons.Alliance for Progress and Awakening strongly supports efforts to reduce the threat posed by nuclear terrorism.That is why I voted for this resolution.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE)
text: written.- The VVD is against unilateral nuclear disarmament and has only agreed to the non-proliferation resolution because it does not advocate unilateral steps.The VVD also endorses the report's observation that nuclear intimidation from Russia is increasing and that this is a threat to Europe, in particular to the Eastern European and Baltic member states.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is important to uphold international peace, security and stability. This is crucial specifically in today’s deteriorating security environment from both a geopolitical and geostrategic perspective.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Joint Motion for a resolution on nuclear security and non-proliferation, because nuclear disarmament should be the most important goal of global arms control policies, and the ultimate long-term goal of the NTP is a world without nuclear weapons.As the security situation in the European Union, especially in its neighborhood, has deteriorated significantly over the past few years and has become more volatile, dangerous and unpredictable, this has forced Member States to face a wide range of traditional and non-traditional threats from state and non-state actors..This Joint Proposal supports the objectives of the Treaty on Nuclear Non-Proliferation, as they underpin global efforts to prevent its proliferation, to promote the safe use of nuclear energy for civilian purposes and to achieve the goal of eliminating nuclear weapons in the world.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- This proposal justifies, in my opinion, a diplomatic role that should not fall to the European Union, just as it threatens the French strike force.I voted against.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In light of the deteriorating relations between nuclear-armed states such as Russia and the US or Pakistan and India, given Russia’s threats to use nuclear weapons or to deploy them to additional areas in Europe, the EU is faced with a very tense and fragile security environment. In that concerning context, the Union must urgently reinforce non-proliferation, disarmament and cooperation on the peaceful use of nuclear energy, which is what this text calls for. I also share the view that the UN must convene a conference in 2017 in order to negotiate legally binding instruments to prohibit the use of nuclear weapons.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted against the resolution on nuclear security and non-proliferation.The text went against France’s nuclear deterrence strategy, which helps protect Europe, which I could not support.However, I agree with the positions denouncing the deterioration of relations between the countries which have nuclear weapons, which seriously undermines the security of Europe.Like the deal with Iran, more than ever we must continue efforts to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons around the world.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written.- The present report contains good proposals for reducing the nuclear threat.These include negative security guarantees, commitments not to use weapons and to disarm their arsenal.Had this report not been formulated so unilaterally against Russia - which has ratified the Non-Proliferation Treaty - I would have approved it.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: written.- The last nuclear safety summit, held in Washington, resulted in good suggestions for improvement and support from international institutions.The summit was a success, although it is unfortunate that Russia did not attend, especially given the size of its nuclear arsenal.Still, 101 countries still comply with the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons.The Alliance for Progress and Awakening strongly supports efforts to reduce the threat posed by nuclear terrorism.That is why I voted for this resolution.
