name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution because it is too aggressive towards Russia.On the other hand and above all, the EU is trying to interfere in France's nuclear defense policy.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution which seeks to end nuclear deterrence.Considering the current international security context, this strategy does not seem relevant, because we need these defensive tools which help to guarantee our sovereignty.This resolution proposes a counterproductive process, while certain countries, including France, are currently committed to progressive and pragmatic disarmament, which would not be applied by the main countries concerned.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of this resolution because nuclear safety and non-proliferation is a key issue among the social democratic proposals. Currently, security conditions for Europe are deteriorating, and armed conflicts of different kinds are taking place very close to our external borders. At this time, Europe is contemplating conventional, unconventional, even nuclear threats, generated by both state and non-state actors. It should be noted how certain actors outside the Union behave in a debatable manner in respecting or applying the agreements related to nuclear safety, with peace, security and stability being seriously questioned by various events, deteriorating relations between nuclear weapon states; It is for this reason that it is very important to highlight the importance for socialists of these three elements of European and global politics: peace, security and stability. International cooperation must be expanded to prevent potential suppliers of these types of weapons from becoming actual suppliers.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted against it, because despite having a positive intention and speaking out in favor of nuclear disarmament, it is a remarkably unbalanced and biased text, which does not contribute to the serious and deep discussion of such an important issue.Once again, the Union suffers from a lack of balance when it comes to making analyzes and proposals that can really serve to contribute to solutions to transcendental issues, such as nuclear security and non-proliferation.An attempt that could be of great contribution to the fight for peace, is lost in disproportionate attacks against the Russian Federation, and at the same time omits the responsibility of NATO and the United States in the proliferation of nuclear weapons.Nor is Israel mentioned, which has more than 300 nuclear warheads, as if it were not a leading actor on the nuclear issue and in the world geopolitical configuration.Faced with this hypocrisy, I have voted against.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: written.- The last nuclear safety summit, held in DC, resulted in good suggestions for improvement and support from international institutions.The summit was a success, although it is unfortunate that Russia did not attend, especially given the size of its nuclear arsenal.Still, 101 countries still comply with the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons.Alliance for Progress and Awakening strongly supports efforts to reduce the threat posed by nuclear terrorism.That is why I voted for this resolution.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I voted against.The report calls for a UN conference to be convened as a "legally binding instrument to ban and eliminate nuclear weapons." I find this both unrealistic and dangerous.Even if some states comply with such a resolution, there may always be others that do not comply with it, and this would upset the security balance in the world.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written.- This resolution warns of a worrying situation around the world where large nuclear arsenals still exist and the risk of increasing international instability and tensions.The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) is a key international agreement aimed at preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons and nuclear weapons technology, promoting cooperation in the peaceful use of nuclear energy and advocating global nuclear disarmament, signed by 191 states.The objectives of this Treaty are based on global efforts to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons, to promote the safe use of nuclear energy for civilian purposes and to achieve the goal of eliminating nuclear weapons in the world.As global cooperation is a key factor in preventing nuclear terrorism, I supported this resolution.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, which entered into force in 1970, was concluded by 191 parties, five of which are recognized as nuclear-weapon countries (United States, United Kingdom, Russia, France and China). Together with the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material, they represent an important tool for promoting the peaceful uses of nuclear energy, global nuclear disarmament and the prevention and investigation of criminal offenses in the handling of nuclear material. The conclusion of a nuclear agreement with Iran has paved the way for cooperation with that country in resolving the conflict, especially in Syria and Yemen. Rising tensions and regional conflicts around the world raise legitimate concerns about possible nuclear terrorism. It is therefore necessary to intensify cooperation between countries in disarmament in order to achieve the conclusion of an international binding document on disarmament and to create the conditions for the elimination of possible misuse of nuclear energy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- I am voting against the joint motion for a resolution on nuclear safety and the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons, because it is incomplete and well-documented, as well as the reasons I gave in detail in my speech to the European Parliament on 26 October 2016.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.This text extends the 2003 European strategy against nuclear proliferation.We are not opposing, with this vote, the international objective of reducing nuclear weapons, but serious attacks on national sovereignty.Indeed, this text envisages forcing France and England to give up their strike forces by establishing a principle of binding international law imposing the end of nuclear weapons, and by resolutions calling for the end of nuclear weapons.technological improvement and maintenance of nuclear arsenals.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: written.- This motion for a resolution deals with nuclear safety and non-proliferation of nuclear weapons.I welcome better security, the reduction of the nuclear arsenal and the reduction in detonations of nuclear weapons.However, I find some points vaguely worded.So I abstained.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution. The security environment in the world, as well as in the EU, is becoming increasingly volatile, unstable and less predictable. We cannot fail to notice the deteriorating relations between nuclear-weapon states such as the Russian Federation and the United States, India and Pakistan. We are watching with concern information about North Korea's nuclear tests. Of particular concern is the Russian military exercise, which simulates the use of nuclear weapons against Poland, and the deployment of Iskander nuclear missile systems in the Kaliningrad region. In the light of these and many other aspects, the European Parliament, in its resolution, deplores the fact that nuclear weapons are once again gaining an important role in the strategic plans of states with these weapons. The resolution calls for dialogue with all nuclear-weapon states and for a common agenda aimed at gradually reducing stockpiles of nuclear warheads. Parliament recommends the creation of nuclear-weapon-free zones as a positive step towards a world without nuclear weapons and as a contribution to overall stability. Parliament also calls on the United Nations General Assembly to convene a negotiating conference open to all states on a legally binding instrument banning nuclear weapons with a view to their eventual abolition. This is expected to reinforce the non-proliferation and disarmament objectives and commitments set out in the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and to contribute to global security.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- This resolution takes the excuse of the fight against nuclear proliferation to attack Russia once again.However, Russia does not threaten any country with nuclear attack and has never carried out a nuclear attack, unlike the United States.In fact, it was the United States which announced in October that it was preparing to invest massively in the renewal of its nuclear weapons for the coming decades, under the pretext of guarding against "the Russian threat".In addition, the two countries are planning to oppose the UN resolution on the ban on nuclear weapons.This resolution, which only denounces the Russian nuclear force, is therefore perfectly hypocritical and asymmetrical.I am in favor of the reduction of nuclear weapons and their non-proliferation.But this text is an act of hawkish commitment which will aggravate the tensions it denounces.I abstain on this text

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing.- The global security situation, and in particular that of the EU, has deteriorated significantly in recent years, becoming more unstable, dangerous and unpredictable.International peace, security and stability are seriously threatened by several developments, notably the deterioration of relations between nuclear weapon states, such as the Russian Federation and the United States of America, India and Pakistan, as well as the continuationof North Korea's nuclear capacity development.We must fight against these threats, otherwise we will be confronted, in the not too distant future, with situations that are very dangerous for world peace.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this cross-party resolution, which calls for the principle of nuclear non-proliferation to be maintained and reinforced, especially in the current climate of open hostility between nuclear armed states.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. - Security in the world has deteriorated considerably, due in particular to global and multidimensional threats. The international community must redouble its efforts to achieve the objectives of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT), which aims, inter alia, to eliminate nuclear arsenals and prevent new states from acquiring nuclear weapons. However, as Ban Ki-moon said, “Multilateral nuclear disarmament has stalled. Tens of billions of dollars are spent on maintaining and improving nuclear weapon systems ”. Thus, North Korea, defying the international community, is stepping up nuclear tests in order to acquire a nuclear arsenal and ballistic missiles. It is our duty, for the good of humanity, to prevent these weapons from spreading around the world, through scientific and technological progress. The NPT, while not perfect, helps to fight against the establishment of anarchy in the world. It is therefore essential that the Union strongly reaffirms its commitment to ensuring security in the world. "The next round of review of the Treaty on the Non — Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons begins in 2017. The world cannot afford another round of inaction."

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing. - At present, global security is increasingly being challenged by various terrorist groups, as well as by some states, including the DPRK, which is destabilizing the region by testing its nuclear systems. The NPT (Non-proliferation Treaty) is currently the only binding promise under the multilateral treaty regarding the goal of disarmament by nuclear-weapon countries. Its signatories also include 5 countries that have the right to legally hold nuclear weapons (USA, United Kingdom, Russia, China and France). Global cooperation is essential to prevent nuclear terrorism. However, the effort to revise the NPT in 2015 ended without a clear result and the absence of Russia, the country with the largest nuclear arsenal in the world, at the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit is not a positive sign of functioning cooperation. I join in the call for the need to strengthen cooperation between states on the safety of nuclear materials in order to reduce the risk of these materials ending up in the hands of terrorist groups.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing.- A motion for a resolution has been tabled by the ECR, PPE, Verts / ALE, GUE / NGL, EFDD, S&D and ALDE groups.Of the seven political groups, the PPE, the Verts / ALE, the S & D and the ALDE have reached an agreement and a joint compromise motion.I voted in favor of the compromise proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - I endorse the rapporteur's concern at the deterioration of the security environment around the European Union and beyond its neighborhood, which can lead not only to the resurgence of nuclear weapons as an active means of deterrence, but also to the possible proliferation among state actors and non-state, and with the failure to apply measures in favor of effective disarmament and non-proliferation. I believe that it is essential for all states with nuclear weapons to take concrete provisional measures to reduce the risk of nuclear explosions, namely by reducing the operationality of nuclear weapons and by transferring them from deployment areas to storage sites, reducing the role of nuclear weapons. of nuclear weapons in military doctrines and the rapid reduction of all types of nuclear weapons. The presentation of the EU's Global Strategy can be seen as a step in transforming the Union into a driving force for strengthening and advancing multilateral nuclear disarmament and non-proliferation agreements.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution on nuclear security and non-proliferation.Indeed, the presence of provisions once again implicating Russia has justified my vote.The European Union, by putting in place sanctions that harm our farmers and our producers more than they provide diplomatic solutions and instead of discussing with Russia to lead an effective fight against Daesh which is more than everour common enemy, prefers to shut himself up in this anti-Russian paranoia.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. - We live in a dangerous world. The European Union is doing its utmost to maintain national peace and stability, but we still face serious challenges. It is scary to think that the accumulation of tensions between individual countries could even end in a nuclear disaster. Perhaps only nuclear weapons falling into the hands of terrorist groups would be more dangerous. Last but not least, recalling the tragic events of Chernobyl, we can say that even a small accident is enough to make thousands of lives bitter. The European Union's goal in this area is a nuclear-weapon-free world, which I can fully support. More and more countries are returning to nuclear weapons development, with the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea, for example, conducting a hydrogen bomb experiment for the second time this year. We also talked about the unfavorable situation in Turkey, in addition to the coup attempt, the Syrian conflict is taking place nearby. The question arises as to the security of US-owned nuclear weapons entrusted to Turkey by NATO. I could go on with the situation in Russia. However, I am confident that the situation will only change for the better, but at the same time I see the need to develop an EU strategy.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution, which supports the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty which entered into force in 1970 through efforts to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons and promote the safe and secure use of nuclear energy.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution because I believe that changes in the security environment around the world in general and in the vicinity of the EU in particular are worrying, leaving the possibility of nuclear weapons becoming an argument for intimidation and negotiation.It is a worrying prospect for the future, if it will once again be dominated by debates about the nuclear capacity of states and not focused on diplomatic approaches.We must also not forget the possibility of nuclear technology falling into the hands of terrorist groups or being owned by states that do not comply with any of the international agreements in force on this subject, do not represent reliable partners and behave unpredictably.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the resolution on nuclear security and non-proliferation, including deep concerns about the increased nuclear threat posed by Russia's stance and its deteriorating relations with NATO, including potential breaches of the medium-range nuclear weapons agreement, as well as statements indicating how greaterreadiness to use nuclear weapons, as well as considerations of the possible deployment of nuclear weapons in other territories in Europe.Russia's military exercises simulating the deployment of nuclear weapons against Poland and the deployment of Iskander missile systems, which can carry nuclear warheads, in the Kaliningrad region, bordering EU member states Poland and Lithuania, are certainly a cause for heightened concern.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I abstained from voting on this motion for a resolution.The report contains a number of points that one can definitely agree with, such as the call on all nuclear-weapon states to refrain from using or threatening to use nuclear weapons.However, the Member States are called upon to start new initiatives to eliminate nuclear weapons.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported.The reduction and elimination of nuclear weapons should be a common goal of all countries, which can only be achieved if all nuclear-weapon states agree on it and implement it together.Unilaterally, such a thing is not possible.In the meantime, however, it is important to defuse global tensions in the search for a peaceful solution to the various conflicts, and all nuclear powers must ensure that nuclear weapons and materials do not fall into the hands of terrorists.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The deterioration of relations between nuclear-armed states is making the European Union 's security environment increasingly tense. States must reduce their nuclear weapons and nuclear capabilities. The need to strengthen non-proliferation and cooperation on the peaceful use of nuclear energy is emphasized. Of particular importance is the proposal to convene a United Nations conference, in 2017, to negotiate a legally binding act on the prohibition of nuclear weapons.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: in writing. - The KKE European Parliamentary Group is voting against the resolution because it does not demand the destruction of nuclear weapons, nor is it really in favor of banning their proliferation. It does not even mention the fact that strong capitalist EU member states have nuclear arsenals and carry out nuclear tests at regular intervals. It hides that the recent NATO Summit in Warsaw decided to install anti-ballistic missile systems in EU Member States, such as Romania and Poland, to develop military bases and NATO multinational troops in Poland, and in EU Baltic states. in the context of US, NATO, EU competition with capitalist Russia. The resolution also incites these rivalries in the field of nuclear weapons, which is based on the conflict of interests of the monopolies of both sides. It legitimizes the presence of ready-to-use nuclear weapons at NATO military bases scattered throughout its members, in the EU and elsewhere, such as in Turkey. Preventing the nuclear catastrophe, the bloodshed of the peoples from the imperialist wars can only be guaranteed by their liberation from the barbaric exploitative capitalist system.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. Nuclear deterrence is purely a matter for the currently recognised nuclear powers in Europe, namely the United Kingdom and France. We completely reject any attempt at EU interference in this and all other aspects of Member State defence policy. Non-proliferation is supported by a long-standing international regime, legally based on the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and other international treaties, and supported by international institutions such as the UN, the International Atomic Energy Agency and others. We see no reason for the EU to potentially displace an already largely successful international norm.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing.- While taking seriously the aspects presented in the document and admitting that international cooperation in this area is essential to avoid the proliferation of nuclear terrorism, I do not believe that the objections presented are complete, therefore, I would not feel like supporting it and would vote negatively.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I support the adoption of a resolution that will clearly and unequivocally express the position and opinion of the European Union against the use of nuclear weapons to intimidate or deter the enemy, or in open conflict. We live in a world where the consequences of radiation pollution are impossible to combat in a narrow area of ​​potential conflict. It is therefore necessary to give a clear signal to all nuclear powers in the world that the use of nuclear weapons is not an option supported by the European Union. Responsibility to the international community must exist. The European Union must do everything in its power and use every opportunity to combat the proliferation of nuclear weapons, the dissemination of knowledge about the process of creating a nuclear arsenal or the parts needed to create one. It is also necessary to work on combating the conduct of nuclear tests in order to protect human health and the environment. The European Union must promote dialogue, cooperation and agreements between countries that are nuclear powers, and there are open issues between them. Combating illegal possession and effective control of nuclear weapons is one of the key preconditions for the security and stability of any state.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. - I fully share the deep concern about the deterioration of the security framework at the borders of Europe and beyond, which risks leading to a return to the use of nuclear weapons as an active deterrent. For this reason, I join the invitation to all states that possess nuclear weapons to take all necessary measures to reduce the risks associated with these arsenals and their progressive reduction, up to their complete and final dismantling. In particular, the provocative attitude of Russia which deployed its nuclear-capable Iskander missiles in the Kaliningrad enclave and the tests carried out by North Korea, in violation of international law and the resolutions of the Security Council of Nations, should be condemned. United. I subscribe to the call to seek political and diplomatic solutions to international conflicts and tensions and to continue the dialogue to renew and improve non-proliferation agreements. I am sure that Europe will play a leading role in this regard by supporting the action of the IAEA and the United Nations. I hope that the creation of new zones free of nuclear weapons and all weapons of mass destruction will soon arrive, starting with the Middle East, and continuing until their total elimination.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - I am concerned about the disrupted regional and international security and the re-strengthening of the role of nuclear weapons in these processes. International peace and stability are threatened by the deteriorating relations of nuclear powers. The illegal development and proliferation of nuclear weapons is among the main concerns of the world community. Our priority must be to stop the acquisition of nuclear capabilities by terrorist actors and additional, potentially unstable, countries. I therefore support the conclusions of this year's Washington Summit and welcome the commitment to stopping the illegal trade and use of nuclear material and to the full control and physical protection of nuclear material. While the 2003 Security Strategy cited the proliferation of nuclear weapons as one of the fundamental threats, the current Global Strategy does not address the issue of weapons of mass destruction, non-proliferation and arms control. I call on EU members to support and act constructively at the next UN Conference in 2017 with a view to adopting a binding document banning nuclear weapons. I call on all countries that possess nuclear weapons to take concrete measures to reduce the risk of nuclear detonation and to diminish the role of those weapons in their military doctrines. I also support the strengthening of the powers of the International Atomic Energy Agency and the creation of a nuclear-weapon-free zone in the Middle East, which is one of the key preconditions for building lasting peace in the region.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution is corroded by a nuclear defect. It is absolutely partial, ignoring a global perspective on the issue. While launching fierce criticism of Russia or the People's Democratic Republic of Korea, stripping them of regional context and framework, it omits the role that the USA and European nuclear powers (France and the United Kingdom) have played in this regard, namely continuing the renewal of its nuclear arsenal, alongside an increasing siege of Russia by NATO. We note the total absence of condemnation of Israel's nuclear policy, or the absence of criticism of the growing militarization of the EU, of the intention to increase the military budgets of States, of deepening the CSDP, of the claim for a European Defense Union parallel to NATO, the decentralization of arms by the USA by different countries. On the other hand, it is absurd, and yet revealing, that there is no reference to the imperious defense of peace, as opposed to the apocalyptic scenario that may result from a nuclear conflict on a global scale. For these reasons, we voted against.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. - I consider the issue of nuclear safety and non-proliferation to be one of the key challenges of modern civilization. This issue has recently become even more important in the face of the deteriorating security environment in Europe. Personally, I am very concerned mainly about Russia's position, which indicates its increasing willingness to use nuclear weapons in certain cases, although these are rather political threats at this stage. However, the past has shown that similar power games can have fatal consequences. In the case of Russia, this is currently mainly a statement concerning the increased readiness to use nuclear weapons, the possible deployment of nuclear weapons to other areas in Europe or the relocation of Iskander missile systems to the Kaliningrad region. The volatile situation in Europe and the feeling of danger could result in the proliferation of nuclear weapons as a means of deterrence, which we must not allow.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- The fight against nuclear proliferation, which is unfortunately still in order in certain countries of the world, is an objective shared by a large majority within the European Parliament.However, the role of MEPs should not be to question the choice of EU member states, in particular France, which make the presence of nuclear a principle of national security.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, signed in 1968, is an important historic landmark, but it is also a binding legal instrument, whose purpose is to prevent the expansion of the use of nuclear weapons and associated technology, while promoting cooperation for the peaceful use of nuclear energy. International security currently faces several challenges in the area of ​​compliance with the Treaty. In this sense, I highlight the deterioration in the relations of two of the nuclear powers, mainly Russia and the United States, with Russia recently suspending the agreement on the disposal of plutonium. The environment of insecurity that crosses Europe and its neighborhood has increased in recent years, becoming volatile, dangerous and unpredictable, forcing Member States to deal with a wide range of conventional and unconventional threats. I support the work carried out by the International Nuclear Energy Agency, which, through cooperation, promotes the safe and peaceful use of nuclear technologies. I vote in favor and call for intensified cooperation efforts in the field of nuclear security, in order to minimize the risks of such products falling into the hands of terrorist groups and assuming as a major objective the destruction of all nuclear weapons on the planet.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. Nuclear deterrence is purely a matter for the currently recognised nuclear powers in Europe, namely the United Kingdom and France. We completely reject any attempt at EU interference in this and all other aspects of Member State defence policy. Non-proliferation is supported by a long-standing international regime, legally based on the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and other international treaties, and supported by international institutions such as the UN, the International Atomic Energy Agency and others. We see no reason for the EU to potentially displace an already largely successful international norm.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor, considering that the global security situation, and in particular that of the EU, has deteriorated significantly in recent years, having become more unstable, dangerous and unpredictable, since there are hybrid, conventional and unconventional threats generated by state and non-state actors, both regionally and globally. International peace, security and stability are seriously threatened by several developments, including the deterioration of relations between nuclear weapon states, such as the Russian Federation and the United States of America, India and Pakistan, as well as the continuation of North Korea's nuclear capacity development. It is regrettable that, since the entry into force of the new START Treaty in 2011, there have been no further negotiations on an urgent reduction in positioned and unpositioned nuclear warheads, including, as previously decided by the USA and Russia, measures to reduce and eliminate tactical and short-range nuclear weapons considered to be sub-strategic or non-strategic nuclear weapons.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written. - Nuclear safety and non-proliferation are a central issue for the Union, especially when a deterioration in the security conditions for Europe is perceived, and armed conflicts of different kinds are taking place very close to our borders. In the current situation, Europe faces conventional, unconventional and even nuclear threats that call peace, security and stability into question. For all these reasons, I have voted in favor of this resolution to expand the international cooperation called for by United Nations resolution 1540 to try to control nuclear weapons and prevent them from falling into the hands of non-state actors, especially terrorist groups. Knowing that, since its approval in 2004, there is a greater decision on the part of these actors to acquire this weapon, a closer, intense and extensive collaboration is necessary in this area to prevent potential suppliers of nuclear weapons from becoming real suppliers .

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this European Parliament resolution on nuclear security and non-proliferation because I am very concerned about the deterioration of the security situation in the Union's neighborhood which could lead to a resurgencenuclear weapons.I am also concerned about the current attitude of Russia, which aggravates the nuclear threat.Therefore, I plead and invite all the nuclear powers to take into consideration the recommendations made through this resolution.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - The global security situation, and in particular that of the EU, has deteriorated significantly in recent years, becoming more unstable, dangerous and unpredictable with the presence of hybrid, conventional and unconventional threats generated by state and non-state actors , both regionally and globally. International peace, security and stability are seriously threatened by recent developments - the deterioration of external relations between nuclear weapon states being one of them. It is therefore essential for States with this type of weaponry to take concrete measures to reduce the risks associated with this possession, with the EU as a world power, acting as a mediator with a view to resolving the various situations of conflict around the globe. It is regrettable that nuclear weapons are returning to the strategic planning of the states that have them. I still consider it urgent to withdraw from Europe the existing nuclear weapons arsenals. In this way, we will contribute positively to the existence of more nuclear weapon-free zones, promoting compliance with non-proliferation and disarmament obligations. As I believe that this is an issue that requires an immediate solution, I voted in favor of this proposal (of which I was a proponent).

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution which expresses our deep concern at the deterioration of the security environment around the Union and beyond its neighboring States, which could lead to the reappearance of nuclear weapons as an active deterrent andits possible proliferation between state and non-state agents, as well as, in the absence of effective disarmament and non-proliferation measures.The resolution also supports the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit and recognizes that the unauthorized trade and use of nuclear materials is an immediate and serious threat to global security, and hopes to achieve a complete monitoring and physical security ofall the appropriate materials for the construction of weapons, something that we consider essential.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted against it, because despite having a positive intention and speaking out in favor of nuclear disarmament, it is a remarkably unbalanced and biased text, which does not contribute to the serious and deep discussion of such an important issue.Once again, the Union suffers from a lack of balance when it comes to making analyzes and proposals that can really serve to contribute to solutions to transcendental issues, such as nuclear security and non-proliferation.An attempt that could be of great contribution to the fight for peace, is lost in disproportionate attacks against the Russian Federation, and at the same time omits the responsibility of NATO and the United States in the proliferation of nuclear weapons.Neither is Israel mentioned, which has more than 300 nuclear warheads, as if it were not a leading actor in the nuclear issue and in the world geopolitical configuration.Faced with this hypocrisy, I have voted against.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution does not encourage states enough to reach the goals set in the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, the Treaty Banning Nuclear Tests in the Atmosphere, in Outer Space and Under Water, the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material and others as main tools for nuclear security and non-proliferation. Instead, it is getting close to breaching the principle of subsidiarity and it also does not acknowledge the right of the recognised nuclear weapons states to retain their nuclear deterrents as an important element of national security. The motion does not call for nuclear security and non-proliferation as such, but takes different approaches to different states and areas.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - International peace, security and stability are currently seriously threatened by various events, including deteriorating relations between nuclear-weapon States. Nuclear weapons tests or any other nuclear explosions are a threat to international peace and security and threaten the global nuclear disarmament and non-proliferation regime. I supported the motion for a resolution of the EP, in which we express our deep concern at the deteriorating security situation around the European Union and beyond its neighborhood, as this deterioration could re-use nuclear weapons for active deterrence and their proliferation between states. also by non-state actors. We therefore called on all nuclear-weapon States to take concrete temporary measures to reduce the risk of nuclear weapons explosions, including reducing the operational status of nuclear weapons and moving nuclear weapons from deployments to depots, limiting the role of nuclear weapons in military doctrines and accelerating the reduction of all types of nuclear weapons. .

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - Global security, and in particular that of the EU, has deteriorated significantly: it is more perilous and less predictable. International peace, security and stability face divergent developments: deteriorating relations between nuclear-armed states such as Russia and the United States and further developments in North Korea's nuclear capabilities. Moreover, the proliferation of nuclear weapons of mass destruction remains one of the major concerns of the global community. For these reasons and in the public interest, the European Parliament is proposing a resolution addressing this issue and encouraging the European Union to take action in the field of nuclear safety and non-proliferation. The priorities include preventing the acquisition or use of nuclear weapons by terrorists or additional states, reducing and eliminating all nuclear arsenals and moving towards a world without nuclear weapons. The resolution also places important emphasis, highlights prominent developments and areas of concern and also makes urgent recommendations. As nuclear safety and non-proliferation are extremely important issues for me and for the Green Group as a whole, I have co-signed and approved this resolution with full conviction.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: written.- The last nuclear safety summit, held in DC, resulted in good suggestions for improvement and support from international institutions.The summit was a success, although it is unfortunate that Russia did not attend, especially given the size of its nuclear arsenal.Still, 101 countries still comply with the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons.Alliance for Progress and Awakening strongly supports efforts to reduce the threat posed by nuclear terrorism.That is why I voted for this resolution.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- Nuclear safety in understanding the world without nuclear weapons is the most important goal of the global arms control policy and also the goal of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons.Given the worrying events of recent years, the significant deterioration in stability and security around the European Union, the deteriorating relations between nuclear-weapon states and the current increased nuclear threat stemming from Russia's position, global cooperation is essential.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: written.- I did not agree to the resolution of the EU Parliament of October 27, 2016 on “nuclear safety and non-proliferation of nuclear weapons”.I fully share the concern about the proliferation of nuclear weapons.However, I find the report unbalanced.He criticizes Russia for modernizing its nuclear arsenal and for not unilaterally renouncing nuclear weapons as a deterrent.At the same time, the United States military has either upgraded or improved all of its strategic and tactical nuclear weapons.The Obama administration has launched extensive modernization programs.The US Secretary of Defense estimates the total cost of this to be between 350 and 450 billion US dollars (source: Arms Control Association).Criticism of nuclear armament or a lack of disarmament: absolutely yes - but worldwide, please.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the joint motion for a resolution on nuclear safety and non-proliferation.Recently, we have witnessed various events that have contributed to the deterioration of relations between countries with nuclear weapons.The deteriorating security situation in the European Union and the wider neighborhood can worry us in the light of the re-emergence of nuclear weapons as a means of actively deterring and potentially spreading them among state and non-state actors.I support the call for all countries with nuclear weapons to take concrete interim measures to reduce the risk of nuclear weapons detonation, including limiting their operational status and storing already installed nuclear weapons.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing.- Nuclear energy and consequently nuclear weapons are a tool for man.States with nuclear arsenals should take steps to prevent their use and try to create the right conditions for all interested members to come to the table for such important talks.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. - The motion responds primarily to the deteriorating security situation in the European Union's neighborhood. All this could lead to a resumption of the practice of nuclear armaments for deterrence. In addition, there is a further risk of non-implementation of effective steps towards disarmament and non-proliferation. The motion calls on nuclear-weapon States to take concrete measures to reduce the risk of nuclear explosions and to take immediate action to reduce the number of nuclear weapons. In addition, the motion expresses concern about Russia’s role and attitude, which has significantly increased the nuclear threat. As a result, the global security situation has deteriorated, stability and predictability have faltered, and NATO-Russia relations have deteriorated significantly. The motion also supports the convening of the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit, recognizing that the unauthorized trade and use of nuclear materials poses a direct and serious threat to world security.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because it raises growing concerns in European public opinion about the potential dangers of the policies of some nuclear-weapon states and their governments and the future of international security as a whole. As Vice-Chair of the EP Delegation for Ukraine and the Association Committee, I am particularly sensitive to the facts and doubts about Russia's regional and global aspirations, supported by my personal experience. The destabilization of Ukraine by military means, the illegal annexation of the Crimea, and political threats against NATO, and above all the Baltic States, without nuclear elements, constitute a realistic threat to the EU's immediate eastern neighborhood, against which strong and united EU action is needed, including a comprehensive and concrete response from the EEAS. The current EP resolution provides, in my view, the appropriate political background and impetus for this and will hopefully also influence the governments of the Member States towards unified political action.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. - The security situation in the neighborhood of the European Union has deteriorated significantly in the last few years and has become more volatile, dangerous and unpredictable, with Member States having to deal with a range of threats from state and non-state actors. The 1968 Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons recognizes five countries with nuclear weapons, while the three countries with de facto nuclear weapons developed nuclear capabilities outside the Treaty's framework (India, Pakistan and Israel). North Korea is recognized as a country capable of producing nuclear weapons. Unfortunately, in recent years both Russia and South Korea have taken numerous actions contrary to the provisions of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, strengthening the sense of threat among the entire international community and leading to the further proliferation of nuclear weapons among state and non-state actors. Now, the European Union and the Member States should take decisive and unequivocal steps to establish global arms control with the unequivocal recognition of a nuclear-free world as a viable long-term goal.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament has once again rolled the war drums by approving by a very large majority threatening and unjustified anti-virus fanfare within the resolution "Nuclear safety and non-proliferation" which, although it has no legislative value, unfortunately has significant political value. The reality is different from what is described in the report: Russia is accused of having launched "an armed attack" in eastern Ukraine in 2014. In fact, prior to this supposed Russian attack, the US and the EU supported in Ukraine, close to the Russian borders, a violent overthrow of the duly elected president and the replacement of him by a viscerally anti-Russian establishment. Furthermore, the resolution says that Russia has deployed nuclear missiles in Kalingrad without providing the context as it was a Russian reaction to the US bombs on the Syrian army, an ally of the Russians, which started the spiral of threats and planetary tensions. The vote on the resolution is available on Vote Watch: all the amendments that tried to tone down the delusional and arrogant tones of the text presented to which the Greens and all the major political groups including the socialists voted in favor have been ignored. We at M5S have clearly voted against.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: signed up. - We are currently witnessing the considerable deterioration of the global security environment, not just the EU, generated by various regional and global actors, despite the EU's efforts in this area. Moreover, international peace, security and stability are severely affected, including deteriorating relations between nuclear-weapon States. As such, it becomes necessary to strengthen the basic non-proliferation and disarmament objectives of the three pillars of the NPT (non-proliferation, disarmament and cooperation) for the peaceful uses of nuclear energy. In this regard, the presentation of the EU's overall strategy in this area is welcome, given that the EU has committed itself to the use of all instruments through the Strategy against the Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction, adopted by the European Council on 12 December 2003. which it has at its disposal to prevent, deter, stop and, if possible, eliminate proliferation programs of global concern. Clearly, for the EU to become the world's driving force in strengthening and continuing multilateral disarmament and nuclear non-proliferation agreements, it is necessary to update and expand the 2003 EU Strategy against the Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - Nuclear safety has been a topic of debate since the early stages of the Cold War and continues to be a topic of great interest today. During this period, we are witnessing the deterioration of the European security environment, in the context in which the old nuclear weapons limitation treaties are denounced by some of the signatories, and some international actors, state or non-state, resort to the development and even expansion of these types of weapons with devastating impact on all of humanity. In this context, it is even a question of addressing more or less conventional nuclear threats, which endanger European and world peace. In these circumstances, the S&D group, in line with its political tradition at European level, is clearly in favor of limiting these dangerous tendencies and defending peace, security and stability on the European continent. The European Parliament, as the guarantor of the security of the citizens it directly represents, must take action and condemn these unfortunate acts, which do not serve anyone's interests in the medium and long term. I support this resolution, which is self-evident.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- By this text, we recognize the right of States officially possessing nuclear weapons to keep, as an essential component of national security, a potential for nuclear deterrence, in view of the numerous nuclear arsenals that still exist in the world., the possible development and proliferation of nuclear weapons, and the risk of increased international instability and tensions.We adhere to the objectives of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty which provides a global framework for preventing the spread of nuclear weapons, for promoting the safe and reliable use of civilian nuclear energy and for ultimately achieving a worlddenuclearized.Both a security context and a sustainable denuclearization necessarily require a multilateral approach.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ As of recently, there has been concern expressed about the deterioration of the security environment around the European Union and beyond its neighbourhood, which could lead to the re-emergence of nuclear weapons as an active deterrent and possible proliferation among state and non-state actors. Specifically, there is concern for the increased nuclear threats arising from Russia, with implications for security, stability and especially in light of Russia’s deteriorating relationship with NATO. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, which calls on all nuclear-weapon states to take concrete measures to reduce the risk of nuclear aggression.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: in writing. - The motion responds primarily to the deteriorating security situation in the European Union's neighborhood. All this could lead to a resumption of the practice of nuclear armaments for deterrence. In addition, there is a further risk of non-implementation of effective steps towards disarmament and non-proliferation. The motion calls on nuclear-weapon States to take concrete measures to reduce the risk of nuclear explosions and to take immediate action to reduce the number of nuclear weapons. In addition, the motion expresses concern about Russia’s role and attitude, which has significantly increased the nuclear threat. As a result, the global security situation has deteriorated, stability and predictability have faltered, and NATO-Russia relations have deteriorated significantly. The motion also supports the convening of the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit, recognizing that the unauthorized trade and use of nuclear materials poses a direct and serious threat to world security.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written.- There are still large nuclear arsenals around the world and the possibility of nuclear weapons spreading even more, which increases international instability and tension.That is why I believe that global cooperation and the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NTP), an international agreement that seeks to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons and nuclear weapons technology, are key factors in combating the proliferation of nuclear weapons.Given the threat posed by terrorist attacks, it is clear that continued cooperation and further improvement of nuclear security is essential, as this is the only way to reduce the risk of nuclear weapons or materials used to make nuclear weapons in the hands of terrorist groups.the least possible measure.As this resolution recognized the need to step up efforts to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons, I voted in favor.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on nuclear safety and non-proliferation. The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons is a groundbreaking international treaty aimed at preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons and weapons technology, promoting cooperation in the peaceful uses of nuclear energy and improving global nuclear disarmament. This treaty is the only binding obligation of nuclear-weapon States in the multilateral treaty to the goal of disarmament. The Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material is a legally binding international instrument in the field of physical protection of nuclear material, which sets out measures for the prevention, detection and punishment of offenses related to nuclear material. The amendment to the Convention makes it legally binding on States Parties to protect nuclear facilities and material during peaceful domestic use, storage and transportation. Parliament is concerned about the recent nuclear tests carried out by the Democratic People's Republic of Korea and the risks it poses to regional stability, and calls on the Democratic People's Republic of Korea to put an end to these tests in the future. Parliament encourages the continued application and strict implementation of the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material and calls on countries that have not yet ratified this treaty to do so.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution which expresses our deep concern at the deterioration of the security environment around the Union and beyond its neighboring States, which could lead to the reappearance of nuclear weapons as an active deterrent andits possible proliferation between state and non-state agents, as well as, in the absence of effective disarmament and non-proliferation measures.The resolution also supports the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit and recognizes that the unauthorized trade and use of nuclear materials is an immediate and serious threat to global security, and hopes to achieve a complete monitoring and physical security ofall the appropriate materials for the construction of weapons, something that we consider essential.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution which expresses our deep concern at the deterioration of the security environment around the Union and beyond its neighboring states, which could lead to the reappearance of nuclear weapons as an active deterrent andtheir possible proliferation between state and non-state agents, as well as, in the absence of effective disarmament and non-proliferation measures.In addition, the resolution supports the 2016 Nuclear Security Summit and recognizes that the unauthorized trade and use of nuclear materials is an immediate and serious threat to global security, and hopes to achieve a complete monitoring and physical security ofall the appropriate materials for the construction of weapons, something that we consider essential.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, which I consider to be excellent news as it clearly stands against the existence of nuclear weapons anywhere in the world.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained of voting on motions for a resolution on nuclear security and non-proliferation. The resolution notes that worsening relations between nuclear-armed states, such as Russia and the US or India and Pakistan, but also Russia’s threats to use nuclear weapons or to deploy them to more territories in Europe, are making the EU’s security environment ever more tense. Moreover, it stresses the concern about nuclear threats arising from the Russian attitude, its statements indicating an increased readiness to use nuclear weapons. It cites the examples of Russian military exercises simulating the use of these weapons against Poland, high-ranking Russian officials’ claims that Russia has the right to deploy nuclear weapons in Crimea and the deployment of the nuclear-capable Iskander missile system to the Kaliningrad region, neighbouring Lithuania and Poland. I abstained because I believe that this resolution is very one-sided and not balanced.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted against it, because despite having a positive intention and speaking out in favor of nuclear disarmament, it is a remarkably unbalanced and biased text, which does not contribute to the serious and deep discussion of such an important issue.Once again, the Union suffers from a lack of balance when it comes to making analyzes and proposals that can really serve to contribute to solutions to transcendental issues, such as nuclear security and non-proliferation.An attempt that could be of great contribution to the fight for peace, is lost in disproportionate attacks against the Russian Federation, and at the same time omits the responsibility of NATO and the United States in the proliferation of nuclear weapons.Neither is Israel mentioned, which has more than 300 nuclear warheads, as if it were not a leading actor in the nuclear issue and in the world geopolitical configuration.Faced with this hypocrisy, I have voted against.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: written.- I've been fighting for non-proliferation for years.Several times I stood up for non-proliferation in the Belgian Chamber of Representatives.The general trend was positive.There was a decrease.I regret that, contrary to what was hoped, nuclear weapons are once again becoming part of the strategic planning of nuclear powers.I agree with the common resolution to call for closer consultation with all nuclear powers to pursue a common agenda aimed at the gradual reduction of the nuclear warhead arsenal.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The NPT is an international treaty of reference that aims to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons and weapons technologies, promoting cooperation in the peaceful uses of nuclear energy and the cause of nuclear disarmament worldwide. The report recognizes the right of states that are known to have nuclear weapons to maintain their nuclear deterrent arsenals as an important element of national security, taking into account the continued existence of large nuclear arsenals worldwide, the possibility of arms proliferation. and the risk of increasing instability and tensions at the international level. But curiously, it only implicitly recognizes this right to Western powers. Hence the persecutory password in relation to Russia and North Korea, to be reminiscent of the axis of evil discourse. It will not be by painting a world in two colors that we will be able to walk the paths of peace and social progress. In this sense, this report represents a step backwards in the construction of a political solution of peace that respects the sovereignty of the peoples.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- The report contains some correct assessments of nuclear security and non-proliferation of nuclear weapons, such as by emphasizing the need to establish further nuclear weapon-free zones and the finding that nuclear weapons tests and other nuclear explosions threaten global peace and security and the global processes of nuclear disarmament andundermine the non-proliferation agreements.However, elsewhere the report, in an extremely one-sided way, blames Russia alone as the culprit for the growing nuclear threat and deteriorating relations with NATO.I therefore abstained from voting.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the High Representative's declaration on nuclear safety and non-proliferation.Nuclear safety and non-proliferation are central themes of our policy, especially now that Europe's security is being challenged by conventional, unconventional and nuclear threats, generated by state and non-state actors.As international peace, security and stability are challenged by the deterioration of relations with states that possess nuclear weapons, I believe it is necessary to promote cooperation aimed at safeguarding our common values.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament has adopted a landmark resolution backing the historic process currently taking place at the UN to negotiate a legally binding instrument to ban nuclear weapons. I am proud to have been a key player in the process to bring political groups together in order to reach agreement. The resolution gives the EU’s External Action Service a clear mandate to engage in the UN process, and play its role as a promoter of peace and international cooperation. All of the EU’s Member States, including nuclear weapons states, are called upon to support and contribute positively to the process. The aim of this process is to create a new international consensus that the humanitarian impacts of nuclear weapons put them in direct violation of international law, so that they could never be used legally. While the text of the resolution is emphatically strong on these issues, I did support amendments that called more attention to the role of nuclear-armed states, including the UK, and the need for them to move actively towards disarmament.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because the global security environment, and particularly that of the EU, has deteriorated considerably, becoming more fluid, more precarious and less predictable. That is why action is needed. One of the main priorities is to prevent terrorists from obtaining or using nuclear weapons. I agree with an open dialogue with all nuclear-armed states trying to pursue a common agenda aimed at progressive reductions of nuclear warheads. This topic is very sensible, especially now with the ongoing tensions in the Middle East.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing. - Nuclear weapons are one of the most effective security policy tools. Deterrence and a second strike strategy guarantee the nuclear powers a degree of inviolability from a direct military attack. However, this policy has its pitfalls, and if even one nuclear warhead is used, there is a risk of global conflict. It is deplorable that states must guarantee their inviolability and power with weapons of mass destruction. Our world is currently on the brink of another Cold War, and the nuclear safety situation is rather degrading. This is a condition for non-state actors trading in nuclear weapons, which poses a huge risk to global security. In addition, deteriorating relations between Russia and NATO are not a good indicator of an improvement in the nuclear safety situation. The deployment of Iskander missile systems in the Kaliningrad region capable of carrying nuclear warheads is worrying. I fully agree with the resolution tabled, which draws attention to the need for dialogue, respect for international treaties in relation to non-proliferation and the ban on nuclear weapons testing. We need more trust, and we will achieve this by having all states work together to eliminate the nuclear arsenal after a dialogue.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: in writing. - The KKE European Parliamentary Group is voting against the resolution because it does not demand the destruction of nuclear weapons, nor is it really in favor of banning their spread. It does not even mention the fact that strong capitalist EU member states have nuclear arsenals and carry out nuclear tests at regular intervals. It hides that the recent NATO Summit in Warsaw decided to install anti-ballistic missile systems in EU Member States, such as Romania and Poland, to develop military bases and NATO multinational troops in Poland, and in EU Baltic states. in the context of US, NATO, EU competition with capitalist Russia. The resolution also incites these rivalries in the field of nuclear weapons possession, which is based on the conflict of interests of the monopolies of both sides. It legitimizes the presence of ready-to-use nuclear weapons at NATO military bases scattered throughout its members, in the EU and elsewhere, such as in Turkey. Preventing the nuclear catastrophe, the bloodshed of the peoples from the imperialist wars can only be guaranteed by their liberation from the barbaric exploitative capitalist system.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution of 27 October 2016 on nuclear safety and non-proliferation. The global security environment, and in particular the EU security environment, has deteriorated sharply, becoming more volatile and uncertain and less predictable. Security threats are created by both state and non-state regional and global actors. The deterioration of the security situation in the European Union and in the wider neighborhood is worrying, which could lead to the re-emergence of nuclear weapons as a means of active deterrence and its possible proliferation among state and non-state actors. I therefore join the call for the European External Action Service to update and expand the 2003 EU strategy against the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and the new guidelines for action from 2009, making the EU a driving force in strengthening and continuing multilateral nuclear disarmament and non-proliferation agreements.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I really like this proposal, this motion for a resolution, because it not only declines one of the values we have, given the times, extraordinarily need, namely solidarity, but it is also an instrument that has proved itselfvery useful for young people.In fact, 75% of volunteers believe that European Voluntary Service is an experience that offers more opportunities to find a job, just as 85% say that this experience has made them more aware of European values.It turns out to be, therefore, an important driving force for young people to then access the job market, these days it is an important thing.This is why I believe that access must be facilitated not only in bureaucratic terms but that it must then be enhanced for access to work, once this service is finished.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - I was very pleased to support the motion for a resolution on volunteering, which is an expression of concrete solidarity between people.Volunteers make the world a better place and it comes back to them in the form of new experiences, valuable contacts and social skills.There are more people who could engage in voluntary activities than there are people who do.This is the potential from which the European Voluntary Service should draw more.Volunteering is a concrete manifestation of active citizenship.Because people who do not care how their neighbors live and do not hesitate to lend a helping hand, such people are not indifferent to the society in which they live, what politicians represent them, how the law is observed and where taxpayers' money goes.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen! This year marks the 20th anniversary of the establishment of the European Voluntary Service. People who participated in this project at the very beginning often already have children of the age to take part in this initiative. It would be extremely interesting to find out how many of these children, who had learned from their parents' experience, decided to take part in the European Voluntary Service. Unfortunately, we are not able to do this because, as noted by Silvia Costa, the European Commission collects little data related to this initiative. We have no information on the contribution of EVS to national and European GDP or to increasing social cohesion. So we do not know what effects this initiative actually brings. It certainly needs to be changed as soon as possible. Consideration should also be given to expanding the category of people who can benefit from European Voluntary Service. Extending the period of life in a good condition means that we are dealing with a large group of people over the age of sixty who have the time and willingness to undertake social activity. It is worth taking advantage of this and creating an opportunity for them to work under either the European Voluntary Service or a completely new program. For these purposes, I voted in favor of the project.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- Volunteering is an activity of fundamental importance, also from an economic point of view, contributing on average to the production of about 5% of GDP.However, this importance is often overlooked by Member States, which should set up well-resourced national volunteering programs and implement promotion initiatives to improve access to information on volunteering opportunities.Because I believe that European Voluntary Service represents an important opportunity for many young people and as such must be adequately supported, I have decided to vote in favor.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non—binding resolution. The resolution called on the Commission to create new initiatives and expand the European voluntary service at the taxpayer’s expense. The UK has its own volunteering schemes in place, and we do not need another service at EU level.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- Although I recognize the social value of volunteering, I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution since it advocates a mercantilist consideration of European volunteering (which is quantified at 5% of GDP) which is used as a substitute for social services that mustbe public.I consider the voluntary work of thousands of citizens and residents of the Union laudable and as such must be socially recognized, but I oppose that volunteering serves as a pretext for the State to disregard its responsibilities, such as for example in the reception ofrefugees, which is the line in which the resolution is directed.For this reason, I have not been able to vote in favor of it.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – In 2016, European Voluntary Service (EVS) celebrates its 20th anniversary. 100 000 volunteers have been supported in 20 years. Parliament, and the Committee on Culture and Education (CULT) in particular, supports volunteering as an expression of solidarity that contributes to the strengthening of active citizenship and counters social exclusion, poverty, intolerance, racism, xenophobia and injustice, while making an important contribution to the dissemination of European values. The MfR focus on volunteering and its merits and how to improve it overall. There were many positive elements to the MfR and it was worthy of supporting to help the growth of volunteering in Europe.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report.Volunteering is an expression of solidarity, freedom and responsibility which helps to strengthen active citizenship and human personal development, and it is an essential tool for social integration and cohesion, alongside training,education and intercultural dialogue, while making a major contribution to the dissemination of European values.It should be noted that its advantages are also recognized in the voluntary activities carried out with third countries, as it is a strategic tool which promotes mutual understanding and intercultural relations.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: written.- In its oral question to the Commission, Parliament pointed out that the EU needed a more coordinated policy in the field of volunteering.Almost 100 million EU citizens volunteer in the fields of education, culture or art, sporting events, humanitarian aid and development aid.Young people should take advantage of volunteer programs to develop skills and experience that will help them find jobs afterward.A supportive environment would be essential to encourage volunteering even more.I would therefore very much welcome a legal framework with clear rights and responsibilities for all actors.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing.- As usual, the European Union uses good sentiments and laudable ideas as a Trojan horse of an ever-deeper integration policy and a strengthening of its powers.It is also to be feared that, like Erasmus +, volunteering may be misled to be used as a school for "future posted workers" from Europe.Finally, the desire to appeal to the good feelings of the citizens of the Member States to deal with the stagnation of the refugee crisis for them is unacceptable.I therefore did not vote in favor of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for the harmonisation of volunteering services at EU level, interfering with national voluntary schemes which already exist. It seeks more taxpayers’ money being spent, and some of the suggested programmes are of questionable value. I therefore, whilst fully supportive of the charitable sector and volunteering, could not support this specific resolution.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution, because it is essential to have a European legal framework for volunteering activities which are the expression of solidarity, freedom and responsibility and which make it possible to strengthencitizenship and personal development.It is necessary to take into account the fact that almost 100 million Europeans are volunteers.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- Every year, thousands of young Europeans work on European Voluntary Service projects.They are given a wide range of tasks, from helping children, seniors or migrants to providing free support at sporting or environmental events, but the service, which celebrates its twentieth anniversary, does not guarantee the proper legal status of volunteers.The European Voluntary Service should be accessible to people of all ages, and its members should receive a certificate of experience to help volunteers find paid employment.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding resolution. The resolution called on the Commission to create new initiatives and expand the European voluntary service at the taxpayer’s expense. The UK has its own volunteering schemes in place, and we do not need another service at EU level.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- I preferred to abstain from this vote because, while I am of course not against the principle of volunteering, the European Union is once again using the goodwill of the citizens to try to arrogate to itself powers threatening oursovereignty and to accelerate the integration of member states.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the text.We recognize in it that volunteering is an expression of solidarity, freedom and responsibility which helps to strengthen active citizenship and human personal development, and that it constitutes an essential tool for social integration and cohesion, at the same time.training, education and intercultural dialogue, while making a major contribution to the dissemination of European values.The advantages of volunteering are also recognized in the voluntary activities carried out with third countries, as it is a strategic tool which promotes mutual understanding and intercultural relations.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report as I consider it extremely important to provide a legal framework that determines a volunteer status with rights and responsibilities for volunteers and volunteering and facilitates mobility and recognition.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on European voluntary service. This is an important instrument that is turning 20 and has made it possible to support over 100,000 volunteers over this period. A manifestation of solidarity and responsibility that has contributed to the strengthening of active citizenship, social inclusion, training, and intercultural dialogue. The text approved today asks to encourage the participation of organizations in programs involving volunteers by allowing volunteering to be counted as a co-financing contribution for Member States' projects linked to the EU structural funds. The Commission must improve the communication strategy by ensuring simplified access to information on the opportunities of the European Voluntary Service; the new initiative for a European Solidarity Corps must be supported but its implementation must not jeopardize existing volunteer programs and their funding. Finally, the creation of a real European statute for volunteering would constitute an important tool for guaranteeing voluntary organizations the right legal and institutional recognition.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted in favor of the JMR on the European Voluntary Service and the promotion of volunteering in Europe since Podemos defends the values ​​of volunteering, solidarity, active citizenship and the mobilization of civil society in favor of the most vulnerable without chrematistic objectives. This JMR has highlighted aspects that are key for us, such as that volunteering should not replace formal employment, that volunteering systems at European level still lack adequate coordination and it is necessary to improve it or that fair funding is needed for its correct developing. The Resolution also values ​​the entire movement of volunteers during the refugee crisis who have known how to react to challenges with great pragmatism, and contemplates the possibility of recognition of volunteer status and improving access to information, recognition of acquired informal capacities. and a better communication strategy. That is why I think it is a good resolution and vote to consolidate this Service.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- I supported this motion for a resolution on European volunteering, which calls for a clear legal status and adequate funding.The EU needs a more coordinated policy on volunteering in which it is necessary to consider giving volunteers a legal status, with their rights and responsibilities clearly defined.Call for adequate funding for volunteer programs to encourage participation and help young people develop skills and gain experience.Many European citizens have volunteered in the educational, cultural or artistic fields, in sporting events, humanitarian or development tasks and, despite the clear economic and social benefits of volunteering for individuals and organizations, participation in the European Voluntary Serviceit remains modest and it is necessary to remove the barriers that still persist.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
