text: in writing.- This year, European Voluntary Service is celebrating its 20th anniversary.During these years, over 100,000 volunteers were supported, who had the opportunity to learn new things and gain valuable experience through non-formal education.Such action undoubtedly has a positive effect on the dissemination of European values, intercultural dialogue and is an important tool for social inclusion and cohesion.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: written.- I did not agree to the resolution of the EU Parliament on “European Voluntary Service and the Promotion of Volunteering in the EU”.It was only through the report that I learned that the European Voluntary Service (EVS) is celebrating the 20th anniversary of its existence in 2016 and that 100,000 volunteers have been supported in these 20 years.In my opinion, this is 20 years and 100,000 too many.The issue does not belong at EU level and is therefore a violation of the subsidiarity principle.I hope that it will take less than 20 years to abolish the instrument without replacement.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the joint motion for a resolution on European Voluntary Service and the promotion of volunteering in Europe.According to data, almost 100 million citizens in Europe are active in volunteering, and their work generates about 5% of its GDP.That is why it is all the more appropriate to provide a European framework for volunteering in terms of a legal framework that defines the status of volunteers, their rights and responsibilities, and promotes mobility and the recognition of skills.In this light, the resolution rightly encourages Member States to define the legal environment for volunteers and to apply the recommendations of the Voluntary Policy Agenda for Europe and the European Charter on the Rights and Responsibilities of Volunteers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - Although formal volunteering has a substantial and long-term goal of the smooth integration of young people into the social system, the acquisition of strong skills and the cultivation of solidarity with fellow human beings, it is unfortunately mainly associated with NGOs, which receive vast amounts of funding treat them as cheap labor, concluding that, under the pretext of volunteering, channels should not be opened to illegal immigrants, so-called volunteers, to settle on European soil.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the joint motion for a resolution on volunteering and European voluntary service, which, like me, believe that volunteering is one of the most visible expressions of solidarity, promoting social inclusion and contributing to both the development of a well-functioning civil society and economic growth. I also agree with the statement that a supportive environment plays a crucial role in ensuring that as many European citizens as possible volunteer, thus guaranteeing safe and sustainable support for volunteering infrastructure, especially for organizations that employ volunteers. It is therefore necessary for Member States to set up properly funded national voluntary service schemes and to improve access to quality information on volunteering opportunities at both national and local level, in particular with regard to existing youth information networks.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. - In 2016, the European Voluntary Service program celebrates its 20th anniversary. For two decades, we managed to support over 100,000. volunteers. On the one hand, it is pleasing that so many people have decided to devote their time to others, without seeking any financial gain. On the other hand, we can say that this is a drop in the ocean of needs and that better promotion and material support for the program is necessary. Volunteering helps to acquire skills and competences as well as demonstrates the solidarity and responsibility that contribute to enhancing active citizenship and personal human development. It has enormous added value and a positive influence on intercultural relations. However, volunteering requires appropriate organizational and legal structures that clearly define the rights and obligations of volunteers. In addition, Member States should promote EVS more actively in their education systems and, by simplifying the current application system, allow young people to access the program quickly and easily.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Volunteering has a value and importance as one of the most visible expressions of solidarity, which promotes and facilitates social inclusion, builds social capital and produces a transformative effect on society. Volunteering contributes both to the development of a thriving civil society, which can offer creative and innovative solutions to common challenges, and to economic growth, and as such it deserves to be measured in a specific, targeted way in terms of both economic and social capital. I supported this report as I believe in the importance of providing a legal framework which identifies a volunteering status, with rights and responsibilities for volunteers and volunteering. Moreover, I think it is a great idea for Member States to establish adequately funded national voluntary service schemes and to improve access to quality information on volunteering opportunities at national and local level.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the text.We recognize in it that volunteering is an expression of solidarity, freedom and responsibility which helps to strengthen active citizenship and human personal development, and that it constitutes an essential tool for social integration and cohesion, at the same time.training, education and intercultural dialogue, while making a major contribution to the dissemination of European values.The advantages of volunteering are also recognized in the voluntary activities carried out with third countries, as it is a strategic tool which promotes mutual understanding and intercultural relations.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In 2016, the European Voluntary Service (EVS) celebrated its 20th anniversary, supporting 100 000 volunteers since its inception. In Europe, volunteering is an expression of solidarity, freedom and responsibility that contributes to the strengthening of active citizenship and to personal human development, and that it is an essential tool for social inclusion and cohesion, as well as training, education and intercultural dialogue and an important dimension of EU values. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the EVS, which encourages Member States to implement a concrete validation process, as well as the creation of an EU framework, which provides volunteer work with a legal status, ensuring rights and responsibilities are protected for volunteers in the EU. I believe it is necessary to give volunteering a greater relevance and a formal status in order to encourage future generations of volunteers.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. - Worthy of appreciation this initiative strongly desired by my colleague Silvia Costa and by the Commission for Culture to celebrate twenty years of the European Voluntary Service through a parliamentary act. The voted resolution asks the EU Commission and the Member States to create the most favorable conditions for the experience of volunteering across Europe to be enhanced and its value recognized, it is the expression of a fundamental dimension of people's freedom and responsibility , single or associated, but also, concretely, of a European value to be safeguarded. In every daily circumstance from calamities, to humanitarian crises or emergencies, such as those we are experiencing in Europe and its borders, as well as in the care and assistance of vulnerable people, the elderly, children, the disabled, the precious work of thousands of volunteers, supports and supplements that of the institutions. It is a free and precious contribution that produces not only social inclusion and cohesion, but also innovation, and creates wealth: it is estimated that volunteering contributes to 5% of the Union's GDP. We strongly urge the Commission to do its utmost to ensure that the recommendations of the Political Agenda for Volunteering and the EU Charter for Volunteers do not remain on paper to those Member States that have not yet legislated on the matter, by establishing national voluntary service plans.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written.- The European Voluntary Service was created with the aim of helping young people aged 17-30 traveling abroad to participate in volunteer projects lasting between 2 weeks and 12 months.This is one of the key actions of the Erasmus + program - mobility for young people and young workers, with a total budget of EUR 9.8 million.I supported this proposal because I believe that it is extremely important to connect young people on a voluntary basis, because the end result is great potential in achieving extremely positive goals such as social inclusion, solidarity, intercultural dialogue and, in my opinion, most importantly, building multiple skills.and competencies from which young people will benefit in the future.I am happy to estimate that between 2014-2020.year about 100,000 young people to participate in this commendable initiative.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on European Voluntary Service and the promotion of volunteering in Europe. In 2016, the European Voluntary Service is celebrating its 20th anniversary and has provided support to 100,000 volunteers over the last 20 years. Volunteering has value and significance as one of the most visible expressions of solidarity, promoting and enabling social inclusion, creating social capital and transforming society, as well as contributing to the development of an active civil society that can offer creative and innovative solutions to common challenges. economic growth, which makes it necessary to judge it by specific criteria in terms of economic and social capital. Volunteering requires a combination of support mechanisms and / or appropriate organizational structures, which should be further strengthened by an appropriate legal framework defining the rights and obligations of volunteers and volunteering. Parliament encourages the Member States to promote European Voluntary Service in their education and university systems as a tool for educating the younger generation on solidarity and civic engagement. The European Voluntary Service should provide quick and easy access to this program, and the current application system needs to be simplified.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted in favor of the JMR on the European Voluntary Service and the promotion of volunteering in Europe since Podemos defends the values ​​of volunteering, solidarity, active citizenship and the mobilization of civil society in favor of the most vulnerable without chrematistic objectives. This JMR has highlighted aspects that are key for us, such as that volunteering should not replace formal employment, that volunteering systems at European level still lack adequate coordination and it is necessary to improve it or that fair funding is needed for its correct developing. The Resolution also values ​​the entire movement of volunteers during the refugee crisis who have known how to react to challenges with great pragmatism, and contemplates the possibility of recognition of volunteer status and improving access to information, recognition of acquired informal capacities. and a better communication strategy. That is why I think it is a good resolution and vote to consolidate this Service.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing.- Professional mobility and constant improvement of competences is a great opportunity for young people and young employees.European Voluntary Service helps people aged 17 to 30 to travel abroad, so they can take part in volunteer projects lasting between 2 weeks and 12 months.Persons in Erasmus + Program Countries as well as in Neighboring Partner Countries benefit from the European Voluntary Service.Individual projects are also aimed at, inter alia,promotion of social integration, solidarity, dialogue between different cultures.It is estimated that the European Voluntary Service will support up to 100,000volunteers between 2014 and 2020.This project deserves support, which is why I voted in favor.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted in favor of the JMR on the European Voluntary Service and the promotion of volunteering in Europe since Podemos defends the values ​​of volunteering, solidarity, active citizenship and the mobilization of civil society in favor of the most vulnerable without chrematistic objectives. This JMR has highlighted aspects that are key for us, such as that volunteering should not replace formal employment, that volunteering systems at European level still lack adequate coordination and it is necessary to improve it or that fair funding is needed for its correct developing. The Resolution also values ​​the entire movement of volunteers during the refugee crisis who have known how to react to challenges with great pragmatism, and contemplates the possibility of recognition of volunteer status and improving access to information, recognition of acquired informal capacities. and a better communication strategy. That is why I think it is a good resolution and vote to consolidate this Service.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint resolution highlighting that the European Voluntary Service (EVS) celebrates its 20th anniversary in 2016 and that 100 000 volunteers have been supported over those 20 years.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Motions for a Resolution on the European Voluntary Service. Almost 100 million EU citizens have taken part as volunteers in education, culture or arts, sport events, humanitarian and development aid work. Young people should take advantage of volunteering schemes to develop skills and acquire experience that helps them to find jobs afterwards. The report stresses out that despite the real social and economic benefits of volunteering for individuals and organisations, participation in the European Volunteering Service remains modest and many barriers still have to be removed. To encourage volunteering, a more supportive environment is essential, including a legal framework with clear rights and responsibilities for programme managers and volunteers, as well as fair funding. I voted in favour because I believe that the EU needs a better coordinated policy on volunteering, to give volunteers a proper legal status and help them join programmes.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- Although I recognize the social value of volunteering, I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution since it advocates a mercantilist consideration of European volunteering (which is quantified at 5% of GDP) that is used as a substitute for social services that mustbe public.I consider the voluntary work of thousands of citizens and residents of the Union laudable and as such must be socially recognized, but I oppose that volunteering serves as a pretext for the State to disregard its responsibilities, such as for example in the reception ofrefugees, which is the line in which the resolution is directed.For this reason, I have not been able to vote in favor of it.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion which calls on the Commission to facilitate the development of a more coordinated European volunteering policy. The European Voluntary Service (EVS) celebrates its 20th anniversary and 100 000 volunteers have been supported over those 20 years. Volunteering is an expression of solidarity, freedom and responsibility that contributes to the strengthening of active citizenship and to personal human development. It is an essential tool for social inclusion and cohesion, as well as training, education and intercultural dialogue, while making an important contribution to the dissemination of European values. Its benefits are also recognised in voluntary work carried out with third countries as a strategic tool for fostering mutual understanding and intercultural relations.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: written.- In Europe, nearly 100 million citizens of all ages are volunteers.Their commitment contributes to the production of about 5% of the European GDP.I voted in favor of this resolution to ask the Commission to take into account the economic value of goods and services generated by volunteers by focusing policy-making more on volunteering.National, regional and local authorities also need to provide adequate funding, streamline administrative procedures and provide fiscal incentives for voluntary organizations and networks, especially in the case of small organizations with few resources.Volunteers are an invaluable asset to our society;they often form the cement of society.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The European Voluntary Service (EVS) is celebrating its twentieth anniversary this year. Five years have passed since the European Year of Volunteering. And yet the questions and the difficulties have changed very little. First of all, I want once again to denounce the Anglicism which is confusing in France when we speak of volunteers, we should speak in French of volunteers. This report rightly denounces the communication gaps of the EVS. Starting by asking to translate all the documents concerning him into all the languages ​​of the Union would be a good start. The text is also rightly concerned about the conditions in which volunteers operate. I welcome the interest in volunteers over the age of 30, but note that there is no demand to extend EVS to all ages. Pity. Finally, I want to support this text when it takes as an example the volunteers who come to the aid of refugees in Europe. These are missions that should be valued and funded within the framework of EVS. I vote for this text while regretting that it lacks ambition, to say the least.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The European Year of Volunteering 2011, strongly supported by the European Parliament, was an important political opportunity to emphasize the added value of volunteering in Europe. However, it should be remembered that volunteering is carried out freely, by choice and personal motivation, without the purpose of obtaining financial compensation. In this sense, it should be valued by highlighting the solidarity component that is a way of addressing human, social or environmental needs and concerns. However, what we see is that this concept has been used criminally to provide extreme forms of exploitation through which young people end up working for free, doing what others have done in the past in exchange for remuneration. Legislating on this concept, even more so at EU level, in such a heterogeneous Europe, does not seem appropriate to us. Going around will result in a concept that is too vague and comprehensive, thus opening even more doors to the abuses that proliferate there.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- In our time, voluntary service is certainly no longer a matter of course and should therefore not only receive praise, but also help.Austria in particular has a pioneering role here, such as volunteer paramedics or the voluntary fire brigades.Since the courage, commitment and willingness to help these people must continue to be fostered, I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU does not have a competence in academic education and curriculum per se. However, it can be a formidable platform to recognise and promote the role that volunteering, together with sports and arts, play in strengthening socialisation processes and for the development and wellbeing of societies and individuals, education for citizenship and in acquiring lifelong transferable skills. Initiatives such as the European Voluntary Service are more important than ever in times of economic hardship and high youth unemployment, increasing job prospects for young people. The challenge now is to ensure that they are accessible to the most vulnerable young people as well, and for people of ages and all horizons, including people with special needs, minorities, marginalised communities, migrants and refugees. I therefore very much welcomed the resolution and voted in favour.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: in writing. - The EU not only does not recognize the right to permanent employment, but promotes anything that can replace it (flexible forms of employment, training programs). This is confirmed by the joint resolution on the European Voluntary Service, but also by the Commission's recent proposal for the so-called "European Solidarity Body". The resolution notes that volunteering "is not accompanied by the pursuit of financial gain" and that it "helps people to acquire qualifications and skills that can facilitate their access to the labor market", effectively recognizing the use of volunteerism for the benefit of working people. business groups under the pretext of "solidarity". After all, as the European Commission provocatively states in its proposal for the "Solidarity Body", those who participate will either be paid with crumbs or will receive pocket money. With these plans, they try in vain to cover the nudity of social services by outsourcing to private sectors, such as health, welfare, reception and hospitality of refugees, where MKOs are already threshing. The people must turn their backs on those who "snatch the bread from their hands" and then appear as supposed supporters of "solidarity". They must step up their fight against the system that breeds and reproduces poverty and exploitation.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: written.- The PVV voted against the (joint) motion because we do not wish to issue visas to people who come from third countries, including Islamic dictatorships.The European Voluntary Service is opening the borders to the whole world and thus also offers free rein to terrorists from war zones including Syria, thus starting a new flow of immigrants.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I was happy to support the report of the Committee on Culture and Education (CULT). European Voluntary Service helps young people to travel and participate in volunteering programs, not only within EU Member States but also in third countries. It not only helps them to gain different experiences, work with people or learn foreign languages, which in turn help them to improve their position in the labor market, and thus helps to combat youth unemployment. On the other hand, it also contributes to the return to fundamental humanity, to selfless help to others and to finding a sense of application or meaning in life. I therefore think that this concept needs to be supported, because it is beneficial in many ways. In addition to supporting volunteering projects, we should make it easier for people who selflessly help their position, not only during volunteering but also after it, at least by recognizing the skills acquired and taking due account of the time spent in volunteering. .

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of the resolution on European voluntary service as it is an essential instrument for inclusion, social cohesion, training, education and intercultural dialogue, while making an important contribution to the spread of European values.I highlight the resolution's proposal to establish a European legal framework for volunteering actions that defines a voluntary status, with rights and responsibilities, and that facilitates mobility and the recognition of skills between Member States.I note that there are around 100 million citizens of all ages who are volunteers in the EU, whose work contributes to the production of approximately 5% of GDP.I therefore advocate supporting the idea of allowing time spent on volunteering to benefit from EU grants for co-financing, as recently suggested by the Commission in the new proposal for a Financial Regulation.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on European Voluntary Service and the promotion of volunteering in Europe.European Voluntary Service is an excellent service with a clear framework for action.For example, the organizations working in it sign a quality charter.Participating volunteers between the ages of 17 and 30 dedicate themselves exclusively to voluntary activities for a period of two weeks to one year.It is known that EVS covers participants' travel and subsistence expenses, insurance and pocket money.Volunteering is an expression of solidarity and responsibility, as it contributes to greater citizen involvement, personal development and, in our case, strengthens European values.It is an important tool for non-formal learning and training.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about young people and we know that the youth unemployment figures are dramatic, they are dramatic in many, in too many, countries of the European Union. This is why we must strengthen but also multiply those tools that allow young people to fulfill themselves and the first realization is to find a job. In fact, we must find these tools above all in the labor market, for access to the labor market, because we are witnessing a sad generational gap, precisely in terms of access to work and also wages. Here, in this sense, the most delicate moment is the transition between training and work. I believe that we need to focus our efforts here and I also think that we need to create an environment conducive to entrepreneurship, an environment conducive to startups in the European Union. Young people with new and creative ideas must have the opportunity to translate them into concrete realities. I believe that here lies the key to bringing down youth unemployment and relaunching growth in Europe.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: - The report on the evaluation of the European Union Strategy for Youth over the past three years has been very ambitious and covered almost all areas of young people's lives. Moreover, she was not as detached from reality as she is, unfortunately, sometimes. It is gratifying that the rapporteur has focused not only on the quality of formal and non-formal education or the key importance of new technologies and the promotion of young people's entrepreneurship, but also on the need for close links between the school public and private sectors and their cooperation with youth organizations. The report also looked in detail at preventing unemployment, poverty and social exclusion of young people, their causes and finding effective solutions. Young people are the driving force for the future of any society, and therefore investing in young people is the surest investment in our common future. I also very much welcome the emphasis on the still underappreciated importance of intergenerational solidarity and volunteering for young people. If we want a more human society for the young generation to build, then this is where the road goes. It is our duty to enable young people to develop them all the way, so that we do not grow lost generations in Europe, but confident citizens who lead a dignified, full and fulfilled life. That is why I voted in favor.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Investing in young people means investing in today's and tomorrow's human capital. It basically means investing in our future. With the aging population in Europe, the future of young people is an urgent priority for us. We need to act accordingly and not just talk about it, because we have been talking for a long time, but to put into practice public policies, strategies, concrete plans that will give them jobs, get them out of the social passivity that has led and to some kind of exclusion. There are over 8 million young people in Europe today who are unemployed. The highest rates are in Greece and Spain, but there are many everywhere. Moreover, this exclusion, the lack of jobs and so on and the lack of concrete measures for them determined them to vote less than in other generations. I support this report, because the Union needs a policy that encourages the participation of young people in the economy in the first place, so it must enter into entrepreneurship, which will lead to their reintegration into society, which means social contribution, inventiveness, imagination, progress and the Union's success.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - I am convinced that youth policies cannot exist on their own. Synergies are needed between the European Union's youth policy strategy and other policies. It must be in line with education and training, health and employment policies. In the same line of thought, I believe that the opinion of young people, as well as the expertise of youth organizations, must be taken into account when formulating and evaluating the strategy. In this regard, I share an opinion that is recorded in the report of the European Youth Forum. They believe that 57% of the expertise of youth organizations is not taken into account. I believe that their contribution should have more weight, especially since they are a major provider of key skills and competences. In conclusion, I believe that the priorities that must be included in the strategy for the next three years are targeted investment in horizontal skills, such as entrepreneurship and digital literacy. I supported the report because I believe that young people must be at the heart of European policies.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, no doubt about it, the economic crisis has had a terrible effect, especially on young people, leaving many of them unemployed and, as a result, disillusioned and maybe passive. But at the same time, the optimism of youth will always win out. This was very clear, especially in the referendum in the United Kingdom on Brexit. The majority of young people voted to stay in the European Union. It was the older generations who are now hell-bent on taking them out of the European Union, doing their youth a terrible disservice. Hopefully those young people, when they come to adulthood and take over positions themselves, will be in a position to reverse this terrible mistake. Therefore, we should do everything we can to help the youth, not just of Britain but right across the European Union, especially in getting jobs and digital skills which will be most needed into the future. It is the youth who will create the digital single market in Europe.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Madam President! I must admit that I cannot clearly assess the implementation of the European Union youth strategy for 2013-2015. On the one hand, youth unemployment has decreased and fewer people leave school prematurely, on the other hand, it is difficult to be satisfied with the knowledge that eight million young people are still unemployed and a significant proportion of those who have one work part-time. hours or below your qualifications. One area where the situation has not been improved is the improvement of young people's digital skills. Therefore, I am pleased that the rapporteur has emphasized this strongly in the report. Last week, there were events across the EU to promote programming skills among young people. It is an extremely valuable initiative and it will certainly bring significant results in a few years. In one respect, however, its course was symptomatic. As the organizers note, girls were little involved in it. This shows the problem that we have to deal with throughout the Union. It is not possible to improve the situation of young people on the labor market if a significant part of them is excluded from the fastest growing sector of the economy. For the above reasons, I voted in favor of the project.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- Although the report does not present particularly negative or critical aspects, I have decided to abstain.The main reasons are the fact that the speaker does not adequately investigate the enormous problems that afflict the current generation, such as, for example, the immense difficulties that young people encounter today in entering the world of work.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non—binding initiative, which bears reference to an increase in funding for current programmes and calls for interference in Member States’ education systems and the harmonisation of EU youth policies, at local and Member State level. These are competencies of the individual Member States and are not for the EU to dictate, therefore we cannot support this initiative.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- Youth policy is the competence of the Member States.While the Union has a coordinating, supporting and advising role, it cannot take any legislative action.Therefore, despite the good intentions contained in this report on the Strategy of the Union for Youth 2013-2015, I voted against it, since it maintains a neoliberal approach and considers that the way to combat youth unemployment passesfor strengthening cooperation between companies and universities.Furthermore, it does not recognize the devastating impact of austerity policies or cuts in education and culture and ignores them as causing the increase in youth unemployment and the social exclusion of young people, which is why I voted against this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted for this report.It is fundamental that young people and youth organizations are systematically involved in the development of youth policies.We need to channel investments into inclusive education to ensure equal access and opportunities for all young people, including those with different socioeconomic backgrounds, as well as vulnerable and disadvantaged groups.We must strive for better recognition of the skills acquired through non-formal and informal learning, not only because they give young people skills and knowledge, but also because they contribute to the personal development of apprentices.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing.- Despite some good proposals, I voted against this report, which uses youth and education policies to promote the settlement of migrants on the European continent.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Once again this report calls for more EU action and greater coordination at EU level. In the light of the recent Brexit vote in the UK, I cannot go against the expressed wish of the British people in terms of harmonisation and therefore felt it important to vote against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text devoted to my main concern since taking office in the European Parliament: the scourge of youth unemployment.The situation is clearly disappointing for the period 2013-2015.Consequently, the period 2016-2018 should mark a turning point in the Union's youth strategy by focusing on the integration of young people into the labor market.Among the avenues to explore, learning is one of the avenues to follow.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- The economic crisis has hit young people particularly hard.The gap between certain categories of young people has widened: some of them have increasingly lost their place in social and civic life.This situation is exacerbated by the fact that some of them are at risk of social passivity, exclusion, isolation and even violent radicalization.Although since 2013The structured dialogue is constantly evolving and is currently receiving more attention in the Youth Strategy, but I agree that the 2016-2018In the 2007-2013 period, we must seek to encourage the widest and most diverse groups of young people to play an active role in local and global communities, within the framework of cooperation in the youth field.We must also support the integration of young people into the labor market.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding initiative, which bears reference to an increase in funding for current programmes and calls for interference in Member States’ education systems and the harmonisation of EU youth policies, at local and Member State level. These are competencies of the individual Member States and are not for the EU to dictate, therefore we cannot support this initiative.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- This resolution seeks to give more power to the European Union in youth and education policies, which is an attack on our sovereignty.These policies will be used as a means to promote the integration of economic migrants, when they should be sent home.Moreover, it is partly because of the Union’s previous strategies on this issue that our young people are now vulnerable, and that is why I voted against it, although there are some good aspects to this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing.- I approved this report, which assesses the Union's strategy for youth 2013-2015.The report underlines in particular that the next cycle (2016-2018) should focus on the causes of unemployment among young people, which remains far too high.It will have to fight against school dropout, invest in education, internships, apprenticeship and vocational training and facilitate the transition to the labor market by means of measures ensuring better coordination between educational programs, policy inemployment and labor market requirements.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. - Young people are a great opportunity for the European Union, but too often they find themselves among the first victims of the economic crisis and of the ineffectiveness of the policies promoted for employment and growth by the various Member States. My support for the Bocskor report stems precisely from the awareness of the urgency and importance of preparing an effective EU youth strategy for the coming years. The text approved today highlights the positive results achieved in recent years, in particular thanks to the development of the EU structured dialogue between policy makers, young people and their representatives. This listening tool, which must also be promoted for the 2016-2018 period, must be accompanied by further efforts to spread EU programs and funding opportunities among young people. The objective must be to stimulate and motivate the various groups of young people to active citizenship both within local and global communities and in civil and democratic life, also defining a framework of cooperation that helps them find a job and participate fully to social life.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because I believe that this review report on the 2013-2015 Youth strategy contains complex elements of analysis and lines of improvement that I believe are consistent with the positions of our training.However, there are elements in the report with which I do not agree, such as the creation of an 'Erasmus for apprentices' or an exacerbated rhetoric of entrepreneurship, to the detriment of other active employment policies.However, I consider that the positive aspects are more than the negative ones, so my vote is in favor.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: in writing. - Talking about culture in the dark and difficult times we are going through in France and in Europe may seem ridiculous and not be a priority for action. And yet, it is not, on the contrary. It is to our young people today that we must give back this feeling of belonging to a country, a nation, a territory, a Western culture because what unites us above all is culture. , this essential element of any society and the foundation of our civilizations. The report we voted for recalls the essential role that European culture must play with our young people. Certainly this is true. But culture is also regional and national, and it is these three cultures that must develop to face the globalization and Americanization of culture among our young people. We must resist. We have to organize ourselves. Our political elites, our teachers, our academics must focus on the teaching of languages, mathematics, history but also, and this is essential, on the history of art, which is in my eyes at least as important as geography, physics or other subjects.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- The cornerstone of the EU Youth Strategy is employment and the emergence of real opportunities to integrate youth talent into our productive economy.That factor solves all the others, empowerment, participation, and requires a decisive intervention in the field of education.Maintaining and improving programs that open the perspective of young people from their own community to the world is another key that forces us to maintain successful initiatives such as Erasmus, review and gain effectiveness in programs such as the Youth Guarantee and support entrepreneurship.with special attention to the field of new businesses.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - Despite some good elements in the report, I had to oppose this text, which aims to give the EU more competence in the field of youth and education policies, used as a mechanism for the integration of migrants. The EU is gripped by the schizophrenia of the 'pyromaniac firefighter', seeking to put out the blaze of endemic youth unemployment, which it itself has created through its ultraliberal policies, its single currency, its posted workers and its immigration. reserve army of capitalism ”. That is why I tabled, on behalf of my group, an alternative motion for a resolution, in which I recall that not only education and youth policies fall within the competence of the Member States, but also that any strategy in favor of youth will be doomed to failure if we persist in "band aid" initiatives such as the youth guarantee or the youth employment initiative, which cannot offset the effects of austerity policies or the tendency to want to make young people, via European programs, future “posted workers”.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- The report on the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015 presents passages that can be shared, however, there are also important critical issues that prompted me to express myself with an abstention.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have abstained. The report looks at the latest three-year cycle of the EU's youth strategy and proposes priorities for the coming period. It makes a good analysis of the general situation of young people in the EU: long-term unemployment, involuntary part-time work, poverty and exclusion. The report also advocates the participation of youth organizations in decision-making bodies and proposes a range of areas for action - education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and well-being, participation, voluntary activities, social inclusion, young people and the world, and creativity and culture. But the report also argues for increased influence for companies and private actors in the education sector. This is something that the Left Party strongly opposes. The presence and profit-taking of private actors in the public sector only increases injustice and creates social exclusion.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, which assesses the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015, a Strategy focused on improving and solving the main challenges of young people: unemployment, poverty and social exclusion.For the next cycle (2016-2018), greater investment in access to education, greater mobility through Erasmus + and greater involvement of young people in policy-making and decision-making is recommended.The vulnerable groups identified in the report include migrants, refugees, minority groups, women and LGTBI people.It also emphasizes the need to tackle the causes of youth unemployment, promote entrepreneurship among young people and invest in education, internships, apprenticeships and vocational training.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which covers the period 2013-2015. Evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy. The economic crisis has hit young people particularly hard. In addition, the gap between certain categories of young people has widened: some of them have increasingly lost their place in social and civic life. This situation is exacerbated by the fact that some of them are at risk of social passivity, exclusion, isolation and even violent radicalization. Youth policy falls within the competence of the Member States, and the role of the European Union includes coordination, guidance and support. As there is no possibility of adopting a legislative instrument in this area at EU level, the open method of coordination has been used. 2016–2018 In the 2007-2013 period, we must seek to encourage the widest possible and most diverse groups of young people to play an active role in local and global communities, as well as in civil and democratic life, within the framework of cooperation in the youth field. Similarly, under the framework of cooperation in the youth field, we should help young people to find work and participate in society. EU funding, under the Erasmus + program, must complement cooperation on policies related to youth work, volunteering and participation in civic life. The integration of young people into the labor market and the development of their human capital will also be supported by other instruments, such as the European Social Fund, the Investment Plan for Europe and the Youth Employment Initiative.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. - My report assesses the results of the EU Youth Strategy for the 2013-2015 cycle. Youth policy is a Member State competence, the role of the European Union is coordination and support. As no legislative action can be taken at EU level in this area, the EU Youth Strategy 2010-2018 has adopted the so-called an open method of coordination, whereby Member States are free to decide whether to accept or incorporate EU recommendations into their national youth strategies. Many young people find it difficult to find lasting and quality jobs, which is a serious obstacle to independence. Youth unemployment has fallen in most Member States recently, but this figure remains a matter of serious concern. In 2015, youth unemployment in Europe fell to 19.7%. According to the latest data, this rate fell to 18.9% in 2016. My report highlights the importance of digital, entrepreneurial skills as well as ‘soft’ skills. A stable and high-quality workplace and a safe environment are very important for creating independence and starting a responsible family. Due to the aging of the population, Europe urgently needs to activate young people, encourage them to start a family and have children. My report underlines the importance of the role of the family, school, religious communities and sport in the healthy development and socialization of young people, while highlighting the involvement of local and regional communities in youth policy.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the evaluation report on the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015. It seems important to me that the report reiterates its call for closer cooperation and exchange of best practice on youth-related issues, which significantly improves the use of good practice. I agree with the statement that the integration of young people with disabilities into the labor market is essential so that we can ensure their independent living and full inclusion in society. I see the strategy as important given the alarmingly high level of youth unemployment in the EU and their social exclusion. It is also important that the next cycle of the EU Youth Strategy includes young refugees and asylum seekers in its objectives. Their access to education, training and employment and social inclusion is essential so that they can build their identity as EU citizens and prevent them from being disappointed. I believe that it is justified to call on the Member States to make the best use of available EU and national policies and financial frameworks to encourage appropriate investment in young people and the creation of quality and secure jobs. I find the Erasmus + program good, especially as regards apprenticeships, which thus encourages further cross-border experience among young people. I agree with strengthening partnerships between youth organizations and public authorities, as they can increase the opportunities for young people and their organizations to participate in policy-making.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. - The human and social capital represented by young Europeans represents a decisive value for the future of the Union. In the last decade the labor market, also in the wake of the macro-economic imbalances caused by the crisis, has undergone profound changes. One of the most worrying effects of this phenomenon has been the alarming rise in youth unemployment in many of the Member States. Responsibility for youth policies lies with the Member States, leaving the European Union with the task of coordination and support. By virtue of this strategic role, Europe must work in parallel in several areas, starting from education to employment and entrepreneurship. This report, which I support, also focuses on the inclusion of young people in policies that are going to be defined through the instrument of structured dialogue; in fact, I believe that it is also through the active participation and involvement of stakeholders that national and regional authorities can develop long-term policies, effective above all in terms of employment.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this Report on the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015, which focuses on the evaluation of the Strategy, but also on the recommendations for the third and last cycle of the three-year European Youth Strategy (2016-2018).The report provides an overview of the challenges facing Europe's young people today, such as unemployment, poverty and social exclusion.Furthermore, the report identifies target groups that are more likely to be unemployed and marginalized: young people with low qualifications, the socially disadvantaged and those of lower socio-economic status, such as ethnic minorities, refugees, migrants and asylum seekers.Building a strategy for youth in the EU involves all stakeholders, especially youth organizations, recognizing voluntary activities and ultimately promoting and investing in mobility programs, in particular the Erasmus + program.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. - The human and social capital represented by young people is one of the major European resources for the future. The EU and its Member States cannot therefore refrain from developing the potential of the pool of knowledge, creativity, skills and competences of 90 million young Europeans. However, the population aged between 16 and 35 was the one most affected by the crisis and least protected by traditional forms of social protection and representation. While the responsibility for youth policy lies with the Member States, the EU can coordinate, promote and support a common framework for action based on facilitating the transition from education / training to the labor market, and on promotion among all young people of active citizenship, social inclusion and solidarity. In recent times, this has become a particularly important priority, due to the radicalization of some groups of young people in degenerated territorial areas and the need to prevent phenomena of social ghettoization or violent and subversive radicalization. Today 13.7 million young Europeans are neither employed nor enrolled in education or training courses (NEETs) and 27 million are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Dealing with this means taking care of our future.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. - The Union's youth strategy incorporates two priorities: fostering the integration of young people into the labor market and contributing to the social integration of young people in our societies. We share most of the observations made in this draft report, which addresses the consequences of the brain drain, the mismatch of skills acquired during higher education with the needs of the labor market, and the entrepreneurial spirit among young people. However, we cannot support certain positions defended in this text, in particular those promoting multiculturalism and multilingualism. This report also calls for promoting the mobility of young people within the European Union in order to remedy the mass unemployment of which they are victims. However, it is first of all the budgetary austerity policies imposed by the European Commission as well as the measures aimed at making the labor market more flexible, which have helped to accelerate the precariousness of young people in our societies. For all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - Following the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy for 2013-2015, it was found that there are positive trends in education indicators, as a result, early school leaving is declining, but youth unemployment has also fallen in most countries member. In order to continue these positive results, the youth policy for the period 2010-2018 proposes eight areas of activity aimed at supporting young people and improving their quality of life. These areas are: education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and quality of life, participation, volunteering, social inclusion, youth in the world, creativity and culture. I am in favor of this report because I am convinced that young people are Europe's most important resource, and that the European institutions need to invest in them, continuing the Union's Youth Strategy and continuing to respond actively to the challenges they face. young people.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing.- The European Union's youth strategy has been put in place for the period 2010-2018.This report aims to assess the cooperation framework for youth and its application by the Member States.The objective of the strategy is twofold: to facilitate the transition from school to the world of work and to encourage young people to be more involved in society.Youth policies are the responsibility of the Member States.The European Union therefore only has a coordinating, guiding and supporting role in this area.The exchange of good practices between Member States must be intensified for the strategy to really bear fruit.It is important to act because young people were and still are particularly affected by the economic and financial crisis of 2008. Adequate funding must be provided for this strategy.I voted in favor of this report.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE)
text: written.- I defend a guaranteed minimum income, taking into account the traditions and practices of each Member State, as a mechanism to fight poverty.However, I think that paragraph 103 is out of place in this report on the evaluation of the Union for Youth Strategy 2013-2015 and I have therefore voted against that paragraph.I have supported the resolution as a whole.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the final vote in this report. There were several positive aspects of this report in terms of proposing to reduce youth unemployment, improve skills and ensure a strong focus on youth participation in decision-making when it comes to youth policy. The most substantial point in the report is that it ‘views the ‘open method of coordination’ as an appropriate but still insufficient as a means for framing youth policies that needs to be complemented by other measures’. In contrast, I support Member States retaining primary competence over youth policy. The main problems I had with the report related to the relationship between education and employment. For example, paragraphs 45 and 51 promote entrepreneurship as a substantial solution to youth unemployment, and a call for collaboration between business and universities in the development of skills needed by the labour market. Despite the positive aspects of the report I could not fully support it due to some of the false solutions it promotes, and its failure to acknowledge austerity policies and lack of investment as the primary cause of youth unemployment in Europe, so I abstained on the final vote.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ We need to invest in our youth, in particular at a time when youth unemployment in some countries has reached around 40 % of those unemployed. They are our future, and we are responsible for their future. We need to empower our youth to be more entrepreneurial, have an innovative attitude and invest in lifelong learning in order to help them be the drivers of growth and help address many societal challenges.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The report does not present particular critical points, but it does not at all reach the heart of the problems affecting the current generation of young people;there is no trace of the enormous difficulties of entering the social and working world.The report renounces, out of conformity with the policies implemented so far, to carry out a realistic analysis of the major structural problems that afflict Europe today and, although it does not say anything wrong, it is therefore not effective.I therefore decided to abstain.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - It is a fact that the economic crisis has hit young people hard. Inequalities between certain categories of young people have increased, and more and more young people are losing their place in social and public life. The situation is further exacerbated by the fact that, for some, there is a risk of social inactivity, exclusion and isolation, and even violent radicalization. We emphasize that young people, as human and social capital, are one of the most important resources and guarantors of Europe's future.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing.- Abstention for this relationship which, as often happens, is politically exploited.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - Today I have the honor of participating in the decisions of an all-encompassing and unique phenomenon in history, but certainly when I started doing politics I could never have foreseen to hold such an office. When at 22 for the first time I crossed the doors of the Municipality of Alba as Deputy Mayor I felt the thrill and emotion of the moment, but at the same time I did not know how long my cursus honorum would last. The same uncertainty about the future that gripped me as a boy, I live now as a father seeing youth unemployment, high and highly variable NEET rates and growing social exclusion flare up in the EU. Therefore, I vote in favor of the Youth Strategy with the full conviction that only the full participation of young people themselves in decision-making processes favors the planning, elaboration, implementation and monitoring of effective policies to address current and future challenges. I applaud the use of more than 12.4 billion from the European Social Fund to implement not only active participation, but also a more intense combination of education and youth employment by promoting entrepreneurship and coordination between skills and the labor market according to a global and inclusive approach.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the assessment of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015 and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The human and social capital of young people is one of Europe's greatest assets for the future, and it is necessary to invest in the potential represented by 90 million young Europeans, in terms of skills, creativity and diversity. I support the Bocskor Report which assesses the progress made in achieving the objectives and priorities of the cooperation framework defined for the period 2013-2015, analyzing the situation of young people and the political measures adopted by the EU and the Member States and proposing concrete measures to the next 2016-2018 cycle. I welcome the positive, albeit mitigated, trend in some states with regard to education indicators, with the decrease in early school leaving, the increase in graduates and the reduction of youth unemployment in most Member States. However, these values ​​need to be improved: 13.7 million young people in Europe do not work and approximately 27 million are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. We also have to encourage young people to play a more active role in local communities, help find jobs and participate in life in society.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the resolution because I believe that we have already achieved a lot in 2013-2015, but that we still need to step up our efforts.We must further intensify the structured dialogue at EU level between political decision-makers and young people and their representatives and support young people in finding jobs and participating more actively in social life.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the text as I firmly believe that young people represent one of the most important resources for Europe and that due to the economic crisis they are today one of the categories most in difficulty. The main risks they face today are social passivity, exclusion, isolation and even violent radicalization. Many young people find it difficult to find a job and this can also be a serious obstacle to becoming independent. I agree with the EU Youth Strategy which defines eight policy areas: education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and well-being, participation, volunteering, social inclusion, young people around the world, creativity and culture. Measures which facilitate the transition from education / training to the labor market and which promote active citizenship, social inclusion and solidarity among all young people need to be prioritized.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- Youth policy is the competence of the Member States.While the Union has a coordinating, supporting and advising role, it cannot take any legislative action.Therefore, despite the good intentions contained in this report on the Strategy of the Union for Youth 2013-2015, I voted against it, since it maintains a neoliberal approach and considers that the way to combat youth unemployment passesfor strengthening cooperation between companies and universities.Furthermore, it does not recognize the devastating impact of austerity policies or cuts in education and culture and ignores them as causing the increase in youth unemployment and the social exclusion of young people, which is why I voted against this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. - The alarming levels reached by youth unemployment and social exclusion among young people require the search for effective and shared solutions. I believe that the EU Youth Strategy is an excellent vector for forging links between various fields of action, including employment and entrepreneurship, education and training and social inclusion, in order to develop comprehensive solutions to support young people. Today, in the face of the growing socio-economic gap, it is necessary and necessary to facilitate the transition from education / training to the labor market, promoting active citizenship, social inclusion and solidarity among young people. This is only possible by channeling investment in inclusive education that ensures equal opportunities for all young people, including those from difficult socio-economic backgrounds or those who, such as refugees, migrants and asylum seekers, are part of vulnerable groups and disadvantaged. From this point of view, I believe that the targeted promotion of cross-border training and professional paths, such as Erasmus Plus, can provide the key to equipping young people with skills and competences, which can expand the opportunities for participation in the labor market and in life. social.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: signed up. - One of Europe's main resources, but also one of the guarantees of the EU's future, is represented by the human and social capital of young people. The role of the European Union is to coordinate, guide and support Member States' policies for young people. The renewed framework for European cooperation in the field of the EU Youth Strategy covers the period 2010-2018 and defines eight areas of action: education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and quality of life, participation, volunteering, social inclusion, youth in world, creativity and culture. There are positive trends in terms of dropping out of school. The percentage for the 18-24 age group decreased from 13.9% in 2010 to 11.1% in 2014. The youth unemployment rate decreased from 24% in February 2013 to 20% in November 2015, but things are not resolved. In total, there are 13.7 million young Europeans who do not have a job or attend any form of education, and some 27 million young people are still at risk of poverty and social exclusion. I voted in favor of further developing projects for young people and supporting them through the tools available to the EU.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. - The economic crisis of recent years has not spared the younger generations of the EU either. Unemployment and the gap between social groups have become increasingly perceptible to young people. All this also affected the vision of young people and their trust in the Union and in the community. Youth unemployment in Europe has fallen from a negative peak in a few years, but in 2016 it is still at 18.9%. Therefore, according to the report, further measures are needed to reduce youth unemployment and, at the same time, to improve the quality of life of young people. Change requires more effective cooperation at EU level, but especially at Member State level, in a number of areas, such as employment, education and training, culture and sport. It is essential to improve the quality of education and better match it to labor market needs. The text raises awareness of the need to activate young people as Europe's population ages, for example through conscious family and youth policies, home-building programs, and family tax breaks. The family, school, sports and churches play a crucial role in the healthy development of young people, and the involvement of local and regional communities in youth policy can bring positive results. The report recalls the importance of using the mother tongue and preserving multilingualism. It is in the interest of the Member States to maintain institutions which guarantee the education of national or linguistic minorities in their mother tongue.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted against the report on the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015 as I believe that youth policy should be the responsibility of the Member States.The role of the EU in this area should be limited to providing guidance and supporting actions taken by Member States.I am concerned about the breach of the subsidiarity principle in the report.By suggesting that intergovernmental cooperation is insufficient, the rapporteur is thus trying to transfer more powers to the EU in this area.Therefore, I voted against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Youth policy is a competence of the Member States, while the European Union’s role is one of coordination, guidance and support. I am in favour of this report as it identifies the problems that youth face daily. I also support the priorities set out in this youth strategy, as they seek to facilitate the transition from school to the work environment, foster active citizenship while also promoting social inclusion and solidarity. I fully support the idea that young citizens and organisations should be involved in youth policymaking as younger generations are not only the future but also the present and their voice must be heard.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. - The report approved by the Parliament focuses on the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015 and on the recommendations for the third and final three-year cycle of the same (2016-2018). The report provided a clear overview of the challenges young Europeans are facing today, such as unemployment, poverty and social exclusion. The report then identified some categories of young people who are particularly susceptible to the phenomena of unemployment and marginalization, including ethnic minority groups, composed mainly of refugees, migrants and asylum seekers. Faced with this reality, Europe cannot remain indifferent and it is for this reason that I have strongly supported the recommendations in the report, including those to encourage investment in "accessible" education and for the promotion of quality internships. . Indeed, it is of fundamental importance to invest in the quality of jobs through the construction of an EU youth strategy that involves all stakeholders, as well as to promote and invest in mobility programs, such as the Erasmus + program, which should be accessible to all to encourage the construction of an ever more solid European identity.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing.- This own-initiative report is based on the Union's youth strategy 2013-2015 and aims to set priority objectives in order to facilitate the transition from school to the world of work and to promote active citizenship,social inclusion and solidarity between young people.Considering that young people, through their creativity, dynamism and knowledge, represent precious human and social capital for the European Union, but that at the same time this segment of the population has been hit harder by the economic crisis,I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the European Union Youth Strategy 2013-2015.More than 4.5 million young people (aged 15 to 24) are unemployed today in the European Union.The youth unemployment rate is more than double the overall unemployment rate and masks considerable differences between countries.Many European initiatives and strategies for youth jobs have already been implemented in recent years, but it is essential that the next cycle (2016-2018) contributes to the objectives of the youth strategy.The Erasmus + program must be fully implemented, particularly with regard to apprenticeships.In addition, the possibilities for internships in other EU Member States must be improved.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. - The report assesses the results of the EU Youth Strategy for the cycle 2013-2015. The human and social capital represented by young people is one of Europe's greatest resources, the key to its future. The European Union and the Member States must therefore not overlook the potential of the creativity, diversity, abilities and skills of the 90 million young people in Europe. Many young people find it difficult to find lasting and quality jobs, which is a serious obstacle to independence. Youth unemployment has fallen in most Member States recently, but this figure remains a matter of serious concern. In 2015, youth unemployment in Europe fell to 19.7%. According to the latest data, this rate fell to 18.9% in 2016. A stable and high-quality workplace and a safe environment are very important for creating independence and starting a responsible family. The basis of all this can be provided by a good education and training system. Due to the aging of the population, Europe urgently needs to activate young people, encourage them to start a family and have children. The report underlines the importance of the role of the family, school, religious communities and sport in the healthy development and socialization of young people, while highlighting the involvement of local and regional communities in youth policy.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. - The report covers the implementation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015. evaluate the results for its cycle. The human and social capital represented by young people is one of Europe's greatest resources, the key to its future. The European Union and the Member States must therefore not overlook the potential of the creativity, diversity, abilities and skills of 90 million young people in Europe. The report underlines the importance of the role of the family, school, religious communities and sport in the healthy development and socialization of young people, while highlighting the involvement of local and regional communities in youth policy.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - The rapporteur for this text, who recalled that youth was a competence of the Member States, is not clear on respect for sovereignty and subsidiarity. In addition, we find a few clichés such as the need for intercultural dialogue, the integration of refugees and migrants through education, sport and the fight against xenophobia. We can read the call for special attention to young people "who identify as LGBTI", for the promotion of multilingualism. We find there the belief in mobility as a solution to unemployment, or the promotion of the "European" dimension in education. The text recognizes the problem of "brain drain" without resolving its causes. He underlines the importance of the family to supervise young people and the necessary support for young entrepreneurs. He also defends apprenticeship and vocational training. However, given the mostly negative aspects, I preferred to vote against this text

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: In written form. - My opinion, and the opinion of my group, is that this report does not correspond to the preliminary idea set out in it to evaluate the EU Youth Strategy (2013-2015), as its title is. At the same time, I cannot agree with many of the ideas contained in it. I am FOR the involvement of youth organizations in shaping Union policy, as long as this policy remains at the level of coordination and exchange of good practice. I am also FOR the open method of coordination, which I consider to be very appropriate, and not, as the report says, 'insufficient'. YES! Our young people need help, support and policies to work in their favor, but let us leave that to the Member States, the Treaties say. Let's stop obliging them and scare them! And why should we strive for youth and education programs that empower young women and girls and facilitate their access to traditionally male-dominated sectors? Do we want women to do men's work, and where is the connection with the evaluation of the youth strategy from 2013-2015? I did not support the report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing.- We are voting against the report.We do not believe that any initiative concerning the youth should have as its primary goal the integration and care of illegal immigrants.It is more important for us to address the problems of Europe's youth first.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. - The report covers the implementation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015. evaluate the results for its cycle. The human and social capital represented by young people is one of Europe's greatest resources, the key to its future. The European Union and the Member States must therefore not overlook the potential of the creativity, diversity, abilities and skills of the 90 million young people in Europe.
