The basis of all this can be provided by a good education and training system. Due to the aging of the population, Europe urgently needs to activate young people, encourage them to start a family and have children. The report underlines the importance of the role of the family, school, religious communities and sport in the healthy development and socialization of young people, while highlighting the involvement of local and regional communities in youth policy.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: written.- The report provides recommendations based on the youth strategy 2013–1015.I chose to vote against the call to introduce minimum wages because I do not believe that this is the right way to go in labor market policy and that it is seriously contrary to the Swedish labor market model.I saw several other parts of the report as problematic, in particular the call for the Commission to invest in education and to introduce housing allowances for students, because I believe that these are areas that the Member States should address.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - The human and social capital of young people represents one of Europe's main resources and one of the main guarantees for its future. In general, early school leaving is decreasing. The values ​​for the 18-24 age group dropped from 13.9% in 2010 to 11.1% in 2014. However, the percentage of early school leavers remains high in Spain, Italy, Malta, Portugal and Romania. One third of young people in Europe (in the 30/34 age range) are graduates and 82% of young people aged 20-24 have completed secondary education. Although, in February 2013, the average level of unemployment among young people (aged 15 to 29 years old) in Europe reached a maximum percentage of 23.9%, this figure decreased to 20% by November 2015. However, in some MS, the situation remains extremely worrying. There is a need to continue to encourage cooperation in the framework of policies related to youth work and volunteering activities and participation in civic life must be complemented by EU funding under the Erasmus + program and the integration of young people into the market and the development of its human capital.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Vote against: the rapporteur is not very clear as to his intentions regarding respect for sovereignty and subsidiarity (in particular recitals B and C, paragraphs 1,, 2, 26 and 30), acknowledging however, in his presentationreasons, that youth is a competence of the Member States and that therefore no act taken by the European Union can have legislative scope.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The Youth Cooperation Framework supports the various measures taken by Member States and the EU, including through data collection, mutual learning, exchange of experiences and dialogue with young people. The renewed framework for European cooperation in the field of the EU Youth Strategy covers the period 2010-2018, and defines eight fields of action, namely: education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and well-being, participation, volunteering , social inclusion, youth and the world, creativity and culture. The fields of action selected show a clear ideological orientation, from which we diverge. The report advocates a Strategy and Youth closely associated with the EU2020 Strategy. It addresses pertinent problems but almost always in the wrong way, as is the case of the “brain drain” phenomenon. There is no reference whatsoever to the effect of policies that have been advocated by the EU on the situation of youth (budget cuts in education and culture, youth unemployment). Regarding higher education and the connection to the labor market, meeting the needs of companies, the report unravels an entire ideological program. Without prejudice to positive aspects, for example, with regard to the issue of refugees, the report is globally bad and that is why we voted against.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstain because the relationship is acceptable and positive, excluding the passages in which one falls back into the usual pro-immigrant and pro-Lgbt rhetoric.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015.I do not think that any initiative concerning the youth should have as its primary goal the integration and care of illegal immigrants.For me, it is more important to address the problems of Europe's youth first.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe young people and youth organisations should be systematically involved in youth policy-making. European young people are facing today many different challenges such as youth unemployment, poverty and social exclusion. There is a need to channel investments into inclusive education with regards to ensure equal access and opportunities for all young people, including those having different socio-economic backgrounds as well as vulnerable and disadvantaged groups such as refugees, migrants and asylum-seekers. We should fight for a better recognition of the learning outcomes of skills acquired through non-formal and informal learning not only because they equip young people with the right set of competences and knowledge, but also because they contribute to the personal development and growth of learners in order to make them proactive, responsible and open-minded citizens.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: in writing. – I have voted in favour of this resolution because youth is a topic that is very close to my heart. I wish first of all to underline my attachment to the reference to actively involving youth in policy and to empowering them. As an MEP, I try to contribute by initiatives aimed at young people to promote citizenship and to seek solutions to challenges such as youth unemployment. Therefore, I am happy with the reference to Structured Dialogue as well as the suggestion to involve local and regional authorities in the area of youth policy. Secondly, I welcome the many references to EU programmes and EU funding aimed at employment and education of young people, especially Eramus and Erasmus+ programmes, the Youth Employment Initiative, Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs programme and Youth Guarantee. I encourage EU institutions to simplify administration procedures and invest in communication so that a maximum of young people can benefit from these tools.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. - The human and social capital represented by young people is one of Europe's greatest resources and the key to its future. The European Union and the Member States must therefore not overlook the potential of the creativity, diversity, abilities and skills of 90 million young people in Europe. Many young people find it difficult to find lasting and quality jobs, which is a serious obstacle to independence. Youth unemployment has fallen in most Member States recently, but this figure remains a matter of serious concern. In 2015, youth unemployment in Europe fell to 19.7%. According to the latest data, this rate fell to 18.9% in 2016. A stable and high-quality workplace and a safe environment are very important for creating independence and starting a responsible family. The basis of all this can be provided by a good education and training system. Due to its aging population, Europe urgently needs to activate young people, encourage them to start a family and have children. The report underlines the importance of the role of the family, school, religious communities and sport in the healthy development and socialization of young people, but also highlights the involvement of local and regional communities in youth policy, which is why I voted in favor of it.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. - The report covers the implementation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015. evaluate the results for its cycle. The human and social capital represented by young people is one of Europe's greatest resources, the key to its future. The European Union and the Member States must therefore not overlook the potential of the creativity, diversity, abilities and skills of 90 million young people in Europe. Many young people find it difficult to find lasting and quality jobs, which is a serious obstacle to independence. According to the latest data, this rate fell to 18.9% in 2016. The basis of all this can be provided by a good education and training system. Due to the aging of the population, Europe urgently needs to activate young people, encourage them to start a family and have children. The report underlines the importance of the role of the family, school, religious communities and sport in the healthy development and socialization of young people, while highlighting the involvement of local and regional communities in youth policy.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. - Although in the field of youth, the competence lies entirely with the Member States, the European commitment to youth policies has undoubtedly marked important objectives, giving young people new and more ambitious perspectives. Just think of the Erasmus program, of which over 3 million students have benefited. The current economic crisis certainly does not help tackle unemployment, long-term unemployment or precarious and low-quality jobs, but the European youth strategy records improving data. This is why I supported this report with my vote, because I believe it is important not only to draw up an action plan, but to constantly monitor its results to make sure we are moving in the right direction, aiming for even more ambitious objectives for the last three-year cycle of the strategy. (2016-2018). To improve the quality of life of our future we must push on the educational and social pillar of young people, giving them greater opportunities for employment and integration, equality and ease of access to training and the world of work - especially for the most vulnerable categories, at risk of poverty. and marginalization - and a strong boost to social awareness and civic participation.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported the EP resolution on the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015 because I largely agree with its structure and content. Since the beginning of the legislature, as socialists and democrats, we have placed youth policies and investments in young people at the center of our political battle, as demonstrated by the advance of the Youth Guarantee funding, which we will also defend with reference to the next EU budget . However, much remains to be done to solve the problem of youth unemployment, poverty and social exclusion that many young people face, in particular young people with low qualifications, so-called NEETs, disabled young people, refugees and migrants. The EU must therefore continue to invest in future generations by strengthening all initiatives to combat youth unemployment and addressing the problem of skills in a digital labor market: we therefore need policies for quality work and training, as well as investment in education and training, to facilitate the mobility of young people within the EU. Lastly, I share the call for the recognition of non-formal education as an integral part of the skills that young people must have in order to fully enter the world of work.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: written.- I voted against the report on the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015.I am fully in favor of maintaining and expanding a holistic EU youth strategy - albeit with a different focus and more realism than what is proposed in this report.I completely oppose the pointless idea of a free Interrail ticket for all 18-year-olds and demand that these billions of taxpayers' money be invested in sustainable youth projects and the fight against youth unemployment.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: written.- At 18.6%, youth unemployment in the European Union is far too high.The EU must continue to act here and protect young people from unemployment, marginalization and radicalization.The EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015 report forms a good basis for further work.The EU programs mentioned here, such as Erasmus +, must continue to give young people the opportunity to continue their education in the future.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because I believe that this review report on the 2013-2015 Youth strategy contains complex elements of analysis and lines of improvement that I believe are consistent with the positions of our training.However, there are elements in the report that I do not agree with, such as the creation of an 'Erasmus for apprentices' or exacerbated rhetoric of entrepreneurship, to the detriment of other active employment policies.However, I consider that the positive aspects are more than the negative ones, so my vote is in favor.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which provides relevant assessments of EU actions in the field of youth policy and recommends priorities for the upcoming years, focusing on education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and welfare, participation, volunteering, social inclusion, youth and the world and creativity and culture.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text aimed at improving the employability of young people, their integration into the labor market as well as their social inclusion and participation.Faced with an increasingly pronounced socio-economic divide and a brutal economic crisis, it is our duty to find lasting remedies to fight youth unemployment, strengthen social inclusion and prevent violent radicalization, which impliesthe establishment of a more systematic cooperation for a whole series of policies at EU and Member State level, for example in the field of employment or education.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: in writing.- Unemployment, poverty and social exclusion, these are the challenges that young people face today.Faced with this situation, the EP calls for investment in quality education, inclusive, accessible to all young people, from all socio-economic backgrounds as well as vulnerable and disadvantaged groups such as refugees, migrants and children.asylum seekers.I believe that we must fight for a better recognition of prior learning in non-formal and informal learning, not only because they provide young people with a good set of skills and knowledge, but also becausethey contribute to personal development while helping to make them engaged, responsible and open-minded citizens.It is for these reasons that I supported this report.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The report highlights the continuing importance of the Structured Dialogue as a tool for youth participation and policy-making. Cooperation on policies relating to youth work, volunteering and participation in civic life must be supplemented by EU funding under the Erasmus+ programme. The integration of young people into the labour market and the development of their human capital will also be supported by other instruments such as the European Social Fund, the Investment Plan for Europe and the Youth Employment Initiative.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. - The report assesses the results of the EU Youth Strategy for the 2013-2015 cycle. The human and social capital represented by young people is one of Europe's greatest resources, the key to its future. The European Union and the Member States must therefore not overlook the potential of the creativity, diversity, abilities and skills of 90 million young people in Europe. For many young people, it is a serious difficulty to find a lasting and quality job, which is a major obstacle to independence. Although youth unemployment has fallen in most Member States recently, this problem remains unresolved. Youth unemployment in Europe fell to 19.7% in 2015, down from 18.9% in 2016, according to the latest figures from this year. A stable workplace and a safe environment are very important for creating independence and starting a responsible family. The basis of all this can be provided by a good education and training system. Due to the aging of the population, Europe urgently needs to encourage family formation and the desire to have children. The report emphasizes the importance of the role of the family, the school, religious communities and sport in the healthy development and socialization of young people, while highlighting the involvement of local and regional communities in youth policy.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I along with the majority of my colleagues in the Parliament supported this own-initiative report on the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015. The report is giving the second period assessment for the framework for European cooperation in the field of the EU Youth Strategy, which covers the period of 2010-2018. It defines eight fields of action, namely: education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and welfare, participation, volunteering, social inclusion, youth and the world, creativity and culture. It is an assessment for the past period. I was happy that the resolution called for better cooperation in finding common solutions to the challenges such as early school-leaving, proper counselling on educational path, involving the youth to the decision-making processes and integrating young refugees via the education and training. Likewise, I was glad that the rapporteur noted that the Youth Guarantee and Youth Employment Initiative has not been fully functional in some Member States.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: written.- The purpose of this report is to evaluate the “Youth Policy” strategy for 2013-2015.“Youth policy” in itself is not an EU competence.The EU’s role is at most to coordinate these.The problematic aspects for me are the following (list is not exhaustive): For me and my party, the principle of subsidiarity is the central principle according to which tasks are to be distributed between the levels of the public sector.Several digits disregard this principle, implicitly or explicitly.These are e.g. 2, 60, 111. In addition, the incorrectly constructed currency area is neither named nor combated as the central reason for the very high youth unemployment in southern Europe.The EU is deliberately excluding the part for which it is actually responsible.I therefore reject this report.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015. As the rapporteur rightly points out in the report, there is a large gap between the different groups of young people in Europe. The differences concern individual countries as well as regions and environments. Therefore, any strategy developed at the EU level must be comprehensive and respond to all challenges. Of course, the problem of unemployment remains one of the most urgent, but we can already see that both the overall economic recovery and the youth employment initiative being implemented are starting to bear fruit. However, the fall in unemployment alone is insufficient. If - as President Juncker announced - we have the ambition to create a triple A social standard in the European Union, we must also ensure the quality of this employment. Unfortunately, statistics confirm that young people are more often affected by precarious forms of employment and work below their own qualifications. The European framework for cooperation must take this into account. It also requires proper use of the European Social Fund and other financial instruments and their appropriate synergy.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: in writing. - The report covers the implementation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015. evaluate the results for its cycle. The human and social capital represented by young people is one of Europe's greatest resources, the key to its future. The European Union and the Member States must therefore not overlook the potential of the creativity, diversity, abilities and skills of the 90 million young people in Europe. Many young people find it difficult to find lasting and quality jobs, which is a serious obstacle to independence. According to the latest data, this rate fell to 18.9% in 2016. The basis of all this can be provided by a good education and training system. Due to the aging of the population, Europe urgently needs to activate young people, encourage them to start a family and have children. The report underlines the importance of the role of the family, school, religious communities and sport in the healthy development and socialization of young people, while highlighting the involvement of local and regional communities in youth policy.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: written.- One of Europe's major challenges is exclusion among young people, and in Sweden, as in other EU countries, youth unemployment is a serious problem.A holistic approach will be required for young people to be given better conditions.However, this must be done with respect for the sovereignty of the Member States.Parliament's report on a youth strategy called for changes in labor market regulations, an expansionary fiscal policy to finance education and regulation of what should be included in curricula.In addition, it was proposed that different groups be given special access to public grants.With respect for national self-determination and for a long-term perspective regarding youth issues, the Moderates voted against the report.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: In written form. - I support the report on the evaluation of the EU's youth strategy, as I believe that there is a need to strengthen the integration of youth policy, cross-sectoral cooperation and social activities within the EU. There is also a need to strengthen the link between the European Youth Strategy and other European strategies, such as education, training, health and employment, so that the policies developed can respond effectively to the situation and needs of young people, who need to deal with severe economic, labor and social problems. I believe that youth policy should be based on rights and support the development of all young people, ensuring that the potential of young people is realized. They are our future and should be considered a resource with great potential for the development of European societies.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Having civil society, specifically young individuals and youth organizations, participate in youth policy—making is of great importance. The European institutions need to create a comprehensive plan in regards to education, equal opportunities and access. The youth are Europe’s future, and they should be moulded into open-minded and responsible individuals.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the 2013-2015 EU Youth Strategy Assessment Report because I believe that young people have a huge potential for the future of European societies.Young people should be actively involved in the planning, development, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of all youth policies.This EU Report recommends that local, regional, national and EU bodies ensure quality communication on the various EU-level programs covering youth policies, and their quality implementation and coordination.Youth policy should, in addition to the open method of coordination, call for closer cooperation and exchange of best practices on youth issues, at local, regional, national and EU level.Also, the inclusion of young people with disabilities in the labor market is necessary so that they can lead an independent life and be fully integrated into a society in which they would actively participate and really contribute to it.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- Although there have been some interesting proposals here and there, the uneven tenor of this report, mixing the good with the bad, has not convinced me.States must remain sovereign in this area, and not accept the schizophrenic policy of the European Union, which encourages on the one hand education and employment for young people and produces, on the other, the conditions ofa dire economic situation.I voted against.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Andrea Bocskor on the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015.This strategy defines a framework for cooperation to promote equal opportunities for all young people in education and in the labor market and to encourage them to participate actively in society.In view of the positive results of the 2010-2018 framework for youth, Parliament renews its support for this initiative and proposes involving local and regional authorities in youth policies.It is by bringing decision-making closer to citizens that we will be able to best meet the needs of young people.I am delighted that this report was adopted by a large majority.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written.- The EU Youth Strategy Evaluation Report 2013-2015 aims to bring more relevant, effective and coordinated youth policies across Europe.However, the rapporteur particularly emphasizes the need for the social inclusion of refugees and migrants, failing to make a priority for European youth in terms of job creation.However, this would be a prerequisite for the successful integration of migrants.So I would not agree with this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which provides a relevant assessment of the actions undertaken by the EU in the field of youth policy and gives positive recommendations on the priorities for the next few years, focusing on education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and welfare, participation, volunteering, social inclusion, youth and the world, creativity and culture.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: written. - The purpose of this report is to evaluate the “Youth Policy” strategy for 2013-2015. “Youth policy” in itself is not an EU competence. The EU’s role is at most to coordinate these. The problematic aspects for me are the following (list is not exhaustive): For me and my party, the principle of subsidiarity is the central principle according to which tasks are to be distributed between the levels of public authorities. Several digits disregard this principle, implicitly or explicitly. These are e.g. 2, 60, 111. In addition, the report is very statist and provides for EU / public authorities to interfere in details of private life that I do not want to support. Examples are the numbers 41, 43, 45, 60, 18, 111. In addition, the wrongly constructed currency area is neither named nor combated as the central reason for the very high youth unemployment in southern Europe. The EU is deliberately excluding the part for which it is actually responsible. I therefore reject this report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. - The report assesses the results of the EU Youth Strategy for the cycle 2013-2015. The human and social capital represented by young people is one of Europe's greatest resources, the key to its future. The European Union and the Member States must therefore not overlook the potential of the creativity, diversity, abilities and skills of the 90 million young people in Europe. Many young people find it difficult to find lasting and quality jobs, which is a serious obstacle to independence. According to the latest data, this rate fell to 18.9% in 2016. A stable and high-quality workplace and a safe environment are very important for creating independence and starting a responsible family. The basis of all this can be provided by a good education and training system. Due to the aging of the population, Europe urgently needs to activate young people, encourage them to start a family and have children. The report underlines the importance of the role of the family, school, religious communities and sport in the healthy development and socialization of young people, while highlighting the involvement of local and regional communities in youth policy.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: In written form. - I voted in favor of the report on the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy (2013-2015). I believe that young people should be actively involved in the planning, development, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of all youth policies. In addition, youth policies and national strategies must be developed together with and for the benefit of young people. Member States must make full use of existing EU policies, national policies and financial frameworks to promote appropriate investment in young people and the creation of quality and secure jobs. I welcome the fact that more than EUR 12.4 billion from the European Social Fund (ESF) and the Youth Employment Initiative (YYI) have been set aside to combat youth unemployment in the new programming period. I believe that a better understanding of EU values, the functioning of the EU and European diversity is crucial both for promoting participation in the democratic process and for promoting active civic participation among young people. It is important to note that young people and youth organizations need to be involved in shaping the priorities and a new EU Framework for Cooperation on Youth Affairs after 2018.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the report on the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015, in which initiatives relating to education and youth entry into the labor market play an important role. Once again, the European Parliament emphasizes the importance of vocational training, the practicality and usefulness of education, as well as the need for business and social partners to work together in creating an education framework that will help young people's adult lives. At the same time, the report does not refer to an emerging trend in the scientific community that criticizes the current state of education, including the tendency to extend the education cycle, not to prepare for more innovative and demanding future challenges, but to escape unemployment and the lack of prospects. Universities as stores of the unemployed and undecided are a waste of time, money and opportunities for both students and lecturers. Education is an important factor in shaping the future, but it will not fill the gaps elsewhere, and it is time for politicians to stop giving education as a universal remedy for all the ills they face in their work. The most important thing young people need in order to enter adult life well is training in creativity, critical thinking, openness and willingness to cooperate. The need to involve young people in the process of making decisions about social life and taking responsibility for them, which is mentioned in the report, is also not without significance.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against this report because it aims to give the EU more competence in the field of youth and education policies, used as a Trojan horse for the integration of migrants.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against the report on the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015.Of course, there are positive points in this text.I am thinking in particular of the proposals to promote young entrepreneurs creating their own SMEs and of the importance given to the role of the family in supervising young people and to intergenerational solidarity.However, we also find the common Europeanist and politically correct clichés of this kind of text.In particular, there is the call for "intercultural dialogue" and the promotion of the "European" dimension in education.The text also testifies to the firm belief that mobility would solve the problem of the mismatch of skills with the labor market and would be a solution to the problem of unemployment, while pretending not to see that it could lead tomake young people future posted workers.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: written.- With regard to youth policy, the role of the EU is mainly to support Member States' policies.In this resolution, however, Parliament constantly comes into the field of the Member States.In addition, there are several recommendations, such as encouraging education in the native language of minorities to ending any cutbacks in health care, that we do not support.Hence our vote against.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this initiative report evaluating the Youth Union Strategy in the last three years, because it focuses on the main challenges of youth: unemployment, poverty and social exclusion and identifying the groupsmost vulnerable.Likewise, it makes a series of recommendations for the next and last cycle of this strategy, which will be from 2016 to 2018, highlighting: greater investment in access to quality education, promotion of quality practices, improvement of skills and professional skills toto develop, greater mobility through Erasmus +, recognition of volunteering and greater involvement of young people and youth organizations in the development of policies and decision-making.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- Youth policy is the competence of the Member States.While the Union has a coordinating, supporting and advising role, it cannot take any legislative action.Therefore, despite the good intentions contained in this report on the Strategy of the Union for Youth 2013-2015, I voted against it, since it maintains a neoliberal approach and considers that the way to combat youth unemployment passesfor strengthening cooperation between companies and universities.Furthermore, it does not recognize the devastating impact of austerity policies or cuts in education and culture and ignores them as causing the increase in youth unemployment and the social exclusion of young people, which is why I voted against this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: written. - Youth, the Union's main asset and guarantor of its future, have been particularly affected by the economic crisis, which has widened the differences between certain groups of young people. In this area, the European Union carries out a mission of coordination, guidance and support and has developed an action that covers eight areas of action, including, among others, education and training and employment and entrepreneurship. This Strategy seeks to facilitate the transition from school to the world of work and promote active citizenship. This report assumes that the open method of youth policy coordination is appropriate, but needs to be complemented by other measures in order to progress more effectively. Thus, it highlights the importance of structured dialogue as a means of youth participation and, in particular, proposes, for example, a better understanding of the values ​​and functioning of the European Union, in order to promote democratic participation and active citizenship among Young. I vote in favor of the report, as young people must be seen and treated as a resource with great potential for the future of the Union.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: written. - The purpose of this report is to evaluate the “Youth Policy” strategy for 2013-2015. “Youth policy” in itself is not an EU competence. The EU’s role is at most to coordinate these. The problematic aspects for me are the following (list is not exhaustive): For me and my party, the principle of subsidiarity is the central principle according to which tasks are to be distributed between the levels of the public sector. Several digits disregard this principle, implicitly or explicitly. These are e.g. 2, 60, 111. In addition, the report is very statist and provides for EU / public authorities to intervene in details of private life that I do not want to support. Examples are the numbers 41, 43, 45, 60, 18, 111. In addition, the wrongly constructed currency area is neither named nor combated as the central reason for the very high youth unemployment in southern Europe. The EU is deliberately excluding the part for which it is actually responsible. I therefore reject this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that focuses on tackling youth unemployment.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I voted against. The resolution states that "it is important to equip young people with sufficient knowledge of the EU and an understanding of how it works, including teaching about the fundamental values ​​of the EU". In my opinion, this is a call for the indoctrination of young people by a one-sided ideology. The report further "calls on the Member States to encourage women to train and pursue careers in under-represented sectors". In my opinion, governments should leave it up to people what professions they choose and not to stuff people of a certain gender in fields they do not want. The resolution states that "the unemployment rate falls sharply as educational attainment increases and that it is therefore necessary to promote and invest in higher education opportunities for young people in the EU". In my opinion, this is a silly and dangerous statement that makes young people across the EU unemployed bachelors. I also disagree with the call "for Member States to support young people at the beginning of their independent lives and to provide for their own families through housing allowances". On the contrary, I think that instead of making the young people dependent on benefits for the state, it is better to reduce taxes.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - Recently, youth unemployment has decreased, but its figures are still a cause for concern. In the period 2013-2015, Member States continued measures to improve youth employment, labor market integration, social inclusion and active civic participation. Although progress has been made, further solutions need to be found to reduce youth unemployment and more systematic cooperation in a number of policy areas at EU and Member State level. The renewed framework for European cooperation in the field of the EU Youth Strategy for the period 2010-2018 has 2 general priorities: facilitating the transition from school to the world of work and supporting active citizenship, social inclusion and solidarity. The report emphasizes the need to strengthen the integration of youth policy, cross-sectoral cooperation and social measures in the EU. Youth entrepreneurship needs to be included in the MFF, while Member States should develop national strategies to achieve synergies between Erasmus +, the ESF, the Youth Employment Initiative and Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs. It is necessary to guarantee access to quality education by investing primarily in internships and vocational training. I therefore supported this report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. - The youth strategy must be based on a real knowledge of the needs of young people. Young people themselves must be actively involved in these processes, bringing their knowledge, needs and experience to them. Despite the existence of formal documents, the actual cooperation and involvement of young people in public life is insufficient, which is reflected in the low turnout. Lack of interest, insufficient and not always quality education, not meeting the needs of the labor market, insufficient and dysfunctional social agenda create space for the penetration of extremist views, movements and parties that can have catastrophic consequences for the future of generations. Therefore, it is necessary to allocate resources and develop activities that, even through modern technologies, will lead to a wider involvement of young people in public life, increase their interest in education and lifelong professional growth. The future of generations depends on the quality of education and work with the current generation of young people, which will be reflected in the whole spectrum of social and political life.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- I abstained from voting on the report on the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015 because it is not sufficiently documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.Although the rapporteur recalls in her explanatory memorandum that young people remain the responsibility of the Member States, and that consequently no act taken by the EU can have legislative scope, she seems to forget this in the content of herproposal!Indeed, it wants, for example, the development of policies in favor of young people within the European Union.In addition, this text calls for better integration of refugees and migrants through education and sport, and encourages the promotion of the "European" dimension in education.We oppose such ideas.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report on the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy for the period 2013/2015 presents the results achieved and presents proposals and priorities for the next cycle, recommending to national, regional, local and EU authorities, to ensure that different programs at European level within the scope of youth policies are properly disseminated, implemented and coordinated, in order to respond to new needs in the face of future social and educational challenges. Nevertheless, it also emphasizes the need for special attention to be given to the participation of young people with special educational needs, vulnerable or marginalized groups, migrants and refugees, whether in active participation in the creation and implementation of these projects, or in the creation of political models and strategies for Youth, whether at EU and / or national and local level. Young people are the main interlocutors in the definition of projects directly related to their specificity and local needs. In this sense, this Strategy will only be effective if it has a bottom-up approach that meets the needs and expectations of everyone, involving the local community, the education system, sports and cultural associations and even companies. I voted in favor!

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: written.- My vote in favor of this initiative because the human and social capital that young people represent is one of Europe's main assets and, therefore, a guarantee for the future.I consider it essential to facilitate the transition from school to the labor market and, at the same time, promote active citizenship, social inclusion and youth solidarity.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favor of the resolution on the evaluation of the EU youth strategy because youth policy should be the responsibility of the Member States and the EU's role is limited to coordination, guidance and support. The goals of the strategy are to facilitate the transition from school to the world of work and then to promote active participation in the public. Finally, the integration of young people into the labor market and the development of their human capital will undoubtedly be supported by other bodies, such as the ESF, the Europe Investment Plan and the Youth Employment Initiative.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which deals with youth employment and social issues.High levels of youth unemployment in the EU remain a concern, and there is a need to strengthen EU social action and the implementation of European youth strategies and to ensure an effective response to youth employment and social challenges.I also believe that the EU's youth strategy needs to pay more attention to entrepreneurship, as it is one of the key drivers of economic growth.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: written.- This report should deal with youth unemployment.The fight against youth unemployment, primarily in the national and more broadly in the European context, needs to be devoted to greater attention.However, I do not accept that this important issue is being misused to expand the rights of asylum seekers in an uncontrolled manner.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - In 120 paragraphs of European Newspeak, this report details the EU's strategy and objectives for young people. It contains good elements: promoting access to the labor market, to Erasmus, by keeping silent that it is now a loan system, to quality education, "to invest more and not to make budget cuts. ". Better still: the report supports the creation of a guaranteed minimum income between the end of studies and the first job, or the RSA (accessible only from 25 years old). And more generally, he defends long-term funds for young people (youth guarantee). But behind these fine words, we retain above all the objective of transforming all young people into “entrepreneurs” (22 occurrences in the text). The text even proposes to develop "entrepreneurial learning" from the first grade! Grotesque! The logic remains to adapt the university to the needs of the private sector and to promote "mobility". Or forced exile for millions of young people forced to look for work elsewhere in the face of the austerity crisis. I am voting against this unnecessary text.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, as it highlights the need for youth to take a more active role in policy-making. The current generation have been hard hit by the global economic downturn, and as they are more educated, more mobile and more aware of the world around them than their parents’ generation, we should do our utmost to involve them in the decisions that will affect their lives.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. - Europe is proud of its youth. However, in a context of increasingly pronounced socio-economic divide, it is necessary to find lasting remedies in order to fight against youth unemployment and strengthen their social inclusion. This presupposes the establishment of more systematic cooperation for a whole series of policies aimed at our young people at the level of the European Union and the Member States, whether in the field of employment, education, training, the fight against discrimination, social policy, citizenship as well as that of culture, sport and health. I am of the opinion that the next cycle of the youth strategy must include in its objectives, otherwise lost generations, young refugees and asylum seekers. This inclusive approach will further promote their integration and strengthen the character of living together between young people from different countries and cultures in the host countries. It is essential to support this rich youth with fantastic potential for society and the economy.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing. - With their human and social value, young people are a guarantee of Europe's future and one of its most important resources. This potential is linked to their knowledge, creativity and skills. European youth face many challenges: 13.7 million young people in Europe are not employed or in education. Almost 27 million young people are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Long-term casual jobs pose a risk of a low quality of life for this generation. The problem of this group is unemployment on the one hand, and underemployment on the other; some are too highly qualified for the opportunities offered by the labor market. The gap between the two groups of young people is great: some with a favorable outlook for the future, others who have little hope of leading a full life and who are at risk of marginalization. These differences adversely affect the social fabric and sustainable long-term economic growth. Youth policy falls within the competence of the Member States, with the EU's role being coordinating, guiding and supporting it. Progress has been made in a number of areas, but further solutions are needed to reduce youth unemployment, improve the quality of life and prospects for the future. To achieve these goals, systematic cooperation is needed at Union and Member State level, including on many policy issues. I support the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which calls for young people and youth organisations to be systematically involved in youth policy-making. There is a need to channel investments into inclusive education with regards to ensuring equal access and opportunities for all young people, including those having different socio-economic backgrounds as well as vulnerable and disadvantaged groups such as refugees, migrants and asylum-seekers. We should fight for a better recognition of the learning outcomes of skills acquired through non-formal and informal learning not only because they equip young people with the right set of competences and knowledge, but also because they contribute to the personal development and growth of learners in order to make them proactive, responsible and open-minded citizens. That is why I have voted in favour.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - The report of the Committee on Culture and Education takes stock of the results of the last three-year cycle of the EU Youth Strategy. The EU Youth Strategy 2010-2018 identifies 8 areas for action: education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and well-being, participation, volunteering, social inclusion, youth and the world, creativity and culture. The two general priorities of the strategy are to facilitate the transition from school to the world of work and to promote young people's active citizenship, social inclusion and solidarity. The report finds that there is a large gap between the two groups of young people: those who are purposeful, continue to study, trust that they will find a good job and participate in social, civic and cultural life, and those who have little hope of fulfillment. and who are at risk of marginalization. This division threatens social cohesion and long-term, sustainable economic growth. And because of the aging population, Europe urgently needs to activate young people, encourage responsible family formation and childbearing. I supported the adoption of the resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing.- The European Union has presented a European youth strategy aimed at creating more opportunities for young people within the European framework.I believe that new strategies for young people should involve youth organizations at national and European level as they are the most knowledgeable entities on the real needs of young people.I also believe that the European Union should focus its strategy on the vectors of mobility, employment and education, given that these are the 3 main areas that young people are looking for at European level and where the EU can make a difference at a strategic level.In this regard, I approve this report hoping that future strategies will be centered on fundamental vectors to support young people.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The economic crisis has hit young people particularly hard. The disparity between certain categories of young people has also grown, while some of them have increasingly lost their place in social and civil life. This situation is further aggravated by the fact that, in some cases, there is a risk of social passivity, exclusion and isolation and even violent radicalisation. I voted in favour of the report which provides a relevant assessment of the actions undertaken by the EU in the field of youth policy and gives positive recommendations on the priorities for the next few years, focusing on education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and welfare, participation, volunteering, social inclusion, youth and the world, creativity and culture.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text relating to the follow-up to the 2013-2015 Union strategy for youth.This text calls in particular for better integration of young people with disabilities into the professional world.More broadly, it sets out a series of principles and elements to be explored in order to better consider the young people who constitute the future of Europe (better language learning, fight against dropping out of school, teaching of ICT in order to better understandactual world, ...).

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. - We welcome the report on the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015, as it offers a comprehensive picture of the challenges that young Europeans are facing, such as unemployment, poverty and social exclusion. The approximately 90 million young Europeans and their potential in terms of knowledge, creativity and skills represent the future of the Union and cannot be neglected. In this regard, the report highlights important recommendations, including investment in quality education and in jobs with a good quality and security level, but above all calls for the systematic involvement of young people and youth organizations in the creation of policies that concern them. Investment in high-quality education systems must aim for maximum inclusion to ensure equal access and opportunities for all young people, including those from different socio-economic backgrounds and those most vulnerable and disadvantaged groups such as refugees, migrants and asylum seekers. We believe that the theme of youth is fundamental, as the campaign for a European Youth Plan launched by the European Socialist Party also demonstrates.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. - I am always happy to discuss and vote on reports aimed at unlocking the potential of young people. I believe it is a really good decision to invest in young people, to support their creativity, their abilities and skills. We need to see young people as the future of Europe. The European Union's youth strategy has ambitiously identified 8 key areas for action, such as education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health, culture, and so on. I attach particular importance to the active citizenship of young people. This can happen at any level, for example, my son was recently elected president of the school student council. Thanks to civic engagement, young people feel they belong somewhere, which helps to avoid radicalization. Sport is based on the same idea, where young people treat each other as teammates, regardless of their skin color, nationality or social background.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Youth Strategy sets out a cooperation framework to achieve objectives such as specific youth initiatives, encouraging non-formal learning, participation, voluntary activities, youth work, mobility and information. I have voted for this report regarding the EU Youth Strategy between 2013-2015, which stresses the two main general priorities of facilitating the transition from school to the working world and fostering active citizenship, social inclusion and solidarity among young people, which still need to be addressed.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this report because I believe that it objectively assesses the EU's Youth Strategy for 2013-2015 and rightly emphasizes the importance of its continuation and development in the period ahead.I consider it a priority to continue the EU Youth Strategy and I am convinced that investments in support of young people, whether educational, financial or to encourage personal development, are what will ensure the development of our societies and economies in the future.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I spoke out against the European Youth Strategy because for a long time no jobs could be guaranteed for local young people and no successful integration of migrants took place either.Furthermore, only non-Europeans are supported here;I cannot support this because our young people have to come first.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported.Investing in young people, involving them in decision-making processes and having a proper youth policy is important to ensure their future.The report assesses the past period and identifies a number of areas where progress is needed.There are problems in finding common solutions, for example in early school leaving and also in integrating refugees into the education system.The adoption of a number of financial instruments has also been delayed.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. Young people, as human and social capital, are one of the most important resources and guarantors of Europe 's future. The financial crisis has hit young people hard. Inequalities between certain categories of young people have increased, and more and more young people are losing their place in social and public life. The situation is further exacerbated by the fact that, for some, there is a risk of social inactivity, exclusion and isolation, and even violent radicalization. The exhibition aims to promote the employment of young people, their integration into the labor market, their social acceptance and their active participation in the public. It could be argued that progress has been made in many areas, but we need to find further solutions to reduce youth unemployment, improve their quality of life, achieve equal opportunities, enhance young people's self-awareness of the commons, increase social participation and prevent violent radicalization. For all these reasons, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: in writing. - One in two young people under the age of 25 is unemployed in Greece according to official data only, while those who work are faced with flexible forms of employment, with salaries of 200-300 euros. The report seeks to perpetuate this harsh reality by ensuring the profitability of business groups, where its main precondition is the crushing of salaries and rights of old and new employees. The report proposes even greater use of training programs, such as the "Youth Guarantee" for a maximum of six months jobs, with wage crumbs, without pension insurance, but also the promotion of "business learning at all levels and in all forms education ". It is a generalization of apprenticeships and the exploitation of students by bribery or cheap labor to the employer, which seeks to camouflage the outbreak of unemployment. Crocodile tears for "early school leaving" can not hide the class character of the school that "throws" the working class children who face survival problems, with which their families are struggling. Now workers and their children must turn their backs on the EU and governments, fighting for an economy and power whose focus will not be on profit, but on meeting their needs.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding initiative, which bears reference to an increase in funding for current programmes and calls for interference in Member States’ education systems and the harmonisation of EU youth policies, at local and Member State level. These are competencies of the individual Member States and are not for the EU to dictate, therefore we cannot support this initiative.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing.- Bearing in mind the importance of the active participation of young people in the planning, design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of all youth policies, considering the need to strengthen the integration of youth policy through greaterinvolvement in democratic and civic life, I agree with the observations contained in the document and would vote positively.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - Young people are the wealth of every society, especially our European one, which in recent years and decades has been facing increasing demographic problems. Despite the undivided view of the importance of our young people, they have been facing a number of difficulties in much of Europe for years, the most pronounced of which are finding employment. There is a noticeable gap between young people from different parts of Europe, but also between certain groups of young people from the same area. All of them today face the risk of social passivity, isolation and eventual radicalization aided by the economic crisis and unstable political developments. To help them tackle these challenges, we need to agree not only on their importance, but also on everything we are willing to do for their well-being. As youth policy is the responsibility of the Member States, the European Union has a great responsibility to advise and support and ultimately coordinate these policies. The key objectives of the Youth Strategy are to facilitate the transition from the education system to the labor market and to encourage active citizenship, social inclusion and solidarity among young people. Although I am not satisfied with the situation of a large number of young people across Europe today, I will support this resolution as I believe that the strategy has nevertheless contributed to improving the position of young people in the Union.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because I believe that EU policies must be able to provide effective responses to the serious economic, employment and social problems affecting young people. Youth unemployment has reached almost double that of general unemployment and the high rate of young people who are neither employed nor enrolled in education or training remains a problem. The third and final three-year cycle of the EU Youth Strategy should have among its priorities the social inclusion of young people from disadvantaged backgrounds, ethnic minorities, refugees, migrants and asylum seekers, while ensuring greater participation in life democratic and civic. Equally important is continuing efforts to increase the labor market participation rate of young women, school leavers and young people with disabilities. I share the importance recognized by the report to structured dialogue, as the most effective tool for improving European programs, both in the development phase and in the implementation and evaluation phase, for the involvement of youth organizations and cooperation with local and regional authorities, families , schools and religious communities.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The Report makes the effectiveness of the Youth Strategy dependent on alignment with the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, seeking a greater framework for youth policies which translates into increasing harmonization. Highlighting youth unemployment and the brain drain, it points to the miraculous solution of increasing mobility, neglecting, on the one hand, the consequences of austerity policies on increasing youth unemployment, and on the other, the fact that mobility policies serve , in practice, job insecurity and the creation of cheap labor. It is understood, therefore, the subordination of education, namely higher education, to relations with the business world and its needs, pointing out entrepreneurship and business culture as a solution to the problems that youth face. We follow some positive points, such as multilingualism, equal opportunities, equality between men and women, or the fight against any type of discrimination. But we have distanced ourselves from the ideological matrix of the report, and we argue that any strategy for youth cannot be based on the needs of companies and the demands of the market economy. Nor do we follow the vision of the causes and solutions to combat youth unemployment and social exclusion, out of step with the reality in which young people live. We voted against.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the Parliamentary recommendations for the third and final three-year cycle of the EU Youth Strategy (2016 - 2018). I am afraid, European young people still keep facing many challenges like youth unemployment, poverty and social exclusion. We should concentrate namely on young people with poor qualifications, NEETs and those with special needs, disadvantaged and lower socio-economic backgrounds such as ethnic minorities, refugees, migrants and asylum seekers. We have to invest more in accessible quality education, promoting quality traineeships and improvement of skills and competences. We cannot succeed without involving all stakeholders, especially youth organisations, recognising voluntary activities and finally promoting and investing in mobility schemes and especially in Erasmus + programme. I am proud the S&D group fought hard to ensure the inclusion of young girls and young people identifying themselves as LGBTI into the report. We must fight for a better recognition of the learning outcomes of skills acquired through non-formal and informal learning not only because they equip young people with the right set of competences and knowledge, but also because they contribute to the personal development and growth of  proactive, responsible and open-minded citizens.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. - The human and social capital represented by young people is one of the major European resources for the future. The European Union and the Member States must do everything possible to develop the potential of the combined knowledge, creativity, skills and competences of the 90 million young Europeans. This motion for a resolution of the European Parliament aims to reduce the gap between the various groups of young people by providing adequate solutions against the risk of social passivity, marginalization or even radicalization. The framework for European cooperation in the youth field supports measures taken by the different Member States and the EU mainly through actions such as data collection, mutual learning, exchange of experiences and dialogue with young people. I fully agree on the need to stimulate young people to assume their responsibilities in the civil and democratic life of their communities and to commit themselves to building a united Europe. For all these reasons, I voted in favor of approving this report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution.Youth policy is a competence of the Member States.Thus, the European Union cannot legislate on this subject but acts as a coordinator of initiatives and projects at European level.It is a matter of strongly recalling how essential it is to put in place a genuine European framework for cooperation for young people, as this will be the necessary condition for the emergence of sustainable European citizenship and increased solidarity between populations ofEuropean states.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. - There is no doubt that the human and social capital of young people, currently 90 million in European territory, constitutes one of Europe's main resources and one of the main guarantees of its future. The inability to adopt any legislative measures in this field at EU level has led to the granting of the open method of cooperation. This method translates into the definition of principles and objectives by the competent MS ministers, within the framework of the EU Council, and then it is up to the Member States to decide how and what measures they intend to accept and incorporate in their youth strategies. Although there is a noticeable improvement in several indicators, such as the numbers of early school leavers, the number of graduates and the youth unemployment figures, some indicators such as the existence of 13.7 million NEET young people (do not work, study or study) follow any formation) I worry a lot. Because I believe it is necessary to find additional solutions to reduce youth unemployment, improve their quality of life and their prospects for the future, guarantee equal opportunities, strengthen civic self-awareness and increase their social participation, as well as prevent violent radicalization , I support this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding initiative, which bears reference to an increase in funding for current programmes and calls for interference in Member States’ education systems and the harmonisation of EU youth policies, at local and Member State level. These are competencies of the individual Member States and are not for the EU to dictate, therefore we cannot support this initiative.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor, as I understand that the human and social capital of young people represents one of Europe's main resources and one of the main guarantees of its future. Therefore, the European Union and its Member States cannot afford to waste the potential inherent in the knowledge, creativity and skills of Europe's 90 million young people. The economic crisis has particularly affected young people and the disparities between certain categories of young people have also increased, in particular, some of them have lost their place in social and civic life. This situation was exacerbated by the fact that, in the case of some of these categories, there are risks of social passivity, exclusion and isolation, and even violent radicalization. The EU must seek to encourage, through the framework for cooperation in the youth field, groups of young people who are as large and as diverse as possible to play an active role in local and global communities, as well as in civic and democratic life. Through the framework for cooperation, we must also help young people find jobs and participate in life in society.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the evaluation of the European Union Youth Strategy 2013-2015. At the end of this study, it appears that countries with poor statistical indicators should adopt more good practices in terms of youth policy, and implement on a larger scale the means having a positive effect, formulated in the framework. of the open method of coordination. To reduce youth unemployment and improve their quality of life, more systematic cooperation is needed at Union and Member State level in several policy areas such as employment, education and training, social policy, youth policy as well as culture, sport and health. By freeing up sufficient financial resources for the implementation of youth programs, the European Union's interest is indeed to create a link between the different actors, to bring them together, to exchange views, to show paths and build bridges between these people and also between the different policies.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- I unequivocally support the draft EU Youth Strategy.Investing in the future - in young people - is perhaps the most rewarding, and I consider it the European Union's duty to do its utmost to ensure that Europe's young people have the best possible conditions to grow and develop.At the same time, I would just like to make a small remark about the fact that I lacked a clearer focus on the new Member States in the strategy.Many of them still have very specific problems in the field of youth policy that targeted EU assistance could address.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - The human and social capital of young people represents two of Europe's main resources and one of the main guarantees of its future. Therefore, the European Union and its Member States cannot afford to waste the immense potential inherent in the knowledge, creativity and skills of the 90 million young Europeans. The economic crisis particularly affected young people, having exacerbated social inequalities. The Youth Strategy for the period 2010-2018, defines eight areas of action with two defined general priorities: facilitating the transition from the education system to the world of work and promoting active citizenship, social inclusion and solidarity among young people. This last aspect was of particular importance due to the growing phenomena of radicalization of young people and the need to prevent these unfortunate occurrences. For the 2016-2018 period, efforts will be made to encourage active participation in local and global communities, as well as participation in civic, political and democratic life. In addition, aid for job search and youth participation in life in society should also be encouraged. For these reasons, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which takes stock of the implementation of the 2013-2015 youth strategy, and which establishes recommendations for the 2016-2018 cycle.It is crucial to ensure that the different programs which deal with Union-wide youth policies are properly implemented in order to meet the new needs linked to the socio-educational challenges to come.In this sense, the Union's youth strategy for the next cycle 2016-2018 must focus on the fight against dropping out, promoting entrepreneurship among young people, investing in education, internships, apprenticeships and vocational training as well as facilitating the transition to the labor market.The fight against unemployment must be the priority of the Union’s action with regard to young people.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because I believe that this review report on the 2013-2015 Youth strategy contains complex elements of analysis and lines of improvement that I believe are consistent with the positions of our training.However, there are elements in the report with which I do not agree, such as the creation of an 'Erasmus for apprentices' or an exacerbated rhetoric of entrepreneurship, to the detriment of other active employment policies.However, I consider that the positive aspects are more than the negative ones, so my vote is in favor.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: written.- I voted for the report on the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015.Young people in particular have been hit hard by the economic crisis and have problems finding qualified jobs.The youth strategy addresses two main themes: on the one hand, support in the transition from school to the world of work and, on the other hand, the promotion of active citizenship, social integration and solidarity among young people.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- Youth policy is the competence of the Member States.While the Union has a coordinating, supporting and advising role, it cannot take any legislative action.For this reason, despite the good intentions contained in this report on the Strategy of the Union for Youth 2013-2015, I voted against it, since it maintains a neoliberal approach and considers that the way to combat youth unemployment passesfor strengthening cooperation between companies and universities.Likewise, it does not recognize the devastating impact of austerity policies or cuts in education and culture and ignores them as causing the increase in youth unemployment and the social exclusion of young people, which is why I voted against this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The economic crisis has hit young people particularly hard. The disparity between certain categories of young people has also grown, while some of them have increasingly lost their place in social and civil life. This situation is further aggravated by the fact that, in some cases, there is a risk of social passivity, exclusion and isolation and even violent radicalisation. I voted in favour of the report which provides a relevant assessment of the actions undertaken by the EU in the field of youth policy and gives positive recommendations on the priorities for the next few years, focusing on education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and welfare, participation, volunteering, social inclusion, youth and the world, creativity and culture.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - I consider human and social capital, represented by young people, to be one of Europe's most important resources and I believe that it is a great guarantee for the future as well. That is also why we should not play with this potential and we should do everything we can to ensure that 90 million young people in Europe find employment in life. I supported the resolution because, thanks to the EU's youth strategy for 2013-2015, unemployment has been reduced in some Member States, quality of life has been improved, young people's civic awareness has been strengthened and social inclusion has been strengthened. I particularly welcome the fact that, during the evaluation period, the Member States and the Commission actively cooperated in a number of areas to encourage young people to enter and integrate into the labor market. I am concerned that youth unemployment remains almost twice as high as the overall unemployment rate. This is evidenced by statistics showing that there are a total of 13.7 million young people in Europe who are not in employment, 8.7 million young people in Europe are unable to find employment and almost 27 million young people are at risk of poverty or social exclusion. I see all this as a serious shortcoming, so I expect that in the period 2016-2018 there will be a greater correction.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. - I would like to highlight an aspect of the situation of young people in the European Union that is having an extremely detrimental effect on the societies of the eastern part of Europe: the emigration of young people from the countries of Central and Eastern Europe. According to a relevant study by the International Monetary Fund, 20 million young people have left these states since 1990 and settled in Western Europe, losing about 16 per cent of the population of Romania and Bulgaria. The problem is exacerbated by the fact that three-quarters of emigrants from the region were of working age, with 80 per cent of those leaving Romania in this category. While these young people are useful members of Western European societies through their work, they are sorely lacking in their original homeland in both economic and demographic terms. Emigration continues today, and in many cases temporary employment abroad will be a permanent expulsion. I am convinced that the trends can only be changed by the faster economic catching-up of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, and the solution to this is to maintain and even strengthen the EU's cohesion policy.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: written. - The purpose of this report is to evaluate the “Youth Policy” strategy for 2013-2015. “Youth policy” in itself is not an EU competence. The EU’s role is at most to coordinate these. The problematic aspects for me are the following (list is not exhaustive): For me and my party, the principle of subsidiarity is the central principle according to which tasks are to be distributed between the levels of public authorities. Several digits disregard this principle, implicitly or explicitly. These are e.g. 2, 60, 111. In addition, the report is very statist and provides for EU / public authorities to interfere in details of private life that I do not want to support. Examples are the numbers 41, 43, 45, 60, 18, 111. In addition, the wrongly constructed currency area is neither named nor combated as the central reason for the very high youth unemployment in southern Europe. The EU is deliberately excluding the part for which it is actually responsible. I therefore reject this report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
