text: in writing.- The European Union initiative has highlighted not only the need to improve access to quality education and training for employment, but also the need to involve young people in active civic life, life in modern society, for example by conducting dialogue with young people through modern technology.The Commission should improve the use of funding by Member States through many European funds, while simplifying the administrative procedures for awarding funding for various youth projects.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: written.- I did not agree to the resolution of the EU Parliament on the “Evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013–2015”.The topic does not belong at EU level, which is a clear violation of the subsidiarity principle.There is no conceivable reason for Brussels to uniformly plan measures for young people.Even at the national level, such measures are hardly conceivable and rarely make sense at all.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the evaluation report on the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015.In Europe, we need a dialogue between active young citizens and decision-makers at the highest level of decision-making.We need to encourage young people to be active, to get involved in youth organizations and thus to shape their future.I support the resolution, which points out that the open method of coordination is not enough to shape youth policies, but that we need other complementary measures, which we will achieve through closer cooperation and exchange of best practice on youth issues at all levels of the European Union.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report contains both positive and negative reports. For example, while emphasizing that unemployment is one of the biggest problems of young people, no reference is made to harsh austerity policies, ie the causes that led to rising unemployment and social exclusion of young people. The same is true of references to the need to fight poverty. Equally problematic is the proposal to strengthen the business relationship with universities as the answer to unemployment. For these reasons we abstained.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing.- The youth strategy should focus primarily on their moral education and then on the development of their skills and vocational training.Leading them to a misunderstood multiculturalism with a simultaneous loss of their national identity is a crime.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. - The report covers the implementation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015. evaluate the results for its cycle. The human and social capital represented by young people is one of Europe's greatest resources, the key to its future. The European Union and the Member States must therefore not overlook the potential of the creativity, diversity, abilities and skills of 90 million young people in Europe. Many young people find it difficult to find lasting and quality jobs, which is a serious obstacle to independence. Youth unemployment has fallen in most Member States recently, but this figure remains a matter of serious concern. In 2015, youth unemployment in Europe fell to 19.7%. According to the latest data, this rate fell to 18.9% in 2016. A stable and high-quality workplace and a safe environment are very important for creating independence and starting a responsible family. The basis of all this can be provided by a good education and training system. Due to the aging of the population, Europe urgently needs to activate young people, encourage them to start a family and have children. The report underlines the importance of the role of the family, school, religious communities and sport in the healthy development and socialization of young people, while highlighting the involvement of local and regional communities in youth policy.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015. The text makes a number of important calls on Member States to make a positive difference in terms of youth unemployment, poverty and other challenges. It is particularly welcome that the rapporteur mentions the specific problems of refugee and migrant youth, as well as young girls and women. At the same time, I consider it important to note that the Hungarian ruling party, of which the rapporteur is a member, consistently disregards the values ​​set out in the report: its education and employment policy makes future generations impossible and That is why I urge the rapporteur to begin to translate the positive recommendations summarized in his report into his party's domestic policy with great energy.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. - The economic crisis in Europe has left millions of EU citizens with financial problems, no prospects or no jobs and livelihoods. Young Europeans were one of the groups that were most severely affected by its effects. In November 2015, the average youth unemployment rate (15-29 age group) in Europe was 20% and in some Member States it was above 40%. Moreover, there are 13.7 million young people in Europe who are not in employment, education or training. Young people are constantly faced with the inability to find full-time or long-term employment and having inadequate qualifications that do not match the needs of the labor market. Despite much progress in the field of youth employment and integration into the labor market, further efforts are needed to reduce unemployment, improve young people's quality of life and prospects, provide them with equal opportunities, increase their civic awareness and prevent radicalization. There is therefore a need for more systematic cooperation at EU and Member State level in many policy areas such as employment, vocational education and training, social policy, youth policy, culture, sport and health. It is also important to ensure that adequate funding is made available for the implementation of youth programs.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: signed up.- The importance of the EU Youth Strategy is major from the perspective of considering human and social capital as a foundation for the development of human society in general, given that the resource of competence, creativity and entrepreneurship is given by young European citizens.Starting from identifying the causes of youth unemployment and investing in education (formal, non-formal and informal), vocational training, health and employment, facilitating the transition to the labor market through coordinated local, regional, national, community (European) programs, using the potential offeredof new technologies and involving all national and European actors in all markets in meeting the two objectives of the Youth Strategy in 2016-2018, we offer the European Union a chance for sustainable development, through proactive and responsible young Europeans.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report gives an overview of the European youth situation, the challenges that youth face in Europe, such as unemployment, social inclusion and poverty, and some recommendations in order to improve the current state of affairs. Moreover, the report identified targeted groups who are more likely to be unemployed and marginalised: young people with poor qualifications, NEETs and those with special needs, disadvantaged and lower socioeconomic backgrounds such as ethnic minorities, refugees, migrants and asylum seekers. The recommendations include investing in accessible quality education, improving cross-sectorial cooperation at all levels and notably between the different EU strategies that affect young people, drafting a new EU youth cooperation framework after 2018, investing in quality and secure jobs and in mobility schemes, especially in Erasmus. I fully support this report, as I believe that the most important solution to the challenges that youth face in the European Union is to invest in education and to involve youth in policymaking that will affect their future.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the evaluation of the European Union Youth Strategy 2013-2015, thus following the opinion of the experts from my political group.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Youth policies, although not the exclusive competence of the EU, are the backbone of the future generation. It is vital that the proper implementation of youth policies be made and that youth are included in the decision-making process at all levels so that decisions are targeted for the next generations. The EU Youth Strategy aims at doing just that. I decided however to abstain from voting on the report on the assessment of the EU Youth Strategy because, although I support the report’s initiative, calling for improvements in efforts to integrate EU youth, I found some of the wording in the report dubious, so I could not vote in favour.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. - The report provides an overview of the challenges young Europeans are facing today such as youth unemployment, poverty and social exclusion. In addition, it identifies targeted groups who are more likely to be unemployed and marginalized. I fully share the need expressed in this report to channel investment into inclusive education to ensure equal access and opportunities for all young people, including those from different socio-economic backgrounds, as well as vulnerable and disadvantaged groups, such as refugees. , migrants and asylum seekers. The report also stresses the need to implement some recommendations at EU level as soon as possible, such as investing in accessible quality education, promoting quality internships, improving skills and competences, investing in quality and of secure jobs, in building an EU youth strategy involving all stakeholders and in particular youth organizations. The recognition of voluntary activities is essential and, finally, promoting and investing in mobility programs, in particular in the Erasmus + program.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: in writing. - The report covers the implementation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015. evaluate the results for its cycle. The human and social capital represented by young people is one of Europe's greatest resources, the key to its future. The European Union and the Member States must therefore not overlook the potential of the creativity, diversity, abilities and skills of 90 million young people in Europe. Many young people find it difficult to find lasting and quality jobs, which is a serious obstacle to independence. Youth unemployment has fallen in most Member States recently, but this figure remains a matter of serious concern. In 2015, youth unemployment in Europe fell to 19.7%. According to the latest data, this rate fell to 18.9% in 2016. A stable and high-quality workplace and a safe environment are very important for creating independence and starting a responsible family. The basis of all this can be provided by a good education and training system. Due to the aging of the population, Europe urgently needs to activate young people, encourage them to start a family and have children. The report underlines the importance of the role of the family, school, religious communities and sport in the healthy development and socialization of young people, while highlighting the involvement of local and regional communities in youth policy.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing.- Mr President, I voted in favor of the report because supporting young people and strengthening the European Union's youth strategy must be our priority in the future.The evaluation of current activities in 2013-2015 can serve as a model for the forthcoming changes in the current strategy of the European institutions.It is true that youth policy is a matter for the Member States, but it has been and should remain the responsibility of the European Union to coordinate closely in this sector and to increase assistance from European funds.What we need to focus on includes greater involvement in the fight against youth unemployment, as the number of unemployed young people is, unfortunately, as high as 14 million.And that should change.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written.- This report should be a review of the results obtained by the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015, however, unfortunately, the report primarily focused on information on investments made, and on actions taken.As youth policy is the sole responsibility of individual Member States of the Union, I cannot agree with the call for a breach of the principle of subsidiarity contained in the report, which emphasizes that the intergovernmental level of coordination of this policy is insufficient.I firmly believe that the role of the Union in this segment is only in coordination, guidance and support, and that the Member States are the ones who know best, and accordingly can only devise appropriate strategies to address youth issues that are specific and significantly different in each country.members individually.So I voted against.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015. Human and social capital, represented by young people, is one of Europe's most important resources and guarantees for its future. That is why the European Union and its Member States must not afford to waste the knowledge, creativity and skills potential of 90 million young people in Europe. Youth policy is the responsibility of the Member States, and the role of the European Union is coordination, guidance and support. In total, there are 13.7 million young people in Europe who are not in employment, education or training. However, almost 27 million young people are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. The poverty rate is higher among young people than among the general population. And because they work involuntarily for part-time work and, in many cases, have their fixed-term contracts extended, this generation is threatened by a poor quality of life in the long run. Member States and the Commission also worked together between 2013 and 2015 to promote youth employment, labor market integration, social inclusion and active citizenship. According to the results, progress has been made in many areas, but other solutions need to be found to reduce youth unemployment, improve their quality of life and prospects for the future, ensure equal opportunities, strengthen citizens' civic awareness and increase their social skills. participation and prevention of violent radicalization.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because I believe that this review report on the 2013-2015 Youth strategy contains complex elements of analysis and lines of improvement that I believe are consistent with the positions of our training.However, there are elements in the report with which I do not agree, such as the creation of an 'Erasmus for apprentices' or an exacerbated rhetoric of entrepreneurship, to the detriment of other active employment policies.However, I consider that the positive aspects are more than the negative ones, so my vote is in favor.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: written. - The purpose of this report is to evaluate the “Youth Policy” strategy for 2013-2015. “Youth policy” in itself is not an EU competence. The EU’s role is at most to coordinate these. The problematic aspects for me are the following (list is not exhaustive): For me and my party, the principle of subsidiarity is the central principle according to which tasks are to be distributed between the levels of public authorities. Several digits disregard this principle, implicitly or explicitly. These are e.g. 2, 60, 111. In addition, the report is very statist and provides for EU / public authorities to intervene in details of private life that I do not want to support. Examples are the numbers 41, 43, 45, 60, 18, 111. In addition, the wrongly constructed currency area is neither named nor combated as the central reason for the very high youth unemployment in southern Europe. The EU is deliberately excluding the part for which it is actually responsible. I therefore reject this report.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Young people are not only the future of Europe but are already the present, and therefore it is good to be involved in the planning, development, implementation and monitoring of youth policies. It is important to implement measures to reduce school drop-out rates and reach the targets of 10% by 2020. The contexts and the situations of young people change in each Member State, and it is worrying when they are not taking measures to reduce, for example, youth unemployment, which is very high in some countries. I hope this proposal will serve to some Member States to update their measures and policies in order to comply with the objectives of the Europe Strategy 2020.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. - Youth policy is the domain of the Member States. It results clearly from Art. 6 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which states that the Union has competence in this area only to support, coordinate and supplement the actions of the Member States. This division of competences obliges the Union to limit itself only to activities that are justified, necessary and balanced. This prism should be used to look at the EU youth strategy for 2013-2015. I have numerous reservations about it. The report assessed the strategy but did not show the level of results achieved. The rapporteur calls for the youth employment initiative to be continued, although it is not producing the expected results in practice. The report also notes that the intergovernmental cooperation in the youth field has so far been insufficient. Regarding the subsidiarity principle, the wording is unclear as to its implications. My doubts are also raised by the numerous references in the text of the report to migrants and their integration as well as LGBT communities. For these reasons, I voted against the resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because I believe that this review report on the 2013-2015 Youth strategy contains complex elements of analysis and lines of improvement that I believe are consistent with the positions of our training.However, there are elements in the report with which I do not agree, such as the creation of an 'Erasmus for apprentices' or an exacerbated rhetoric of entrepreneurship, to the detriment of other active employment policies.However, I consider that the positive aspects are more than the negative ones, so my vote is in favor.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive to this report, which establishes two general priorities: facilitating the transition from school to ‘work’ and fostering active citizenship, social inclusion and solidarity among young people.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the assessment of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015. The report stresses that effective implementation of the EU Youth Strategy should be closely linked to achieving the Europe 2020 headline targets, particularly those of having 75% of the population aged 20 to 64 in employment and lifting as many young people as possible out of poverty and social exclusion. It equally underlines that inclusion of youth with disability in employment is necessary so they can lead an independent life and be fully integrated in society as active participants and real contributors. I voted in favour because I believe that young people should be helped and empowered to address the extremely serious problems they currently face and to tackle the challenges they will face in the future through more relevant, effective and better coordinated youth policies and targeted use of economic, employment and social policies resources at local, regional, national and EU level.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- Youth policy is the competence of the Member States.While the Union has a coordinating, supporting and advising role, it cannot take any legislative action.For this reason, despite the good intentions contained in this report on the Strategy of the Union for Youth 2013-2015, I voted against it, since it maintains a neoliberal approach and considers that the way to combat youth unemployment passesfor strengthening cooperation between companies and universities.Likewise, it does not recognize the devastating impact of austerity policies or cuts in education and culture and ignores them as causing the increase in youth unemployment and the social exclusion of young people, which is why I voted against this report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The economic crisis has hit young people particularly hard. The disparity between certain categories of young people has also grown, while some of them have increasingly lost their place in social and civil life. This situation is further aggravated by the fact that, in some cases, there is a risk of social passivity, exclusion and isolation and even violent radicalisation. I voted in favour of the report which provides a relevant assessment of the actions undertaken by the EU in the field of youth policy and gives positive recommendations on the priorities for the next few years, focusing on education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and welfare, participation, volunteering, social inclusion, youth and the world, creativity and culture.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: written. - Young people are one of Europe's greatest "raw materials" and a guarantee for the future. That is why the European Union and the Member States must not let the potential of knowledge, creativity, talents and skills that lie in the 90 million European young people unused. The economic crisis has hit young people especially hard. The gap between certain groups of young people has deepened further, and some of them are increasingly fringing the margins of society and civilian life. This situation is exacerbated by the fact that some of them run the risk of no longer actively participating in society, of being excluded, isolated or even violently radicalized. The EU Youth Strategy, which covers the period 2010-2018, identifies the following eight action areas: education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and well-being, participation, volunteering, social inclusion, youth and the world, creativity and culture. I wholeheartedly support this strategy.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- No youth strategy can focus on the needs of businesses and the demands of the market economy.However, that is where the report points.Instead of looking at the causes of youth unemployment, which are also the causes of poverty, social exclusion and a certain type of delinquency, the report again parrots the same heated solutions that are nothing more than means to increase exploitation for benefits.companies.Putting the education system at the service of companies, making the labor market more flexible, increasing mobility and versatility or even promoting entrepreneurship to exhaustion, this is the neoliberal cassette in all its splendor.Fortunately, the youth are attentive, resisting and mobilizing more and more in defense of their rights and will, more or less, take their destiny in their hands.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- The report contains some correct approaches to tackling youth unemployment and mainstreaming youth issues in all policy areas.However, elsewhere, an unconditional and guaranteed minimum income as well as an explicit betterment and positive special treatment of supposedly disadvantaged groups such as “LGBTI people”, refugees or asylum seekers are called for.I therefore rejected the report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The economic crisis has hit young people particularly hard. The disparity between certain categories of young people has also grown, while some of them have increasingly lost their place in social and civil life. This situation is further aggravated by the fact that, in some cases, there is a risk of social passivity, exclusion and isolation and even violent radicalisation. I voted in favour of the report which provides a relevant assessment of the actions undertaken by the EU in the field of youth policy and gives positive recommendations on the priorities for the next few years, focusing on education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and welfare, participation, volunteering, social inclusion, youth and the world, creativity and culture.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since I believe that young people should be actively involved in the planning, development, implementation, monitoring and assessment of all youth policies. It can be noticed that young people are politically engaged in many ways, but their participation in elections is decreasing. From my liberal point of view, I believe in the liberty of expression and that an increase in different opinions only be beneficial for the policy decision-making process. I believe that education and training can contribute to tackling social disengagement, marginalisation and radicalisation of young people. For example the specific nature of sports activity and its contribution to the social inclusion of disadvantaged young people, especially refugees and migrants, can help to overcome xenophobia and racism.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing. - Young people are a living force and an important social capital, which is extremely important for the future of Europe. Although youth policy is the responsibility of the Member States, the European Union helps to coordinate and support it. Youth policies, which cover the years 2010-2018, cover eight areas of action, with the whole strategy having two general priorities: 1. facilitating the transition from school to work, and 2. promoting active citizenship, social inclusion and solidarity among young people. The figures for the development of young people's employment in the labor market are not very optimistic. In February 2013, the European average was at its peak and reached the level of 23.9% of the unemployed (15-29 years). Already at the end of 2015, this rate was at the level of 20%. This is a slight improvement, but it is still an alarming number. Moreover, the situation in the EU Member States is not the same - in some, youth unemployment exceeds 40%. Although the Commission's efforts to address the catastrophic situation of young people in the labor market cannot be denied, progress has been small and unsatisfactory. We need to be able to motivate young people more, because the gap between those who are ambitious and want to participate in social life and those who are on the verge of social exclusion is wide. I therefore abstained in the vote on the resolution tabled.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: in writing. - One in two young people under 25 is unemployed in Greece according to official data only, while those who work are faced with flexible forms of employment, with salaries of 200-300 euros. The report seeks to perpetuate this harsh reality, ensuring the profitability of business groups where its main condition is the crushing of salaries and rights of old and new employees. The report proposes even greater use of training programs, such as the "Youth Guarantee" for a maximum of six months jobs, with wage crumbs, without pension insurance, but also the promotion of "business learning at all levels and in all forms education ". It is a generalization of apprenticeships and the exploitation of students by bribery or cheap labor to the employer, which seeks to camouflage the outbreak of unemployment. Crocodile tears for "early school leaving" can not hide the class character of the school that "throws" the working class children who face survival problems with which their families are struggling. Now workers and their children must turn their backs on the EU and governments, fighting for an economy and power whose focus will not be on profit, but on meeting their needs.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the recommendations proposed in the report aimed at ensuring the highest possible effectiveness of the EU youth strategy. Of course, youth policy is a competence of the Member States, but the important role of the European Union is its coordination as well as assistance and support within the so-called the open method of coordination. I find particularly alarming the still high youth unemployment rate and the high percentage of young people not in employment, education or training. Therefore, I believe that identifying the causes of youth unemployment and the measures to counter them is essential in achieving the goals of the future EU Youth Strategy (2016-2018). In this context, I underline the importance of investing in education, internships, apprenticeships and training in skills reflecting the opportunities, needs and development of the labor market, and the importance of facilitating entry into the labor market through measures ensuring better coordination of education programs, employment policy and labor market demand. As in other cases, I would also like to remind you that, in order to achieve the expected effectiveness of the strategy, it is necessary to properly promote and coordinate actions not only at the EU level, but also at national, regional and local levels. Like the rapporteur, in this case, I am paying particular attention to the potential of new technologies in establishing dialogue with young people and in increasing their ability to participate in society.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: written.- The PVV voted against the motion for a resolution (Rule 170 (4) of the Rules of Procedure) to replace the non-legislative motion for a resolution A8-0250 / 2016, as education and youth policy is an exclusive competence of the Member States.And that is a good thing: at national level, a Member State can use youth policies and available resources in a more relevant, effective and coordinated manner according to its own priority.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - Mrs Bocskor's report focuses on the evaluation of the European Union's youth strategy for 2013-2015. It is divided into several key areas in which it assesses the situation over a given period, identifies shortcomings and formulates future recommendations. Among the main problems related to the youth strategy, it addresses in particular the high unemployment rate, early school leaving, discrimination, the integration of refugees and migrants or the problem of acquiring skills that do not meet the requirements of the labor market. Following on from these issues, the report expresses concern that young people will be at risk of social exclusion, isolation or radicalization without a targeted and effective strategy. The report also provides many potential solutions to the main problems, with a special focus on the most disadvantaged and vulnerable groups of young people. On the other hand, it also brings opinions that can be described as problematic, such as the requirement of a minimum guaranteed income, gender quotas, several problematic references in connection with the refugee crisis or calls for support for projects that have proved very ineffective in practice. . In view of these facts, I have decided to abstain in the final vote.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of the Bocskor report as it agrees with the general lines presented in the youth strategy, namely the call for the involvement of young people in decision-making processes.I highlight the proposal to channel investments towards an inclusive education that ensures equal access and opportunities for all young people, regardless of gender, race, ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability or sexual orientation.I also underline the need to adopt measures to better recognize the skills acquired by young people informally, namely in voluntary actions.In this context, I also highlight the campaign launched by the European socialist group for "A Youth Action Plan".

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The report calls on Member States to make the best use of available national and EU policies and financial frameworks in order to promote adequate investment in youth and job creation.However, I believe that the document does not enter into the heart of the problems affecting the current "stolen generation", that is, the enormous difficulties in entering the social and working world.We give up on addressing the major structural issues that afflict today's Europe.We limit ourselves to formulating a series of generalities that from a practical point of view lead to little or nothing.It is not fully understood that the future of Europe is represented by our young people.I strongly believe that the EU should make a strong effort to support these generations by creating concrete opportunities and promoting targeted actions.In the light of these considerations, I have chosen to vote abstention from the report.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the evaluation of the EU Youth Strategy 2013-2015.I agree with the report's findings on the need to strengthen youth policy integration, cross-sectoral cooperation and social action within the EU, as well as synergies between the European Youth Strategy and other European strategies, such as education, training, health and employment,to ensure that current and future policies successfully address the situation and needs of young people facing severe economic, employment and social problems, and whereas it is crucial for youth organizations to be involved in policy-making.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, here I have to say with regret that I had to vote against this resolution because the idea suggested by the title is very good and acceptable, but, nevertheless, the rapporteur has deviated too much from the declared intentions, up to get to intertwine with the most recent political debate and for this reason we were unable to share the report. It is truly a shame, a missed opportunity. In particular, I must say that I found the opposition expressed against trade agreements tout court to be very prejudicial and not very objective. In reality these agreements are necessary pillars for the relaunch of the European economy, they represent, in fact, an excellent opportunity for the growth of jobs, for the internationalization of businesses and also of our professionals. Of course, they must be done well, but the one with Canada, for example, is an excellent example precisely to protect our agri-food excellence against fraud and falsification. I am sorry, I repeat, I would have preferred something less ideological and closer to the facts.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, farmers are currently facing a very difficult situation, and it is crucial to ensure a sustainable, competitive and economically viable sector in the future. For a long time, EU rural areas have been suffering from high unemployment and depopulation. We need to put in place the right tools to help make rural areas more attractive for living there. We need, amongst other things, more support for young farmers in embracing their challenging job, more effective ways of farming the land and to increase farmers’ bargaining power in the food supply chain. However, this report goes too far, blaming the CAP market liberalisation as a main cause of the recent crises in the different agri-markets. In addition, it calls for going back to a regulated and planned CAP with fixed prices and production amounts. I am sorry to say it, but this is not the right way to go. That is why I cannot support this report and I think it should be entirely rejected.

name: Момчил Неков (
text: S & amp; D). - Madam President, I strongly believe in the potential of rural areas for job creation and development opportunities, and I hope that the European Commission will reflect the recommendations of this report in future proposals. I am convinced of the role of European quality schemes - especially geographical indications and organic farming - in creating active and productive rural areas. Quality, local and traditional foods are part of local livelihoods and traditions and at the same time add value to the development of local tourism. They have the potential to create and return livelihoods in rural areas. Therefore, they need to receive additional funding and measures. I would like to draw attention to the role of so-called free trade agreements, which pose a real threat to European farmers, especially small and medium-sized producers and businesses. Through these agreements we bring competition. It will affect both the quality of food and indirectly the standards of production and the environment. That is why I stand against them - they do not serve either the Bulgarian or the European farmer.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: - A Uacharáin, vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí seo go léir agus ós rud é gur chailleamar vótaí tábhachtacha cinniúnacha, vótálamar i gcoinne an tuairisc go léir ag an deireadh agus an ceart againn mar mar mar a dúinteo ó shin, tá an tuarascáil seo ag dul thar fóir. Táimid go léir i bhfabhar níos mó jabanna a chruthú in áiteanna tuaithe agus ba chóir go ndéanfaimis gach rud chun é sin a dhéanamh agus cabhraíonn an CAP (an Comhbheartas Talmhaíochta) chun é sin a dhéanamh. Ach ag cur an milleáin ar an Aontas agus ar an CAP (an Comhbheartas Talmhaíochta) do a lán rudaí atá ag tarlú faoi láthair, ní doigh liom go bhfuil without féaráilte. Freisin ag iarraidh rialacha dochta dainge a leagadh sios ar leibhéal na hEorpa gan aon solúbthacht ann do na tíortha nó do na réigiún rudaí a dhéanamh atá tábhachtach don áit féin, níl aon chiall leis without ach oiread. Dá bhrí sin is doigh liom go mbeidh an Coimisiún ag obair go dian ar jabanna a chruthú ach téann seo thar fóir.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: written.- Today, the European Parliament voted on an own-initiative report on the future of the Union's agricultural policy.The Christian Democrats want to gradually get away from the big subsidy systems.Agricultural policy needs to be less extensive, as does agricultural support.Instead, this report goes in the other direction and wants to roll back the necessary reforms of recent years, use the aid as a labor market measure and make greater interventions in the agricultural market.It also paints trade as a threat, instead of an opportunity.Overall, the report goes against Christian Democratic policy in this area and I therefore vote no.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- Nowadays agricultural and rural areas are faced with a very serious problem linked to employment in these areas.In fact, rural areas are emptied more and more and work becomes increasingly rare.The CAP (common agricultural policy) from this point of view must represent the main lever to revive these areas.Unfortunately, it presents aspects that are not properly adapted to the current situation, there is a need for a CAP that takes into consideration the needs of all, reflecting a global vision and that is oriented to the present and to the future.Since I think it is essential to use European funds to try to solve the current European problems in the above-mentioned area, by encouraging family businesses, youth employment in rural areas and improving infrastructure, I voted in favor.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report as I consider the debate on the need to reorient CAP aid to farmers with real agricultural activity and to job creation in European rural areas as positive. It is of special interest that the accent is placed on the incorporation and access to land of young people and women. The report also highlights the contribution of short supply chains in the creation of rural employment, emphasizing the importance of quality systems and Geographical Indications, due to the opportunities they generate for the development of the agri-food sector. The text assumes that farmers operate in an increasingly global market, recognizing, on the one hand, that in some rural areas employment may be threatened by lacking viable alternatives to the traditional agricultural model; while for other areas and sectors, such Agreements can offer great opportunities for economic development and employment. With this report, the European Parliament opens the debate on how the CAP can contribute to strengthening employment and maintaining population, with a view to the future Common Agricultural Policy post 2020.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We oppose this because of its lack of realism in understanding both how markets work and the current fiscal climate.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- This report supports small-scale agriculture, encourages support for young people to enter agricultural activity, better inclusion of women in agricultural activity and short circuits of production and consumption.Likewise, he is critical of free trade agreements and with the support of the CAP for the intensive industrial agricultural model.For all these reasons, I have voted in favor of it.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which I shadowed through the Agriculture Committee. This report takes stock of how reforms since 2013 have been working in terms of job creation in rural areas, and looks forward to a CAP post-2020. After consulting with various interested parties in my constituency, I tabled a number amendments that would sought to draw attention to the devastating impact austerity policies have had on the social fabric of rural areas. I was happy that the majority of my amendments were included in the final report, so that the final result was a progressive text. Of note are paragraphs on the skills migrant workers and refugees can bring to rural areas, the needs for more supports for women in farming, the need to bring more equality to the way CAP is distributed and the need to strengthen social security, services and infrastructure in rural areas to promote job growth.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing. - I am pleased to have brought together all the forces of the European left on my report. This vote gives color to the common agricultural policy (CAP) and to the European project as a whole! This is proof that there is a common vision on the left for the future of agriculture, and that another agricultural model is possible. Despite their fine speeches, it is clear that the National Front and the Right did not support a report that advocates market regulation, the redeployment of aid to family farms or even better support for young farmers. Today there are two clashing models: an intensive, productive and concentrated operating model, oriented towards export markets, the one supported by the European right; and, a model favoring the reconquest of the internal market, food quality, short circuits and family structures, the one we advocate. In any case, the divisions observed within the right and the far right during the vote on my report are proof that neither the right nor the National Front have a clear vision on the future of agriculture!

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: written.- In its own-initiative report, Parliament dealt with the question of how the common agricultural policy (CAP) can improve job creation in rural areas.Among other things, all member states are called upon to create long-term prospects for young farmers.In addition, the Member States are encouraged to give more support to small and medium-sized farms and to give more consideration to less-favored areas (e.g. mountain areas, overseas areas, outermost regions, sensitive natural areas), as the maintenance of agriculture there is crucial for economic, socialand environmental development with an emphasis on employment.I welcome many of the points raised in the adopted text, but not all, which is why I abstained from the final vote.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against this report which was polluted by the usual demands on migrants, and gender issues.In this regard, paragraph 74 which promotes the social and economic integration of migrants and refugees (and their wives) is unacceptable.What is more in a double context of crisis in agriculture and employment.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report seeks to achieve the impossible. It seeks to increase EU intervention and increase environmental regulation on farming, whilst simultaneously reducing the burden of bureaucracy on farmers. It adds further targets and objectives. The non-legislative own-initiative report seeks to assist rural job creation, but to achieve this would require more taxpayers’ money. I do not oppose taxpayers’ money being spent on farming subsidies, but this should be done by the United Kingdom directly, not through the European Union. The comments on refugees are ill-conceived and confused; there is no reason for a report on rural job creation to discuss the refugee situation. I therefore voted against this rather confused report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- On reading this report, I note that the rapporteur has gone beyond the initial objective assigned to him by the AGRI committee, taking the task of drawing up the specifications for a new CAP.I also underline this Manichean vision consisting in separating the “good” small and the “bad” big.On the contrary, their complementarity is the key to maintaining activity in rural areas.However, I recognize that the measures aimed at simplifying the CAP are going in the right direction.I have therefore chosen to vote for this report, hoping that this text will open up avenues for concrete responses to quickly respond to the disarray in our countryside.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- Agriculture covers a large part of Europe's territory, but is currently practiced by only a small proportion of the working population in rural areas.In addition, the bulk of CAP direct payments go to the richest farms and in 2014only 13 percent.74% of beneficiaries receivedCAP direct payments.I do not think that this is helping to create jobs in agriculture and small farms need more labor, because 53% offarm workers work on farms classified as small economies.I therefore agree with the need for a better distribution of CAP payments to small farmers.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose this because of its lack of realism in understanding both how markets work and the current fiscal climate.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report was spoiled by the intervention of the FEMM and EMPL committees.Indeed, they added unacceptable demands on migrants, which the European Union is once again trying to put before our producers.Despite many positive points, including the defense and promotion of PDOs and IGPs to which I am very attached as well as support for SMEs, I preferred to abstain.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the own-initiative report by my socialist colleague Eric Andrieu (FR) on how the common agricultural policy (CAP) can improve job creation in rural areas. Rural areas represent more than 77% of the territory of the European Union and a large number of jobs in these areas are linked to agriculture and the agrifood industry. As the economic crisis has particularly affected rural areas, it appears crucial that the Union mobilizes the range of tools at its disposal to help these areas in difficulty. After insisting on the need to retain the two pillars of the CAP of supporting agricultural markets and incomes and rural development policy, this report calls on Member States to create future prospects for young farmers in order to '' provide a response to the rural exodus, in particular by making full use of all the possibilities offered by the new CAP, and to strengthen their support for small and medium-sized farms, in particular by making greater use of redistributive payments.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report.The report is divided into two parts, a first part on the current CAP and a second part on the 2020 CAP. The objective of this report is to influence the 2017 revision of the Common Agricultural Policy. Furthermore, the report constitutes a basissolid to deal with issues of capital importance such as depopulation in rural areas, lack of opportunities, falling employment, etc.The text emphasizes the importance of protecting small and medium-sized farmers and making the distribution of subsidies more proportional and fair.More specifically, it proposes that medium-sized family farms be the main beneficiaries of European agricultural aid.I voted in favor of a CAP that really benefits family farms, that creates jobs in rural areas and that diversifies the economy of our towns.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- I supported this report on how the CAP can improve job creation in rural areas.I have changed many of my group's voting guidelines and even the final vote.It is necessary to guarantee food safety in the Union and this must remain the guiding principle for the action of the future CAP without discouraging external markets, also considering that trade agreements can also provide opportunities for this sector.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - I preferred to abstain from this report concerning the improvement of job creation in rural areas via the CAP, despite the presence of some very positive elements. Indeed, the amendments tabled in the AGRI committee by my ENL colleagues have been adopted, which made it possible to include in the report the promotion of local production in markets and public calls for tenders, or to highlight the dangers for our country. agriculture of the TTIP and CETA free trade treaties. However, despite a generally positive report voted in committee, defending in particular the PDO and IGP or the desire to find tools to regulate prices on the markets, the text voted in plenary was completely deviated by the proposals of the EMPL and FEMM committees. In particular, these have transformed a positive report into an immigrationist and pro-gender theory “globi-boulga”, sacrificing the interests and survival of our agriculture to libertarian and communalist inclinations, with in particular the priority given to the integration of migrants and refugees compared to that of our farmers.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- Although the text contains some shared hints on the role of the agricultural sector, the Andrieu report unfortunately lapses into rhetoric in favor of employment in this sector of alleged illegal refugees.On the other hand, I believe that the priorities are quite different.In fact, for some time I have been asking the European institutions to hurry up to implement effective support measures for the thousands of Italian farmers affected by the economic crisis.For these reasons I preferred to express myself with an abstention.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have voted against the report. The Left Party wants agricultural policy to be governed nationally and organic production to be favored. EU agricultural policy is expensive and bureaucratic, CAP takes as much as 40% of the EU budget. Winners are the EU's large farmers, losers are small farmers in the third world. If agricultural policy is renationalised and regional aid is reduced, the taxpayers' contribution to the EU would be significantly reduced. The report criticizes the way in which the CAP works in practice and states "that the absolute majority of direct payments under the common agricultural policy goes to the richest farms, where only 13% of the beneficiaries received 74% of the direct payments under the common agricultural policy". . But it still wants to operate within the framework of the CAP and is deficient in terms of the environment, climate, rural development, organic farming, improved animal care and concrete proposals for increased employment in rural areas. In addition, several critical points were voted against the EU trade agreements TTIP, CETA and EU-Mercosur and their negative effects on the agricultural sector.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report as I consider the debate on the need to redirect CAP support to farmers with real agricultural activity and to job creation in European rural areas as positive. It is of special interest that the accent is placed on the incorporation and access to land of young people and women. The report also highlights the contribution of short supply chains in the creation of rural employment, emphasizing the importance of quality systems and Geographical Indications, due to the opportunities they generate for the development of the agri-food sector. The text assumes that farmers operate in an increasingly global market, recognizing, on the one hand, that in some rural areas employment may be threatened by lacking viable alternatives to the traditional agricultural model; while for other areas and sectors, such Agreements can offer great opportunities for economic development and employment. With this report, the European Parliament opens the debate on how the CAP can contribute to strengthening employment and maintaining population, with a view to the future Common Agricultural Policy post 2020.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which examines how the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) can improve job creation in rural areas. The European Parliament emphasizes the importance of the agricultural and agricultural products sector for social and territorial cohesion because of its role in sustainable economic growth, the creation of quality jobs and the preservation of rural communities. It also emphasizes the need to maintain the CAP budget and strengthen its socio-economic role, with a special focus on micro and small farms and taking into account regional specificities. In addition, it is essential that the effective implementation of the CAP contributes to social inclusion in rural areas by ensuring decent living and working conditions and good prospects for the future. Parliament emphasized the importance of territorial cohesion in the EU and the need to implement it through economic development policies that meet the challenges facing rural areas. It also draws attention to the strong links between rural systems, small communities and municipalities, and therefore calls for better synergies between cohesion policy measures and the CAP. Parliament called on the Member States to encourage young farmers to take part in vocational training under the ERASMUS + program, in particular the part relating to apprenticeships, in order to encourage them to acquire new technical and language skills abroad.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. - It is extremely important to me that the resources of the common agricultural policy actually go to farmers. Together with my Hungarian People's Party MPs, I was forced to reject the Andrieu report on the relationship between the common agricultural policy and job creation. I did so despite the fact that the text proposes a strong and properly funded common agricultural policy, an objective that is fully in line with the interests of Hungarian farmers. However, provisions have also been included in the report which would jeopardize the future financing of the CAP. Paragraphs 21 and 77 of the report propose that we also support social and demographic projects from agricultural sources. It is extremely important to us that the resources of the common agricultural policy actually go to farmers. Therefore, we must not allow direct or compulsory development funds to be used to cover crises caused by social and demographic change, either on a voluntary or compulsory basis. Funding for social issues does not have a place in the common agricultural policy, which is why in 2013 EU support for the most deprived people came out of this policy. Unfortunately, the same proposal has been included in the planned amendment to EU legislation on the Structural Funds and the backbone of the CAP, the so-called omnibus package. Here, too, we will take consistent action to prevent the withdrawal of Structural Funds, including rural development funds, even on a voluntary basis.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing.- In agriculture and rural development, trends all over Europe, including Slovenia, where I come from, are similar: the number of farms is declining, and young people are finding it increasingly difficult to become enthusiastic about agricultural activity.In my opinion, the measure for young farmers is one of the highest quality and which also gives the best results, because the European countryside needs young people, new knowledge, new approaches.In the old, traditional way, it will be very difficult to resist modern trends.Digitization in agriculture is one that, together with rural mobility, must be brought into the context of agricultural and regional policy and thus improve employment in rural areas.Unfortunately, there was not much talk about this in the proposed report.In the end, I abstained from voting on the report because, in my opinion, it did not adequately address some current issues in European agriculture, and it was also very critical of international trade, which can strengthen many European producers.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. - Globalization and the economic crisis have long been putting a strain on European agriculture, particularly in rural areas. In many Member States, the number of farmers has dramatically decreased, as have their income and employment in the sector. Despite the merits of the common agricultural policy (CAP) in favoring the growth of European agriculture over the past decades, the limits of the CAP in the face of current challenges cannot be ignored. The CAP has in fact proved incapable of counteracting the depopulation of the countryside, creating distortions of the agricultural market following the austerity policies, neglecting the social function of the primary sector in terms of employment. I therefore support this report as a more social agricultural policy is essential for the future of the rural world; Indeed, the CAP must be able to put farmers in the foreground as well as the quality and competitiveness of their products. Faced with the economic crisis, the EU has made employment one of its key priorities; it is for this reason that the CAP must reassert itself as one of the instruments of European action for the maintenance and creation of employment in rural areas.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this CAP report which emphasizes the need to make the best use of the CAP to counter the declining trend in agricultural and non-agricultural businesses over many decades in rural areas.Diversification on farms, ensuring sustainable business, development, ensuring maximum opportunities and involving young farmers, women and other stakeholders in rural development are key to strengthening resilience in rural communities and keeping people in the countryside and tackling depopulation and decline.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. - In rural areas, jobs are linked to agriculture and the agri-food industry. These sectors are important for social and territorial cohesion, therefore it is necessary to maintain the CAP budget and strengthen its social and economic role. A coordinated approach between the second pillar of the CAP and other EU funds needs to be implemented in order to enhance effectiveness and avoid inefficiencies. Urgent reforms are needed on the first pillar of the CAP which favors large producers and therefore leads to market concentration and a lack of incentives for employment. Further measures should be developed for the introduction of proportionality and flexibility in relation to the administrative burden of the CAP. A gender perspective should be developed in the cohesion policies of EU rural areas, therefore in the CAP, to bridge the gap that still exists, especially in terms of pay. Specific programs need to be introduced to encourage female entrepreneurship and improve professional training. It is also necessary to foster the social and economic integration of all rural workers, including refugees, migrants and seasonal workers. Digital and transport links in rural areas need to be developed and improved to help farmers achieve work-life balance.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report contains very good ideas such as the defense of PDOs, local priority in the markets or even the questioning of free trade treaties.Unacceptable additions are made to the necessary integration of migrants, in the midst of the agriculture and employment crisis, as well as to gender issues.I therefore abstained.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report as I consider the debate on the need to redirect CAP aid to farmers with real agricultural activity and to job creation in European rural areas as positive. It is of special interest that the accent is placed on the incorporation and access to land of young people and women. The report also highlights the contribution of short supply chains in the creation of rural employment, emphasizing the importance of quality systems and Geographical Indications, due to the opportunities they generate for the development of the agri-food sector. The text assumes that farmers operate in an increasingly global market, recognizing, on the one hand, that in some rural areas employment may be threatened by lacking viable alternatives to the traditional agricultural model; while for other areas and sectors, such Agreements can offer great opportunities for economic development and employment. With this report, the European Parliament opens the debate on how the CAP can contribute to strengthening employment and maintaining population, with a view to the future post-2020 Common Agricultural Policy.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the report in question because I believe it is a comprehensive proposal to tackle the problem of employment in rural areas in a decisive way. Supporting young farmers with aid from the first and second pillar of the CAP, intensifying support for small and medium-sized farms and fighting price volatility to ensure income for agricultural businesses are the key actions to be implemented to ensure a future for the sector. primary species in rural areas. I believe that the volatility of agricultural product prices is one of the main factors in the dramatic situation facing many European farmers. I am therefore in favor of strengthening risk management tools, crisis management measures such as countercyclical aid, POs and the role of price observers, which are useful for guiding production and intervening in the event of a crisis. I think the CAP is at a crossroads. Starting in 2020, a radical reform will be required that puts farmers, quality and the environment at the fore. We need to plan a new model of more sustainable agriculture that focuses much more on supporting and developing small and medium-sized agricultural enterprises.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which I shadowed through the Agriculture Committee. This report takes stock of how reforms since 2013 have been working in terms of job creation in rural areas, and looks forward to a CAP post-2020. After consulting with various interested parties in my constituency, I tabled a number amendments that would sought to draw attention to the devastating impact austerity policies have had on the social fabric of rural areas. I was happy that the majority of my amendments were included in the final text, so that the final result was a progressive text. Of note are paragraphs on the skills migrant workers and refugees can bring to rural areas, the needs for more supports for women in farming, the need to bring more equality to the way CAP is distributed and the need to strengthen social security, services and infrastructure in rural areas to promote job growth.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as it calls for an agricultural policy which delivers a more competitive and sustainable European agricultural model based on family-run, diversified and multifunctional holdings and generates fairly paid jobs. This is a very timely resolution which focuses on the changing realities within the agricultural sector.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this own-initiative report which launches concrete ideas on how to repopulate rural areas which have been increasingly emptying over the last decade and where work is becoming increasingly rare.EU agriculture is facing a multitude of challenges: food, environmental, energy, climate, and so on, to respond to all these challenges we need to think of a CAP (Common Agricultural Policy) that has a global vision, which reflects therequests and needs of all and that it is at the service of all.We recall that the CAP is one of the most important Community policies, committing about 34% of the European Union budget.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - I applaud the report given its timely correspondence to my vision: in order to achieve solid and stable employment in rural areas, they must be valued as cradles of opportunity - and I am thinking in particular of Italy. In line with the very rich heterogeneity present in our territory, it is precisely through the provision of aid aimed at the cultivation of local varieties and the breeding of indigenous breeds that regional employment is promoted and biodiversity is maintained. Such aids certainly need to be focused on corporate sustainability and profitability to sow and feed jobs. Consistently with this, it is a priority to protect and implement quality schemes, geographical indications and organic agriculture to allow full development of the agri-food sector and create employment potential in the rural environment, as well as preserving indigenous culture and identity. Access to the wider markets for these local excellences must also be facilitated and therefore, improving their promotion and marketing would have significant repercussions on the entire economy thanks to the trust placed by the consumer in them and the global demand for goods generated by the environmental heritage. Rural development and employment would grow simultaneously thanks to the contribution of local authorities, well aware of the strong incentive represented by the diversification of agricultural activity.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the vote on the report on how the CAP can improve job creation in rural areas, because the report focused on CAP reform rather than job creation.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- This report supports small-scale agriculture, encourages support for young people to enter agricultural activity, better inclusion of women in agricultural activity and short circuits of production and consumption.He is also critical of free trade agreements and with the support of the CAP for the intensive industrial agricultural model.For all these reasons, I have voted in favor of it.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: signed up.- Rural areas account for 77% of the European Union's territory, and many jobs in these regions depend on agriculture and the agri-food industry.These industries together account for 6% of the European Union's GDP, bringing together 15 million businesses and generating around 46 million jobs.In recent years, we have seen a drastic reduction in the number of farmers and a steady decline in their incomes.In the period 2005-2014, the volume of work in agriculture decreased by almost a quarter.I voted in favor of developing the tools needed to modernize and guarantee the competitiveness of economic sectors in rural areas in a sustainable way and in accordance with environmental norms.The development prospects of this sector are huge, and the economy of the member countries has only to gain from it.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Andrieu report on the relationship between the common agricultural policy (CAP) and job creation proposes a good and well-financed common agricultural policy. Although the objectives of the report are in line with the interests of domestic farmers, proposals have also been made within the text that could jeopardize the future financing of the CAP. The report would pave the way for projects to address, among other things, social and population problems through agricultural policy, which is not acceptable, as CAP funds must actually reach farmers. The report is not a legislative text and therefore has no legal implications for the EU's common agricultural policy. It is unacceptable to cover crises caused by social and demographic change from direct payments or rural development resources, whether on a voluntary or even compulsory basis. The resources of the common agricultural policy must actually go to farmers and food producers, failing which the EU would not be able to ensure an adequate food supply for the continent.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on how the CAP can improve job creation in rural areas.In my opinion, the report deals with a very important subject of the rural economy, focusing most on employment in this area.I also supported the report because its aim is to simplify the CAP for individual farmers, to ensure better access to services in rural areas and to encourage more research and innovation in the sector.For these reasons, I voted in favor.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as I believe that the rural development policy should be strengthened and allowed more flexibility to maximise its job creation potential. The report sets out a number of solutions which include support for farmers to branch out into rural tourism, the production of renewable energy, and also organic farming. This report highlights the need to make best use of the CAP to counter the downward trend in agricultural and non—agricultural jobs over many decades in rural areas. Ensuring basic services and connectivity all help retain people in the countryside and tackle depopulation and decline.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing. - This own-initiative report deals with the contribution of the CAP to employment in rural areas. While I fully support the principle of this report, its content created controversy as soon as it was examined in parliamentary committee. This report is built on the systematic opposition of agricultural models to promote an outdated view of agriculture, based on small farms, suspicion of progress and a withdrawal of Europe into itself. In addition, the rapporteur has made this report a platform to propose his vision of an overhaul of the CAP, evoking crisis management, volatility, international trade and other subjects, admittedly indirectly linked to employment but being outside the mandate given for the drafting of this report. Although I support a large part of the ideas defended, in terms of crisis management, rebalancing aid between farms and territories and support for niche productions, I felt it necessary to oppose this report, which breaks the he political balance of the latest CAP reform and calls into question the foundations of a policy which has just been difficult to put in place. Our action must promote the stability of public policies, not the gas factories.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted against the text, without binding legislative value, on the contribution of the CAP to employment in rural areas.Under the guise of promoting employment in rural areas, an improvement in crisis management, or the rebalancing of aid between farms and territories, this text, carried by a left-wing deputy, proposes a premature overhaul of the CAP which highlightsdanger current balances difficult to achieve.In particular, I objected to the presumption that international trade would automatically be harmful to employment in agriculture.I regret that a text on such an important subject has been diverted from its main objective and turned into a plea for the left in matters of agricultural policy.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: in writing.- This report has a commendable plan because it wants to develop jobs in rural areas.However, he proposes a mid-term review of the current CAP which is not relevant.Reforming now would be tantamount to jeopardizing the substantive discussions that should be carried out during the preparation of the next CAP by 2020. In addition, this report proposes several questionable measures.It transforms the CAP into a policy of social assistance, whereas that is not its vocation.He takes positions on trade agreements that go beyond the subject.It is for these reasons that I voted against this report, even if some ideas are interesting avenues for reflection that need to be deepened.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. - It is extremely important to me that the resources of the common agricultural policy actually go to farmers. Together with my Hungarian People's Party MPs, I was forced to reject the Andrieu report on the relationship between the common agricultural policy and job creation. I did so despite the fact that the text proposes a strong and properly funded common agricultural policy, an objective that is fully in line with the interests of Hungarian farmers. However, provisions have also been included in the report which would jeopardize the future financing of the CAP. Paragraphs 21 and 77 of the report propose that we also support social and demographic projects from agricultural sources. It is extremely important to us that the resources of the common agricultural policy actually go to farmers. Therefore, we must not allow direct or compulsory development funds to be used to cover crises caused by social and demographic change, either on a voluntary or compulsory basis. Funding for social issues does not have a place in the common agricultural policy, which is why in 2013 EU support for the most deprived people came out of this policy. Unfortunately, the same proposal has been included in the planned amendment to EU legislation on the Structural Funds and the backbone of the CAP, the so-called omnibus package. Here, too, we will take consistent action to prevent the withdrawal of Structural Funds, including rural development funds, even on a voluntary basis.

name: Angel Dzhambazki (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. It is clear, that there are certain aspects of the CAP, which should be improved, such as simplifying the CAP for individual farmers by providing better access to services and promoting research. However, the report is often overly prescriptive and in disregard of the important role of Member States in this matter. Especially when it comes to taxation and security, it is up to the Member States to decide. Furthermore, whilst I would gladly support improvements on the CAP, the report also goes way beyond the current debate and issues on some matters, which in my opinion, are not realistic at this point.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - This text is distinguished by many positive features. We consider the main thing to be the contradiction with the international free trade agreements. At the same time, it advocates the simplification of bureaucratic procedures related to the CAP and the strengthening of regional identity and tradition in the field of agriculture. It wants to strengthen the role of youth in agricultural production and to strengthen agricultural populations across Europe. At the same time, it will give priority to remote and mountainous as well as sea areas. In principle, we only disagree on the existence of the CAP, because we believe that agriculture is a matter for the Member States to deal with. Due to the fact that this report corrects many of the problems of the existing regulation that had a negative impact on agriculture in Greece, we will support it.
