name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: written.- These are difficult times for many farmers around Europe and change is needed for us to get out of the negative development that has unfortunately characterized agriculture for too long.Unfortunately, we see too little of future development and faith in the future in this report.Instead, they want to see re-regulation and more subsidy dependence for Europe's farmers, when we must instead ensure that once and for all create a market where the farmer can get paid for the products he produces.And we will never do that if we are to pursue a policy described in this report, which is why I voted against it.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing.- Rural areas represent more than 77% of the EU's territory and many jobs in these areas depend on agriculture and the agri-food industry.Together, agriculture and the agri-food industry represent 6% of the EU's GDP, 15 million companies and 46 million jobs.In the context of the current economic crisis, the European Union has made employment one of its main priorities and, in this context, the CAP must become more effective and see its legitimacy reaffirmed, with a view to maintaining and creating jobs, as well ascompetitiveness in rural areas, mainly in the agricultural sector.I agree that it is necessary to assess the extent to which the CAP has an impact on the creation and maintenance of jobs in rural areas, bearing in mind that the vast majority of direct CAP payments go to the wealthiest farms, with only 13% of beneficiaries receiving74% of direct CAP payments in 2014.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We followed most of the concerns expressed in the report. Agriculture represents a fundamental sector which, in addition to guaranteeing the production of food and other agricultural goods essential for our survival, represents a fundamental lever for rural development, which can help prevent desertification and promote territorial cohesion. Agriculture can and must contribute to job creation. Although it contains positive aspects, the report fundamentally lacks a lack of criticism of the current CAP, ending up guaranteeing the direction it has been following. More than defending job creation, it is necessary to defend the quality of this job and the need to combat the growing precariousness of agricultural employment. The current CAP orientation does not contribute to this objective. Strong instruments for regulating production are needed, which have been and are being completely dismantled with successive CAP reforms. It is important to intervene at the level of the distribution chain, imposing a fairer distribution of value creation, with fair prices paid to the producer. Finally, it is important to stop this succession of free trade agreements either with Canada, with the USA or with the Mercosur countries. Agreements that represent the ruin of small and medium-sized agriculture and family farming.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstain from the report, there are many positive and shareable passages, but then the importance of immigration in agriculture is always emphasized.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing.- I am in favor of the report on how the CAP can improve job creation in the countryside, and I believe that, in this context, trade agreements such as the TTIP, CETA and the EU-Mercosur Free Trade Agreement represent a seriousthreat to agricultural products and European labor markets, and will run counter to policies to encourage local production and support.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe we need to make best use of the CAP to counter the downward trend in agricultural and non-agricultural jobs over many decades in rural areas. Diversification on farms, ensuring sustainable business development, and ensuring maximum opportunity and involvement of young farmers, women and other stakeholders in rural development are all key to building resilience in rural communities. Ensuring basic services and connectivity all help retain people in the countryside and tackle depopulation and decline. Ensuring CAP tools are fit for these purposes is a continuing task for policy makers and all who put them in place and use them on the ground. Finally, I welcome the strong focus on diversification, environmental aspects, organic and quality food systems, short food supply chains, and fairness in the supply chain for primary producers.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. - Together with my Hungarian People's Party MPs, I was forced to reject the Andrieu report on the relationship between the common agricultural policy (CAP) and job creation. I did so despite the fact that the text proposes a strong and well-financed common agricultural policy, an objective that is fully in line with the interests of Hungarian farmers. However, there are also provisions in the report that would jeopardize the future financing of the CAP. The report proposes that we also support social and demographic projects from agricultural sources. In my opinion, it is extremely important that the resources of the common agricultural policy are actually given to farmers, so we cannot allow direct payments or rural development resources to be used to deal with crises caused by social and demographic change, either on a voluntary or compulsory basis. The financing of social issues has no place in the common agricultural policy.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report as I consider the debate on the need to redirect CAP aid to farmers with real agricultural activity and to job creation in European rural areas as positive. It is of special interest that the accent is placed on the incorporation and access to land of young people and women. The report also highlights the contribution of short supply chains in the creation of rural employment, emphasizing the importance of quality systems and Geographical Indications, due to the opportunities they generate for the development of the agri-food sector. The text assumes that farmers operate in an increasingly global market, recognizing, on the one hand, that in some rural areas employment may be threatened by lacking viable alternatives to the traditional agricultural model; while for other areas and sectors, such agreements can offer great opportunities for economic development and employment. With this report, the European Parliament opens the debate on how the CAP can contribute to strengthening employment and maintaining population, with a view to the future Common Agricultural Policy post 2020.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the EP resolution on how the CAP can improve job creation in rural areas, of which I was shadow rapporteur for the opinion in the Employment Committee, because I believe that agriculture in rural areas plays a major role importance for the future of many Member States and of Europe as a whole. The current economic crisis has generated a high rate of unemployment in many EU countries, the CAP could, if made more effective, help to create new jobs and improve the competitiveness of rural areas and promote the development of tourism and industry. of agri-food processing. The future of rural areas is strongly linked to the maintenance of other economic activities such as forestry, crafts and the development of SMEs and the ability of the latter to integrate different productions, demonstrating how rural development and the creation of jobs go hand in hand. For these reasons, I supported the invitation to the Commission and the Member States to support cooperative enterprises operating in the social economy, in order to foster social integration and the invitation to the Commission to promote the contribution of the social economy to rural development. , for example through an action plan for the social economy.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on 'How can the CAP improve job creation in rural areas?' Because, as the rapporteur responsible for my group in FEMM, I support the approach to more jobs in rural areas and pay particular attentionto support women.An important factor, which unfortunately does not come into play in this report, is the recognition of the achievement of mothers and fathers in rural areas as a real "profession" with social relevance through the introduction of national education salaries.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: written.- I reject the Social Democrat Andrieu report because it does not reflect the reality of agriculture today.The creation of jobs in rural areas is also a matter close to my heart, but this must not happen at the expense of modern agriculture.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because it is an important moment for the common agricultural policy, which in some ways is at the center of controversy. One wonders what went wrong, because despite having an important budget at its disposal, it was not able to "protect" the farmers from the terrible crisis of the last year. Because it didn't lead to a real development of agriculture and a substantial increase in employment. I believe that this is the time to act and I believe that first of all if we want the CAP to work we must simplify it and ensure that funding is also adequate in the coming years, not accept cuts. And then the CAP must be inclusive, it must "attract" new farmers. We need to look at young people and access to land and support small and medium-sized companies, which must become the first beneficiaries of aid. It is unacceptable that most CAP direct payments go to the richest farms and that only 13% of beneficiaries received 74% of CAP direct payments in 2014. Helping those who are strong is not useful, the agricultural fabric is made up mainly of small farmers, small family farms, they are the engine of rural development, it is to them that the aid must reach.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report.The report is divided into two parts, a first part on the current CAP and a second part on the 2020 CAP. The objective of this report is to influence the 2017 revision of the Common Agricultural Policy. Furthermore, the report constitutes a basissolid to deal with issues of capital importance such as depopulation in rural areas, lack of opportunities, falling employment, etc.The text emphasizes the importance of protecting small and medium-sized farmers and making the distribution of subsidies more proportional and fair.More specifically, it proposes that medium-sized family farms be the main beneficiaries of European agricultural aid.I voted in favor of a CAP that really benefits family farms, that creates jobs in rural areas and that diversifies the economy of our towns.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which highlights how the CAP can be a force for employment in rural areas, both in farming and beyond. This report outlines the reasons for falling rates of employment in the primary sector following the advances in intensification of European agriculture. The report highlights mechanisms to create employment beyond agriculture.  Crucially, the report points out the role of local, bottom-up initiatives such as the LEADER approach, which can galvanise the support of local communities and help orientate public funds. It also emphasises the role of women in rural areas as well as the contribution of non-agricultural sectors, such as forestry and tourism.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: in writing. - Between 1957 and today, the agricultural population has grown from 20% to 4% of the EU's working population; more than one in five farms disappeared in the EU between 2007 and 2013, rising from 13.6 million to 10.8 million six years later. Faced with this situation, we need a CAP that is a real instrument at the service of employment while guaranteeing healthy and accessible food to as many people as possible. It is in this sense that my colleague Eric Andrieu spoke, to whom I gave my full support. Among the measures proposed, I retain the importance of supporting the installation of young farmers to encourage the renewal of generations. In order to strengthen the attractiveness of this profession, my colleague also proposes to reactivate, by adapting them, the tools for market regulation and the fight against price volatility, and to put an end to the laissez-faire of the markets, which is devastating for farmers, employment and the economy of the territories. By further strengthening small and medium-sized farms, we will be better able to support employment and sustainable development, as well as more harmonious land use planning.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report. The report does not provide an in—depth analysis on the situation in Member States and how well the potential of CAP has been already used in the area of job creation. Also, the Member States should advertise better the potential of the second pillar of the CAP for the diversification of activities in rural areas (e.g. agro-tourism, production of renewable energy).

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report ‘How the CAP can improve job creation in rural areas’ and I was very happy that it passed. I was pleased that the report noted the importance of maintaining the two pillars of the CAP and the need for Member States to give young farmers long-term prospects in order to address rural depopulation and to make full use of all the possibilities provided under the new CAP to support young farmers and new entrants to farming (especially those aged over 40). I was also happy that the rapporteur called upon Member States to step up their support for small and medium-sized farms, in particular by making more use of the redistributive payment. In regard to prevention tools, I was very happy to support the establishment of observatories, like the Milk Market Observatory, in all major production areas in order to monitor markets which would help steer production and ensure a response to crises by means of flexible and responsive market management tools which would be activated when necessary. Finally, I supported the reference to the possible negative effects that trade deals may pose to EU agriculture.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The report, which assesses the impact of the CAP in rural areas, fails to look at the rural economy as a whole and infringes on the subsidiarity principle. Moreover, it is overly critical of how the CAP is used to support what it calls ‘intensive’ farming. My group and I have therefore voted against this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The CAP is a good opportunity to re—launch the agricultural sector in Europe, which has been spiralling downwards. The CAP could bring in farm diversification, more opportunities and involvement for young farmers and a plan for sustainable business development.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report on how the CAP can stimulate job creation in rural areas, because these areas face a number of challenges such as low incomes, negative population growth, lack of jobs and high unemployment, poor development tertiary sector, lack of food processing capacity, low skill level and limited capital. Agriculture and the agri-food industry account for 6% of the European Union's GDP and 46 million jobs, so our task is to preserve agricultural production in order to maintain the dynamism of rural areas and the number of jobs. Employment is one of the EU's main priorities, especially within the EFSI, and in this context the legitimacy and effectiveness of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) need to be strengthened so that it becomes one of the main factors in European action to preserve and create jobs. places in rural areas and fostering competitiveness.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- This proposal presents several positive aspects, such as support for small and medium-sized farms, the demand for recognition of the role played by women in the agricultural sector and the rights which derive from it, local priority in markets and employment, or eventhe condemnation of free trade treaties.I am also pleased that our voices have been heard and taken into account in the compromises.However, the FEMM and EMPL committees were quick to distort this promising report, particularly through the issue of migration.At a time when the agricultural sector is in crisis and unemployment is breaking records, it is intolerable to promote, as recommended in paragraph 74, the social and economic integration of migrants and their families.I voted against.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported the report, which addresses the question of how the common agricultural policy can improve job creation in rural areas, although it could include more forward-looking prospects.Rural areas represent 77% of the territory of the European Union, which is why I consider it important to develop them dynamically and to reduce the disparities in job opportunities between urban and rural areas.The report highlights the challenges of tackling labor supply in rural areas, such as low wages and declining populations, and looks at ways to improve job creation.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted against the report by my colleague Eric Andrieu on job creation in rural areas with CAP funds.Initially the report aimed to make the CAP contribute to the maintenance and creation of jobs in rural areas, which I encourage, but it has been diverted to introduce provisions contrary to the spirit of the CAP.Indeed, the report promotes agriculture opposing agricultural models (large farms against small ones), hostile to progress and against international trade.Despite the provisions for employment, crisis management or the rebalancing of aid between farms and territories, I could not bring myself to vote in favor of this report.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written.- I would vote in favor of this report because I am of the opinion that the canon of subsidies and subsidies helps Austrian farmers, above all smallholders, financially.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Rural areas make up a substantial part of the EU's territory. For many years, more than 50% of the EU population has lived in cities. After World War II, there was a decrease in the workforce in agriculture and forestry, in the last 10 years it was a quarter of jobs. Some rural areas have literally become depopulated, and it is agriculture that determines the appearance of a substantial part of the Union's territory. Smaller and medium-sized settlements are expanding in suburban areas, where there are usually not many job opportunities, but at the same time the necessary services are relatively available. In more remote areas, it is a problem to provide these services. The age structure of those who run agricultural holdings corresponds to this. The European Commission recommends redirecting direct payments under the CAP towards small farmers. National governments often also provide support from their state budgets or regional funds. The Commission considers that environmental legislation should be simple, clear and easy to implement. For the development of job opportunities, it offers support to producers and farmers who grow local varieties and breed local breeds. Interestingly, the Commission is ignoring the dangers posed by the adoption of CETA, TTIP and the agreement with Mercosur. The recommendation to support services related to tourism looks real. As a curiosity, I see support for the creation of specialized enterprises with more than 200 hives, this lack of hives will not solve.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I supported the report on 'How can the CAP improve job creation in rural areas?', In particular on the following points: 'whereas the Commission states in its own impact assessment on the consequences of TTIP that predominantly rural areas are more vulnerable; areas that focus on specific activities and have limited alternatives; whereas rural areas and rural jobs are threatened by the departure from traditional agricultural models that this agreement will bring; ',' whereas the trade agreements currently being negotiated, such as the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Facility, Partnership Agreement (TTIP), the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement between the EU and Canada (CETA) and the EU-Mercosur Free Trade Agreement the impact of the agreements currently under discussion, such as the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Cooperation Agreement with Canada (CETA) and the EU-Mercosur Free Trade Agreement, on agriculture. name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The common agricultural policy (CAP) remains to this day one of the prime means of action that the EU brings to bear in rural areas. However, CAP so far favoured more agricultural production that relies on increasingly concentrated and specialised farms. The CAP, has unduly neglected the preservation of local production and jobs. This report presents new measures that should be implemented in CAP. Such as the simplification of CAP, measures to support young farmers, better inclusion of women into the agricultural sector, some critics towards TTIP, and CETA and measures to stimulate local production. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Agriculture is very important sector in the EU economy which currently employs 22.2 million people. It is important to note that predominantly rural areas cover nearly 52 % of the EU’s territory and are home to 112 million people. Unfortunately, these rural areas have been particularly hard hit by the economic crisis. Because of that, many rural areas in the EU are facing socio-economic challenges such as depopulation, high unemployment rates, lower levels of income, lack of opportunities for young people and women, and lower level of education and skills. In this context, CAP is one of the EU’s main tools for action in rural areas. With its total budget of EUR 408.3 billion, it involves large transfers of funds to rural areas, with an impact on job creation. However, currently CAP cannot create the expected job numbers because direct payments from the policy are not fairly distributed among farmers and CAP procedures are quite complicated and slow. Therefore, in order to improve CAP effectiveness in job creation in rural areas, better distribution among small and medium-sized farms should be introduced and CAP procedures should be simplified.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on this report because it contains good and bad provisions.Good ones: it supports family farming (even if it is too late or even hypocritical because the CAP has ruined it!).Bad ones: he praises the benefits of immigration on economic growth and social cohesion, and calls for positive discrimination against migrant workers!

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted against this report which studies the contribution of the common agricultural policy (CAP) to job creation in rural areas.Indeed, this report was built on the systematic opposition of agricultural models to promote an outdated vision of agriculture, based on small farms, suspicion in the face of progress and a withdrawal of Europe into itself byinternational trade terms.In addition, the rapporteur has made this report a platform to propose his vision of a reform of the CAP, evoking crisis management, the volatility of agricultural prices and other subjects, admittedly indirectly linked to employment, butbeing outside the mandate given for the drafting of this report.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on the report entitled "How can the CAP improve job creation in rural areas?"This text recommends several positive points: support for small and medium-sized farms, the defense and promotion of PDOs and IGPs, the call for the recognition of the role of women on farms (access to social security, retirement...), local priority in markets and employment, and questioning of free trade treaties (in their agricultural aspects).Unfortunately, this report is polluted by the opinions of the FEMM and EMPL committees, which have incorporated the usual demands on migrants.In the double context of the agriculture and employment crisis, this is unacceptable.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: written. - This non-legislative report examines what measures can be taken under the common agricultural policy to boost employment in rural areas. The MEPs of the N-VA did not support this text because it insists on a one-sided solution, namely increasing financial support for local farmers. Moreover, this report already calls for more funding for agriculture beyond 2020 (end date of the current Multiannual Financial Framework) and almost completely overlooks a very important factor for job creation, innovation. In addition, the Commission is also asked for financial aid for social measures that Flanders should in principle decide itself. Finally, the text contains strong language about the possible negative consequences of negotiating international trade agreements, but forgets about the associated job creation.

The report also highlights the contribution of short supply chains in the creation of rural employment, emphasizing the importance of quality systems and Geographical Indications, due to the opportunities they generate for the development of the agri-food sector. The text assumes that farmers operate in an increasingly global market, recognizing, on the one hand, that in some rural areas employment may be threatened by lacking viable alternatives to the traditional agricultural model; while for other areas and sectors, such Agreements can offer great opportunities for economic development and employment. With this report, the European Parliament opens the debate on how the CAP can contribute to strengthening employment and maintaining population, with a view to the future post-2020 Common Agricultural Policy.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- This report supports small-scale agriculture, encourages support for young people to enter agricultural activity, better inclusion of women in agricultural activity and short circuits of production and consumption.He is also critical of free trade agreements and with the support of the CAP for the intensive industrial agricultural model.For all these reasons, I have voted in favor of it.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, as it was not the appropriate place or method to look at future reform of the CAP.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I voted against. According to the resolution, "there is a need to promote active measures and policies emphasizing the positive role of migration in boosting economic growth and promoting social cohesion in rural areas". In fact, this calls for the EU to use some advertising to convince people that migration has a positive effect on rural cohesion. I do not agree with such a challenge. The resolution further "calls on the relevant national, regional and local authorities to promote the participation of women in local action groups and the development of local partnerships under LEADER and to ensure gender-balanced participation in their boards". In short, the report is a detached praise of bureaucracy and subsidy projects in the field of agriculture. On the contrary, I believe that we will not help agriculture by pushing for the introduction of equality between women and men on the boards of subsidy projects.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - Agriculture still covers most of European territory. Large bureaucracy and administrative burdens pose difficulties for European farmers as not all provisions are yet fully defined. The report points out that direct payments under the CAP should be granted exclusively to persons whose main activity is agriculture. The CAP should not only apply to farmers but also to others who are end users of agricultural products and goods. Rural areas and jobs can thus potentially become threatened by a departure from the traditional agricultural models that will emerge by concluding agreements. European farmers today operate in an increasingly globalized market and are therefore more exposed to price volatility than other sectors. The trade agreements currently being negotiated, such as the EU-Canada TTIP, the EU-Canada CETA and the EU-Mercosur Free Trade Agreement, pose a threat to job creation and the creation of conditions to support the agricultural way of life. u is by no means in the plan. Job creation in rural areas must be part of a sustainable policy tailored to specific areas. They take into account the preservation and development of agricultural activities and activities indirectly related to the agriculture and forestry sector, as well as rural activities that are the foundation of social relations and solidarity. Because of the above, I did not support this report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. - Agriculture and food account for 6% of the European Union's GDP. It is 15 million businesses and 46 million jobs concentrated mainly in rural areas. Support for agriculture and employment is therefore directly linked to the development and maintenance of life in rural settlements. When adopting measures and providing assistance, it is necessary to take into account the existing specificity of agriculture, such as differences in climatic and geographical conditions and higher employment of women in this sector. Small and medium-sized enterprises must also have secure financing for their investments from EU resources. There is also a need to increase young people's interest in working and doing business in this area. The common agricultural policy is therefore an important tool for maintaining employment, ensuring sufficient quality and safe food and, at the same time, rural development. The Commission and the Member States must focus their efforts on this enduring goal.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: in writing. - Since 1957, the agricultural population has increased from 20% to 4% of the European working population. Indeed, the CAP, by promoting since its creation the intensification of production and the concentration of farms, has had a negative impact on employment in rural areas. The current CAP must therefore be reformed in order to respond to 4 challenges: food, environmental, climate and territorial. This report therefore calls on the Member States to implement a global strategy for the renewal of generations, thereby supporting young farmers. This text also underlines the need to reactivate and adapt the tools for market regulation and the fight against price volatility; to stop the laissez-faire of the markets, which is devastating for farmers, jobs and the economy of the territories. Finally, he recommends giving priority to direct support to small and medium-sized farms, and calls for promoting innovation, apprenticeship and vocational training to adapt the skills of stakeholders to the needs of the new agricultural model. I am voting in favor of this text because it contains many proposals capable of allowing the future CAP to regain all of its legitimacy and meet the major challenge of employment.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- I do not support the report on how the CAP can improve job creation in the countryside, because it is not complete and documented, and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the European Parliament on 27 October 2016.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.This text contains many positive points (efficient support for small and medium-sized farms, defense and promotion of protected designations of origin (PDO) and protected geographical indications (PGI), local priority, etc.), but, moving awaysubstantive issues, takes a position on gender issues, as well as on the social and economic integration of migrants and refugees.We oppose these positions in the current context of crisis in the agricultural sector.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- This report aims to influence the review of the CAP in 2017 and the future reform of the EU's agricultural policy, serving as a starting point for open discussion on ensuring that EU rural areas, in all their diversity, have a future., with the firm emphasis placed on employment and job growth in rural areas.This report also calls for simplification of the CAP, strengthening its social role, paying special attention to small-scale agriculture, diversification of rural areas, sufficient funding for rural areas in various European funds, support for young farmers, better inclusionwomen in the agricultural sector, etc.This report is critical of the risks to local economies and jobs, therefore, against policies aimed at stimulating local production and supporting European agricultural and employment livelihoods.I voted in favor.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: in writing. - Like the vast majority of the European parliamentary left (social democrats, environmentalists, united left) and unlike the right and the National Front, I voted in favor of the Andrieu report on the future of the common agricultural policy, which calls for a reform of the CAP in a more employment-friendly direction. I share both the diagnosis and the recommended solutions. The text is based on a well-known but still relevant observation: the CAP, despite the budgetary envelope at its disposal, is misguided. It is at the service of productivist and intensive agriculture rather than family farming, promotes export competition rather than short circuits and weakens territorial cohesion and ecosystems. The CAP must be reformed to respond to these ecological and social challenges (1/5 of European farms disappeared between 2007 and 2013), but also to initiate a strategy of generational renewal - those under 35 currently only represent 7% of farms. The solutions exist but are neglected by the liberal right at the helm of Europe: better market regulation, increased support for small farms, promotion of the circular economy. This report marks a turning point towards more political voluntarism in agriculture.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I abstained on the report on 'How can the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) improve job creation in rural areas'.This report contains a number of provisions criticizing the EU's ongoing negotiations on free trade agreements TTIP, CETA, MERCOSUR.I believe that free trade agreements can open up particularly large and lucrative US, Canadian, South American markets for our farmers' products.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report provides a critical look at EU agricultural policy. In an integrated approach, it considers that the “development of the agricultural sector is also linked to the diversification and maintenance of other economic activities, such as forestry and handicrafts, and to the development of small and medium-sized enterprises and capacities of integrated production, rural tourism, recreational, educational and sports activities ”. This promotes a model based on small farms rather than agro-industry. The report also underlines that “trade agreements under negotiation such as the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), the Union-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) and the Free Trade Agreement EU-Mercosur threatens employment and the creation of favorable conditions for farmers ”. Finally, the report calls for the common agricultural policy (CAP) to "support organic and biodynamic agriculture more effectively". I vote for this text

name: Susanne Melior (S&D)
text: written.- Focusing on company sizes is not expedient.The assumption that smaller structures generally create more stable economic conditions has not been proven.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I could not support the text that was put to a vote, as it would have limited the Union’s ability to gain access to new markets for the Union’s agricultural products through free trade agreements.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: written. - In the context of the common agricultural policy, it is up to the Commission to develop initiatives that provide a solution to the crises in agriculture while generating sustainable employment in agricultural holdings. After all, our European agriculture has sufficient assets to aspire to a leading position in the world market. To achieve this objective, sufficient resources will have to be allocated to promote innovation in agriculture and rural policy. A better distribution of CAP payments to the smaller companies, adapting intervention prices to changes in cost prices as well as shorter supply chains and the promotion of our excellent food quality systems and our renowned European gastronomy on the world market can create a favorable dynamic and generate sustainable employment in rural areas. Despite some good elements in the report aimed at supporting small and family businesses, I did not approve the report in the final vote because the negative references to trade agreements such as CETA and TTIP show great fatalism. The international trade agreements should be seized precisely as an opportunity to promote the assets of our European agriculture and the exports of our unique agricultural products and to support employment opportunities in agriculture.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing. - Rural areas occupy more than 77% of the EU's territory and many jobs in these areas depend on agriculture and the food industry. Within the EU's common agricultural policy, it is important to maintain its 2 pillars. The first pillar prevents the outflow of small and family farms from the sector and preserves jobs in the agricultural sector; funding from the second pillar ensures job creation in other areas, such as tourism, food processing and others. The crisis that has hit Europe has affected rural areas the most. In order to prevent, it is necessary to promote the diversity of agricultural systems. Small and medium-sized enterprises, which are more innovative, highly flexible and often better organized in the form of producer groups, are more resilient during a crisis and able to adapt more easily to its consequences; at the same time, they benefit local communities, thus helping to support the rural economy. The challenge for the future post-2020 CAP must be to simplify procedures and provide sufficient financial coverage. More attention must be paid to modernization and investment. Rural development contributes directly to job creation. It is therefore essential that Member States, through their local authorities, contribute to the objectives of the CAP by using the available resources it offers. Rural development and operational programs can be used to create jobs, maintain them and improve services in rural areas.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development reports that rural areas cover more than 77% of the EU's territory and that many jobs in these areas depend on agriculture and the agri-food industry. Agriculture and the agri-food industry account for 6% of EU GDP, representing 15 million businesses and 46 million jobs. He points out that the economic crisis has hit rural areas hardest, and that these areas have seen an unprecedented decline due to austerity policies. The report urges a change in light of the fact that in 2014, 13% of beneficiaries received 74% of CAP direct payments. As small farms are more labor-intensive and 53% of farm workers work on farms classified as small, this obviously does not help job creation within agricultural production. Looking to the future, the report advocates modernization and investment, and attributes an important role to tourism in solving the problems of the countryside. Advocates that direct payments under the CAP should be limited to those whose main activity is agriculture, and states that, in future, CAP resources should provide more support to slow down the closure of small and medium-sized farms and enterprises in producer organizations; . I voted in favor of the draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing.- This own-initiative report presents several positive points: efficient support for small and medium-sized farms, defense and promotion of PDOs and PGIs, local priority in markets and employment, questioning of free trade treaties (intheir agricultural components), willingness to reuse market price regulation tools, etc.Despite everything, this report was polluted by the opinions of the FEMM and EMPL committees, which therefore incorporated the usual demands on migrants and gender issues.In this regard, paragraph 77 which promotes the social and economic integration of migrants and refugees (and their wives) in rural employment is demagogic, irrelevant and therefore unacceptable, a fortiori in a double context of the crisis ofagriculture and employment.For this reason, and despite the elements of agreement, the vote will be against.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. - In recent decades, in many European countries, we have seen the exodus of farmers from rural areas and a drastic reduction in the incomes of farmers and other agricultural workers and that employment in agriculture is constantly declining. I endorse the rapporteur's position in asking Member States to give young farmers long-term perspectives to tackle the depopulation of rural areas, to implement a comprehensive strategy of renewing generations and, to this end, to make full use of all the possibilities foreseen under the new CAP to support young farmers and newly installed farmers, including outside the family framework, namely through the provision of aid to young farmers under the first and second pillars, as well as to facilitate the installation in the agricultural sector and the entrepreneurial spirit of farmers over 40 years old. I defend the need to encourage the development, commercialization and sale of high quality agricultural products and to carry out initiatives aimed at opening new markets, as well as introducing operational programs and product marketing campaigns, in order to guarantee diversification and the competitiveness of the European food chain.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which offers a positive narrative on how the CAP can be a force for employment generation in rural areas, both in farming and beyond. The report addresses the question of falling rates of employment in the primary sector following the advances in intensification of European agriculture. The report also presents a range of tools to stimulate employment beyond agriculture. Importantly, the report points out the role of local, bottom-up initiatives such as the LEADER approach which can galvanise the support of local communities and help orientating public funds where they could be most effective in enhancing entrepreneurship and employment generation. It also emphasises the role of women in rural areas as well as a contribution from non-agricultural sectors, such as forestry and tourism.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted against this report on the contribution of the CAP to employment in rural areas.Indeed, this report further exposes the vision that the Socialist rapporteur has of the common agricultural policy instead of truly proposing solutions in terms of promoting employment, crisis management, rebalancing aid between farms and territories andsupport for niche producers.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing.- I am a big fan of the common agricultural policy, I have always supported the idea of providing consumers with safe and sufficient food at a constant and affordable price, while providing a livelihood for farmers.I know agriculture first-hand, as it plays a very important role in my country, Slovakia as well.Nevertheless, I was forced to reject the report presented in plenary.The report has been very one-sided, it deeply criticizes the common agricultural policy, which has worked well so far, and it would introduce a completely new system.International trade agreements are important to the European Union, which this report completely ignores.Surely the current common agricultural policy also has shortcomings that we want to correct in the future, but the proposal before us today was not really acceptable to me.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In 1962 the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) was introduced, implementing a system of agricultural subsidies and other programmes. I have voted for this report regarding the improvement of CAP for the creation of new jobs in the rural areas that calls on Member States to offer young farmers long-term prospects to address the issue of rural depopulation, stresses that a large part of CAP direct payments are going to big farms and encourages the Member States to step up their support for small and medium-sized farms.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: signed up.- I decided to vote in favor of this report on the CAP and how it can create quality jobs in rural areas, because it is an extremely important topic for Romania as well.It is essential that the Common Agricultural Policy supports farmers and farmers, but at the same time, a step forward is needed to increase support for investment that creates jobs.The problem of labor market supply in rural areas is one that we face in all Member States, and Romania is no exception.In the context in which the area of agricultural areas is in constant competition with development and areas declared protected, I believe that the CAP must give more support to the sustainable development of agriculture, always with a view to creating quality jobs.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report.Despite the socialist to planned economy approaches, financial aid would also be made available to farmers in Austria, especially smallholders.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- Impartial.The aim of the report is to look at what is causing rural unemployment and emigration from the countryside to the city, and whether there is any way the CAP can change this process.I abstained because, however, the report did not set out solutions that could help with these problems.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report.It is indeed important, in the context of the forthcoming reform of the common agricultural policy, to make it an instrument at the service of employment.Tools to regulate the markets and fight against price volatility must therefore be put in place.Finally, I broadly share the stated objective of the report, which is to "re-territorialize" agriculture around short circuits and the circular economy.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose this because of its lack of realism in understanding both how markets work and the current fiscal climate.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing.- While taking into consideration the aspects presented in the document relating to the possible effects that the CAP may have in rural areas and while noting the importance of the aforementioned topic, as well as the fundamental importance of maintaining the two pillars of the CAP with the aim of improvingcreation and, in particular, employment in rural areas, I do not believe, however, that the objections presented are complete and therefore I would not feel I can fully support them.Therefore, I would intend to abstain.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - The CAP can and must encourage job creation in rural areas. However, the CAP cannot replace the social policy that this report promotes. Food production and life in rural areas is not and must not be a social policy but must be a key economic policy to ensure a sufficient supply of healthy and quality food to Union consumers while guaranteeing a decent income for workers in the sector, not just crumbs from the rich powerful. I believe that the CAP should be developed in the direction of strengthening primary producers, establishing fair relations between stakeholders in the food supply chain and other measures aimed at production based on both traditional experiences and new technologies that must become available to family farms. Only empowered economies can become drivers of employment. Furthermore, trade agreements should be seen as an opportunity to further strengthen European agriculture, but at the same time domestic, European policies should be tailored to the specific needs of Member States to compete in the global market, such as the right to decide independently and unconditionally . As this report is vague in this segment, but also in some other components, I was reluctant to adopt it.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Agriculture represents a fundamental sector which, in addition to guaranteeing the production of food and other agricultural goods essential for our survival, also represents a fundamental lever for rural development aimed at preventing desertification and promoting territorial cohesion. However, it is important to underline first of all the quality of this job and the need to combat the growing job insecurity in this sector where seasonality often overrides the fundamental rights of those who work. It is important to underline that in order to contribute to job creation, the CAP must completely reverse its political orientation hitherto based on a liberalizing logic, all oriented towards markets. In this way, strong instruments for regulating production are needed which form and are being completely dismantled with the successive revisions of the CAP. It is important to intervene at the level of the distribution chain, imposing a fairer distribution of value creation, with fair prices paid to the producer. Finally, it is important to stop this succession of free trade agreements, either with Canada, with the United States or with the Mercosur countries that represent the ruin of our small and medium family farming.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing.- Although agriculture and the agri-food sector account for 6% of the European Union's GDP, interest in employment in this area is constantly declining.In many European countries, there has been a long-term outflow of labor from the agricultural sector and farmers' incomes are constantly falling.Therefore, a comprehensive strategy for overall generational renewal in agriculture needs to be put in place.It is necessary to make full use of all the possibilities that the CAP offers to support young and beginning farmers and to promote these possibilities more effectively.There is also a need to create opportunities for young farmers, for example in terms of access to land.Special attention needs to be paid to greater involvement of women.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing.- Unfortunately, in my vote on this report, I had to speak out against the proposal because, in addition to the positive elements, it also contains a number of moments with which I cannot agree in any way.As an example, the resolution contains a passage calling for 'policies' that will promote the positive impact of migration on the labor market.That, I think, is not the task of European Union policies.In my opinion, I am also bothered by the disproportionate criticism of free trade agreements.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. - We must question the political motivations behind this non-legislative initiative report, for which a large number of MEPs opposed, with also a high number of abstentions. The text is based on a systematic opposition of agricultural models, thus offering an unrealistic view of agriculture, supposedly based on small farms folded in on themselves while European exports in agriculture are important. We have understood that the Socialist rapporteur used this report to propose a sort of overhaul of the CAP. However, his French socialist colleagues, and particularly Stéphane Le Foll, stood out for their ineffectiveness in carrying the voice of France to manage the unprecedented agricultural crisis that our country is experiencing. Promotion of employment, crisis management, rebalancing of aid between farms and support for niche productions are certainly priority and laudable objectives, but this text undermines the balance reached during the last reform of the CAP. Like many colleagues, including Michel Dantin, I opposed this text: it promotes a gas plant while our farmers demand that simplicity and stability be the watchwords of agricultural policy.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. - Currently in the European Union (EU), rural areas represent more than 77% of the Community territory, and many jobs in these areas - a large percentage of them are not relocatable - depend on agriculture and the agri-food industry. Agriculture and the agri-food industry represent 6% of the EU's GDP, 15 million companies and 46 million jobs, and are therefore an important share in the European economy. It is true that many rural areas face a series of challenges, such as low incomes, negative population growth, lack of jobs and a high unemployment rate. Job creation in rural areas is one of the Union's challenges and this is considered in the provisions of the European Union's Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). I believe that this report addresses an important issue, however I disagree with some of the guidelines presented and, in my view, there are more appropriate approaches to promote job creation in rural areas. For the above, I am voting against this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose this because of its lack of realism in understanding both how markets work and the current fiscal climate.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted against, as this report gives a negative connotation to trade agreements (TTIP and CETA) instead of presenting concrete and realistic measures to combat unemployment in rural areas.Contrary to the report, agreements such as the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, the Global Economic and Trade Agreement between the EU and Canada and the Free Trade Agreement between the EU and Mercosur, do not pose a threat to the creation ofemployment and conditions to support subsistence agriculture.At the same time, it is noted in this report that its author intended to print the same an enormous ideological component, reducing what could be a good instrument for the Union and its farmers to a mere exercise of demagogy.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing.- Mr President, the Common Agricultural Policy must contribute more to the creation and long-term maintenance of jobs in rural areas and thus to combat unemployment and depopulation.Public services are needed in these areas, diversification of production, care for environmental aspects, creation of opportunities for women and young people, tourism opportunities, shorter food supply chains and fair treatment of primary producers.The report includes many measures to strengthen the social dimension.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report as I consider the debate on the need to redirect CAP aid to farmers with real agricultural activity and to job creation in European rural areas as positive. It is of special interest that the accent is placed on the incorporation and access to land of young people and women. The report also highlights the contribution of short supply chains in the creation of rural employment, emphasizing the importance of quality systems and Geographical Indications, due to the opportunities they generate for the development of the agri-food sector. The text assumes that farmers operate in an increasingly global market, recognizing, on the one hand, that in some rural areas employment may be threatened by lacking viable alternatives to the traditional agricultural model; while for other areas and sectors, such Agreements can offer great opportunities for economic development and employment. With this report the European Parliament opens the debate on how the CAP can contribute to reinforcing employment and maintaining population, with a view to the future Common Agricultural Policy post 2020.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this European Parliament resolution on how the common agricultural policy can improve job creation in rural areas.I share the opinion of the rapporteur of this resolution, which calls on Member States to be able to create future prospects for young farmers and to support small and medium-sized farms.I also supported this request to increase the possibility of granting coupled payments and to make this type of support more flexible.In line with these elements, but also with many other recommendations made in this resolution, I have decided to support it.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- Europe's rural areas are in crisis.In a crisis that manifests itself not only in fluctuating prices, uncovered farmers' incomes, abuse of intermediaries, but also in the rapidly declining number of people living in rural areas and working in agriculture.From 2000 to 2012Almost 5 million jobs have been lost in European agriculture.Instead of small farms, "mega-farms" are being set up.Is this the kind of European agriculture we want?As a shadow rapporteur, I can say that this report is very well drafted.It sets out a vision of what the European countryside needs from the current CAP reform and the new CAP.I can only emphasize that we need to make the European CAP more rural and quality food-friendly.We must also strive for a level playing field for farmers, in particular through the unification of direct payments.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: in writing. - Faced with the multiple crises facing the agricultural world, this report tackles the subject of the CAP and employment for the first time. He recommends making the CAP a real instrument at the service of employment, while guaranteeing healthy and accessible food to as many people as possible. The report proposes to support the installation of young farmers to promote the renewal of generations, but also to reactivate, by adapting them, the tools of market regulation and the fight against price volatility, and to put an end to laissez-faire. to make markets, devastating for farmers, employment and the economy of the territories. The objective is clear: to strengthen small and medium-sized farms in order to better support employment and sustainable development, as well as harmonious spatial planning. As the revision of the CAP approaches, this report makes it possible to lay the groundwork for an agricultural policy combining rurality and modernity: innovation, apprenticeship, professional training and collective organization must make it possible to respond to the challenges facing agriculture by the beginning of the 21st century! I voted for this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this report.The report is divided into two parts, a first part on the CAP currently in force and a second part on the 2020 CAP. The objective of this report is to influence the 2017 revision of the Common Agricultural Policy. Furthermore, the report forms a basissolid to deal with issues of capital importance such as depopulation in rural areas, lack of opportunities, falling employment, etc.The text emphasizes the importance of protecting small and medium-sized farmers and making the distribution of subsidies more proportional and fair.More specifically, it proposes that medium-sized family farms be the main beneficiaries of European agricultural aid.I have voted in favor of a CAP that really benefits family farms, that creates employment in rural areas and that diversifies the economy of our towns.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: written.- I voted against the report on job creation in rural areas through the CAP (Common Agricultural Policy).The report focuses exclusively on small farms, a very one-sided negative view of international trade agreements and the general desire to set up a completely new agricultural policy.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- This report supports small-scale agriculture, encourages support for young people to enter agricultural activity, better inclusion of women in agricultural activity and short circuits of production and consumption.He is also critical of free trade agreements and with the support of the CAP for the intensive industrial agricultural model.For all these reasons, I have voted in favor of it.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. - Agriculture in the outermost regions absorbs an important part of the active population and forms the basis of the regional economy, with positive externalities in other sectors, whether tourism or agro-industry. Due to its characteristics, the search for employment solutions in the outermost regions, in case of contraction of the economy, is compromised by the lack of interconnectivity. On the other hand, production costs in these regions are relatively higher than other areas on the continent. For these reasons, crises in the agricultural sector are having an exacerbated effect in these regions. We therefore call for agricultural policy to be equipped with the right instruments and, in the event of a crisis, to apply criteria adapted to the needs of the outermost regions. The Azores, the region where I come from, produce 30% of Portuguese milk and the last 2 years of crisis in the sector demonstrate the urgency of this need.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which explores how the CAP rules and budgetary spending can be optimised in order to enable this policy to play a bigger role in promotion of employment in the rural areas. It discusses the reasons driving rural depopulation and economic stagnation in the European countryside, induced partly by negative impacts of the intensification of farming and globalisation. An important positive contribution presented by this report focuses on highlighting the role of CAP’s rural development measures, local initiatives and approaches (including LEADER) and measures to strengthen rural-urban links. The report also explores solutions to enhance rural entrepreneurship and diversification of economic activity away from farming, including through innovation, improvements in rural infrastructure and public services, etc. Moreover, the report calls for action in favour of integrating rural communities more strongly thanks to tools addressed specifically to migrant workers and women in order to improve their often more disadvantaged situation in rural economies.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - Total agricultural employment in Europe has fallen by 25% over the last ten years, with a total loss of 3.7 million jobs (Eurostat 2010). Unfortunately, the number of farmers in rural areas, which account for more than 77% of the EU's territory, has also fallen dramatically in many European countries in recent decades. I supported the resolution because I believe that only more effective measures can provide citizens with better living and working conditions in rural areas, which will ultimately provide all families with reasons to stay there and lead a successful life. I come from the countryside and I find that the importance of working in the agricultural sector is becoming increasingly marginal and the presence of young people is constantly declining. That is why I consider it particularly important for young people to be at the heart of the future common agricultural policy (CAP), because without stronger support, agriculture in rural areas has no future. I think it is necessary to restore the prestige to the profession of agriculture and farmer and to guarantee young people an adequate income that will provide them with sufficient security.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - Where the direct payments from the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) help and support farmers to stay active, they also lead to increased concentration, scaling-up of business operations and a number of super-industrial companies that rely very heavily on chemical inputs and monocultures and hardly create any employment. This report draws attention to this. Between 2000 and 2012, 4.8 million jobs in the sector were lost in Europe. Small businesses are more labor-intensive, yet we see that resources are not always equitably distributed. The report calls for greater benefits to be given to small and medium-sized farms after 2020. Now 13% of companies receive 74% of the funds. Furthermore, the administration around the CAP must be simplified, and the second pillar rural development must be strengthened, so that as many jobs as possible can be created. Services and infrastructure in rural areas must be sound, so that it is attractive for people to live and work there. Solutions go towards short-chain initiatives, organic farming, diversification - in the field of tourism, renewable energy production or farm shops - or investments in sustainable agricultural models. During the vote some strengths were lost, but the main message remains, so I voted in favor.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- The European Union's common agricultural policy needs to be fundamentally reformed, because instead of cohesion between agro-sectors, it discriminates against farmers in the new Member States.In the future, we must focus more on more efficient production, including with the latest technical means, the elimination of pointless direct payments and the promotion of sales from the court.With a set of measures that will increase competitiveness and take into account the real situation and potential of the agro-sector, we can significantly reduce rural depopulation and support the growth of jobs and wages in European agriculture.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report on how the CAP can improve job creation in rural areas. This report attempts to touch on an extremely wide range of issues surrounding agriculture. Whether substantial, such as subsidies, unemployment, impact of trade deals, environmental regulation, or irrelevant i.e. gender equality. Regardless of one’s position on these various issues, I firmly believe that this report should be rejected on its haphazard, confused, and seemingly random ‘pick ‘n’ mix’ approach. Regulators are still captured by the false illusion that they can wave a magical legislative hand as if they were a Pharaoh and say ‘So let it be written. So let it be done.’

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I abstained from voting on the report: How the common agricultural policy can increase job creation in rural areas.Rural areas account for more than 77% of the European Union's territory, while agriculture and the agri-food industry together account for 6% of EU GDP.Unfortunately, we missed the opportunity for a good report, as this report focuses mainly on political debate and goes in the wrong direction.Of course, we all support additional jobs, but we cannot support biased opposition to trade agreements, which will, above all, revitalize the European economy and bring new jobs.The agreement with Canada is an example of how we will secure our excellence in agriculture.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing.- The Common Agricultural Policy must protect farmers from international free trade agreements.At the same time, it should promote the simplification of bureaucratic procedures and strengthen regional identity and tradition in the agricultural sector.It must promote youth participation in agricultural production and give priority to remote, mountainous and coastal areas.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because I believe that one of the most important objectives of the common agricultural policy is to create jobs in rural areas. Unfortunately, we have seen a significant drop in employment in these areas in recent decades, especially in the regions of Eastern and Central Europe. This was despite the fact that a number of job creation measures have been introduced with the help of various funds. In my opinion, effectiveness in some Member States is hampered by overt government corruption, so that resources for job creation are not able to change the situation effectively. Cooperatives for small farms must be supported, agricultural employment must be made attractive and this must be done with the interests of young people in mind. The future of rural areas does not only depend on agriculture, I agree that farms must be diversified in order to achieve sustainable business development and that young people and women must be involved as much as possible. By providing basic services and connectivity, it is possible to retain the population and avoid depopulation. The direction in which we start can be determined at the level of maximum guidelines, and real solutions must be given space for bottom-up initiatives. Member States should introduce more targeted measures to create jobs in rural areas, with strong central control.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - The rural area of ​​the EU Member States has been one of the hardest hit by the financial and economic crisis in recent years. It has also created a false impression that in the future the rural area will not be as important, forgetting that it generates most of the food of the inhabitants of the cities. The Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) is intended to prevent this negative trend and ensure the sustainable development of those areas. In this context, the First Pillar of the CAP can help to support sectors that generate a large number of jobs, helping to maintain rural producers. At the same time, coupled payments could be supplemented by the introduction of a maximum ceiling of € 150,000, mainly to support young entrepreneurs and women entrepreneurs. The Second Pillar of the CAP can support rural development and job creation, including by encouraging rural tourism and other areas related to agriculture. In this way, the current depopulation of rural areas, which would become more attractive to young entrepreneurs and better connected to the dynamics of the European economy, could be avoided. I support this commendable initiative.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted for the report by my eminent colleague Andrieu.It is indeed necessary to create future prospects for young farmers in order to provide a response to the rural exodus;implement a global strategy for the renewal of generations;and, to do this, make full use of all the possibilities offered by the new CAP to support young farmers and those who have just settled down, including outside the family framework, in particular through measures to support young farmers in the firstand second pillar, as well as by facilitating the installation and creation of businesses by newcomers aged over 40.Measures relating to national policies (land policy, fiscal and social policy, etc.) must complement the provisions in question, with which they must be compatible.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ For a long time, EU rural areas have been suffering from high unemployment rates and depopulation. The report seeks to find out what are the options and possibilities that the Common Agricultural Policy can offer to improve the situation in rural areas, particularly for farmers. European Rural Development is one of the main tools to help to make rural areas more attractive for living there. Although the subject matter is pertinent, I voted to reject the report based on the very poor quality of content, which I felt lacked much added value with regards to proposing viable solutions to improve the unemployment situation in rural areas.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: in writing. - While there have been many debates on agricultural policy since the 1957 Treaty of Rome, the aspect of its relationship to employment had never been addressed until Eric Andrieu's report. Between 1957 and today, the agricultural population has grown from 20% to 4% of the total labor force in the European Union and more than one in five farms disappeared in the EU between 2007 and 2013. L he analysis by Eric Andrieu, which I share, shows that the CAP, by promoting the outsourcing of production and the concentration of farms, has had a significant negative impact on employment in rural areas and on family farming . The report calls for a new social contract between farmers and citizens which transforms the CAP into a real instrument at the service of employment, but also at the service of healthy food accessible to as many people as possible. It should also allow the installation of young farmers, to ensure the renewal of farms. In this sense, small and medium-sized farms, which represent a very large share of production and are the most efficient in terms of jobs and sustainable development, deserve specific attention.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: in writing. - Together with my Hungarian People's Party MPs, I was forced to reject the Andrieu report on the relationship between the common agricultural policy and job creation. I did so despite the fact that the text proposes a strong and well-financed common agricultural policy, an objective that is fully in line with the interests of Hungarian farmers. However, provisions have also been included in the report which would jeopardize the future financing of the CAP. Paragraphs 21 and 77 of the report propose that we also support social and demographic projects from agricultural sources. It is extremely important to us that the resources of the common agricultural policy actually go to farmers. Therefore, we must not allow direct or compulsory development funds to be used to cover crises caused by social and demographic change, either on a voluntary or compulsory basis. Funding for social issues does not have a place in the common agricultural policy, which is why in 2013 EU support for the most deprived people came out of this policy. Unfortunately, the same proposal has been included in the planned amendment to EU legislation on the Structural Funds and the backbone of the CAP, the so-called omnibus package. Here, too, we will take consistent action to prevent the withdrawal of Structural Funds, including rural development funds, even on a voluntary basis.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of Mr Andrieu's report.I share the view that the common agricultural policy should facilitate job creation in rural areas.The economic development of these areas needs to be analyzed and understood in relation to their social and demographic development.Therefore, more support is needed for families living in rural areas and the search for new solutions in the labor market, for example through greater promotion of services in the agricultural sector.The CAP is one of the most important instruments that should be used for this purpose, so that European agriculture can emerge from the unprecedented crisis that is currently taking place.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written.- I agree that the CAP after 2020 should be given great importance to instruments intended for modernization and investment that guarantee the competitiveness of economic sectors located in rural areas.I believe that the development of a competitive and sustainable agricultural model based on family, diverse and multifunctional farming has no alternative.I also support the call for Member States to develop tools for better land surveillance and regulation.The report also emphasizes that direct payments under the CAP should be granted only to those persons whose main area of activity is agriculture, with which I fully agree.Since the average European farmer cultivates 12 hectares of land and 70% of farms cultivate an area of less than five hectares, it is logical that the focus of the CAP should be small farms.So I voted in favor.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I did not support the motion for a resolution on how the common agricultural policy can increase job creation in rural areas, as I believe that the report highlights good things, but due to some votes with which I cannot agree, I could not support the report . Rural areas make up more than 77% of the EU's territory, which also means that there are many jobs that are often unrelocated and are linked to agriculture and the food processing industry. Agriculture and the agri-food industry together account for 6% of the European Union's GDP, 15 million companies and 46 million jobs. Labor input in agriculture in the EU-28 fell by almost a quarter (-23.6%) between 2005 and 2014. In order to maintain jobs on farms, the sector will need to use new risk management tools and make greater use of tools such as producer organizations under the Single CMO and the second pillar in order to better respond to volatility and requirements. global market. In future, further vocational training for farmers and agricultural workers will need to be encouraged and scientific knowledge and innovation disseminated in order to ensure adaptability to the changing environment and to facilitate economic activities.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this report.The report is divided into two parts, a first part on the CAP currently in force and a second part on the 2020 CAP. The objective of this report is to influence the 2017 revision of the Common Agricultural Policy. Furthermore, the report forms a basissolid to deal with issues of capital importance such as depopulation in rural areas, lack of opportunities, falling employment, etc.The text emphasizes the importance of protecting small and medium-sized farmers and making the distribution of subsidies more proportional and fair.More specifically, it proposes that medium-sized family farms be the main beneficiaries of European agricultural aid.I have voted in favor of a CAP that really benefits family farms, that creates employment in rural areas and that diversifies the economy of our towns.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ 13% of beneficiaries receive 74% of the expenses for direct payment of the CAP, which does not contribute to job creation in the agricultural sector, as small farms have a higher level of intensity of labour. It is essential that Member States redistribute payments to benefit small and medium-sized farms. Long-term strategy is needed for young people to see that they can live in rural areas and avoid the current depopulation. It would be good to establish recommendations for each Member State, because each one has a specific reality. It’s a good idea to diversify aid, also for renewable energy in the field. I support this proposal so that it can serve to change things that do not work properly. Agriculture is a key sector in our countries and we must protect and help it to have a good future.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
