text: written.- I voted in favor of this report.The report is divided into two parts, a first part on the current CAP and a second part on the 2020 CAP. The objective of this report is to influence the 2017 revision of the Common Agricultural Policy. Furthermore, the report constitutes a basissolid to deal with issues of capital importance such as depopulation in rural areas, lack of opportunities, falling employment, etc.The text emphasizes the importance of protecting small and medium-sized farmers and making the distribution of subsidies more proportional and fair.More specifically, it proposes that medium-sized family farms be the main beneficiaries of European agricultural aid.I voted in favor of a CAP that really benefits family farms, that creates jobs in rural areas and that diversifies the economy of our towns.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on how the CAP can improve job creation in rural areas. Although agriculture remains the main form of land use in Europe, it nowadays employs only a fraction of the working population of rural areas; whereas the diversification of land use in rural areas, combining a productive economic function with the functions of accommodating residential and recreational use and of nature protection and conservation, is a considerable challenge in terms of development and employment in the various rural regions of the Union. The report calls on all the Member States to give young farmers long-term prospects in order to address rural depopulation, to implement a comprehensive generational renewal strategy and, in order to do this, to make full use of all the possibilities provided under the new CAP to support young farmers and new entrants to farming, including from outside the family. I voted in favour because I believe that there is a need for additional support for agriculture and for the creation of agricultural jobs in less favoured areas and in areas on the EU’s external borders.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- This report supports small-scale agriculture, encourages support for young people to enter agricultural activity, better inclusion of women in agricultural activity and short circuits of production and consumption.He is also critical of free trade agreements and with the support of the CAP for the intensive industrial agricultural model.For all these reasons, I have voted in favor of it.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The economic crisis has hit young people particularly hard. The disparity between certain categories of young people has also grown, while some of them have increasingly lost their place in social and civil life. This situation is further aggravated by the fact that, in some cases, there is a risk of social passivity, exclusion and isolation and even violent radicalisation. I voted in favour of the report which provides a relevant assessment of the actions undertaken by the EU in the field of youth policy and gives positive recommendations on the priorities for the next few years, focusing on education and training, employment and entrepreneurship, health and welfare, participation, volunteering, social inclusion, youth and the world, creativity and culture.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted for this report because the focus here on small farmers was paramount.For the most part, the European Parliament voted out the amendments that incorrectly referred to negative effects that CETA (the free trade agreement with Canada) would have on employment.It is good that the European Parliament is paying attention to small farms and that we as the EU want them to have a future too.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report is based on the observation that the economic crisis is particularly striking in rural areas and even more so in areas with geographical handicaps. To remedy this, it calls on States to increase support for the cultivation of plant proteins (for which the EU depends on imports from third countries) and for the cultivation of local species (which contributes to the protection of the biodiversity). It also calls for promoting short supply chains and developing quality systems, geographical indications and organic farming, which share the same localized logic. These are all proposals that I welcome, as well as the affirmation, which is particularly welcome in the current context, of the "positive role of migration in stimulating economic growth and social cohesion in rural areas". I would nevertheless like to express my disappointment (but not my surprise) that recital T of the version submitted to the vote, which underlined the negative consequences that the TTIP, as the Commission itself admits, could have on rural areas by harming in fact to traditional agriculture, was deleted from the text by a vote of the PPE, S & amp; D and ALDE groups. I nevertheless voted in favor.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Agriculture represents a fundamental sector which, in addition to guaranteeing the production of food and other agricultural goods essential for our survival, also represents a fundamental lever for rural development aimed at preventing desertification and promoting territorial cohesion. However, it is important to underline firstly the quality of this job and the need to combat the growing job insecurity in this sector where seasonality often overrides the fundamental rights of those who work. It is important to underline that in order to contribute to job creation, the CAP must completely reverse its political orientation hitherto based on a liberalizing logic, all oriented towards markets. In this way, strong instruments for regulating production are needed which form and are being completely dismantled with the successive revisions of the CAP. It is important to intervene at the level of the distribution chain, imposing a fairer distribution of value creation, with fair prices paid to the producer. Finally, it is important to stop this succession of free trade agreements either with Canada, with the United States or with the Mercosur countries that represent the ruin of our small and medium family farming.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- The report makes useful proposals to encourage smallholders through better sharing of payments under the CAP and encourages Member States to better support SMEs by making more use of the redistributive payment.It is also right to point out that short supply chains can link regional farmers and local producers and encourage job creation in rural areas.I therefore approved the report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which offers a valuable contribution to the debate on how public support can best reflect the needs of rural economies. It addresses the question of falling rates of employment in the primary sector following the advances in intensification of European agriculture. The report also introduces a range of tools to stimulate employment beyond agriculture. Importantly, the report points out the role of local, bottom-up initiatives such as the LEADER approach which can galvanise the support of local communities and help orientate public funds where they could be most effective in enhancing entrepreneurship, and employment for the young generation, for example. The report also emphasises the role of women in rural areas as well as the unique contribution from non-agricultural sectors, such as forestry, arts and tourism to the sustainability of remote communities.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution on the Common Agricultural Policy because it contains some very interesting points to create a more efficient and well-managed CAP. We need to look at how we can reduce the level of administrative burden, especially for our SMEs. We also underline the positive effects farmers have in our rural areas, and how they create sustainable local jobs. Agriculture is a vital sector, which is also increasingly being modernised and made more efficient. I believe we should continue in this direction.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing.- The text presented correctly reflects the depopulation of the countryside and the need for generational change.I also appreciate that the report states that most direct payments under the common agricultural policy go to the richest farms and that this situation does not contribute to the desired effect of job creation.The report also draws attention to the bee ecosystem and acknowledges that they are at risk throughout the EU.Therefore, supporting this industry, which, moreover, does not require large investments, is crucial for food security.Despite this good intention, I had to vote against, because the report goes beyond the positives with its negatives.Discrimination, whether positive or negative, is a bad principle.Not to mention the violation of the principle of equality before the law in favoring certain groups of the population.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: in writing. - The report seeks to conceal how the CAP strengthens capitalist agricultural enterprises and eradicates poor farmers. The EU's goal is to increase competitiveness and entrepreneurship in the agricultural sector as well, through economic growth. The report is revealing: "The vast majority of direct payments go to the richest farms, with only 13% of beneficiaries receiving 74% of direct CAP direct payments in 2014." Despite the report's inexpensive wishes for "small, family farms", this is the result of EU and government policy: the extermination of hundreds of thousands of poor farmers. This is supported by the report, which is based on the premise that the CAP must be "market-oriented" and argues that its direct aid "should only be distributed to people whose main activity is agriculture". The measures for the strengthening of the second pillar of the CAP (business, agritourism, "green" agriculture, etc.) are part of the same logic. The only way out for the poor peasants is their struggle against poverty and cleansing, it is the path of popular power, for the socialization of capitalist agricultural holdings, for the satisfaction of the popular needs, food and industry materials.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - This report addressed in particular the question of how the use of existing CAP instruments for job creation can be improved. According to this report, the solutions focused mainly on making the agricultural environment more attractive so that it would attract new businesses and thus create new jobs. At the same time, the rapporteur used the report as an opportunity to point out shortcomings, in particular strong support for dominant types of agriculture through existing instruments. Although I agreed with some elements of this report, in particular the calls to simplify the common agricultural policy and thus ease the situation for small farmers, as well as the calls for better access to services in agricultural areas and a focus on research and innovation, on the other side contained many elements with which I disagree. For example, the report intervened in the areas of taxation, social rights or other issues that fall within the exclusive competence of the Member States. This violated the principle of subsidiarity, which is why I decided to vote against the report as a whole.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of the Andrieu report because I agree with the need to make full use of all the possibilities provided for under the new CAP for the creation and retention of jobs in rural areas, as well as to combat unemployment and population decline.I highlight the proposal to adopt a specific strategy for the restocking of honey bees, not only because of the potential that this sector represents in rural areas in terms of jobs, but also because of the need to recover a declining sector that has known a high rateof mortality of honey bees, with harmful consequences for food security.Finally, given that the vast majority of direct CAP payments have been found to be for the wealthiest farms, I advocate a more equitable distribution of CAP payments to small farmers.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - For more than a decade, in most European countries, we have been witnessing the depopulation of rural areas. The local economies of these areas are found to be increasingly weak with a consequent drastic decrease in the job opportunities offered in these territories. The CAP, the EU's common policy, is part of this framework, designed to be the main lever for reviving the economies in rural areas. But reality shows a different picture. The CAP fails to use its full potential to make rural areas job-rich. With this report, to which I voted in favor, we are proposing in a concrete way to find solutions to the problems and challenges posed by these areas. It is emphasized here that the future of rural areas does not depend only on the development of the agricultural sector but is synergistically linked to the diversification of other economic activities such as forestry, crafts, the development of small and medium-sized enterprises, and rural tourism. It is necessary to invest in local infrastructures, encourage young people to take up rural jobs and reconvert the over 40s in order to recreate an economy that favors the repopulation of these areas.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I did not support the motion for a resolution on how the common agricultural policy can increase job creation in rural areas.Agriculture and the agri-food industry together account for 6% of the European Union's GDP, 15 million companies and 46 million jobs.The findings show that the number of farmers in rural areas has fallen sharply in the last few decades in many European countries, and the income of farmers and other agricultural workers is declining, and the number of jobs in agriculture continues to decline.I believe that it will be necessary to encourage further vocational training for farmers and agricultural workers and to ensure the dissemination of scientific knowledge and innovation in order to ensure adaptability to the changing environment and to facilitate the pursuit of economic activities.As the report does not provide a concrete and effective response to the current challenges in the agricultural sector, I did not support it.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: This concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the switch from summer to winter time (2016/2951 (RSP)).

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on Sunday, 30 October 2016, the Union will switch back to winter time in a harmonised manner as required under Directive 2000/84/EC. Allow me to remind you of the background of the summer- and winter-time arrangements and the reason why these arrangements exist.  Summer time was introduced by most Member States in the 1970s as a response to the energy crisis. Also, governments wanted to provide people with more leisure opportunities by making the most of daylight time. With the emergence of the internal market and as Member States began to apply different summer- time start and end dates, it became clear that a harmonised approach for summer-time arrangements in the EU was essential.  Transport, in particular, would be among the many direct beneficiaries since such a harmonised approach would ensure smooth transport operations and coordinated timetables for cross-border and international transport. Therefore, it was decided to harmonise the dates of the application of summer time in the EU in a Directive in 1980.  The latest Directive adopted in 2001 imposed the application of summer time for an indefinite time. We are aware of different studies from various external sources. So far, there are no conclusive arguments to be gained from them. This concerns any possible effects either way, whether they relate to people’s health, energy savings, agriculture or transport.  In 2014 the Commission carried out a study to look closely at the potential effects of not having harmonised summer time in the EU in the context of the internal market. The study examined the effects of Member States applying different summer-time arrangements. The study includes scenarios of abolishing summer time in one or more Member States. It did not look into the savings or costs that would result from abolishing the harmonised approach to summer time for the European Union as a whole.  Based on the evidence from some of these studies, however, we are convinced that a shift away from a harmonised approach has the potential to inconvenience large numbers of people, most visibly in the transport and communications sectors.  Recently the Commission received a letter from seven of the honourable Members of this Parliament. Those honourable Members asked the Commission to evaluate the functioning of the Summer-time Directive and to consider abolishing it. The Commission replied that it intends to examine the issue more closely and will analyse the impact of current arrangements in Member States based on available evidence.  Work has already started on this analysis. It would be premature to go into further detail at this stage, but it would be interesting to hear specific views and evidence from Parliament.

name: Herbert Reul
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues! I'm sorry: these are now no answers to any of the three questions we asked. I think that's not fair. We have been doing this for months now, for ages. We ask questions, there are never answers. What you said - now you are not the Commissioner responsible and you have to fill a role for which you are not responsible, but the answer is always the same: we want a harmonized procedure. I don't know anyone who doesn't want that. We also all want the same procedure in all European countries. It can't be different. But we would like someone to finally investigate whether the allegations - which we are familiar with and for which there are investigations - whether or not the change in time that is carried out twice a year has disadvantages. There is now a wealth of evidence for this. I also do not understand why the Commission simply does not take note of this or denies it, or, if it thinks that this is wrong, then it should put its own investigations on the table in the House. We have talked to sleep researchers, we have talked to transport companies, we have talked to representatives of the agricultural sector, and we know that this time change twice a year does have an impact on people's health, and indeed a negative one - not all, but on several. I think that if a lot of people - no matter how many - feel negative effects, then there is no reason to do it twice a year, because there is no benefit from it. It was introduced back then because everyone believed that it would save energy. It is now clear: no energy is saved. That's crystal clear. If energy is not saved, why annoy people with such a change twice a year? It means Cost, it means health problems. I expect a commission that takes its task seriously and that otherwise takes action on every little thing, when damage to health is even on the horizon, and takes care that it does the same. We even have investigations in several Member States. In the Federal Republic of Germany there is a detailed report, in the Czech Republic there are reports, in several national parliaments people are starting to look into it, there are endless petitions in high percentages. People expect these concerns to be taken care of. It would be the simplest - if a measure like changing the time twice does not bring any benefit, but only harm, at least for a larger part of people - that the consequence is drawn and people say: Then we just leave it. We do not expect from you that you will accomplish great deeds somewhere, but the normal state should be restored: that one simply refrains from changing the time. Unless you provide evidence that there is no harm, no harm, but that all is well. So far nobody has delivered that. The answers that the Commission provides are always the same: we do not want to jeopardize the internal market, we want harmonized conditions between the Member States. We all agree with that. That is why one state cannot abolish and another introduce it; it must be done the same everywhere. Can you finally take this seriously, please?

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, yes, the services of the House have told me - they have just told me - that it is a record. And I hope that my colleagues forgive me because, really, I did not aspire to that much, and I would have perhaps preferred more than, yesterday, when we had the Annual Report of the Court of Auditors, they would have given me a few more minutes, and not these fifteen now. But anyway, I hope I don't bore you and, therefore, I ask your forgiveness in advance. It is true that, in the early morning of next Saturday to Sunday - in the early hours of Sunday - a change will occur while we sleep that apparently we will not notice while we sleep, but that, over the following weeks, we will notice. in a very important way. And it is precisely an accumulation of fatigue, due to that change in social jet lag that is being talked about, via lack of sleep or the change that has occurred in sleep, which, of course, does affect the health of our citizens and citizens. The cost has even been qualified and quantified - between the direct and indirect cost, we speak of 1% - of those health problems that we carry over the following weeks and months. In some cases, moreover, it has had an impact on road accidents that we already studied at the time when Directive 2000/84 / EC was put into effect. And in fact, not even the accidents increased in the following weeks, but the peak of the rise of the victims on the road was noticeable a month after the time change. Why? Because what accumulated was the chronic stress of lack of sleep that was causing it, which was when there was a situation of greater vulnerability in transportation after a month. In the Spanish case we even have an added peculiarity. Spain, in the 1940s, with Franco, adopted the time of Nazi Germany in 1942 and, since then, it has never changed it again. Just as the rest of the countries returned to the Greenwich meridian - which is the one that it would correspond to Spain—, in the Spanish case it was not done. Hence, every time since the adoption of the European Directive, change occurs, there are obviously important debates. And it is true that these days there has been a decision in the Balearic Parliament; There have also been decisions and debates especially in the part of the Valencian Community. These are regions, territories that live essentially from tourism, that is, services; very seasonal and have a lot to do with the hours of sunshine. Hence, even the hotel industry in the Mediterranean, in the Spanish part of the Mediterranean, has come to quantify that, in the week following the change to winter time, up to seven points are lost in hotel occupancy, precisely because of the drastic reduction of the hours of sunshine in the afternoon. In other words, it really does have an important effect and it is perceived in the economic and industrial part, in the part also of health and in the part - as I have also said - of road safety, which is so important. And although it is true that the Commission made us a study in 2014, the study was a bit of leaving it to the status quo. And I think that right now, given the demographics we have in the European Union, with diseases precisely due to that chronic stress of poor work or poor sleep or age, which is also making us increasingly vulnerable, the health aspect it is becoming more and more important. And of course, a change twice a year, that is, a social jet lag twice a year generates important effects on health. And that is what any study tells us, such as the one that was presented at last year's hearing, where precisely the need to add from the European Union - which we are no longer particularly popular - an added stress is taken into account for the purposes of that change. That is why it would be important for the Commission - as we have done in other areas - not only to carry out a study of how it affects in a scattered way, but also included the effect of the opposite, that is, what would happen if precisely there were not that change twice a year and, therefore, people could maintain that relationship with the biological clock but, above all , with the social clock. Added to this is also the need - and there I believe that the Commission has not given us sufficient figures either - to examine cross-border effects. Because it is true - I was present, I was not a Member, but I was in Parliament working with my group when the Directive was launched - that, in addition to the social, safety and health effects, it was proposed that harmonization - which it is a good thing, as Mr Reul said very well - it had to have a significant impact on the cross-border side. In other words, this harmonization should help the transport companies - which at that time were the most interested; now even transnational companies, transport, energy or other types of services—, which is why the “harmonization” aspect should prevail throughout the year over the “change” aspect. Therefore, the Commission should be able to offer us a study precisely on the need not to change, even if the harmonized situation remains. It is true that it is more complex to get all the Member States to agree to accept a single standard time and, thus, to be able not to change twice a year, but to maintain the one that is most positive for health, for safety, in end, for all economic aspects, but especially social and health. And maybe that's the challenge; that is, once we have done the test and have been harmonizing for many years, see how we could avoid an added change that adds only chronic stress to social stress. And there we are too - and then I go back to the Spanish case - because the debate never ends because we never have enough studies but, of course, When we have been able to go to Mars and go even further, the Commission says that it does not yet have the evidence, sufficient proof of that effect on health and in what way we could improve that situation, it is a bit incredible. In other words, right now we have studies of all kinds; Then, somehow, at some point, we will have to have the tests, the evidence in all sectors so that, to those for whom it is most positive, we can help them in some way, and where it is negative and where we see precisely that the health part is the one that prevails, of course being able to make another decision that does not affect the health of European citizens so much. And in that sense, returning home again, returning to Spain again, we have a rather complex situation right now in that debate, because, as if that were not enough, the double time zone we have in Spain - one for the peninsula and one for the Canary Islands—, the third possibility of going to a third time zone also joins the current debate, that is, that Spain would have three time zones: one for the Balearic Islands, one for the peninsula and another for the Canary Islands. We have reached that level precisely because of a debate that does not quite have the proof that we ask the Commission for. Commissioner - even if you are not the point of reference, because we were expecting Mrs Bulc - I think we certainly need the Commission to raise, take on its responsibilities and carry out a study - whatever it is; we agree, we agree with the Council, whatever it may be - to reach an agreement whereby citizens are not jolted twice a year when it comes to adapting their biological clock to the European clock. And above all because, of course, it is not in our interest as the European Union if it is the changes induced or promoted by the European Union and by the institutions that generate the most discomfort among European citizens. So I ask you very strongly, Commissioner, That the Commission adopt, as Mrs. Bulc told us last year, a really more systemic, holistic approach, and instead of giving us a study - which would be the umpteenth - on the different sectors, bits, etc., well, let it be atruly systematic approach where evidence to reconsider opinion is final.

name: Arne Gericke
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mister President! I was also a bit astonished that I suddenly turned up so early. Dear Commissioner Navracics! I can imagine what you are thinking right now: procedure same procedure as every year, James. ’Although you are here today on your behalf and may not feel that way at all. Together with some colleagues, I have once again put the question of switching between summer and winter time on the European Parliament's agenda. But not because we would like it or because we need this annual premium. No, we're discussing the time change again today because, despite complaints and input, nothing has changed over the years. We stand there year after year in April and October and ask each other with Paulchen Panther: Who turned the clock? In July last year I asked the European Commission: Can the Commission prove that the time change has added economic value? Are there any data on the desired energy savings through the introduction of the Central European Time? Does the Commission see a possibility of amending national legislation and international agreements between the Member States on the time change in a joint position so that artificial summer time will no longer apply across the EU? Does the EU Commission consider a European citizens' initiative on this subject to be possible in principle? Does the EU Commission have any findings on the negative health effects of summer time? Commissioner Navracsics, do you know what the officials' response was at the time? I want to tell you. I quote: "In 2014 the Commission commissioned a study on the harmonization of summer time in Europe" - as you have already mentioned. “The study led to the result that a non-harmonized application of summer time in the European Union was significant Cause inconvenience and disruption for citizens and businesses. In the light of the above, the Commission has no current plans to revise or repeal Directive 2000/84 / EC. ”Do you notice what? I ask about the possibility of a uniform abolition of summer time and you tell me that you want to leave it that way because different regulations are crap. But I hadn't asked about that at all. That is certainly not an option. We need a uniform solution, but it can also mean: no time change. Your officials ignored all other questions anyway: economic value, added value - no answer; Energy savings - no answer; health risks - no answer. These answers have been around for a long time. Countless expert reports confirm that the added value of summer time in terms of energy policy is zero. The economic added value tends to be negative, because the time change produces costs in the company. It gets worse with the health disadvantages. Just ask a mother or a father how the children are doing days after the clock change: sleepless, excited, sleepless! Many have problems at school and and and. All disadvantages, all reasons that speak against the clock change. So I ask again: answer my questions! Let's finally accept realities and get rid of this time change! It is high time - no one will miss her. Not even those who are not here today.

name: Gesine Meissner
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mister President! Commissioner, you are not to blame for the whole thing, we know that. We / you are not responsible, but you are in the Commission and that is why we naturally expect you to report back to the relevant Commissioners on what we are saying here. I think there is a great deal of unity in the room here - we are not that many; that's because it's Thursday afternoon. But I am sure we all speak in unison for all European citizens. We no longer want the time to be permanently changed. Most people don't want that. In Germany, according to the latest survey, 73% do not want that. I don't know why the others want that - but it doesn't matter. 73%, that's a clear majority. We have also had various initiatives from Parliament on this. There were joint hearings from various committees on which you expressed your views. And my colleague Arne Gericke quoted the 2014 study. However, you have only examined the question of whether the Member States would agree to the fact that the time change was abolished without agreeing on what the same new time is now. But we don't want that at all. We want it to be made uniform across Europe, that everyone really agrees on either winter or summer time - that would have to be agreed upon -; but that of course the time remains the same everywhere. When it was introduced in 1980 there were certain reasons why it was done - on a trial basis. You wanted to see if you could save energy, and you wanted to see if you could e.g. B. can reduce the accident rate. The fact is: energy savings are zero - as has already been said. You can see from 0.9% less to 1% more energy consumption, alternating between summer and winter time, so practically no effect at all. The accident rate is also not decreased - instead of late in the evening, the accidents are now early in the morning. So that also had no effect at all. So the purpose is clearly wrong - actually in all areas. On the contrary: In terms of health, many people - this has already been said -, especially the elderly and children, but also others, complain about difficulties: circulatory disorders, sleep disorders, heart problems, even depression - 12% get depression due to the clock change, which has been proven - 15% more Sick reports up to four weeks after the time change. These are all very serious things, and with the medication you have regularly, you also have problems. In the economy: The German construction industry, for example, lost EUR 30 million in sales last year due to changed lighting conditions in the construction sector - due to the time change, was calculated. There are problems with the timetables in rail transport, the cows give less milk. So there are a lot of areas where this is really the case. Then the Office for Technology Assessment of the German Bundestag, on behalf of the Bundestag, found out just this year: The framework conditions have changed significantly since the introduction of the time change: There are now other employment models; In the meantime there has also been a structural change in the energy sector; there is a different mobility and leisure behavior. In other words, they come to the conclusion that a reassessment is urgently needed - uniform throughout Europe - I will say that again. So my conclusion: I think that the eternal half-yearly back and forth between winter and summer time, we all no longer want that. It absolutely needs to be abolished, it is no longer appropriate, it is superfluous and it is even harmful. Please order this from your colleagues in the Commission!

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, we are talking today about the custom of changing the time twice a year; a custom already established by a European Directive in 1981, as the Government of Spain recently reminded the Parliament of the Balearic Islands, which this week voted in favor of maintaining the schedule without any change. As a curious fact, Roosevelt referred to this change as "the time of war", because it was established in the period of the world wars, with the aim of saving on coal. Of course, right now, in the middle of the European legislature, if the grand coalition continues to be reissued —as is happening in Spain—, turning the clock back one hour is going to seem rather little. And I do not say this by chance, but because this time change is made with one objective, which is energy saving or energy efficiency. To all this, we already have an Energy Efficiency Directive that, as you will recall, we recently revised and that, for very little, did not include binding targets for countries. And, in addition to this, the governments of the Member States are not making enough efforts to implement these energy efficiency measures, which is what it is all about, after all. And this should be a primary issue for economic reasons and to curb climate change. Now, we have to think: does this measure really save energy? This argument was based more on the old heavy industry, but the current reality is that the most energy-demanding industrial sectors may be operating 24 hours in a row, so the savings are not so noticeable - I repeat, this Directive is from 1981 -. The reality today is that the scientific community is not entirely in agreement with the savings that are being produced with this, which could be 5% or even as little as 1%. Some studies even say that this saving could occur only in the first days after the change of time, and then return to consumption similar to those before changing the time. The daily reality of citizens is that the energy savings that families make in the morning could be being spent in the afternoon. And this is also important, because we darken the natural light in the leisure and free time of most people, and this must be linked to the need for more dignified and consistent schedules to reconcile and end the working day earlier, enjoying life with light. By the way, there are 50 million people affected by energy poverty in Europe, and this is not discussed in this House. According to the WHO, the fact that households cannot afford heating leads to more illness, death and even fire danger. I believe that this is also an important issue for discussion in this House. We believe that it should be studied whether saving is currently sufficient, but above all, we must not waste time. There are many people who are not guaranteed access to electricity because of its costs and there are many ways to promote energy savings that are not debated or applied in the European Union, nor in the Member States.

name: Indrek Tarand
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I hope to be briefer than five minutes. Commissioner, there is actually no need to amend what was said by those colleagues who spoke earlier. They have provided all the scientific evidence and facts, and if it were for this Parliament to decide, even though we are not very large in numbers tonight, we are representing a much bigger group of MEPs. So, if it were for Parliament to take a decision, you would come back in the spring without switching your clock. That is what I say. The problem is that the Commission and the Council seem to live on a different continent, not on the continent which has given mankind great minds like Galileo or Copernicus, even though – ironically – we have European programmes and budget lines which are named after those guys. But we in the Commission and in the Council seem not to have understood their teaching, which is basically that the earth goes around the sun, not vice versa, and man is not God who can create more light, by just tickling their watches. It is impossible to create more light. Commissioner, you said that the EU introduced this measure as a response to the 1970s energy crisis. Yes, indeed, you are right. But actually, the measure was introduced as a part of wartime economics, as was pointed out by the previous speaker – by the German Empire, the Austro-Hungarian Empire, the Russian Tsarist Empire and the Ottoman Empire. Where are these empires today? They are not to be found, because they were wrong. Who introduced it again? Ah, two fellows, also famous in European history, Mr Hitler and Mr Stalin, because they also dreamed about how to have war on the continent. The first thing Hitler did in Belgium in 1940 was to tear down the Tricolore, put up the red banner – and switch the clock. The same happened months later in Estonia, but that was done by Stalin. So in my opinion, the European Union is not at war. Yes, indeed we have tremendously important crises which we have to deal with, but internally we are not at war. So it is at last time to stop the wartime economic measure. And you were right, pointing out that harmonised and coordinated management of time zones is very relevant from the internal market point of view and from many other aspects – transport, etc. But this is what we are telling you. We are not against coordination and harmonisation. We are just asking you to stop this toying with the clocks because, as was said by Ms Ayala Sender, it is harmful for children, it is harmful for the elderly, it causes traffic accidents, it is harmful for animals, be they pets or be they farm animals, because then again these guys who want to change the time twice a year destroy the quality of animal life. And as you know, Commissioner, we have many people within this Parliament who are fighting for animal rights. So finally, I think there will always be people who deny the laws of nature, and they believe that if we turn the clock, we get more light, particularly in the evenings. But you know, Galileo was also sentenced to death because he had discovered how the laws of nature work, and I hope – and I wish you good luck, Commissioner – that you will go back to your colleagues, to the responsible Commissioner, and ask them, by spring (because it is six months away), to come up with a meaningful proposal to stop this stupidity. It is that easy. And if you come back with that, we will welcome you. If you do not make a proposal, you had better tell them not to come. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: Question "blue card".- Mr Tarand, I know that in Estonia the sun rises very late and sets very early in winter.In most of the countries of Europe, when it comes to autumn, the sun is obviously less present.You said, Mr Tarand, that this increases the risk of accidents.Don't you think that the increase in the number of accidents is due more to weather conditions - given that frost is more frequent in October and, above all, November - than to the change in schedule?

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Tarabella, you are normally, as always, right: the ice and snow have an impact on traffic accidents and that is why normally in France and Belgium, when the winter comes, your drivers will be advised not to follow Estonian and Finnish drivers because they are used to ice, but you are not. The light is a limited amount. I mean, the more north you go there is a polar day and polar night and we cannot change it by switching clocks.

name: Julia Reid
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, we, the British, are time lords. We invented the time machine – HG Wells did that – and we invented Doctor Who, who used it to travel through all of time and space. So actually, we invented time itself in the form of Greenwich Meantime, the world standard and a world first. Once we had also invented the railway, we forced time standardisation, and it happened in my constituency. In the 1840s and 1850s, the best railway in the world – the Great Western Railway, engineered by the greatest engineer of his day, Isambard Kingdom Brunel – necessitated that a model of time zones be brought into the age of technology. In 1825, the fastest anyone could go was dictated by the speed of a horse – about 20 mph maximum, in very short bursts. Railways changed everything, and for the better. This is relevant because, as a scientist, I know that we need to be practical. What works best to meet the needs of ordinary people in a changing world? The answer is straightforward. Ordinary people want to maximise daylight and do as much as possible during the daylight hours. I want my country to take the lead again. We are, after all, the lords of time. We must determine rationally how we can absolutely maximise the availability of daylight for ordinary people and then apply it. Thus, once again, the rest of the world can follow our lead into a better, brighter, and (hopefully) a sunnier future, just as they should now over Brexit.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - It is unbelievable, but almost exactly a year ago, we had a debate here in the plenary of the European Parliament on the reasons why the alternation of summer and winter time should be abolished. However, after the Commissioner's speech, I see that we have not made progress on this matter even after a year. Let us realize that we are not just talking here about simplifying people's lives. We are talking about health, even about human lives saved, about property damage, as experts have already sufficiently demonstrated the link between the change in time and the higher accident rate on the roads, as well as the complications of medical operations. And I am no longer talking about the negative consequences in agriculture and animal husbandry. Moving the hands on the watch twice a year not only does not save money. On the contrary, experts estimate that the European economy will lose 1 to 2 percent of its gross domestic product each year as a result of this change. This represents a loss of almost € 300 billion. I admit, I was a little surprised that Commissioner Bulc, in her letter to us MEPs, defended the Commission's lack of interest in this subject, the importance of Europe-wide harmonization of the changeover to summer and winter time. However, it is not in dispute that each Member State should determine its own date for that transition. None of the Members asked for that, because it is obvious nonsense. I can only believe that the Commissioner did not take this part of her letter quite seriously. Undoubtedly, it was more of an attempt at a joke, which we may appreciate over time. However, I very much welcome, like my fellow predecessors, that the Commission recognizes that the transition from summer to winter and from winter to summer is a problem that bothers our citizens. And I add that perhaps even more than other issues that the Commission is dealing with much more promptly. We can only believe that the European Commission, despite its busyness, will also have the capacity to reconsider the arguments in favor of abolishing the alternation of summer and winter time. That it will deal responsibly with the issues of this Parliament and that the outcome of the examination will be factual and duly substantiated. I hope that when we meet here in a debate on this subject for a year, we will no longer talk about our demands, but we will have a proposal to amend Directive 2000/84 on the table.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I am going to speak here in a dissonant voice compared to all the colleagues I have heard so far. I am an advocate of the time change, and in particular of summer time. Why? Because when I was 13 and in school, at Saint-Roch College in Ferrières, Belgium, after the Easter holidays in 1976, the time change was applied for the first time. . Thanks to summer time, we were able to play football and basketball on the sports fields which were not lit. From this real-life example, I just wanted to tell you that the lighting later at night allows children in particular - and this is good for their health - to stay a little more outside by practicing physical activities, while leisure time. - as we know - have become very sedentary. The second benefit is the terraces and the conviviality. Rather than gulping down drugs for depression, let's go sit on a patio, this is the best antidepressant. It's good for business and for people, who can chat with each other. Therefore, usability is further facilitated by the change to summer time. It is not the traders who will contradict us. Other benefits are linked to the return to winter time. As Ms. Reid just said, winter time is the best way to take advantage of the natural daylight. When the sun decreases, the return to winter time allows for clarity a little earlier in the morning and, therefore, perhaps more safety, especially on the way to school. This is why I think harmonization is obviously useful. We know that the UK has often made different choices. This is normal, the Greenwich meridian passes over its territory. I heard earlier that we were talking about the Canary Islands. Since they are located at 28 degrees west latitude, it makes sense that they have one hour different.However, harmonization across Europe and a change from winter time to summer time and vice versa at the same time are obviously fundamental.Would not change a thing!Tell Mr. Timmermans he can sit down on that as well.Don't change anything!(The speaker accepts to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: blue card question.- Mr President, I just wanted to remind my colleague Marc that I understand nostalgia for youth, but that, precisely, health studies tell us that change - not the fact of having daylight saving time, which is so much for himNice, that is what we are proposing, that it be maintained - it is also what leads to obesity problems throughout Europe and that has been told us by several universities and scientific institutes that were in Parliament last year.Therefore, I ask you: Wouldn't it be better if we talked rather about keeping the schedule that is better for the health and for the morale of the citizens and thus, perhaps, to be able to make a schedule more familiar, more social, something thatin some Member States for the jobs is not achieved?

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: Answer "blue card". - Ms. Ayala Sender, we could perhaps fund studies that will show the opposite, we may not have done so. I'm just saying that for conviviality and more to enjoy the daylight when spring and summer arrive, that seems fundamental to me, but when people talk to me about the changes, clearly, we have to stop. When you take a plane and go to a country where there is a two hour difference, you change your watch. Now we don't even need to change the mobile phone, it changes by itself. So we adapt. The jetlag exists for those who take trips every day and here in this compound there are quite a few who fly. When we go to winter time, we know we have an extra hour of sleep. When we switch to summer time, we have one less and therefore, we may go to bed earlier. It can be a problem the next day, the next two days, and then it's forgotten. Let us stop talking nonsense!

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, I want to be completely clear at the outset. Having analyzed many of the pros and cons, I will advocate for the abolition of so-called daylight saving time. The reasons why daylight saving time was once introduced are no longer the arguments they once were. One hundred years ago, when a change in timekeeping was first introduced in wartime, the main argument at the time was the saving of a key coal fuel. The way of life, of course, was completely different from today. Today, fortunately, we have more and more renewable energy sources, and our daily lives have of course completely changed. I can mention our habits of space heating and cooling or even more drastic habits of using means of transportation. Thus, it is evident that energy saving is no longer a strong enough argument to change clocks during the year. I think today we need to start with the undoubted fact, the proven harmfulness of the impact on human biorhythm when changing weather. This is especially evident in the elderly. It has also been shown to affect animal welfare. In addition, changing the timing often creates additional chaos in communication. Human life, in addition to animal welfare, should be ahead of economic interests. If we never had knowledge of daylight saving time and its consequences, now we undoubtedly have it. That should be the main argument in this debate and the main argument for abolishing the change of time. An online survey conducted on a sample of 1,500 respondents by our colleague, Mr. Škrlec, shows that as many as 85% of citizens in Croatia are against changing the weather. They claim there are virtually no energy savings. So I call on the Commission and you, Commissioner, to simply respect this practically unanimous thinking in this House and to amend the directives and to give up the double counting of time.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, táim i gcoinne an athrú ama seo le blianta fada anuas anois ach go dtí gur eagraigh Herbert Reul cruinniú cúpla seachtain ó shin agus fuaireamar ansin an fhianaise agus an díobháil a bhí an t-athrú ama seo á dhéanamh do shláinte, geilleagar agus mar sin de ní raibh mé in ann é a rá go hoscailte. Agus anois táim ag teacht anseo inniu agus freisin tá breis fianaise againn nach bhfuil aon mhaitheas leis an athrú ama seo agus ba chóir dúinn deireadh a chur leis agus a luaithe is a dhéanfaimid é is fearr. The Commission is right: we need a harmonised approach, and that means that only the Commission can bring about this change; Member States cannot do it individually. All the evidence is there now that this needs to happen. Why do we deny scientific evidence of social jetlag? Many people suffer as a result of the change of time, as if they had jetlag. Also health has been mentioned. Accidents, and this supposedly beneficial aspect from the point of view of climate change. There are no benefits. For me actually it happens next Saturday. Autumn will finish next Saturday; winter will be advanced by a month; it will come in overnight. People will stop going for walks in the afternoon. It is ok for Mr Tarabella to talk about floodlights; they are not available to most people, and, as well as that, the energy consumption will go up, and then next year, spring will be postponed by about a month, which has a huge impact in terms of social activity, games, sport – you name it. I was very interested in what one of our speakers mentioned: that 73% of Germans are against the change. I would say that reflects the feeling right across Europe, and, indeed if they had the evidence which we have got now here today, I think the figures would actually go up. So why won’t the Commission come forward with something that actually matters to citizens; that citizens are in favour of doing; that nobody can do for them, only the Commission, and they will get great praise for it. I think it is a no-brainer, as we say in English. I will give you another example. This Saturday, many of the hotels in my constituency will close for the winter. The season is over. Again, the evidence is there that the hotels and the bookings drop by over 7% or more as soon as we switch over. So if there was no changeover, if we had summertime all year round, everybody would benefit: health wise, socially, young people and the economy. So at least Commission: come forward with a proposal. If it fails, it fails, but I guarantee you it would be a success and you will get some praise for so doing. (Applause)

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: - This year it is exactly one hundred years ago that daylight saving time was first introduced. It was a German idea during the First World War, and it simply had to do with the savings on coal. The regulation of summer time is now a European competence: we are about that. We introduced it during the oil boycott by the Arab countries to save energy. In the meantime, it has turned out that the whole energy argument is no longer valid. It is outdated. Various studies show that this regulation saves little or no energy, but actually causes many disadvantages, such as - and this concerns people - sleep disorders. This has been scientifically demonstrated by various experts here in this group or in this Parliament. The biological clocks are getting totally disrupted, and we all have to deal with that. A social jet lag. Children should be out of bed an hour earlier in the morning and elderly people in nursing homes should be put to bed an hour later. By shifting time, parents and children often tire earlier and family life suffers. Sleep disorders occur that have all kinds of consequences: unruly children and unruly elderly people in the retirement home, more sickness reports. Furthermore, appointments are missed and old clocks break because of the tinkering with the hands. Businesses also have to adapt machines time and again to new times; I am thinking of the bakers and the signals from the transport sector. What applies to humans, also applies to animals. Then I think of dairy farming, among other things, because not everyone has a milking robot. In addition, changing the clock leads to more social problems: morning traffic jams drive longer in the dark, which is dangerous for traffic. Evening traffic jams drive more in ozone heat, which is harmful to the climate. More and more countries are therefore deciding no longer to change the clock: Russia, Turkey and Japan. She no longer participate.To save energy, we can better insulate houses, install more solar panels or ensure that cars indicate actual use.That is why the time has come for the European Union to set the clock for the last time after a hundred years.Stop this unnecessary hassle.We must listen to the criticism of the citizens and this affects every citizen.That will certainly help to make our Europe a little more loved by the citizens, and that is what our European Commissioner Frans Timmermans, who is responsible for this, wants too, right?Our Health Commissioner always talks about prevention, so shouldn't we tackle this?We do not have to meet for hours about that.Now there is only one question: do we in this Parliament choose summer time or winter time?As far as I'm concerned for daylight saving time.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Our cross-party question to the Commission on the twice-yearly time change results from the fact that we have been actively studying the scientific principles. Hence my additional questions to our question - I would ask you to pass them on to the Commissioner: Are you familiar with the research work of the Ludwig Maximilians University in Munich, which reports that with 150,000 personal data it has now become clear that a daily jet lag of 40 minutes is the result that children, schoolchildren, professionals and the elderly in particular suffer with massive effects on the biological clock of the human organism? Are you familiar with the scientific studies by the Australian researchers Hillman, Murphy, Pezzullo entitled The Economic Costs of Sleep Disorders ’, according to which the economic damage is estimated to be 1% of GDP? That is the unbelievable figure of 150 billion euros in European standards! 150 billion euros every year! Do you know the statistics from Sweden, Germany, Finland, the USA - only those from 2012 - according to which the risk of heart attack increases by up to 30%? If you do not know any of this, then I am questioning your performance as Commissioner. But if you know this data, then I ask: Why did you not react? Why didn't you order serious scientific research? A year and a half after the parliamentary hearing with a lot of this data, that is too late! You are not taking your responsibility seriously! Make up your mind now!

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the debate and I am more or less unable to make any further arguments. I can only conclude here that I underline and agree with all the arguments made here by my predecessors, who have clearly pointed out how unfavorable the alternation of summer and winter time is for the human body and for the body of domestic animals. In the smaller case, this causes difficulties and problems, and in the worst case, this alternation of time is directly responsible for some diseases of civilization. I must say, Commissioner, that I have listened to your introductory speech, I understand that you represent the Commissioner in charge of this point here, but your introductory speech has not really been sufficient from my point of view and did not adequately answer the questions put by Members here. It would be really useful for the Commission to perceive that not only the citizens of the European Union, by a majority, but also the Members representing their constituents, make it clear that it would be good to put forward a proposal to abolish summer and winter time and have it voted on by the European Parliament. Let democratically decide whether the majority is on the side of us who say that rotation is wrong. Or the majority is on the side of colleagues, such as Mr Tarabella, who say that the rotation should be maintained. No one wants to break the fact that the whole of the EU has one time. The question is whether or not it has time to take turns across the EU. And as has been said many times here, the economic benefits of alternating time are simply not good today, it has been shown that they do not exist and, in fact, today there is no reason at all for alternating between summer and winter time. So please perceive it. I can say from my practice, Commissioner, that if citizens have been asking me something recently and if they are not refugees, it is the alternation of summer and winter time. It is a very hot topic, it is of great interest to EU citizens, and I think that Europe, if it abolishes the alternation of summer and winter time, will do something for citizens that citizens will immediately perceive as a tangible and positive thing.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as a conclusion, for me it was a very interesting and useful discussion about the time switch. I can promise you that I have taken note of all your ideas and views, and I will pass them to Commissioner Bulc. However, let me remind you that the Commission has not received any official requests from the Member States on the issue of summertime/wintertime. But of course, the Commission will take into consideration your input in our ongoing analysis, and the Commission is equally committed to keeping you informed once the analysis has been concluded, which should be in the course of next year, 2017.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: written.- I am against switching between summer and winter time.The benefit of the changeover is questionable: the original goal of saving energy is not achieved and there are numerous studies that show that the time changeover is a burden for people and their health.I would therefore like to call on the Commission to come up with constructive proposals to end the clock change.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. - According to a current survey, 80% of Hungarians would cancel the clock. Although the survey is not representative, it well reflects people's opinions. Most of them twice a year - in spring and autumn - are confused before the time change. They don't understand why it's needed. The majority of respondents to the survey cite biological imbalances and cumbersome transitions as primary problems. Today, several studies prove that the economic reasons voiced in the past are not necessarily relevant, and in addition to its positive returns, we must also reckon with the negatives and inconveniences. For people, the transition to the summer time in the early spring is the main problem, as the earlier awakening disrupts the biorhythm of the people and leads to fatigue and insomnia. From a transport point of view, the disruption that this switchover will not be negligible either. Long-distance buses and trains lose an hour during the spring changeover, while they wait an hour at the stations for the autumn reset to adjust to the reset time. It is also worth mentioning the safety aspect of this, as earlier awakening can lead to fatigue, greater inattention and thus an increased number of accidents. There are few provisions in which the position of citizens is so unified. Let us not ignore the opinion of the majority. I therefore call on the Commission to review this provision, taking into account today's economic, health and safety circumstances.
